title: Knox v. Greenville Hospital System
description: Robert and Beatrice Knox appealed the circuit court order granting summary judgment to defendant Greenville Hospital System (Hospital) on his medical negligence claim and her loss of consortium claim, arguing the circuit court erred in finding the applicable two-year statute of limitations barred the claims. text:
Knox v. Greenville Hospital Systems


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Robert Knox and Beatrice Knox, Appellants,
v.
Greenville Hospital System, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3914
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  4, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes and Mark Stan Meglic, of Greenville, 
  for Appellants.
J. Ben Alexander, Sarah McMillan Purnell and G. Dewey Oxner, 
  Jr., of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Robert and Beatrice Knox 
  appeal the circuit court order granting summary judgment to defendant Greenville 
  Hospital System (Hospital) on his medical negligence claim and her loss of consortium 
  claim, arguing the circuit court erred in finding the applicable two-year statute 
  of limitations barred the claims.Â  Viewing the facts and circumstances in the 
  light most favorable to Knox, [1] 
   we find that under the discovery rule he should have reasonably been aware 
  of a potential claim on the date of his injury, May 2, 2000, regardless of the 
  fact that he did not know the extent of his injury until later diagnosed by 
  an orthopedic surgeon.Â Â Â  Because the two-year statute of limitations commenced 
  on May 2, 2000, and Knox did not file the present action until May 8, 2002, 
  we find the statute of limitations bars the present action.Â  Accordingly, we 
  affirm the grant of summary judgment to the Hospital.
FACTS         
On May 2, 2000, Knox sought treatment 
  for high blood pressure at Hospitalâ€™s emergency room.Â  In an effort to intravenously 
  administer a saline treatment (I.V.) to Knox, a nurse inserted a needle into 
  his wrist.Â  In response, Knox â€œscreamed,â€ â€œsquealed and hollered,â€ and his â€œwhole 
  hand jumped up â€¦ in [his] fingers.â€Â  Knoxâ€™s nurse stated that she â€œhit the wrong 
  thing in thereâ€ and â€œapologized.â€Â  Although Knox received â€œplenty of I.V.s before,â€ 
  he knew something was â€œdifferentâ€ about this one because of the pain, reaction 
  of his hand, and the nurseâ€™s admission to â€œhit[ting] the wrong thing.â€Â  Knox 
  believed that â€œthe doctor had hit a nerve in there.â€ [2] Â  Before the Hospital discharged Knox, he informed 
  his nurses that he was still experiencing pain in his wrist.Â  They told him 
  to treat his wrist with ice packs and to return to the Hospital if he experienced 
  trouble. 
The icepacks did not alleviate Knoxâ€™s wrist pain, 
  which continued unabated.Â  Consequently, on May 9 Knox returned to the Hospital, 
  where he was advised to take non-prescription pain medicine and apply warm compresses 
  to his wrist.Â  Knox sought treatment from an orthopedic surgeon at the Hospitalâ€™s 
  clinic on July 12, 2000.Â  On July 26, 2000, the orthopedic surgeon confirmed 
  Knoxâ€™s suspicions and informed Knox that he suffered a permanent injury to his 
  radial nerve. Â Knox subsequently underwent surgery and received pain management 
  treatment.
The Knoxes initiated the present action on May 
  8, 2002.Â  The Hospital answered and subsequently moved for summary judgment 
  on the ground that the applicable two-year statute of limitations barred the 
  Knoxesâ€™ claims. The Knoxes responded by submitting a memorandum opposing the 
  Hospitalâ€™s summary judgment motion. [3] 
The circuit court granted summary judgment to the 
  Hospital, ruling that both â€œPlaintiffsâ€™ claims are barred by the applicable 
  statute of limitations.â€Â  The court noted that Knoxâ€”who had received â€œplenty 
  of I.V.s beforeâ€ without incident, and experienced admittedly abnormal pain, 
  coupled with the uncharacteristic hand movement, when the nurse inserted the 
  needle in his wrist on May 2, 2000â€”â€œwas on notice that a claim against another 
  party might exist.â€Â  The court consequently found that the applicable two-year 
  statute of limitations began running on that date, May 2, 2000, and had expired 
  prior to the filing of the complaint on May 8, 2002.Â  This appeal followed the 
  denial of a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A motion for summary judgment shall be granted 
  â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on 
  file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue 
  as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Russell v. Wachovia Bank, N.A., 
  353 S.C. 208, 217, 578 S.E.2d 329, 334 (2003).Â  On a summary judgment motion, 
  â€œa court must view the facts in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  
  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).
DISCUSSION
Knox argues the circuit court 
  erred in finding he should have reasonably discovered the existence of a potential 
  claim on May 2, 2000, because he did not know the extent of his injury until 
  the July 26, 2000, diagnosis by the orthopedic surgeon.Â  As a result, Knox contends 
  the circuit court erred in barring his medical malpractice claim under the applicable 
  two-year statute of limitations.Â  We disagree.
The Hospital is a governmental 
  entity under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act (Act), S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-10 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  Under the Act, an action is â€œforever barred unless . . . commenced 
  within two years after the date the loss was or should have been discovered 
  . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-110 (Supp. 2003).
Actions brought under the Act 
  are subject to the discovery rule.Â  Joubert v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. 
  Services, 341 S.C. 176, 190, 534 S.E.2d 1, 8 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œAccording 
  to the discovery rule, the statute of limitations begins to run when a cause 
  of action reasonably ought to have been discovered.â€Â  Id.Â  The statute 
  does not necessarily run from the date of the negligent act, but from when the 
  injury resulting from the negligent act is discovered or may be discovered by 
  the exercise of â€œreasonable diligence.â€Â  Id., 341 S.C. at 8, 534 S.E.2d 
  at 190-91.Â  â€œThe exercise of reasonable diligence means simply that an injured 
  party must act with some promptness where the facts and circumstances of an 
  injury would put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice that 
  some right of his has been invaded or that some claim against another party 
  might exist.â€Â  Snell v. Columbia Gun Exch., Inc., 276 S.C. 301, 303, 
  278 S.E.2d 333, 334 (1981).Â  â€œThe date on which discovery should have been made 
  is an objective, not subjective, question.â€Â  Joubert, 341 S.C. at 191, 
  534 S.E.2d at 9.Â  Additionally, the fact that the injured party does not comprehend 
  the full extent of his injuries is immaterial.Â  Dean v. Ruscon Corp., 
  321 S.C. 360, 364, 468 S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996).
Here, Knox argues he did not 
  discover that he had a cause of action until his orthopedic surgeon informed 
  him of the true nature of his injury on July 26, 2000.Â  Thus, Knox maintains 
  the two-year statute of limitations did not start running until that date and 
  did not expire until July 26, 2002, well after he filed suit on May 8, 2002. 
  We find this argument unavailing under the facts of this case.Â  
In particular, we note that Knox 
  acknowledged that he â€œscreamed,â€ â€œsquealed,â€ and â€œholleredâ€ from pain when the 
  I.V. was injected in his wrist, and his fingers â€œthrewâ€ and his hand â€œjumped.â€Â  
  He testified that the nurse who administered the I.V. apologized and told Knox 
  she â€œhad hit the wrong thing in there.â€Â  Knox testified she also said: â€œIt must 
  have been a nerve.â€Â  He stated he previously had many other I.V.s. and knew 
  something was different about this one because â€œthat hand felt like my whole 
  hand jumped straight up like that.Â  But she know [sic] she had hit something 
  wrong in there.â€Â  Before he was discharged, Knox told relatives he was experiencing 
  pain, and the â€œdoctorâ€ had hit a nerve. Â When he left the emergency room, Knox 
  knew he had experienced pain upon injection, that the pain was not a normal 
  consequence of an I.V. administration, that the nurse had hit a nerve, and that 
  the nerve was the â€œwrong thingâ€ to hit.
We, of course, recognize that 
  varying degrees of pain and discomfort are frequently associated with certain 
  medical procedures, especially invasive ones.Â  The mere presence of pain or 
  discomfort, to be sure, will ordinarily not serve to trigger the commencement 
  of the applicable statute of limitations.Â  The distinctive feature here is Knoxâ€™s 
  multiple, uneventful experiences with â€œplenty of I.V.s before.â€Â  The exercise 
  of reasonable diligence under these facts â€œwould put a person of common knowledge 
  and experience on notice that some right of his has been invaded or that some 
  claim against [the Hospital] might exist.â€Â  Snell, 276 S.C. at 303, 278 
  S.E.2d at 334. 
Viewing this evidence objectively 
  and in the light most favorable to Knox, we find the circuit court correctly 
  concluded that the â€œloss â€¦ should have been discoveredâ€ on May 2, 2000, and 
  consequently Knox was on notice at that time of a potential claim against the 
  Hospital.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-110.Â  Additionally, we find it immaterial 
  that Knox did not know the extent of his injury on May 2, 2000.Â  See 
  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 720, 511 S.E.2d 
  413, 416 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œ[T]he statute of limitations is not tolled during 
  the period of time in which a plaintiff is merely unaware of the extent of an 
  actionable injury.â€).Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that a reasonably diligent 
  person of common knowledge and experience, under the admitted facts, would have 
  been aware at the time of the incident on May 2, 2000, that a claim against 
  the Hospital might exist, even though the full extent of the injury was only 
  subsequently discovered.Â  Thus, we conclude that the two-year statute of limitations 
  period began to run on May 2, 2000.Â  Because the complaint was not filed until 
  May 8, 2002, we find no genuine issue of material fact exists as to whether 
  the two-year statute of limitations bars this action.Â  The grant of summary 
  judgment to the Hospital is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 
  

 
   
    [1] We refer only to Mr. Knoxâ€™s claim, recognizing as the parties 
    do that the viability of Mrs. Knoxâ€™s consortium claim is contingent upon the 
    timeliness of Mr. Knoxâ€™s claim.

 
   [2] The record indicates a nurse administered 
    the I.V., but Knox refers to the person who administered the I.V. as a â€œdoctor.â€

 
   
     
    [3] In their memorandum, the Knoxes only challenged the 
    statute of limitations defense with respect to Mr. Knoxâ€™s claim.Â  They did 
    not dispute the Hospitalâ€™s assertion that if the statute barred Mr. Knoxâ€™s 
    claim, it would also necessarily bar Mrs. Knoxâ€™s claim for loss of consortium.
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

title: Parker v. Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer District
description: In this civil case, the Court analyzes whether the trial court erred: 1)	In not reducing the juryâ€™s verdict to comply with the limitations of recovery set forth in the Tort Claims Act; (2)	In not allowing Appellant to amend its answer; (3)	In not allowing Appellant to introduce evidence concerning amounts actually paid by Medicare towards the Respondentâ€™s total medical bills.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Wilma K. Parker, Respondent,
v.
Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer District and David Michael Pace, Defendants, 
        of whom Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer District is, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3915
Heard December 7, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  4, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  and REMANDED


  
    
      
Stephen L. Brown and Matthew K. Mahoney, of Charleston, 
  for Appellant.
Kenneth L. Holland, of Gaffney, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Wilma K. Parker brought suit 
  against David Michael Pace and his employer, the Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer 
  District (the Sewer District), alleging Paceâ€™s negligence proximately caused 
  an automobile accident in which she suffered injuries.Â  The trial judge dismissed 
  Pace from the suit pursuant to the South Carolina Tort Claims Act (the Tort 
  Claims Act), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 to â€“200 (Supp. 2003).Â  The jury returned 
  a $450,000 verdict against the Sewer District.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in 
  part, and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Parker and Pace were involved in an automobile 
  accident in which Parker suffered injuries.Â  At the time, Pace was driving a 
  van owned by the Sewer District.Â  Parker filed a complaint against Pace and 
  the Sewer District averring Paceâ€™s negligence was the direct and proximate cause 
  of her injuries.Â  Parker claimed that, because Pace was acting as an employee 
  of the Sewer District when the accident occurred, Paceâ€™s liability was imputed 
  to the Sewer District.Â  In her complaint, Parker stated: â€œThis action as to 
  Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer District is brought under section 15-78-40 et seq., 
  S.C. Code of Laws, the â€˜S.C. Tort Claims Act.â€™â€Â  The Sewer District did not 
  plead the Tort Claims Act as an affirmative defense in its answer.
On the morning of the first day of trial, 
  the Sewer District filed an amended answer, which asserted:

The Defendants would show the Court that since Defendant Pace 
  was acting within the scope of his employment with the Spartanburg Sanitary 
  Sewer District at the time of the accident complained of and since this action 
  was brought (as to the Spartanburg Sanitary Sewer District) under the South 
  Carolina Tort Claims Act, . . . the Plaintiff is entitled to recover only actual 
  damages not to exceed the maximum amount permitted under the applicable provisions 
  of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.

During the trial, the circuit judge declared:

I didnâ€™t see the Amended Answer yesterday.Â  I donâ€™t think 
  amended pleadings can be filed without permission of the Court, and particularly 
  after the trial has started.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
  Well, the Answer I have in the file for this trial, there 
  is no defense found.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
  You cannot file it without leave of the Court under the Rules.Â  
  I donâ€™t believe you can file an Amended Complaint that late or an Amended Answer, 
  without permission of the Court.

The Sewer District then moved to amend its answer 
  to comport with the evidence.Â  The judge denied the motion. 
At trial, the Sewer District made two requests 
  to introduce evidence of the amounts actually paid by Medicare for services 
  rendered to Parker as a result of the accident.Â  The trial judge denied these 
  requests.
The jury returned a verdict for Parker 
  in the amount of $450,000.Â  The Sewer District moved to reduce the amount of 
  damages by $150,000 to reflect the monetary statutory cap on recovery provided 
  in the Tort Claims Act.Â  Specifically, the Sewer District asked â€œfor a reduction 
  to the amount of the cap as pleaded by Mr. Holland in his Complaint, less the 
  property damage already paid to his client.â€Â  The trial judge denied the motion.
LAW/ANALYSIS 
I.Â  REDUCTION OF VERDICT
A.Â  Vivacity of Pleading/Accedence at Trial
The Sewer District argues 
  the trial judge erred in denying its request for a reduction in the jury award 
  to comply with the limitation on recovery as set forth in the South Carolina 
  Tort Claims Act.Â  We agree.
The Tort Claims Act governs all tort 
  claims against governmental entities and is the exclusive civil remedy available 
  in an action against a governmental entity or its employees.Â  Flateau 
  v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 584 
  S.E.2d 413 (Ct. App. 2003); Wells v. City of Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 
  501 S.E.2d 746 (Ct. App. 1998); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-200 (Supp. 
  2003) (â€œNotwithstanding any provision of law, this chapter, the â€˜South Carolina 
  Tort Claims Act,â€™ is the exclusive and sole remedy for any tort committed by 
  an employee of a governmental entity while acting within the scope of the employeeâ€™s 
  official duty.â€).Â  South Carolina Code section 15-78-120(a)(1), which pertains 
  to the limitation on liability under the Tort Claims Act, provides:

(a) For any action or claim 
  for damages brought under the provisions of this chapter, the liability shall 
  not exceed the following limits:
  
(1) Except as provided in Section 15-78-120(a)(3), no person 
  shall recover in any action or claim brought hereunder a sum exceeding three 
  hundred thousand dollars because of loss arising from a single occurrence regardless 
  of the number of agencies or political subdivisions involved.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-120(a)(1) (Supp. 2003); see 
  Wimberly v. Barr, 359 S.C. 414, 421, 597 S.E.2d 853, 857 (Ct. App. 2004) 
  (â€œWith some exceptions, the Tort Claims Act limits the amount of damages recoverable 
  for any claim to $300,000.â€); see also Oliver v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Hwys. & Pub. Transp., 309 S.C. 313, 316, 422 S.E.2d 128, 130 (1992) 
  (â€œThe jury awarded Oliver damages in the amount of $3,250,000.00,â€ which the 
  judge reduced to $250,000, â€œpursuant to the statutory capâ€ provided in the Tort 
  Claims Act); Jeter v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 358 S.C. 528, 
  532, 595 S.E.2d 827, 829 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œBy consent order, the trial court 
  reduced the verdicts in accordance with the statutory caps set forth in the 
  [Tort Claims] Act.â€); Clark v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 353 
  S.C. 291, 298, 578 S.E.2d 16, 19 (Ct. App. 2002) (in case tried prior to amendment 
  increasing limitation on liability to $300,000, â€œ[t]he trial court reduced the 
  verdict against the Department to $250,000 in accordance with the limit imposed 
  by the Tort Claims Actâ€); Smalls v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Educ., 339 
  S.C. 208, 528 S.E.2d 682 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting that proper method to set off 
  damages awarded against Department of Education under Tort Claims Act by amount 
  of pre-trial settlement paid by private defendant was to reduce juryâ€™s verdict 
  by amount of settlement allocated to each cause of action, to then further reduce 
  verdict by plaintiffâ€™s comparative negligence, and, finally, to apply 
  damages cap under Tort Claims Act).
Parker contends â€œthe trial court did not err in 
  refusing to reduce the verdict to the Tort Claims cap amount based on the fact 
  that Defendants had not properly pled the cap as an affirmative defense which 
  means that they waived it.â€Â  The cases Parker cites in support of this proposition 
  are distinguishable.Â  In Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing 
  & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999), the issue presented 
  on appeal was whether the trial judge erred in denying the defendantâ€™s motion 
  for a new trial nisi remittitur, in which it asked the judge to reduce the verdicts 
  for the plaintiffs to $250,000 each under the Tort Claims Act.Â  The Supreme 
  Court noted the case was filed â€œtwo days before the reinstatement of the limits 
  [of the Tort Claims Act].â€Â  Id. at 402, 520 S.E.2d at 157.Â  In addition, 
  Steinke examined the various statutory exceptions to the waiver of immunity 
  as they related to the defendant.Â  The question of whether the statutory cap 
  is an affirmative defense which is waived if not pled was not discussed.Â  Likewise, 
  Pike v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 540 S.E.2d 87 
  (2000), does not analyze the issue presented in this appeal.Â  The defendant 
  maintained the verdict should have been reduced to $250,000 in accordance with 
  the reenactment of the statutory cap.Â  The Pike court explicated: â€œThe 
  instant action was filed on June 23, 1994[, eight days before the reinstatement 
  of the limits]. . . . Pursuant to Steinke, the statutory cap simply does 
  not apply.â€Â  Id. at 236, 540 S.E.2d at 93.Â  Furthermore, Pike 
  addressed applicability of the exception to the waiver of immunity for discretionary 
  acts under the Tort Claims Act.Â  This discussion is inapposite to the present 
  issue.
Additionally, the Sewer District did not need to 
  plead the Tort Claims Act statutory cap as an affirmative defense in its answer 
  because Parker already conceded the Tort Claims Act applied to her claim.Â  Parker 
  expressly set forth in her complaint that she brought her cause of action pursuant 
  to the Tort Claims Act.Â  Moreover, upon a motion by the Sewer District to dismiss 
  Pace as a defendant pursuant to section 15-78-80 of the South Carolina Code 
  (Supp. 2003), the trial court and Parkerâ€™s counsel agreed the Tort Claims Act 
  applied to this action:

[Attorney for the Sewer District]: . . . I would submit that 
  should you direct a motion to dismiss Mr. Pace, then any charge related to punitive 
  damages we would object to as irrelevant, in view of the Tort Claim[s] Act. 

  . . . .
[Attorney for Parker]: . . . Of course, the Tort Claims 
  Act applies.Â  In this case, we have alleged at the outset of this case â€“ 
  have established that this gentlemanâ€™s independent gross negligence brought 
  this about.
  That makes his employer responsible under the Tort Claims 
  Act, but I donâ€™t know of any structure in the law which shields him from personal 
  responsibility.
The Tort Claims Act is real clear that punitives are not 
  recoverable against a State agency or governmental agency under the Tort Claims 
  Act, but I donâ€™t know of an umbrella that David Michael Pace is carrying around 
  that keeps that rainful [sic] from coming down on him.
  . . . .
The Court:Â  Iâ€™m not sure that the individual â€“ I know of nothing 
  that protects the individual from gross negligence, recklessness or willfulness.

However, the Tort Claims Act would apply to the Sewer 
  District in regard to the actual damages.

(Emphasis added).
Subsequent to this discussion on the record, the 
  trial judge stated the Tort Claims Act must be raised as an affirmative defense 
  in the answer.Â  However, the judge then granted the Sewer Districtâ€™s motion 
  to dismiss Pace pursuant to the Tort Claims Act. [1] Â  The trial judgeâ€™s statement 
  that the Tort Claims Act applies to this action and his dismissal of Pace are 
  inconsistent with the judgeâ€™s failure to apply the monetary statutory cap set 
  out in the Tort Claims Act.Â  Further, Parker is factually and legally bound 
  by her pleading and trial concession: (1) she declared in her complaint that 
  her cause of action is brought under the Tort Claims Act; and (2) at trial, 
  she conceded the Tort Claims Act applies.Â  See Ex parte McMillan, 
  319 S.C. 331, 461 S.E.2d 43 (1995) (by conceding at trial that the complaint 
  was, in part, under the Tort Claims Act, the party could not argue on appeal 
  that the case was not under the Tort Claims Act).
The trial judge committed reversible error 
  in denying the Sewer Districtâ€™s request for a reduction in the juryâ€™s verdict 
  to conform to the monetary statutory cap set forth in the Tort Claims Act.
B.Â  Other Jurisdictions
Numerous jurisdictions which have addressed the 
  issue conclude the statutory cap on recovery need not be pled.
In Mitchell v. State of Louisiana, 
  596 So. 2d 353 (La. Ct. App. 1992), the plaintiffs, who were injured in an automobile 
  accident, sued the State of Louisiana, through the Department of Transportation 
  and Development.Â  On appeal, the plaintiffs complained â€œit was error not to 
  rule that the state waived the [statutory] cap . . . by its failure to plead 
  the cap as an affirmative defense.â€Â  Id. at 354.Â  The court enunciated:

While we are on the subject of the statutory cap, La.R.S. 
  13:5106, we will respond to the contention made by the plaintiffs in their answer 
  to the appeal, that the state should not have been permitted to avail itself 
  of the benefit of this cap because of its failure to plead it as an affirmative 
  defense.Â  We find no merit to this argument.Â  The statute does not create an 
  affirmative defense; rather, it imposes a limitation on liability.Â  The plaintiffâ€™s 
  petition pleaded general damages.Â  The state in its answer denied the allegations.Â  
  The subject of the amount of general damages was thus put at issue in the case.Â  
  The State did not waive its right to invoke the cap by its failure to specifically 
  plead reliance on it as a limitation on its liability.

Id. at 357.
The case of Snyder v. City of Minneapolis, 
  441 N.W.2d 781 (Minn. 1989), is particularly instructive.Â  Snyder alleged â€œthe 
  limit on municipal liability created by Minn.Stat. Â§ 466.04, [the cap on municipal 
  tort liability,] is an affirmative defense and therefore should have been set 
  forth affirmatively in the Cityâ€™s responsive pleading.â€Â  Id. at 787 (footnote 
  omitted).Â  He averred the City waived the cap on damages because it failed to 
  plead or raise it prior to the completion of trial.Â  The Supreme Court of Minnesota 
  expounded: â€œWe . . . hold that the cap on municipal tort liability provided 
  by Minn.Stat. Â§ 466.04 is not an affirmative defense but a statutory rule of 
  law that trial courts are obliged to impose whenever damages exceed the statutory 
  limit.â€Â  Id. at 788.
The Court of Appeals of Texas, in Whipple 
  v. Deltscheff, 731 S.W.2d 700 (Tex. App. 1987), elucidated: â€œA sovereign 
  does not waive the $100,000 limit of liability imposed by the Texas Tort Claims 
  Act by failure to plead and urge it; the damages are strictly limited to those 
  imposed by the statute.â€Â  Id. at 705; see also Tarrant County 
  Hosp. District v. Henry, 52 S.W.3d 434, 451 (Tex. App. 2001) (â€œFurther, 
  because a sovereign would have no liability absent legislative consent to suit 
  and liability, a sovereign cannot waive the damage limits imposed by the Legislature 
  by failing to plead them.â€).
There is absolutely no verbiage articulated within 
  the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, sections 15-78-10 to â€“200 of the South Carolina 
  Code, mandating that a governmental entity plead the monetary statutory cap 
  included within section 15-78-120.Â  The Tort Claims Act is imbued with public 
  policy considerations limiting and qualifying liability of governmental entities.Â  
  We conclude that the monetary statutory cap is self-executing and the court 
  is required to apply the monetary statutory cap to any jury verdict exceeding 
  $300,000.
II.Â  MOTION TO AMEND ANSWER
Because this court should address all 
  issues in the event of certiorari review, we analyze the motion to amend the 
  answer on an alternative basis for affirmance.
The Sewer District maintains the circuit 
  judge abused his discretion in refusing an amendment to assert the Tort Claims 
  Act limitation on recoverable damages as an affirmative defense.Â  We agree.
Amendments of pleadings are controlled by Rule 
  15, SCRCP, which provides in pertinent part:

15(a). Amendments.Â  A party may amend his pleading 
  once as a matter of course at any time before or within 30 days after a responsive 
  pleading is served or, if the pleading is one to which no responsive pleading 
  is required and the action has not been placed upon the trial roster, he may 
  so amend it at any time within 30 days after it is served.Â  Otherwise a party 
  may amend his pleading only by leave of court or by written consent of the adverse 
  party; and leave shall be freely given when justice so requires and does 
  not prejudice any other party.Â  (Emphasis added).

A motion to amend is addressed to the sound discretion 
  of the trial judge.Â  Stanley v. Kirkpatrick, 357 S.C. 169, 592 S.E.2d 
  296 (2004); City of North Myrtle Beach v. Lewis-Davis, 360 S.C. 225, 
  599 S.E.2d 462 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Leave to amend pleadings pursuant to Rule 15, 
  SCRCP, shall be liberally and freely given when justice so requires and does 
  not prejudice any other party.Â  Crestwood Golf Club, Inc. v. Potter, 
  328 S.C. 201, 493 S.E.2d 826 (1997); Pruitt v. Bowers, 330 S.C. 483, 
  499 S.E.2d 250 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The prejudice Rule 15 envisions is a lack of 
  notice that the new issue is going to be tried, and a lack of opportunity to 
  refute it.Â  Tanner v. Florence County Treasurer, 336 S.C. 552, 521 S.E.2d 
  153 (1999); Lewis-Davis, 360 S.C. at 232, 599 S.E.2d at 465.Â  The party 
  opposing the amendment has the burden of establishing prejudice.Â  Foggie 
  v. CSX Transp., Inc., 315 S.C. 17, 431 S.E.2d 587 (1993); Pruitt, 
  330 S.C. at 489, 499 S.E.2d at 253.Â  This rule strongly favors amendments and 
  the court is encouraged to freely grant leave to amend.Â  Jarrell v. Seaboard 
  Sys. R.R., 294 S.C. 183, 363 S.E.2d 398 (Ct. App. 1987).
In the instant case, the trial judge did 
  not articulate any finding of prejudice with regard to Parker in denying the 
  Sewer Districtâ€™s motion to amend.Â  In addition, statements by Parkerâ€™s counsel 
  on the record indicate Parker would not be prejudiced by the Sewer Districtâ€™s 
  request to amend.Â  Parkerâ€™s attorney stated: â€œOf course, the Tort Claims Act 
  applies.â€Â  When discussing whether Parker consented to the Sewer Districtâ€™s 
  request to amend, Parkerâ€™s counsel professed:

He sent me a copy over the weekend in the mail . . . . Your 
  Honor, I got it and looked at it.Â  I didnâ€™t see anything â€“ we did have a conversation, 
  and I didnâ€™t see anything new, so I told [counsel for the Sewer District], frankly, 
  in our conversation that I did not have any problem with it at that time.

Parker did not satisfy her burden of establishing 
  prejudice.Â  See Pruitt v. Bowers, 330 S.C. 483, 499 S.E.2d 250 
  (Ct. App. 1998).Â  On the contrary, Parkerâ€™s complaint and her attorneyâ€™s comments 
  demonstrated just the opposite.
Further, the Sewer Districtâ€™s request was not a 
  surprise to Parker.Â  Parker specifically pled the application of the Tort Claims 
  Act in her complaint.Â  Concomitantly, she was not surprised by the Sewer Districtâ€™s 
  request to limit her amount of recovery pursuant to the Act.Â  The circumstances 
  surrounding the Sewer Districtâ€™s requests to amend were such that justice would 
  be furthered by allowing it to amend its answer and Parker would not be prejudiced 
  as a result of the amendment.Â  The trial judge abused his discretion in denying 
  the Sewer Districtâ€™s motion to amend its answer.
III.Â  MEDICARE PAYMENTS
Finally, the Sewer District asserts the 
  trial judge erred in not allowing it to introduce evidence of amounts actually 
  paid by Medicare toward Parkerâ€™s total medical bills.Â  The Sewer District argues 
  this evidence was relevant to show Parkerâ€™s medical expenses were less than 
  the amount reflected in bills she submitted into evidence.Â  The Sewer District 
  complains it was so prejudiced by its inability to introduce this evidence it 
  should be granted a new trial.Â  We disagree.Â  
The decision to admit or exclude evidence 
  is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  See Clark 
  v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 529 S.E.2d 528 (2000); Gamble v. International 
  Paper Realty Corp., 323 S.C. 367, 474 S.E.2d 438 (1996).Â  The courtâ€™s ruling 
  to admit or exclude evidence will only be reversed if it constitutes an abuse 
  of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry 
  Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 540 S.E.2d 113 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  For 
  an appellate court to reverse based on an erroneous exclusion of evidence by 
  the trial court, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and resulting 
  prejudice.Â  Recco Tape & Label Co. v. Barfield, 312 S.C. 214, 439 S.E.2d 838 (1994); Ellis v. Davidson, 358 
  S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004).
In the case at bar, the trial judge did 
  not err in denying the Sewer Districtâ€™s request to admit evidence of Medicare 
  payments.Â  This case is analogous to Covington v. George, 
  359 S.C. 100, 597 S.E.2d 142 (2004), a recent South Carolina Supreme Court case.Â  
  In Covington, the defendant, Gary George, appealed the trial judgeâ€™s 
  decision to exclude evidence that the hospital, which treated the plaintiff, 
  accepted as full payment an amount less than what it billed. Â Id. at 
  101, 597 S.E.2d at 143.Â  Similar to the case sub judice, George did not 
  object to the plaintiffâ€™s introduction of the full amount of the hospitalâ€™s 
  bill, but thereafter sought to introduce the actual payment amount to challenge 
  the reasonableness of the plaintiffâ€™s medical expenses.Â  Id. at 102-03, 
  597 S.E.2d at 143-44.Â  The supreme court held the amount a hospital accepted 
  as payment was inadmissible under the collateral source rule.Â  The court inculcated:

The collateral source rule provides â€œthat compensation received 
  by an injured party from a source wholly independent of the wrongdoer will not 
  reduce the damages owed by the wrongdoer.â€Â  Citizens & S. Natâ€™l Bank 
  of South Carolina v. Gregory, 320 S.C. 90, 92, 463 S.E.2d 317, 318 (1995).Â  
  A tortfeasor cannot â€œtake advantage of a contract between an injured party and 
  a third person, no matter whether the source of the funds received is â€˜an insurance 
  company, an employer, a family member, or other source.â€™â€Â  Pustaver v. Gooden, 
  350 S.C. 409, 413, 566 S.E.2d 199, 201 (Ct. App. 2002) (citations omitted).Â  
  In this case, the actual payment amounts were made by a collateral source.

Id. at 104, 597 S.E.2d at 144.Â  The court 
  explained the collateral source rule applied becauseÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

any attempts on the part of the plaintiff to explain the compromised 
  payments would necessarily lead to the existence of a collateral source.Â  Inevitably, 
  the inquiry would lead to the introduction of matters such as contractual arrangements 
  between health insurers and health care providers, resulting in the very confusion 
  which the trial judge sought to avoid in his proper application of Rule 403, 
  SCRE.

Id. at 104, 597 S.E.2d at 144.Â  
In its brief, the Sewer District cited Haselden 
  v. Davis, 353 S.C. 481, 579 S.E.2d 293 (2003), for the proposition that 
  amounts paid by Medicaid may be relevant to determining a reasonable value of 
  medical services and, therefore, this information should be provided to the 
  trier of fact for it to consider in determining damages.Â  Covington, 
  however, specifically limited the holding in Haselden: â€œThe admissibility 
  of the actual payment amount was not an appellate issue in Haselden, 
  but rather the issue was Plaintiff's entitlement to recover the difference 
  between the billed amount and the actual payment amount.â€Â  Covington, 
  359 S.C. at 103, 597 S.E.2d at 143-44 (emphasis in original).
Based on the holding in Covington, the trial 
  judge did not err in excluding evidence of the Medicare payments.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial judge committed reversible 
  error in denying the Sewer Districtâ€™s request for a reduction in the jury award 
  to comply with the limitation on recoverable damages set forth under the South 
  Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  We hold that the liability cap articulated within 
  the Tort Claims Act is NOT an affirmative defense and the failure to 
  plead the specific limitation on the amount of recovery allowed under the Tort 
  Claims Act is NOT a waiver of the cap.Â  We conclude the trial judge abused 
  his discretion in refusing to allow the Sewer District to amend its answer to 
  assert the Tort Claims Act limitation on recoverable damages as an affirmative 
  defense.Â  Finally, we rule the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in excluding 
  evidence of Medicare payments.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court 
  isÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Parker did not appeal the trial courtâ€™s ruling regarding the 
    dismissal of Pace.

title: State v. Smith
description: Reverses a conviction of voluntary manslaughter upon finding that the facts of the case justify neither the jury charge nor the verdict.  As a result, the conviction for possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime is also reversed.
text:
State v. Smith


<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Thurman O’Neil Smith, Jr., Appellant.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3916
Heard November 10, 2004 â€“ Filed January 10, 2005
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled February 10, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Edward T. Hinson, Jr., of Charlotte, and Leland Bland Greeley, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant and Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Thurman Oâ€™Neil Smith, Jr. was tried for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime and convicted of voluntary manslaughter and the weapons charge.Â  He appeals, arguing the evidence did not support either the verdict of voluntary manslaughter or its submission as a verdict option.Â  We reverse.
BACKGROUND

On June 10, 2002, Smithâ€™s 16-year-old daughter told her mother her paternal grandmotherâ€™s husband, Tommy Moss, molested her when she was approximately 8 years old.Â  She said the molestation happened at her grandmotherâ€™s home while her grandmother was sleeping. Â Although she did not tell her parents at the time, she never spent the night at her grandmotherâ€™s home again.Â  
Around 7:00 a.m. the next day, Smithâ€™s wife relayed the allegation to Smith. Â Although shaken by the news, Smith went to work until about 3:15 p.m., when he left one work site and stopped by another to give a price estimate. Â Smith arrived at home between 4:00 and 4:20 p.m.Â  While there, he had a beer and talked for about 45 minutes to his wife and daughter about the alleged molestation.Â  They discussed seeking counseling for Smithâ€™s daughter, which spurred Smith to call his therapist to arrange an appointment. Â They also discussed whether law enforcement could be involved and about exposing what Moss had done.Â  Smith then showered, talked to the therapist, and retrieved a gun from his dresser.Â  He left the house, with his wife and daughter unaware he had the gun and under the impression he was going to a lake he frequented.Â  
Instead, Smith drove to the home of a friend, and without mentioning the molestation allegation, discussed target practice.Â  During the discussion, he asked his friendâ€™s son or the sonâ€™s friend to go buy some shells for him, which he did.Â  Smith left and stopped at a local bar and grill around 5:30 p.m.Â  He talked with another friend, Tommy Edwards, and drank part of a beer.Â  The two walked outside and continued to talk.Â  Smith told Edwards about the alleged molestation of his daughter and the earlier abduction and death of another daughter many years before.Â  
After Edwards left, Smith loaded the gun with six bullets and started driving to the home of his mother and stepfather. Â Along the way, Smith stopped and removed the bullets, but he put two back in the gun.Â  He arrived at the Mossesâ€™ home about twenty minutes later.Â  
Smithâ€™s mother, Loretta, saw a truck she did not recognize[1] arrive in her driveway.Â  When Smith stepped out of his truck, Loretta then recognized her son.Â  Smith was yelling, asking Loretta something to the effect of â€œWhere is that son of a bitch youâ€™re married to?â€Â  He screamed out the accusations against Moss, and Loretta responded Smith was wrong and his daughter was a â€œlying slut.â€Â  Loretta testified Smith said, â€œIâ€™ve come down here to kill youâ€ to Moss.Â  At this point, Moss was outside at his doorway.Â  Smith was waving the gun, and Loretta was asking him to put the gun away.Â  Moss possibly raised his hand and made contact with Smithâ€™s arm, and the gun fired.Â  Moss was shot and he fell blocking the door, requiring Loretta to enter the house from the back to call for emergency assistance.Â  Moss died.Â  
DISCUSSION

Smith argues the trial court erred in charging the jury on the law of voluntary manslaughter and allowing the juryâ€™s voluntary manslaughter guilty verdict to stand.Â  We agree.
The trial court must determine the law to be charged based on the evidence at trial.Â  State v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 51, 584 S.E.2d. 110, 112 (2003).Â  When the record contains no evidence to support it, a voluntary manslaughter jury charge should not be given.Â  See State v. Cooley, 342 S.C. 63, 67-68, 536 S.E.2d 666, 668-69 (2000).Â  
In considering a new trial motion based on insufficiency of the evidence, the trial court is concerned with the existence of evidence rather than its weight.Â  See State v. Pauling, 264 S.C. 275, 278, 214 S.E.2d 326, 327 (1975).Â  The weight of the evidence is a question for the jury.Â  Id.Â  Where there is any evidence supporting the juryâ€™s verdict, the court commits no error in denying the motion.Â  Id.

  Voluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in the sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.Â  Both heat of passion and sufficient legal provocation must be present at the time of the killing.Â  The provocation must be such as to render the mind of an ordinary person incapable of cool reflection and produce an uncontrollable impulse to do violence.

State v. Cooley, 342 S.C. at 67, 536 S.E.2d at 668 (internal citations omitted).Â  Even if sufficient legal provocation has aroused a defendantâ€™s passion, â€œif at the time of the killing those passions had cooled or a sufficiently reasonable time had elapsed so that the passions of the ordinary reasonable person would have cooled, the killing would be murder and not manslaughter.â€Â  State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 303, 555 S.E.2d 391, 395 (2001).Â  
 Assuming without deciding sufficient legal provocation existed in this case, the evidence clearly does not establish Smith acted in the sudden heat of passion. Smith heard the allegation early in the morning, went to work, talked to his family and called to make his daughter an appointment with a therapist, went to a friend’s house to talk, dropped by a bar where he talked with another friend, and finally arrived at Moss’s home in the evening. This was certainly a long enough period to render Smith capable of cool reflection. Also, during this time he retrieved his gun, had someone buy him ammunition, loaded the gun, unloaded it, and reloaded it. Although there was testimony he was upset, this evidence suggests he in fact coolly reflected on the situation. Because demonstration of sudden heat of passion is required to establish voluntary manslaughter, the evidence supports neither the voluntary manslaughter verdict option nor the verdict itself.
 As a consequence of our reversal of Smithâ€™s conviction on the charge of voluntary manslaughter, we also reverse his conviction for possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, because the former is a prerequisite for the latter.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490 (2003) (providing contemporaneous indictment and conviction of violent crime prerequisite to punishment under section 16-23-490).Â  Absent the voluntary manslaughter conviction, Smithâ€™s conviction for violation of section 16-23-490 cannot stand.Â  State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 235 n.4, 589 S.E.2d 1, 5 n.4 (2003); State v. Mouzon, 321 S.C. 27, 29 n.1, 467 S.E.2d 122, 124 n.1 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  


REVERSED [2]Â  
SHORT, J., concurs.Â  
ANDERSON, J., dissents and concurs in a separate opinion.
I VOTE to REVERSE and REMAND for a new trial on involuntary manslaughter.Â  In my judgment, a reversal is proper in regard to the charge of voluntary manslaughter, but the case must be remanded for the purpose of a new trial on involuntary manslaughter.Â  
 I am convinced that a retrial of the defendant on the charge of involuntary manslaughter is proper.Â  In State v. Cooley, 342 S.C. 63, 536 S.E.2d 666 (2000), our supreme court edified:

  Furthermore, based on the testimony presented at Defendantâ€™s trial, the result of our holding here is that without any evidence of legal provocation Defendant cannot be retried on the charge of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Thus, retrial will be limited to the charge of involuntary manslaughter.Â  

Id. at 69, 536 S.E.2d at 669.Â  
Applying Cooley, a reversal encapsulates a retrial on involuntary manslaughter.Â 

[1]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Smith and his mother had been estranged for nearly three years. 
[2]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The majority thoroughly agrees with the dissent that State v. Cooley would allow Smith to be tried on a charge of involuntary manslaughter.Â  Even though this court does not specifically remand for that purpose, that option remains open should the solicitor in his discretion determine the facts of the case warrant it.Â

  unwanted attention.Â  Victim told the pastor Hubner needed to be removed from 
  the youth group, telling the pastor she was frightened of Hubner, that he hugged 
  her too much, told her he loved her unconditionally, told her that her body 
  was beautiful, and always wanted to be alone with her.Â  While she did not detail 
  any illegal behavior on Hubnerâ€™s part, victim did, at the pastorâ€™s request, 
  write a letter in the summer of 1998 explaining some of the aspects of their 
  relationship and the reasons she felt uncomfortable around Hubner.Â  As a result 
  of that letter, Hubner was asked to step down from his position in the youth 
  ministry department.Â  
Thereafter, when victim was fifteen and sitting alone outside the sanctuary 
  during a Christmas pageant practice, Hubner sat down beside her, placed his 
  arm around her shoulder and rested his hand on the side of her breast.Â  During 
  this incident, victim reported he told her he still loved her and they had a 
  special relationship that was very secret.Â  
Eventually, victim opened up to her youth pastor and 
  detailed some of the more explicit incidences that had occurred with Hubner.Â  
  These allegations came to the attention of law enforcement, and Hubner was subsequently 
  charged with six counts of committing a lewd act upon a child.Â  After jury selection, 
  the State requested it be allowed to introduce evidence of prior criminal actions 
  by Hubner against another child which occurred in Maine in 1981 and 1982.Â  The 
  State argued there were numerous similarities between the two cases and the 
  evidence should be admitted in order to demonstrate the existence of a common 
  scheme or plan.Â  The defense countered the allegations in the two cases were 
  not that similar, but were merely general to this type of case.Â  Further, the 
  defense asserted, given the dissimilarities between the two cases and the fact 
  that the prior case was almost twenty years old, the evidence should be excluded.Â  
  The trial court held an in camera hearing on the matter, which included taking 
  the testimony of Hubnerâ€™s prior victim, Rachel,2 regarding the incidents of abuse she suffered at 
  the hands of Hubner.Â  
Rachel, who was thirty-two at the time of the trial, 
  voluntarily traveled from her home in Arizona to South Carolina to testify against 
  Hubner.Â  She testified at the end of the summer of 1981, when she was eleven 
  but about to turn twelve, her family moved to a new house in Waterville, Maine.Â  
  Hubner lived three to four houses away and became acquainted with Rachelâ€™s parents.Â  
  Thereafter, Rachel began to watch television with Hubner and became his friend.Â  
  She would help him shovel his driveway and baby-sat his children at his house.Â  

Rachel thought Hubner was nice to her. Â Hubner began 
  to give Rachel short hugs.Â  At some point, however, these hugs became a kind 
  where Hubner would touch her body in the wrong way.Â  He also began to kiss Rachel 
  on the neck, and cheek, and would French kiss her.Â  This contact occurred at 
  his house while Rachel was baby-sitting.Â  There came a time when Hubner began 
  to fondle Rachelâ€™s breasts and bottom through her clothing and would tell Rachel 
  she had a nice body.Â  On one occasion, Hubner came up from behind Rachel, grabbed 
  her chest, and â€œrub[bed] certain body parts.â€Â  In another incident, Hubner removed 
  Rachelâ€™s shirt, but not her bra, and just stared at her.Â  
Hubner also would put his hands in her front and back 
  pockets and would massage her vagina and her buttocks through her clothes.Â  
  This progressed until he would also touch her vaginal area under her clothes.Â  
  Hubner would also come up behind her while he had an erection and rub himself 
  against her.Â  On other occasions, she touched his crotch both with and without 
  his clothes on.Â  This behavior progressed to him masturbating in front of Rachel 
  and having sexual intercourse with her.Â  Hubner also gave her alcohol.Â  Rachel 
  testified Hubner would tell her she was pretty, she had a beautiful body, and 
  that he loved her.Â  He threatened to kill her if she ever told anyone.Â  
On cross-examination, Rachel admitted giving a statement 
  to police indicating the hugging started in December, 1981.Â  The statement showed 
  it was also during December that he was hugging her from behind and, by the 
  next Saturday, put his hands in her shirt and played with her breasts.Â  Rachel 
  therefore agreed that within a week of the hugging in December, Hubner was touching 
  her breasts.Â  The statement further showed that â€œby the next Saturday, [Hubner] 
  started making passes at [her] by pointing at [her] and then him and then upstairs,â€ 
  so that he was almost immediately propositioning her for sex.Â  Thus, Hubner 
  was propositioning her within two weeks of the first hug.Â  Rachel also admitted 
  these sexual encounters involved other people.Â  She testified one of her friendâ€™s, 
  Michelle, was with her on one occasion where Hubner exposed his penis and masturbated 
  in front of them.Â  She also testified to an occasion when another man came over 
  to Hubnerâ€™s house and this man had intercourse with Rachel.Â  Rachelâ€™s statement 
  also indicated that around Christmas, Hubner was at Rachelâ€™s home and he put 
  her on her bed and touched her near her breasts.Â  Another time at Rachelâ€™s home, 
  Hubner slapped her and tried to kiss her.Â  Sometime after the hugging started, 
  Hubner attempted to take Rachelâ€™s pants off while they were watching television.Â  
  Rachel also indicated in her statement that Hubner offered to pay her for fellatio 
  and to masturbate him.Â  Rachel reported the matter in early February 1982.Â  
  She agreed that all of these incidences took place over roughly a two-month 
  period.Â  
During the hearing, Hubner took the stand and admitted 
  pleading guilty to one count of unlawful sexual contact against Rachel, but 
  denied he committed any of the acts Rachel claimed he committed.Â  After hearing 
  the testimony and arguments, the trial judge noted that the progression of the 
  seriousness of the acts over a period of time was different between the two 
  cases and there were â€œa number of acts that were very dissimilar.â€Â  Nonetheless, 
  the judge found the similar acts were probative, and their probative value outweighed 
  their prejudicial effect.Â  He thus determined it was proper to admit the portions 
  of Rachelâ€™s testimony regarding the similar acts, but the State was not allowed 
  to go into dissimilar acts.Â  The case proceeded to trial, and Rachelâ€™s testimony 
  regarding the hugging, kissing and inappropriate touching was allowed into evidence 
  over Hubnerâ€™s objection.Â  Thereafter, Hubner was found guilty on all charges 
  and was sentenced to three consecutive twelve-year terms, two concurrent twelve-year 
  terms, and one fifteen-year term, which was suspended with five years of probation.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Ordinarily, determinations concerning the admissibility of evidence are treated 
  as involving questions of fact.Â  State v. Tutton, 354 S.C. 319, 326, 
  580 S.E.2d 186, 190 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  However, the determination of whether 
  the facts surrounding an assault sufficiently evidence a common scheme or plan 
  is a question of law.Â  Id. at 326-27, 580 S.E.2d at 190.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Generally, evidence of prior crimes or bad acts is inadmissible to prove the 
  specific crime charged; however, an exception exists for evidence tending to 
  establish (1) motive, (2) intent, (3) the absence of mistake or accident, (4) 
  a common scheme or plan embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related 
  to each other that proof of one tends to establish the other, or (5) the identity 
  of the person charged with the present crime.Â  See State v. Lyle, 
  125 S.C. 406, 416, 118 S.E. 803, 807 (1923); Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  For the common 
  scheme or plan exception to apply, a close degree of similarity or connection 
  between the prior bad act and the crime charged is necessary.Â  State v. Timmons, 
  327 S.C. 48, 52, 488 S.E.2d 323, 325 (1997).Â  The connection between the prior 
  bad act and the charged crime must be more than just a similarity, as a common 
  scheme or plan concerns more than just the commission of similar crimes; some 
  connection between the crimes is necessary.Â  Id.Â  Under the common scheme 
  or plan exception, there must be a close degree of similarity or connection 
  between the prior bad act and the crime charged which enhances the probative 
  value of the evidence so as to outweigh its prejudicial effect.Â  State v. 
  Hough, 325 S.C. 88, 95, 480 S.E.2d 77, 80 (1997).Â  
Further, common scheme or plan evidence in criminal sexual conduct cases will 
  be admitted on a generalized basis only where there is a pattern of continuous 
  illicit conduct.Â  Tutton, 354 S.C. at 328, 580 S.E.2d at 191.Â  The conduct 
  need not be continuous, however, to fall within the common scheme or plan exception.Â  
  Id. at 330, 580 S.E.2d at 192.Â  Rather, the determination of the admissibility 
  of a prior bad act that does not include continuous conduct rests solely on 
  whether the requisite degree of similarity between the separate acts is present.Â  
  Id.
In arguing to the trial judge that Rachelâ€™s testimony should be admitted, the 
  solicitor asserted our appellate courts have been â€œextremely liberal in the 
  acceptance and the admissibility of Lyle-type testimony in child sexual 
  assault cases.â€Â  However, there is no case law to support that position.Â  Indeed, 
  this court noted in Tutton, that prior case law did not â€œlower the bar 
  for admissibility under Lyle simply because sexual crimes are involved.â€Â  
  Id. at 328, 580 S.E.2d at 191.Â  
In Tutton, we found Lyle evidence of a previous attack against 
  one of the same child victims to be inadmissible.Â  Tutton was accused of improperly 
  fondling two sisters who were visiting his live-in girlfriendâ€™s daughter.Â  It 
  was alleged that on the first night the children slept on the floor near Tuttonâ€™s 
  bed and he fondled one of them by touching her â€œbuttâ€, rubbing her private parts, 
  and using his fingers to penetrate her vagina.Â  Tutton, 354 S.C. at 323, 
  580 S.E.2d at 188.Â  The second night, Tutton slept on a couch and the girls 
  again slept nearby on the floor.Â  Id.Â  Another sister testified Tutton 
  fondled her â€œbuttâ€ and touched her private parts before she could move over 
  and out of Tuttonâ€™s reach.Â  Id.Â  At trial, the State was allowed to introduce 
  evidence from one of these girls that Tutton had previously assaulted her some 
  four to five years prior to the trial.Â  Id. at 324, 580 S.E.2d at 189.Â  
  The girl testified Tutton forced her to lie on her back, take off her panties, 
  and Tutton then performed oral sex on her and forced her to perform oral sex 
  on him.Â  Id.Â  Additionally, she testified he threatened to tell her parents 
  she was misbehaving if she told anyone of the incident.Â  Id.Â  
Recognizing that there were some similarities between the prior alleged assault 
  and the charged offenses, this court, in Tutton, nonetheless found the 
  separate offenses were dissimilar in significant ways.Â  Id. at 331-32, 
  580 S.E.2d at 193.Â  There we stated:

For purposes of analyzing 
  evidence of prior misconduct under the common scheme or plan exception, we believe 
  it is crucial to distinguish similarities that merely link the two crimes from 
  those similarities that tend to paint the broader, more relevant picture.Â  Where, 
  for example, the similarities are used to prove only the defendantâ€™s intent, 
  very little is required because the charged act in such cases is assumed done.Â  
  2 Wigmore, Â§ 304.Â  However, â€˜where the very act is the object of proof, and 
  is desired to be inferred from a plan or system, the combination of common features 
  that will suggest a common plan as their explanation involves so much higher 
  a grade of similarity as to constitute a substantially new and distinct test.â€™Â  
  Id. â€˜The added element, then, must be, not merely a similarity in the 
  results, but such a concurrence of common features that the various acts 
  are normally to be explained as caused by a general plan of which they are the 
  individual manifestations.â€™Â  Id. (emphasis in original).

Id. at 331, 580 S.E.2d at 192-93.Â  Noting that the balancing of similarities 
  is a difficult task in cases dealing with the admission of common scheme or 
  plan evidence, we found the similarities in the case were insufficient to support 
  the inference that Tutton employed a common scheme or plan to commit the assaults 
  alleged by the victims.Â  Id. at 333, 580 S.E.2d at 194.Â Â Â Â Â  
In the case at hand, the acts were against two different victims and occurred 
  some fourteen years apart.Â  Thus, the testimony cannot be admitted on a generalized 
  basis as a pattern of continuous illicit conduct under the common scheme or 
  plan exception.Â  Rather, the admissibility of Rachelâ€™s testimony rests solely 
  on whether the requisite degree of similarity between the separate acts is present.Â  
  As noted, this similarity must not merely be a similarity in the results.Â  Rather, 
  there must be such a concurrence of common features that the various acts are 
  normally to be explained as caused by a general plan of which they are the individual 
  manifestations.
The trial judge here recognized the numerous dissimilarities in the two cases.Â  
  He nonetheless allowed into evidence prior bad acts against Rachel, attempting 
  to limit the impact of these dissimilarities by restricting the examination 
  of Rachel to testimony concerning only similar acts.Â  The evidence was thus 
  presented in a vacuum to the jury. However, this does not diminish the fact 
  that an overwhelming number of significant dissimilarities were present between 
  the prior bad act and the case at hand.Â  While the similarities may â€œlink the 
  two crimes,â€ the question is whether they â€œpaint the broader, more relevant 
  pictureâ€ of a common scheme or plan of which they are the individual manifestations.Â  
  Tutton, 354 S.C. at 331, 580 S.E.2d at 192-93.Â  Thus, the trial judge 
  failed to balance the similarities and dissimilarities in making a determination 
  as to whether Rachelâ€™s testimony concerning the prior bad acts was admissible 
  at all.Â  
In the instant case, we find there are insufficient similarities between the 
  conduct with Rachel and the conduct with victim to support admission of the 
  evidence of Hubnerâ€™s prior abuse of Rachel.Â  First, while the prior acts with 
  Rachel did include a few general similarities to the case at hand that may â€œlink 
  the two crimes,â€ including the hugging and inappropriate touchings of twelve-year-old 
  girls, there were numerous dissimilarities between the acts.Â  The kissing with 
  Rachel included kissing her on her neck and cheek and French kissing her, while 
  with victim it was one kiss on her cheek, which victim believed was meant for 
  her lips.Â  The acts with Rachel further included intercourse, fellatio, masturbation, 
  and multiple partners.Â  The conduct with Rachel included an almost immediate 
  progression from innocuous hugs to inappropriate touching and beyond, such that 
  it is hard to segregate the less egregious acts from the more egregious.Â  Victim, 
  on the other hand, alleged a slow progression in the development of a sexual 
  based relationship where she was hugged, fondled, and ultimately persuaded to 
  touch Hubner.Â  The degree in and progression of behavior experienced by Rachel 
  and victim is markedly different.Â  Second, Hubner threatened to kill Rachel, 
  whereas he told victim that God had given them a special, secret relationship.Â  
  Thus, Hubner used victimâ€™s religious habits and beliefs to take advantage of 
  the opportunities to commit these sexual acts and to keep her from telling anyone 
  of them, whereas he used money, employment and physical threats to do the same 
  to Rachel.Â  Third, Hubner also committed sexual acts with another girl in the 
  presence of Rachel, whereas there is no testimony he also committed such acts 
  with any of victimâ€™s friends or that anyone else was present with victim during 
  any of the abuse she experienced.Â  Likewise, Rachel indicated Hubner brought 
  in another man to join in the sexual acts with Rachel, while no such thing occurred 
  with victim.Â  Additionally, all abuse against Rachel took place at Hubnerâ€™s 
  house or Rachelâ€™s house, whereas the alleged abuse against victim, with the 
  exception of one incident at Hubnerâ€™s home, took place in public places such 
  as the church, an amusement park, and church camp and all of these incidences 
  were affiliated with church activities.Â  Further, while Hubner often talked 
  to Rachel about sex and gave her alcohol, victim alleges Hubner talked to her 
  about God, religion, and her family problems.Â  Victim did not indicate any instances 
  where Hubner gave her any alcohol.Â  Finally, the State focuses on the position 
  of authority Hubner had over victim as a church deacon and leader within the 
  youth group.Â  He held no such special position of authority over Rachel, however, 
  to whom he was simply a neighbor and person who employed her as a babysitter.Â  
  Thus, the incidences with Rachel and victim occurred â€œunder different circumstances, 
  at different times, in different places, and in different ways.â€Â  State v. 
  Berry, 332 S.C. 214, 219, 503 S.E.2d 770, 773 (Ct. App. 1998).Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
We are especially mindful of the exhortation in Lyle that â€œif the court 
  does not clearly perceive the connection between the extraneous criminal transaction 
  and the crime charged, that is, its logical relevancy, the accused should be 
  given the benefit of the doubt and the evidence should be rejected.â€Â  Lyle, 
  125 S.C. at 417, 118 S.E. at 807.Â  As previously noted, a close degree of similarity 
  or connection between the prior bad act and the crime charged, which enhances 
  the probative value of the evidence so as to outweigh its prejudicial effect, 
  is required for the evidence to be admissible under the common scheme or plan 
  exception.Â  In the context of sexual assault cases, â€œ[t]he rationale for this 
  rule is that the overwhelming result of admitting unconnected sexual relationships 
  is to establish an accusedâ€™s character or propensity to engage in the alleged 
  sexual conduct as a basis for inferring that he committed the charged crime.â€Â  
  State v. Rivers, 273 S.C. 75, 78, 254 S.E.2d 299, 300 (1979).Â  Here, 
  there simply is not such a close degree of similarity or connection between 
  the prior bad act and the crimes charged as would enhance the probative value 
  so as to outweigh its prejudicial effect.Â  Because we do not clearly perceive 
  the required connection between these two cases, we hold the trial judge erred 
  in admitting Rachelâ€™s testimony.
In addition to finding Rachelâ€™s testimony was admitted in error, we find the 
  admission was not harmless.Â  In determining whether the improper introduction 
  of evidence is harmless, the appellate court must review the other evidence 
  admitted at trial in order to determine whether the defendantâ€™s guilt was conclusively 
  established by competent evidence such that no other rational consideration 
  could be reached by the jury.Â  Tutton, 354 S.C. at 334, 580 S.E.2d at 
  194.Â  While the State presented some evidence that corroborated Hubnerâ€™s opportunity 
  to commit the acts in question and victimâ€™s reaction to Hubner, there was no 
  testimony by anyone that witnessed a clear instance of Hubnerâ€™s commission of 
  a lewd act on victim.Â  Hubner vehemently denied victimâ€™s accusations, and the 
  case effectively came down to a challenge of credibility between Hubner and 
  victim.Â  Therefore, we cannot say that without Rachelâ€™s testimony the evidence 
  was so overwhelming that a guilty verdict was the only rational conclusion.3 

For the foregoing 
  reasons, we reverse Hubnerâ€™s convictions and remand for a new trial.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
  2 The prior victimâ€™s name has been changed in this opinion to protect 
    her identity. 

 
  3  Because we find the trial judge erred in admitting the prior bad 
    act evidence, we need not address other issues raised by Hubner.Â  See 
    Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 
    518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review remaining 
    issues when its disposition of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
