title: State v. Mitchell
description: In this criminal case, a novel and intriguing issue is presented in regard to whether involuntary manslaughter is a lesser included offense of homicide by child abuse.
text:
FACTS


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Nathaniel Mitchell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3918
Heard December 7, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John 
  W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior 
  Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Nathaniel Mitchell (Mitchell) was found guilty 
  of homicide by child abuse.Â  Mitchell argues the circuit court should have charged 
  involuntary manslaughter as a lesser included offense.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Nathaniel and Sonya Mitchell were acting as foster parents for Hodari, Nautica, 
  and Passion Gardner.Â  While under the Mitchellsâ€™ care, Passion, who was approximately 
  two years and three months of age, died from severe head injuries.Â  Mitchell 
  was indicted and tried for homicide by child abuse under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-85.Â  

At trial, numerous physicians testified for the State that Passionâ€™s injuries 
  were not only consistent with, but a result of shaken baby syndrome.Â  They further 
  opined that trauma of that type and severity could not have been inflicted accidentally.Â  

Passion arrived 
  at the hospital alive, but in critical condition.Â  Dr. Hubbird was called to 
  assist the effort to resuscitate Passion.Â  At trial, he described her condition:

  
    
    
      
        A. 
         . . . [Her] eyes were widely dilated . . . . I saw hemorrhages, areas 
  of bleeding into the retina on both eyes. . . .
      
      
        
        . . . .
      
      
        
        . . . [T]he main thing that I was noticing, I came into the
          E.R., the child 
  was in the emergency department in a bed intubated, not moving, and the pupils 
  were widely dilated so neurologically I already knew the child was quite devastated.
      
      
        
        
. . . .
        
      
      
        Q.
        Did the C.T. scan in fact confirm that the child hadâ€”when you say neurological, 
  do you mean brain damage?
      
      
        A.
        Brain damage, yes.
      
      
        Q.
        And what did the C.T. scan show?
      
      
        A.   
        . . . It showed what we call a subdural
          hematoma, meaning thereâ€™s a 
  collection of blood. . . .
      
      
        
        . . . It showed the subdural hematoma and it showed swelling of the brain itself.
      
      
        
        . . . [T]here was so much swelling on the right side that the brain was pushed 
  over against the left, there was some midline shift.Â  Midline shift is very 
  dangerous.Â  Any swelling of the brain is dangerous, but midline shift in particular 
  means that thereâ€™s massive, massive swelling and that causes massive damage.
      
    
    
  

Dr. Hubbird then asseverated as to the likely cause of Passionâ€™s 
  injuries: 

  
    
    
      
        A. 
         My examination, with the subdural hematoma, with the retinal hemorrhages, 
  and the abnormal neurological findings is the evidence of big time swelling 
  and neurological deficit, that indicated child abuse.Â  Thatâ€™s what causes it, 
  thatâ€™s what it is.Â 
      
      
        
         . . . .
      
      
        A.
         This isâ€”those three things together virtually is diagnostic, meaning 
  it tells us what it is.Â  They used to call itâ€”and a lot of people still call 
  it shaken baby syndrome.
      
      
        Q. 
         And when you say shaken baby syndrome, what type of trauma is inflicted 
  on this child to cause these injuries?
      
      
        A. 
         Shaken baby syndrome is violent whiplash type shaking of an infant or 
  small toddler.Â  It has to be very violent.Â  The human brain is meant to take 
  a niceâ€”you know, if you fall you might be a little dazed.Â  We are meant to take 
  a quick trauma to the brain, if itâ€™s just a one time deal, I mean, you wake 
  up like that, and it doesnâ€™t usually cause a big problem.
      
      
        
        
But back and forth, sustained shaking and violent shaking, the brain is not 
  meant to take that and it causes bleeding, retinal hemorrhages, and all that 
  then causes the swelling of the brain.Â  
           
      
      
        Q.  
        And Doctor, in your expert opinionâ€”and you mentioned could a fall, say 
  from even like a countertop or a bed or even from several feet, could that cause 
  these types of injuries?
      
      
        A. 
         No.Â  The only trauma that I know of, and Iâ€™ve never seen this, but from 
  whatâ€™s reported, that can cause anything even similar is a big time automobile 
  accident, either head-on or side impact where the child is ejected from the 
  car.Â  And I guess itâ€™s a potential from a several story fall, but then youâ€™d 
  see associated other injuries as well.
      
      
        
        . . . .
      
      
        Q.
         Could a child cause these types of injuries, say a three year old?
      
      
        A.  
         No maâ€™am.Â  A three year old wouldnâ€™t have the strength.Â  Generally in 
  head injuries, itâ€™sâ€”a serious injury is caused by serious forces.Â  Violent forces 
  cause big injuries.
      
      
        
        . . . .
      
      
        Q. 
         What about justâ€”If I, as a grown person, were picking the child up in 
  the air and its head goes back, could that cause these types of injuries?Â  Could 
  this be accidental in any way?
      
      
        A.
         No this was not accidental.
      
      
        Q. 
         So taking a child and lifting it in the air or slightly shaking it wouldnâ€™t 
  cause this?
      
      
        A. 
         No, this would be violent, violent shaking. . . .
      
    
    
  

Dr. Linda Christmann was qualified as an expert and explained the force necessary 
  to sustain the injuries to Passion:

  
    
    
      
        Q.
         . . . Doctor, the hemorrhages that you saw, could they have even been 
  caused by falling down say a flight of stairs?
      
      
        A. 
         No they could not.
      
      
        
        . . . .
      
      
        Q. 
         Doctor, in your opinion, could this have been an accidental shaking?
      
      
        A. 
         No.
      
    
    
  

Another expert, Dr. Close, corroborated the opinions of Drs. Hubbird and Christmann:

  
    
    
      
        Q.   
         And, Doctor, how would you characterize the type of shaking and/or trauma 
  that would be necessary to inflict this on a two year old, three month child?
      
      
        A. 
         That would be brutal.Â  Iâ€™ve seen children fall.Â  Kids come to the hospital 
  after falling out of shopping carts and things like that.Â  You donâ€™t see bleeds 
  from that kind of trauma.Â  You see this bleed from bad car wrecks.Â  You see 
  itâ€”when I was a resident, when a child that had fallen out of a windowâ€”a third 
  floor window.Â  Itâ€™s significant trauma.
      
    
    
  

One physician testified for the defense that his examination of the child was 
  inconclusive.Â  He further stated the rebleeding of an existing head injury could 
  have caused the death.Â  
At trial, Mitchell averred that he discovered Passion and her brother, Hodari, 
  playing in the toilet.Â  He stopped them, spanked both with his belt, cleaned 
  them up, and let them leave to play while he cleaned up the bathroom.Â  Thereafter, 
  Hodari directed Mitchellâ€™s attention to Passion, who was facedown in the hallway.Â  
  The jury did not credit Nathaniel Mitchellâ€™s testimony and found him guilty.Â  
  He was sentenced to twenty-five years imprisonment.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Involuntary Manslaughter 
  Is Not a Lesser Included Offense
The circuit court declined to charge the jury on involuntary 
  manslaughter.Â  The court found (1) involuntary manslaughter is not a lesser 
  included offense of the specific, statutorily defined crime of homicide by child 
  abuse, and (2) the facts did not support involuntary manslaughter.Â  The question 
  of whether involuntary manslaughter is a lesser included offense of homicide 
  by child abuse is a novel issue of law in South Carolina. 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â  Elements Test
â€œThe test for determining when an offense is a lesser included offense of another 
  is whether the greater of the two offenses includes all the elements of the 
  lesser offense.â€Â  State v. Elliott, 346 S.C. 603, 606, 552 S.E.2d 727, 
  728 (2001); accord Murdock v. State, 308 S.C. 143, 144, 417 S.E.2d 
  543, 544 (1992).Â  â€œIf the lesser offense includes an element not included in 
  the greater offense, then the lesser offense is not included in the greater.â€Â  
  Hope v. State, 328 S.C. 78, 81, 492 S.E.2d 76, 78 (1997).Â  
One commentator on South Carolina courts has written that in recent years our 
  courts have â€œtended to parse the elements of offenses quite closely, often finding 
  two offenses contain separate elements and therefore that one offense is not 
  contained within the other.â€Â  William Shepard McAninch & W. Gaston Fairey, 
  The Criminal Law of South Carolina 51 (4th ed. 2002).Â Â  An 
  example is Hope v. State, 328 S.C. 78, 492 S.E.2d 76 (1997).Â  In Hope, 
  the court determined entering without breaking is not a lesser included offense 
  of first degree burglary.Â  The supreme court explained that first degree burglary 
  is defined in part as entering a dwelling without consent, whereas the 
  alleged lesser included offense involves entering without breaking.Â  
  Id. at 81-82, 492 S.E.2d at 78-79.Â Â  
In Stevenson v. State, 335 S.C. 193, 516 S.E.2d 434 (1999), the court 
  determined resisting arrest is not a lesser included offense of assault and 
  battery of a high and aggravated nature: â€œABHAN requires proof of circumstances 
  of aggravation which is not required for resisting arrest.Â  Resisting arrest 
  requires proof that the person assaulted is a law enforcement officer which 
  is not an element of ABHAN.â€Â  Id. at 200, 516 S.E.2d at 438.Â  The Stevenson 
  court addressed lesser included offenses to ascertain whether the double jeopardy 
  clause was violated by convicting the defendant on charges of ABHAN and resisting 
  arrest.Â  Id. at 198-200, 516 S.E.2d at 436-439.Â  The court did this by 
  relying on the â€œsame elementsâ€ test created in Blockburger v. United States, 
  284 U.S. 299, 304 (1932).Â  In this way, the elements test used to determine 
  lesser included offenses apparently is an artifact of double jeopardy jurisprudence.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-85 (2003) provides:

(A)Â  A person is guilty of homicide by child abuse 
  if the person:
  
(1)Â  causes the death of a child under the age of 
  eleven while committing child abuse or neglect, and the death occurs under circumstances 
  manifesting an extreme indifference to human life.Â  
  

Involuntary manslaughter is defined as: â€œ(1) the unintentional 
  killing of another without malice, but while engaged in an unlawful activity 
  not naturally tending to cause death or great bodily harm; or (2) the 
  unintentional killing of another without malice, while engaged in a lawful activity 
  with reckless disregard for the safety of others.â€Â  State v. Reese, 359 
  S.C. 260, 597 S.E.2d 169 (Ct. App. 2004) (emphasis added) (citing State v. 
  Tyler, 348 S.C. 526, 529, 560 S.E.2d 888, 889 (2002); State v. Chatman, 
  336 S.C. 149, 152, 519 S.E.2d 100, 101 (1999)).
Homicide by child abuse requires child abuse or neglect; 
  therefore, Mitchell is compelled to argue that he would fit within the first 
  prong of involuntary manslaughter, involving an unlawful activity, rather than 
  the second, involving a lawful activity.Â  Obligatorily, Mitchell is forced to 
  show that engaging in an unlawful activity not naturally tending to cause death 
  or great bodily harm is a lesser element of homicide by child abuse.Â  Here, 
  Mitchell fails.Â  
The crime of homicide by child abuse only applies 
  in cases where the decedent is under the age of eleven whereas the application 
  of involuntary manslaughter is not affected by the age of the decedent.Â  Moreover, 
  homicide by child abuse involves child abuse or neglect; in contrariety, involuntary 
  manslaughter exists based on a larger number of factual predicates.Â  Indeed, 
  Mitchell concedes in his brief that â€œobviously involuntary manslaughter 
  could not be a lesser-included offense under the elements test[.]â€Â  
  (Emphasis added).Â  Apodictically, homicide by child abuse does not include all 
  the elements of involuntary manslaughter.Â  The elements test is not met.Â  See 
  also State v. Elliot, 346 S.C. 603, 611, 552 S.E.2d 727, 731 (2001) 
  (Pleicones, J., dissenting) (observing that the legislature has created several 
  statutory forms of homicide, including homicide by child abuse, which â€œare not 
  lesser included offenses of common law murder charge because they cannot 
  meet the â€˜elements testâ€™ applied when the greater-lesser question involves a 
  common law/statutory combination.â€) (emphasis in original).
Our arbitrament that involuntary manslaughter is not 
  a lesser included offense of homicide by child abuse is not exclusively an application 
  of the strict elements test.Â  The decision to create the crime of homicide by 
  child abuse displays the legislatureâ€™s intent to define and target a specific 
  societal problem.Â  See generally People v. Payne, 282 N.W.2d 
  456 (Mich. App. 1979) (refusing to find â€œassault with intent to do great bodily 
  harm less than murderâ€ a lesser included offense of criminal sexual conduct 
  because sexual assault is a particularly heinous form of assault and the prohibition 
  of these crimes serves different societal interests).Â  Legislatively, the entirely 
  new crime of homicide by child abuse was created instead of opting to enhance 
  the punishment for involuntary manslaughter.Â  In fact, a purpose given for enactment 
  of the statute was the â€œcreat[ion of] the felony criminal offenseâ€ of homicide 
  by child abuse.Â  1992 S.C. Acts 412.Â  

B.Â  Historical Antecedent Test/Elliot

The utilitarian efficacy of the elements test has 
  been limited by our supreme court.Â  In State v. Elliott, 346 S.C. 603, 
  552 S.E.2d 727 (2001), the court deviated from the strict elements test and 
  determined that assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) 
  is a lesser included offense of assault with intent to commit criminal sexual 
  conduct (ACSC).Â  In this academic and erudite endeavor titled â€œan anomaly in 
  the law,â€ our supreme court retrocedes from the elements test:

To the extent that the elements of ABHAN and ACSC 
  do not meet the elements test, we recognize this situation presents an anomaly 
  in the law, akin to manslaughter and murder.Â  The common law does not always 
  fit into the neat categories we might prefer.Â  Nevertheless, we find compelling 
  reasons not to abandon our longstanding inclusion of ABHAN as a lesser included 
  offense of attempted sexual battery crimes. 
. . . . We recognize this holding deviates from 
  the strict elements test, yet decline to overrule our many cases leading to 
  this result.Â  Despite the existence of a few anomalies, we reiterate our commitment 
  to the elements test.Â  We will continue to consider offenses on a case-by-case 
  basis, beginning with the elements test.

Elliot, 346 S.C. at 607-08, 552 S.E.2d at 729-30 
  (emphasis added).Â  The court rooted its decision in the historical fact that 
  ABHAN was a lesser included charge of the precedent crime of assault with intent 
  to ravish.Â  Id. at 606-07, 552 S.E.2d at 729.Â  
Subsequently, in State v. Watson, 349 S.C. 
  372, 563 S.E.2d 336 (2002), our supreme court declined an invitation to deviate 
  from the elements test on the question of whether reckless homicide was a lesser 
  included offense of murder.Â  Although the court had previously statedâ€”in dictumâ€”that 
  reckless homicide was a lesser included offense of murder, the Watson 
  court held:Â  â€œDespite the . . . dictum in State v. Reid, [324 
  S.C. 74, 476 S.E.2d 695 (1996)], this Court has never held that reckless homicide 
  is a lesser included offense of murder.Â  We decline to do so.Â  We instead adhere 
  to the result dictated by the elements test for lesser included offenses . . 
  . .â€Â  Id. at 377, 563 S.E.2d at 338.
In the case sub judice, there is no 
  historical antecedent that suggests involuntary manslaughter is a lesser included 
  offense of homicide by child abuse.Â  Homicide by child abuse is a crime of relatively 
  recent legislatorial vintage, the statute having been promulgated in 1992.Â  
  See 1992 S.C. Acts 412.Â  In departing from the elements test, the Elliot 
  court recounted that it had â€œconsistently incorporated ABHAN into the CSC framework 
  as a lesser included offense of ACSCâ€ and cited a number of cases in which it 
  had done so.Â  Elliot at 607, 552 S.E.2d at 729.Â  Contrastively, our courts 
  have never held or suggested that involuntary manslaughter is a lesser included 
  offense of homicide by child abuse.Â  
Furthermore, Elliot involved the lesser crime 
  of ABHAN as it relates to ACSC.Â  The predecessor crime to ACSC was assault with 
  intent to ravish.Â  The Elliot court cited State v. Stewart, 283 
  S.C. 104, 109, 320 S.E.2d 447, 450-51 (1984), which explicates: â€œThe statutes 
  dealing with rape and assault with intent to ravish were repealed by Act. No. 
  157 of the 1977 Acts and Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly.Â  In the 
  same act, the crime of criminal sexual conduct was established.â€Â  Elliot, 
  346 S.C. at 607, 552 S.E.2d at 729.Â  Here, there is no predecessor crime to 
  homicide by child abuse.Â  No statutes were repealed in its promulgation; it 
  takes its place amid the laws and jurisprudence of this State on a tabula 
  rasa.Â  Because there is no predecessor crime which homicide by child 
  abuse supersedes, there is no longstanding tradition from which to justify a 
  departure from the elements test.
Finally, State v. Jarrell, 350 S.C. 90, 98, 
  564 S.E.2d 362, 367 (Ct. App. 2002) states that â€œin the context of homicide 
  by abuse statutes, extreme indifference is a mental state akin to intent characterized 
  by a deliberate act culminating in death.â€Â  Therefore, the homicide by child 
  abuse statute requires a type of activity similar to a deliberate act leading 
  to death whereas involuntary manslaughter treats situations where an unlawful 
  act leads to death when death would not normally have been expected.Â  
The quiddity of Mitchellâ€™s argument focuses on the fact that the standard for 
  homicide by child abuse is â€œextreme indifference to human lifeâ€ whereas the 
  standard for involuntary manslaughter is â€œreckless disregard for the safety 
  of others.â€Â  Mitchell contends the involuntary manslaughter standard has traditionally 
  been treated as a lesser included offense and an alternative where the jury 
  does not find â€œmaliceâ€ or â€œextreme indifference to human life.â€Â  However, this 
  argument withers when exposed to the light of Jarrellâ€™s definition of 
  extreme indifference.Â  Mitchell fails the Elliot historical antecedent 
  test.Â  

C.Â  Other Jurisdictions

This case involves a novel issue of law.Â  Concomitantly, we look to other jurisdictions 
  for edification, enlightenment, and guidance.Â  Californiaâ€™s involuntary manslaughter 
  statute parallels South Carolinaâ€™s division between lawful and unlawful activity 
  except that our unlawful activity element requires the activity not naturally 
  tend to cause death or great bodily harm.Â  Additionally, Californiaâ€™s unlawful 
  activity element requires the activity not be a felony.Â  See Cal. Penal 
  Code Â§ 192(b) (West) (defining involuntary manslaughter as â€œthe unlawful killing 
  of a human being without malice . . . in the commission of an unlawful act, 
  not amounting to a felony; or in the commission of a lawful act which might 
  produce death, in an unlawful manner, or without due caution and circumspection 
  . . .â€).
Cal. Penal Code Â§ 273ab reads:

Any person who, having the care or custody of a child who is under eight years 
  of age, assaults the child by means of force that to a reasonable person would 
  be likely to produce great bodily injury, resulting in the childâ€™s death, shall 
  be punished by imprisonment in state prison for 25 years to life . . . .

In Orlina v. Superior Court, 86 Cal. Rptr. 2d 384, 386 (Cal. Ct. App. 
  1999), the court concluded involuntary manslaughter is not a lesser included, 
  but a lesser related, offense of that stateâ€™s crime of â€œassault on a child under 
  eight years of age resulting in death.â€Â  The Orlina court held: â€œ[T]he 
  elements of involuntary manslaughter are not necessarily encompassed within 
  the elements of section 273ab.Â  Involuntary manslaughter is a lesser related 
  rather than a lesser included offense of the charged crime.â€Â  Orlina 
  at 386. While this decisionâ€™s persuasive authority is limited by some dissimilarity 
  in South Carolinaâ€™s and Californiaâ€™s definitions of the related crimes, we find 
  the decision supports our determination.Â  
Similarly, New York law buttresses our conclusion.Â  The pertinent New York 
  statute provides:

A person is guilty of murder in the second degree when:
. . . .
4.Â  Under circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human 
  life, and being eighteen years old or more the defendant recklessly engages 
  in conduct which creates a grave risk of serious physical injury or death to 
  another person less than eleven years old and thereby causes the death of such 
  person . . . . 

N.Y. Penal Â§ 125.25 (McKinney).Â  New York defines manslaughter in the second 
  degree as â€œrecklessly caus[ing] the death of another person.â€Â  N.Y. Penal Â§ 
  125.15 (McKinney).Â  In People v. Robinson, the New York Appellate Division 
  held:

[M]anslaughter in the second degree is not a lesser included offense of murder 
  in the second degree under Penal Law Â§ 125.25(4).Â  Creating a grave risk of 
  serious physical injury is an element of Penal Law Â§ 125.25(4) but is not an 
  element of manslaughter in the second degree, and thus it is possible to commit 
  the greater crime without also committing the lesser (see, People 
  v. Glover, 57 N.Y.2d 61, 64, 453 N.Y.S.2d 660, 439 N.E.2d 376).Â  

Robinson, 723 N.Y.S.2d 277, 277-78 (N.Y. App. Div. 2000).Â  
We find the trial judge correctly concluded, as a matter of law, 
  that Mitchell was not entitled to an instruction on involuntary manslaughter 
  as a lesser included offense of homicide by child abuse.Â  Mitchell fails both 
  the elements test and the Elliot historical antecedent test.Â  Consequently, 
  the circuit court did not commit error.Â  
II.Â  Involuntary Manslaughter Is Unsupported Factually
The circuit court found the evidence did not support a charge of involuntary 
  manslaughter.Â  A charge on a lesser included offense is only required when the 
  evidence warrants such an instruction.Â  State v. Coleman, 342 S.C. 172, 
  175, 536 S.E.2d 387, 389 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Hopper v. Evans, 
  456 U.S. 605, 611 (1982)).Â  The circuit court does not err in refusing to charge 
  a lesser included offense â€œunless there is testimony tending to show that the 
  defendant is only guilty of [the lesser included offense].â€Â  State v. Hollman, 
  245 S.C. 362, 364, 140 S.E.2d 597, 598 (1965).Â  â€œ[A]n instruction on a lesser 
  included offense is proper only when the charged greater offense requires that 
  the jury find a disputed factual element which is not a requisite for conviction 
  of the lesser included offense.â€Â  State v. Cude, 265 S.C. 313, 316, 218 
  S.E.2d 240, 242 (1975) (citation omitted).
In this case, Mitchell 
  essentially argued he had no contact with Passion, except for a prior spanking, 
  and he simply found her unconscious on the floor.Â  These facts do not support 
  an application of the charge of involuntary manslaughter.
CONCLUSION
We hold that involuntary manslaughter is NOT a lesser 
  included offense of homicide by child abuse based on the elements test.Â  We 
  rule that involuntary manslaughter is not a lesser included offense of homicide 
  by child abuse under the Elliot antecedent test.Â  Additionally, we conclude 
  that this factual record does not support involuntary manslaughter as a lesser 
  included offense of homicide by child abuse.Â  
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb
description: In this civil case, the Court decides whether the Circuit Judge erred in: (1)	Concluding that the Respondent had standing; (2)	Failing to conclude that the Respondentâ€™s case was barred by the Statute of Limitations; and (3)	Granting Respondent summary judgment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Mulherin-Howell, a South Carolina Partnership,
Plaintiff,
v.
Elvis Cobb, Jean Cobb, William Rickborn, Patricia
Rickborn, The Council 
        Of Timesharing Interest Owners Of Apartments Of Sea Cabin On The Ocean 
        III, Charles A. Gray, and Francis M. Gray, Defendants,
And,
The Council Of Timesharing Interest Owners Of Apartments Of Sea Cabin 
        On The Ocean III, Third-Party Plaintiff,
v.
Allen P. Howell, Howell & Associates, Inc., and the Estate of 
        Charles M. Mulherin, by Katherine S. Mulherin, Personal Representative, Third-Party Defendants.
_________________________
Of Whom Mulherin-Howell, A South Carolina Partnership, Elvis Cobb, 
        Jean Cobb, William Rickborn, Patricia Rickborn, Charles A. Gray and Francis 
        M. Gray are the, Respondents,
And The Council of Timesharing Interest Owners of Apartments of Sea 
        Cabin on The Ocean III is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3919
Heard December 8, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  10, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert R. Black and W. Andrew Gowder, of Charleston, for Appellant.
William C. Cleveland, of Charleston, for Respondent
Mulherin-Howell.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â This appeal arises from Mulherin-Howellâ€™s (Mulherin) 
  suit to quiet title to property previously owned by Mulherin.Â  After competing 
  motions for summary judgment were filed, the trial court found Mulherin had 
  standing to bring the suit and Mulherinâ€™s action was not barred by any applicable 
  statute of limitations.Â  Additionally, the court granted summary judgment in 
  favor of Mulherin, Elvis and Jean Cobb, William and Patricia Rickborn, Charles 
  and Francis Gray, and Mulherinâ€™s individual partners (collectively, Mulherin) 
  on the counterclaims and third-party complaint filed by the Council of Timesharing 
  Interest Owners of Apartments of Sea Cabin on The Ocean III (the Council).Â  
  The Council appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In the mid-1980â€™s, 
  Mulherin developed timeshare units on the Isle of Palms in the horizontal property 
  regime known as Sea Cabin on the Ocean III.Â  Homeowners purchased a specific 
  week in a specific unit.Â  In 1987, Mulherin sold week 22 of unit 123 to the 
  Cobbs.Â  A deed was recorded in Charleston County.Â  The Cobbs subsequently exchanged 
  their first week for week 23 of unit 104.Â  No deed was given by the Cobbs back 
  to Mulherin for the first week.Â  A deed was prepared establishing the Cobbs 
  as owners of week 23 of unit 104, but it was never recorded.
The Rickborns purchased week 22 of unit 123 from Mulherin in 1989.Â  
  The deed from Mulherin to the Rickborns was duly recorded.Â  The Rickborns have 
  continuously occupied and paid dues to the Council on their week.Â  The 
  Cobbs have continuously occupied and paid dues on week 23 of Unit 104.Â  The 
  Cobbs have never exercised ownership over week 22 of unit 123.Â  The Council 
  has continuously received dues from each party without questioning their right 
  to the property.
In 1994, the Council sued Mulherin, asserting it was not properly 
  paying dues on the timeshares it continued to own.Â  The parties settled the 
  suit in 1997.Â  As part of the settlement, Mulherin agreed to deed its unsold 
  units to the Council.Â  Mulherin gave the Council a quitclaim deed to 
  interests it held in any other units.Â  Each party signed a release, which stated: 
  â€œIT IS UNDERSTOOD AND AGREED that this is a full and final Release of all claims 
  of every nature and kind whatsoever, and releases claims that are known and 
  unknown, suspected and unsuspected.â€Â  In addition to the settlement, the Council, 
  through its attorney, agreed to â€œaccommodate dues paying contract purchasersâ€ 
  in regard to settling their title once the quitclaim deed was issued.Â  A letter 
  written by the Councilâ€™s attorney to Mulherinâ€™s attorney dated November 26, 
  1997, read:

As to your inquiry concerning the quitclaim deed, it was my understanding of 
  the settlement that this would cover unidentified weeks which might have title 
  problems or any retained or reversionary interests which [Mulherin] might have.Â  
  Basically my client would prefer no lingering presence of [Mulherin] in the 
  timeshare apartments. . . . [I]t would be my expectation that the quitclaim 
  deed may in fact transfer nothing, but rather insure that [Mulherin has] no 
  further interest.Â  (Emphasis added)

Thereafter, according to William Rickborn, the Council advised him â€œthat the 
  Homeowners Association considered itself to be the owner of Unit 104, Week 23 
  [by operation of the quitclaim deed from Mulherin] and that it would not cooperate 
  in having title to the units heretofore occupied by [Rickborn] and Mr. Cobb 
  clarified.â€
In 1998, Mulherin, as owner in trust of week 23 of unit 104 for the 
  Cobbs, brought suit against the Council to quiet title to the various units 
  and weeks in which deeds were not properly filed and recorded.Â  Mulherin alleged 
  fraud based on the representations of the Councilâ€™s attorney and contended the 
  Council improperly interfered with its contract with the Cobbs for them to exchange 
  weeks and then to deed back to Mulherin the unit, which was subsequently sold 
  to the Rickborns.Â  The Cobbs and Rickborns were made defendants because of their 
  interest in the outcome of the lawsuit. [1] Â  Mulherin did not seek any relief 
  from them.
The Council filed an answer denying Mulherinâ€™s claims.Â  The Council 
  pled affirmative defenses averring Mulherin: (1) lacked standing to bring the 
  suit; (2) released the Council â€œfrom the claims asserted in the Amended Complaintâ€; 
  and (3) could not bring the suit because it was barred by the statute of limitations.Â  
  The Council set forth counterclaims for breach of contract, breach of the covenant 
  of good faith and fair dealing, fraud, and slander of title.Â  Finally, the Council 
  filed a third-party action against Mulherinâ€™s individual partners for conspiracy.Â  
  Because Charles M. Mulherin had died, his estate was named as a party.
Each party filed motions to dismiss and for summary judgment.Â  The 
  trial court considered all motions as motions for summary judgment.Â  The court 
  found Mulherin had standing to bring the suit.Â  The court concluded there 
  was no breach of the settlement agreement by Mulherin as it properly presented 
  a quitclaim deed to the Council and the nature of a quitclaim deed is that there 
  is no warranty made as to the quality of the title being transferred.
As to the Councilâ€™s other claims, the court ruled: (1) the counterclaim failed 
  to properly allege all nine elements of fraud; and (2) there is no evidence 
  the Council did not or could not know of the existence of title problems with 
  respect to the Cobbs and Rickborns.Â  On the claim for slander of title, the 
  court determined it was premature to bring the action as a counterclaim in the 
  same action which serves as the basis of the claim because it can only be based 
  upon a lawsuit in which a party prevails.Â  The court found no special damages 
  or malice were pled by the Council.Â  As to the Councilâ€™s third-party 
  complaint alleging the individual partners of Mulherin engaged in a conspiracy 
  with respect to how the timeshare units were originally sold, the court held 
  the events involved took place prior to the 1997 release signed by the parties 
  and, therefore, were barred.Â  The court granted summary judgment in favor of 
  Mulherin as to the Councilâ€™s counterclaims and third-party complaint.
The court denied the Councilâ€™s motion for summary judgment as to Mulherinâ€™s 
  claims.Â  The court declared Mulherin had standing to bring the action, the claims 
  were not barred by the release as the purported actions took place after the 
  signing of the release, and the claims were not barred by â€œany applicable statute 
  of limitations.â€
The Council filed a motion pursuant to Rules 52(b) and 59(e), SCRCP, averring: 
  (1) the court erred in determining Mulherin had standing; (2) there was an issue 
  of material fact related to the Release and what claims it barred; (3) the complaint 
  alleged special damages as to the conspiracy claim; and (4) the claim for slander 
  of title should not have been dismissed.Â  The court denied the motion.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant 
  of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard 
  which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper 
  when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party 
  is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  White v. J.M. Brown Amusement 
  Co., 360 S.C. 366, 601 S.E.2d 342 (2004); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. 
  Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 603 S.E.2d 629 (Ct. App. 2004); Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship 
  v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 581 S.E.2d 496 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In determining 
  whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which 
  can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.Â  Medical Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 
  S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004); McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 499 
  S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go to 
  the jury.Â  Baril v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 573 S.E.2d 
  830 (Ct. App. 2002); Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 
  S.C. 714, 511 S.E.2d 413 (Ct. App. 1999).
Summary judgment is appropriate 
  where the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions 
  on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment 
  as a matter of law.Â  Belton v. Cincinnati Ins. Co., 360 S.C. 575, 602 
  S.E.2d 389 (2004); McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C. 
  372, 597 S.E.2d 181 (Ct. App. 2004); Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Higgins 
  v. Medical Univ. of South Carolina, 326 S.C. 592, 486 S.E.2d 269 (Ct. App. 
  1997) (noting that when ruling on motion for summary judgment, trial judge must 
  consider all of documents and evidence within record, including pleadings, depositions, 
  answers to interrogatories, admissions on file, and affidavits).Â  â€œOn appeal 
  from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all 
  ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in 
  a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.â€Â  Ferguson v. Charleston 
  Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 563, 564 S.E.2d 94, 96 (2002); see 
  also Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 592 S.E.2d 326 (Ct. App. 
  2003) (noting that all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from 
  the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party).
Summary judgment is not 
  appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to 
  clarify the application of the law.Â  Brockbank v. Best Capital Corp., 
  341 S.C. 372, 534 S.E.2d 688 (2000); Hawkins v. City of Greenville, 358 
  S.C. 280, 594 S.E.2d 557 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Summary judgment should not be granted 
  even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts if there is disagreement 
  concerning the conclusion to be drawn from those facts.Â  Moriarty v. Garden 
  Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 534 S.E.2d 672 (2000); Ellis v. 
  Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, when plain, 
  palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, 
  summary judgment should be granted.Â  Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. 
  Co., 348 S.C. 340, 559 S.E.2d 327 (Ct. App. 2001); Pye v. Aycock, 
  325 S.C. 426, 480 S.E.2d 455 (Ct. App. 1997).
The party seeking summary 
  judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue 
  of material fact.Â  McCall, 359 S.C. at 376, 597 S.E.2d at 183.Â  Once 
  the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an 
  absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot 
  simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Regions 
  Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Rather, 
  the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a 
  genuine issue for trial.Â  Ellis, 358 S.C. at 518-19, 595 S.E.2d at 822; 
  Peterson v. West American Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 89, 518 S.E.2d 608 (Ct. 
  App. 1999); Rule 56(c), SCRCP.
The purpose of summary 
  judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services 
  of a fact finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003); 
  Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 593 S.E.2d 183 
  (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Because it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be 
  cautiously invoked to ensure that a litigant is not improperly deprived of a 
  trial on disputed factual issues.Â  Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters 
  Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 594 S.E.2d 455 (2004); Hawkins, 358 S.C. 
  at 289, 594 S.E.2d at 561-62; Murray v. Holnam, Inc., 344 S.C. 129, 542 
  S.E.2d 743 (Ct. App. 2001).
ISSUES

  
    
    
      
        I. 
         Did the circuit court err in finding Mulherin had 
  standing to bring the underlying action?
      
      
        II. 
         Did the circuit court err in concluding Mulherinâ€™s action was not 
  barred by any applicable statute of limitations?
      
      
        III. 
         Did the circuit court err in granting summary judgment in favor 
  of Mulherin where there are genuine issues of material fact?
      
    
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  STANDING
The Council argues the court erred in finding Mulherin had standing 
  to bring the underlying action.Â  We disagree.
A plaintiff must have standing to institute an action.Â  Joytime 
  Distribs. & Amusement Co. v. State, 338 S.C. 634, 528 S.E.2d 647 (1999); 
  Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 590 S.E.2d 338 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
  To have standing, one must have a personal stake in the subject matter of the 
  lawsuit.Â Â  Sea Pines Assâ€™n for the Prot. of Wildlife, Inc. v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Natural Res., 345 S.C. 594, 550 S.E.2d 287 (2001); Evins v. 
  Richland County Historic Pres. Commâ€™n, 341 S.C. 15, 532 S.E.2d 876 (2000); 
  Newman v. Richland County Historic Pres. Commâ€™n, 325 S.C. 79, 480 S.E.2d 
  72 (1997).Â  One must be a real party in interest.Â  Charleston County Sch. 
  Dist. v. Charleston County Election Commâ€™n, 336 S.C. 174, 519 S.E.2d 567 
  (1999); see also Henry v. Horry County, 334 S.C. 461, 463 n.1, 
  514 S.E.2d 122, 123 n.1 (1999) (â€œTo have standing, one must be a real party 
  in interest.â€).Â  A real party in interest is one who has a real, material, or 
  substantial interest in the subject matter of the action, as opposed to one 
  who has only a nominal or technical interest in the action.Â  Charleston County 
  Sch. Dist., 336 S.C. at 181, 519 S.E.2d at 571; see also Anchor 
  Point, Inc. v. Shoals Sewer Co., 308 S.C. 422, 428, 418 S.E.2d 546, 549 
  (1992) (holding a party has standing to sue if the party has â€œa real, material, 
  or substantial interest in the subject matter of the action, as opposed to . 
  . . only a nominal or technical interest in the actionâ€); Huff v. Jennings, 
  319 S.C. 142, 148, 459 S.E.2d 886, 890 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œA real party in interest 
  is one who has a real, actual, material or substantial interest in the subject 
  matter of the action, as distinguished from one who has only a nominal, formal, 
  or technical interest in, or connection with, the action.â€) (internal quotations 
  omitted).
The Council maintains McLeod v. Baptiste, 315 S.C. 246, 433 S.E.2d 834 
  (1993), and Shaw v. Hardy, 270 S.C. 298, 241 S.E.2d 906 (1978), are determinative 
  in this case.Â  In McLeod, the court concluded a â€œgrantor lacks standing 
  to enforce a covenant against a remote grantee when the grantor no longer owns 
  real property which would benefit from the enforcement of that restrictive covenant.â€Â  
  McLeod, 315 S.C. at 247, 433 S.E.2d at 835.Â  Thus, McLeod is distinguishable.
In Shaw, a claim of title to property was brought by Shaw against Hardy. [2] Â  The Shaw court noted: 
  â€œHardy does not claim, nor is there any indication that he could claim, any 
  interest in the property.Â  Indeed, Hardy expressly gave up any interest he may 
  have had in the property in question by conveying that interest to the Martinâ€™s 
  Lake Club prior to the institution of this suit.â€Â  Id. at 300, 241 S.E.2d 
  at 907.Â  The court concluded Hardy was not a proper party to the lawsuit.Â  The 
  court explicated:

It is true that Hardy may have an â€œinterestâ€ in the placement of the boundary 
  line in the sense that he may be concerned with its ultimate placement and his 
  potential liability, if any, to his grantee but this does not give him any adverse 
  claim to the property claimed by Shaw so as to bring him within the purview 
  of the statutes above quoted.Â  Having parted with any interest in, or claim 
  to, this property and there being no showing of his having reacquired any interest 
  in it, Hardy was neither a necessary nor proper party defendant and his motion 
  for summary judgment should have been granted. 
  [3] 

Id. at 300-01, 241 S.E.2d at 907.Â  Shaw is inapposite because 
  Mulherin is claiming an interest in week 23 for unit 104, unlike Hardy who had 
  disclaimed all interests adverse to Shaw.
In the instant case, Mulherin claims to be in possession of one of the weeks, 
  specifically week 23 of unit 104.Â  In the amended complaint, Mulherin maintained 
  it holds the unit in constructive trust for the Cobbs pursuant to prior agreement, 
  which allowed the Cobbs to exchange weeks.Â  Additionally, Mulherin has an interest 
  in enforcing its contracts with both the Cobbs and Rickborns in which it alleges 
  the Council is interfering.Â  The circuit court found:

[Mulherin] clearly has an interest in the dispute because of the potential exposure 
  it may have to the third parties if the [Council] succeed[s] in dispossessing 
  those to whom [Mulherin] sold the units.Â  [Mulherin] has an interest in the 
  effect of the quitclaim deed which it provided to the [Council].Â  Therefore, 
  [Mulherin] is a real party in interest and does have standing to enforce the 
  rights that arise out of its contract of settlement with and/or quitclaim deed 
  to the [Council].

Mulherin is â€œa real party in interest.â€Â  Apodictically, the trial court correctly 
  determined Mulherin had standing to bring the instant action.
II.Â  STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS
The Council contends the trial court erred in failing to find Mulherinâ€™s 
  claims were barred by any applicable statute of limitations because the events 
  underlying the action occurred not in 1998, when the suit was filed, but in 
  1987-1989 when the titles to week 23 of unit 104 and week 22 of unit 123 were 
  originally conveyed with problems.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note 
  the Council failed to cite any supporting authority for this position.Â  Further, 
  all arguments made are merely conclusory statements.Â  Concomitantly, the Council 
  abandoned the issue on appeal and it need not be addressed by this court.Â  See 
  First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 444 S.E.2d 513 (1994) (stating 
  Appellant was deemed to have abandoned issue for which he failed to provide 
  any argument or supporting authority); R&G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry 
  Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 540 S.E.2d 113 (Ct. App. 2000) (declaring 
  an issue is deemed abandoned if argument in appellate brief is only conclusory).
Even if properly presented, the issue fails on the merits.Â  The events 
  giving rise to the underlying action occurred after Mulherin gave a quitclaim 
  deed to the Council for any interest it may own.Â  The bulk of Mulherinâ€™s claims 
  were to correct title after the Council alleged ownership of week 23 of unit 
  104.Â  William Rickborn filed an affidavit indicating the Council refused to 
  recognize his ownership over week 22 of unit 103 and had frustrated the process 
  of the Cobbs signing over that week and taking week 23 of unit 104 as agreed 
  upon with Mulherin.Â  These claims could not have been brought until after the 
  1997 agreement and the quitclaim deed were filed.
Other claims are based upon representations made by the attorney 
  for the Council regarding the settlement agreement.Â  Indubitably, these claims 
  could not have been brought in 1989, as the Council claims, because the representations 
  were not made until 1997.Â  The trial court properly concluded Mulherinâ€™s claims 
  against the Council were based on events that occurred no earlier than 1997.Â  
  Therefore, the action brought in 1998 is not barred by any applicable statute 
  of limitations.
III.Â  SUMMARY JUDGMENT
The Council avers the trial court erred in granting Mulherinâ€™s motion 
  for summary judgment as to its counterclaims for breach of contract, breach 
  of covenant of good faith and fair dealing, fraud, and slander of title.Â  Additionally, 
  the Council complains the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on 
  its claim for conspiracy.Â  We disagree.
First, the Council 
  failed to cite any supporting authority for its position.Â  All arguments made 
  are merely conclusory statements.Â  Consequently, the Council abandoned the issue 
  on appeal and we need not consider it.Â  See Medical Univ. of South 
  Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004) (noting that failure 
  to provide arguments or supporting authority for an issue renders it abandoned); 
  Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999) 
  (declaring that conclusory arguments may be treated as abandoned).Â  Second, 
  even if this issue was properly raised, it would fail on the merits.
A.Â  Breach of Contract
On the breach of contract claim, the Council argues the jury â€œmay 
  well have regarded the settlement agreement as a bar to [Mulherinâ€™s] initiation 
  of this lawsuit.â€Â  However, this in no way refutes the trial courtâ€™s conclusion 
  that the agreement required a quitclaim deed and did not require a warranty 
  as to the title being transferred between the parties.Â  A quitclaim deed does 
  not guarantee the quality of title, but only conveys that which the grantor 
  may lawfully convey.Â  See Martin v. Ragsdale, 71 S.C. 67, 50 S.E. 
  671 (1905).
If the Council is maintaining Mulherin breached the contract and 
  settlement by bringing the lawsuit after â€œreleasing all claims,â€ we find this 
  argument meritless.Â  The release did not explicitly bar claims brought subsequent 
  to the date of the release.Â  It does not operate as a bar to the claims brought 
  by Mulherin because those claims arose after the settlement agreement and subsequent 
  deeds were filed.
B.Â  Fraud
The only claim 
  regarding fraud made by the Council in its brief is â€œ[t]he trial court is in 
  error when it states that the complaint does not set forth the nine elements 
  of fraud.Â  It does. . . . The other statements regarding this cause of action 
  are matters of fact which present questions of fact for the jury.â€Â  These statements 
  fail to edify this court as to any evidence in the record to dispute the findings 
  made by the circuit court.
The judge specifically found the Council failed to offer evidence 
  of a representation made by Mulherin upon which the Council either relied or 
  had a right to rely.Â  The Council alleged in its counterclaim: â€œThe representation 
  that [Mulherin] would convey without disclosure of secret deeds and encumbrances 
  was material and false and known by [Mulherin] to be false or recklessly made 
  since some of the property to be transferred had already been secretly transferred 
  or encumbered by [Mulherin].â€Â  Yet, as the trial court determined, the Council 
  knew or should have known of the confusion regarding title to week 22 of unit 
  123 and week 23 of unit 104.Â  Both owners had been paying dues for years on 
  the respective weeks.Â  The Council, through its attorney, agreed to â€œaccommodate 
  dues paying contract purchasersâ€ in regard to settling their title once the 
  quitclaim deed was issued.Â  Therefore, the trial court properly concluded no 
  representation was made upon which the Council had a right to rely, as it knew 
  there were problems with the title and agreed to accommodate some owners whose 
  titles had problems.
C.Â  Slander of Title
The only claim the Council makes in its brief regarding slander of 
  title is â€œ[t]his also presents facts for the jury for no discovery has been 
  taken prior to hearing in this matter.â€Â  Summary judgment is not appropriate 
  where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the 
  application of the law.Â  Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 
  336 S.C. 53, 518 S.E.2d 301 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, the Council never moved 
  for a continuance to conduct discovery, nor was this issue ever raised to the 
  trial court.Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  See 
  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt 
  is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but 
  must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for 
  appellate review.â€).
On the merits, the slander of title claim is based upon the filing 
  of the pleadings in the underlying matter.Â  The Council has not established 
  a proper basis for the claim.Â  See Pond Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 
  351 S.C. 1, 567 S.E.2d 881 (Ct. App. 2002) (finding judicial proceedings are 
  privileged and cannot form the basis of a claim for slander of title).
D.Â  Conspiracy
The allegations in the third-party claim of conspiracy all relate 
  to the sale of shares in Sea Cabins by Mulherin and its partners.Â  The Council 
  asserted the individual partners of Mulherin engaged in a conspiracy with respect 
  to how the timeshare units were originally sold.Â  As a result of the settlement 
  agreement, Mulherin transferred all of its properties to the Council.Â  The allegations 
  do not state it continued to sell any properties after the transfer.Â  Without 
  question, these sales all took place prior to the settlement agreement between 
  Mulherin and the Council.Â  Concomitantly, the release barred all claims which 
  either party had at the time of the settlement.Â  The trial court properly found 
  the conspiracy claim was barred by the release.
CONCLUSION
We rule the trial court properly found Mulherin was a real party 
  in interest and had standing to bring the action.Â  We hold the action brought 
  by Mulherin was not barred by any applicable statute of limitations.Â  Finally, 
  we conclude the trial court properly granted summary judgment to Mulherin on 
  the Councilâ€™s counterclaims and third-party complaint.Â  Accordingly, the decision 
  of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.




 
   [1]  
    By consent order, Charles A. Gray and Francis M. Gray were made party defendants 
    in this action.

 
   
    [2]  Shaw was the collective name used to identify two individuals and 
    their d/b/a company name.

 
   
    [3]  The statutes involved in Shaw were: (1) S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-30 
    (1976), which has been repealed and replaced with Rule 17, SCRCP; and (2) 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-67-10 (1976), which allows a person in possession of property 
    to bring an action to settle all claims against any parties who may have adverse 
    claims.
