THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Amy P. Lacke,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Michael R. Lacke,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Peter R. Nuessle, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3920
Heard December 7, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  10, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  and REMANDED


  
    
      
Frank S. Potts, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Gary Hudson Smith, III, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â  Amy P. Lacke (Amy) initiated 
  this action against Michael R. Lacke (Michael) to enforce a Joint Parenting 
  Agreement (the agreement) entered into by the parties and made part of an Illinois 
  courtâ€™s order of divorce.Â  Amy appeals a South Carolina courtâ€™s construction 
  and enforcement of the agreement.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Amy and Michael were divorced by decree 
  of an Illinois court filed in February 1990.Â  The Illinois court incorporated 
  the Joint Parenting Agreement into its order. Â The following provision encompassed 
  the partiesâ€™ duties regarding college funding for their children:

The parties shall utilize their best efforts for the payment 
  of the childrenâ€™s college education, which obligation is predicated upon the 
  scholastic aptitude of the child and the parties current respective financial 
  abilities.Â  The decision affecting the education of the child, including the 
  choice of college or other institution, shall be made jointly by the parties 
  and shall consider the expressed preference of the child, but neither party 
  shall unreasonably withhold his or her consent to the expressed preference of 
  the child.Â  Said college tuition shall be subject to the childrenâ€™s application 
  for grants and scholarships and both parties shall timely cooperate in completing 
  any financial aid forms to secure any said funds for higher education.Â  

Amy brought this action to enforce Michaelâ€™s 
  obligation to contribute to their daughter Lauraâ€™s college education.Â  At the 
  time of trial, Laura had completed approximately two years of college.Â  During 
  the hearing, it was determined Michael had only contributed approximately $1,550 
  toward Lauraâ€™s education.Â  Amy testified she contributed roughly $8,300 toward 
  Lauraâ€™s education expenses, although some of these payments were for automobile 
  expenses incurred by Laura.Â  
According to their financial declarations, 
  Michael and Amy had gross incomes of $88,392 and $46,440 per year, respectively.Â  
  Michael previously made as much as $140,000 per year.Â  Additionally, he makes 
  child support payments for two other children from his second and third marriages.Â  

The trial court found the provision requiring 
  the parties to pay for college was ambiguous, and therefore, considered the 
  partiesâ€™ intent in making the agreement to determine the partiesâ€™ responsibilities 
  and obligations thereunder.Â  The court concluded: (1) transportation expenditures 
  were not part of the expenses contemplated by the agreement; (2) Laura was obligated 
  to apply for loans; (3) the parties were only required to pay toward Lauraâ€™s 
  expenses after she applied for loans and after her income had been considered; 
  (4) Michael and Amy were to bear equally any amount owed for Lauraâ€™s education; 
  and (5) Michael was to reimburse Amy his share of the expenses within thirty 
  days. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this Court may find 
  facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Emery v. Smith, ___S.C.___, 603 S.E.2d 598 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Rutherford 
  v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992)).Â  However, this broad 
  scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  
  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002); Badeaux 
  v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 522 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Nor must we ignore 
  the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better 
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their 
  testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 280 S.E.2d 541 (1981); 
  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 526 S.E.2d 241 (Ct. App. 1999); see 
  also Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 
  477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. App. 1996) (ruling that because the appellate court lacks 
  the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great 
  deference to the family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).
ISSUES ON APPEAL

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in construing the Joint 
  Parenting Agreement?
  
A.Â  Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding the agreement 
  is ambiguous? 
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding transportation 
  costs are not college expenses under the agreement?
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding the agreement 
  requires Laura to incur loans and allocate her income toward her college expenses?
D.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding the agreement 
  requires Amy and Michael to share Lauraâ€™s education expenses equally?Â  
  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in allowing Michael thirty 
  days in which to reimburse Amy for any amount owed?
III.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in failing to award Amy 
  attorneyâ€™s fees?

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Construction of the Agreement
A parent may contractually obligate himself 
  to pay educational expenses beyond the age of majority.Â  Ellis v. Taylor, 
  316 S.C. 245, 449 S.E.2d 487 (1994).Â  Construction of such an agreement is a 
  matter of contract law.Â  Id.Â  Generally, where an agreement is clear 
  and capable of legal interpretation, the courtâ€™s only function is to interpret 
  its lawful meaning, discover the intention of the parties as found within the 
  agreement, and give effect to it.Â  Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 543 
  S.E.2d 224 (Ct. App. 2001); Bogan v. Bogan, 298 S.C. 139, 378 S.E.2d 
  606 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  When an agreement is unambiguous, effect should be given 
  according to the ordinary and popular sense of the words employed therein.Â  
  See, e.g., Warner v. Weader, 280 S.C. 81, 311 S.E.2d 78 (1983) 
  (providing that an unambiguous contract must be construed according to the terms 
  which the parties have used, to be taken and understood in their plain, ordinary, 
  and popular sense); see also Heins, 344 S.C. at 158, 543 S.E.2d 
  at 230 (â€œThe court must enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms, 
  regardless of the contractâ€™s wisdom or folly, or the partiesâ€™ failure to guard 
  their rights carefully.â€). 
However, where an agreement is ambiguous, the court 
  should seek to determine the partiesâ€™ intent.Â  Ebert v. Ebert, 320 S.C. 
  331, 465 S.E.2d 121 (Ct. App. 1995); Mattox v. Cassady, 289 S.C. 57, 
  344 S.E.2d 620 (Ct. App. 1986); see also Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 
  S.C. 329, 491 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1997) (explaining unambiguous marital agreements 
  will be enforced in accordance with their terms, while ambiguous agreements 
  will be examined in same manner as other agreements in order to determine intention 
  of parties).Â  â€œA contract is ambiguous when it is capable of more than one meaning 
  or when its meaning is unclear.â€Â  Smith-Cooper v. Cooper, 344 S.C. 289, 
  295, 543 S.E.2d 271, 274 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Construction of an ambiguous contract 
  is a question of fact.Â  Skull Creek Club Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Cook & Book, 
  Inc., 313 S.C. 283, 437 S.E.2d 163 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  

A.Â Â Â Â Â  Ambiguity

In McDuffie v. McDuffie, 313 S.C. 
  397, 438 S.E.2d 239 (1993), the South Carolina Supreme Court found â€œthe words 
  â€˜all college expenses,â€™ without more, [are] patently ambiguous.â€Â  McDuffie, 
  313 S.C. at 400, 438 S.E.2d at 241.Â  In the instant case, the first clause of 
  the original agreement is patently ambiguous.Â  It states:Â  â€œThe parties shall 
  utilize their best efforts for the payment of the childrenâ€™s college education, 
  which obligation is predicated upon the scholastic aptitude of the child and 
  the parties current respective financial abilities.â€Â  It fails to define college 
  education, or delineate which expenses should be paid for by the parties.Â  Accordingly, 
  we agree with the trial court that the agreement is ambiguous as to the expenses 
  encompassed by the phrase â€œcollege education.â€Â  The court properly sought to 
  determine the intent of the parties.Â  See Mattox v. Cassady, 289 
  S.C. 57, 344 S.E.2d 620 (Ct. App. 1986). 

B.Â Â Â Â Â  Expenses Covered

Amy contends the trial court erred in 
  finding transportation costs were not included as college education expenses.Â  
  We disagree.
The agreement is vague as to which expenses qualify 
  as â€œcollege educationâ€ costs.Â  McDuffie, 313 S.C. 397, 438 S.E.2d 239, 
  illustrates when transportation costs may be covered by an otherwise ambiguous 
  agreement to pay for a childâ€™s college education.Â  In McDuffie, the court 
  determined that transportation was not an expense intended to be covered by 
  the fatherâ€™s agreement â€œto pay all expenses associated with [the] college education 
  of any of said children . . . .â€ Id. at 398, 438 S.E.2d at 240.Â  The 
  court noted that â€œin her testimony, Mother defined college expenses as â€˜tuition, 
  room, and board . . . books or supplies,â€™ and advised that she was willing to 
  pay for transportation.â€Â  Id. at 400, 438 S.E.2d at 241.Â  Thus, the court 
  gave credence to the partiesâ€™ testimony of their intent in making the agreement.
Here, there is no evidence establishing 
  the partiesâ€™ intent regarding the inclusion of transportation as a college expense.Â  
  During cross-examination, Amy professed:

Q.Â Â Â Â Â  But you agree with Mr. Lackeâ€”he says nothing about 
  covering transportation expenses?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  I disagree.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  So, where it says payment for the childrenâ€™s college 
  education your understanding of that is to mean transportation and everything 
  else?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  There are many other things that Iâ€™ve read about 
  the law in Illinois and it always includes transportation as part of that.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  But thatâ€™s not in this agreement, 
  is it?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  It is in that agreement.Â  I think it is implicit 
  in that agreement.Â  

Critically, this discussion does not edify as to 
  the partiesâ€™ intent in signing the agreementâ€”it only demonstrates Amyâ€™s desire 
  that transportation now be covered and her misunderstanding of Illinois law.Â  

In her brief, Amy points to 750 Ill. Comp. Stat. 5/513 as 
  grounds for inclusion of transportation costs in education expenses.Â  The statute 
  provides, in relevant part:Â  

The educational expenses may include, but shall 
  not be limited to, room, board, dues, tuition, transportation, books, 
  fees, registration and application costs, medical expenses including medical 
  insurance, dental expenses, and living expenses during the school year and periods 
  of recess, which sums may be ordered payable to the child, to either parent, 
  or to the educational institution, directly or through a special account or 
  trust created for that purpose, as the court sees fit.

Id. (emphasis added).Â  This statute, however, lends 
  no great benefit to Amy.Â  
Nothing in the agreement indicates it 
  is to include transportation costs.Â  The statute uses the word â€œmay,â€ which 
  merely indicates transportation expenditures are not prohibited from inclusion 
  as an education-related expense.Â  The agreement does not reference the statute, 
  and neither party expressed intent that a vehicle be a covered cost of Lauraâ€™s 
  education; therefore, the trial judge was within his discretion in ruling that 
  transportation expenses are not covered in the agreement.Â  See McPherson 
  v. J. E. Sirrine & Co., 206 S.C. 183, 33 S.E.2d 501 (1945) (providing 
  that words cannot be read into a contract which import intent wholly unexpressed 
  when the contract was executed). 
Presented with a dearth of evidence from which 
  to glean the intent of parties, the trial judge ruled the following to be covered 
  expenses: â€œ1. tuition; 2. room; 3. board; 4. books; and 5. supplies.â€Â  We find 
  no error in the determination that the parties did not intend to include transportation 
  costs as an expense covered under the agreement.

C.Â Â Â Â Â  Loan and Work Requirements

The trial court concluded that Laura was 
  required to incur debt in the form of student loans and to work to support herself 
  prior to the parties being responsible for any payment of her college expenses.Â  
  Amy contends this was error, and we agree.
While the agreement is ambiguous as to 
  precisely which expenses are to be included under â€œcollege education,â€ the agreement 
  is unequivocal as to who is to pay the expenses.Â  Consequently, the courtâ€™s 
  only function was to enforce the agreement according to its terms.Â  See 
  Heins, 344 S.C. at 158, 543 S.E.2d at 230 (â€œUnambiguous marital agreements 
  will be enforced according to their terms.â€).Â  
The agreement makes clear that Laura should incur 
  no cost for her education.Â  Although the agreement requires her to apply for 
  scholarships and grants, neither type of financial aid requires reimbursement, 
  and certainly neither requires her to assume debt and make payments of principal 
  and interest.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court has considered a similar clause 
  in an agreement to pay for college expenses:Â  â€œThe agreement states that Father 
  will pay all reasonable expenses â€˜to the extent that such expenses are not provided 
  by any scholarship, grant or other assistance available to the children.â€™â€Â  
  Ellis v. Taylor, 316 S.C. 245, 248, 449 S.E.2d 487, 488 (1994).Â Â  The 
  court announced:Â  

When words of particular and specific meaning are followed 
  by general words, the general words are construed to embrace only persons or 
  things of the same general kind or class as those enumerated.Â  See Swanigan 
  v. American Natâ€™l Red Cross, 313 S.C. 416, 438 S.E.2d 251 (1993).Â  The forms 
  of â€œassistanceâ€ enumerated in the agreement are all within the same general 
  class of programs that do not require repayment.Â  We find â€œother assistanceâ€ 
  does not include loans that require repayment.

Id.
The provision in question here does not 
  include loans or even â€œother assistanceâ€ as a category.Â  It simply and unquestionably 
  limits Lauraâ€™s contributions to scholarships and grants, and it was error to 
  oblige her to incur debt where no such requirement exists in the agreement.Â Â  

Similarly, the agreement does not require that 
  Laura work to support herself through college before the parties are required 
  to contribute.Â  The agreement provides: â€œThe parties shall utilize their 
  best efforts for the payment of the childrenâ€™s college education, which obligation 
  is predicated upon the scholastic aptitude of the child and the parties current 
  respective financial abilities.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  The agreement places 
  only the requirement of scholastic aptitude upon the child.Â  The partiesâ€™ financial 
  ability and best efforts are to be considered, but no reference is made to Lauraâ€™s 
  ability to pay or her financial condition.Â  In Ellis, the supreme court 
  â€œreverse[d] the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding that . . . [the childâ€™s] ability to 
  contribute reduced Fatherâ€™s obligation to pay.â€Â  316 S.C. at 248, 449 S.E.2d 
  at 488.Â  Lucidly, when a party enters into an agreement to pay for his childâ€™s 
  education, the terms of that agreement control the rights and obligations of 
  the party. 
The trial courtâ€™s comments during a colloquy with 
  the attorneys indicates an error in its determination.Â  The court explained:Â  


Well, over time I have found that that is the big dilemma 
  in all of these cases.Â  This one may be a little different because youâ€™ve got 
  an Illinois agreement, but thatâ€™s the big dilemma in all of these cases.Â  It 
  is getting more and more difficult to show need.Â  I have had two or three of 
  these lately, and Iâ€™ve noticed overall it is getting more and more difficult, 
  I suppose, as there are more grants, scholarships, and loans available.Â  

(Emphasis added).

The agreement included no provision for the establishment 
  of need, and neither party indicated intent that Laura demonstrate need prior 
  to the parties being required to pay for her education.Â  For the court to include 
  need as a requirement is a significant modification of the Illinois order and 
  is not allowed under section 20-7-1152 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003), 
  because Illinois has exclusive jurisdiction under the Uniform Interstate Family 
  Support Act (UIFSA), S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-960 and â€“1010 (Supp. 2003).Â  See 
  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 207-08, 522 S.E.2d 835, 841 (Ct. App. 
  1999) (providing a detailed and extensive summation of UIFSA statutes and requirements).
Furthermore, this case is governed by the partiesâ€™ 
  agreement.Â  Consequently, Risinger v. Risinger, 273 S.C. 36, 253 S.E.2d 
  652 (1979), is inapplicable.Â  Pursuant to Risinger, the family court 
  may order a parent to pay for a childâ€™s college education where no agreement 
  to pay exists.Â  The Risinger court held:

[A] family court judge may require a parent to contribute 
  that amount of money necessary to enable a child over 18 to attend high school 
  and four years of college, where, as here, there is evidence that: (1) the characteristics 
  of the child indicate that he or she will benefit from college; (2) the child 
  demonstrates the ability to do well, or at least make satisfactory grades; (3) 
  the child cannot otherwise go to school; and (4) the parent has the financial 
  ability to help pay for such an education.

Id. at 39, 253 S.E.2d at 653-54.Â  
Subsequently, in Hughes v. Hughes, 
  280 S.C. 388, 313 S.E.2d 32 (Ct. App. 1984), this Court elaborated upon the 
  third prong of the Risinger test.Â  We adjudged that 

[a]mong the factors to be considered in determining whether 
  and to what extent financial assistance for college is necessary are the availability 
  of grants and loans and the ability of a child to earn income during the school 
  year or on vacation.Â  [Citation omitted].Â  We find these factors relevant because 
  an emancipated child has a duty to help minimize college expenses when a parentâ€™s 
  financial support for these expenses is sought through the family courts.

Id. at 391, 313 S.E.2d at 33-34.Â  See 
  generally Nicholson v. Lewis, 295 S.C. 434, 369 S.E.2d 649 (Ct. App. 
  1988) (finding trial court properly required father to pay a portion of daughterâ€™s 
  remaining educational expenses where daughter worked full time during summer 
  breaks, helped with the upkeep of her automobile, was searching for part time 
  work during the school year, and had obtained grants and student loans); Kelly 
  v. Kelly, 310 S.C. 299, 301, 423 S.E.2d 153, 154 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding 
  the family court erred by requiring mother to contribute to sonâ€™s college expenses 
  where son â€œmade no attempt whatever to apply for educational loans.â€).
However, Risinger and Hughes 
  have no application to situations where a parent voluntarily binds himself in 
  an agreement to assume a childâ€™s college expenses.Â  When such an agreement exists, 
  the child is under no obligation to minimize expenses, incur student loans, 
  or apply her own income to pay for college unless the agreement so provides.Â  
  See McDuffie v. McDuffie, 313 S.C. 397, 438 S.E.2d 239 (1993).Â  
  Here, the agreement unambiguously places the burden to pay for Lauraâ€™s education 
  exclusively on Michael and Amy.Â  It was error to hold otherwise.Â Â  

D.Â Â Â Â Â  Partiesâ€™ Shares of Expenses

The trial court found each party should 
  be equally responsible for the remaining costs of Lauraâ€™s education after applicable 
  sources have been exhausted.Â  Amy argues the court erred by placing an equal 
  burden on the parties.Â  We agree.
The agreement, without ambiguity, mandates 
  that the parties bear the burden of Lauraâ€™s education costsâ€”not equally, but 
  according to their respective abilities.Â  The agreement provides:Â  â€œThe parties 
  shall utilize their best efforts for the payment of the childrenâ€™s college education, 
  which obligation is predicated upon . . . the parties current respective 
  financial abilities.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  The trial court did not set forth 
  any findings regarding the partiesâ€™ current financial abilities.Â  Nor did the 
  court explain the evidence upon which it was relying in finding an equal division 
  appropriate.
After our full review of the evidence, 
  we conclude an equal division of Lauraâ€™s education costs is unfair, inappropriate, 
  and fails to give effect to partiesâ€™ agreement.Â  The agreement predicates each 
  partyâ€™s obligation to bear the cost of Lauraâ€™s education upon that partyâ€™s respective 
  ability to pay.Â  Concomitantly, enforcement of the agreement requires analysis 
  of Amy and Michaelâ€™s economic conditions.Â  An equal sharing of the expenses 
  could only be supported by finding an equal ability to pay.Â  
The financial declarations reveal that Michaelâ€™s 
  annual gross income at the time of trial was approximately $88,392.Â  Amyâ€™s total 
  income, including sums received for child and spousal support, amounted to $46,440 
  per year.Â  However, Michael confessed that when Laura began college, his annual 
  income was â€œprobably 130 to 140,000 a year.â€Â  
The Illinois Appellate Court has found all aspects 
  of a partyâ€™s financial condition should be considered in reaching a conclusion 
  regarding their ability to pay college expenses.Â  In re Marriage of Drysch, 
  732 N.E.2d 125 (Ill. App. Ct. 2000).Â  The order is from an Illinois court, and 
  Illinois continues to retain continuing exclusive jurisdiction over the order.Â  
  See Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 207-08, 522 S.E.2d 835, 841 
  (Ct. App. 1999) (explaining where a foreign jurisdiction has entered an order 
  and this state does not have grounds for accepting exclusive jurisdiction, the 
  continuing exclusive jurisdiction will remain in the issuing state); S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-1000 and â€“1010 (Supp. 2003).Â  Therefore, the trial court should 
  have looked to Illinois law for determination of the partiesâ€™ rights and responsibilities 
  under the order.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1138(A) (Supp. 2003) (establishing 
  law of the issuing state governs the nature, extent, amount, and duration of 
  current payments and other obligations of support).Â  
In Drysch, the Illinois court concluded 
  the income of a partyâ€™s new spouse should be included as part of his or her 
  ability to pay if that money is pooled and used to support each spouse.Â  732 
  N.E.2d at 129.Â  At trial, Michael declared that his new wife earned â€œ[a]pproximately 
  $58,000 a year.â€Â  Additionally, in Greiman v. Friedman, 414 N.E.2d 77 
  (Ill. App. Ct. 1980), the Illinois Appellate Court found fatherâ€™s expenses in 
  raising a second family should be considered.Â  Id. at 82-84.Â  
These numbers reveal substantial disparity between 
  the financial abilities of Michael and Amy.Â  Based on the partiesâ€™ respective 
  gross incomes of $88,392 and $46,440, we require Michael to pay 66% of Lauraâ€™s 
  education expenses, with Amy bearing the burden of 34%.Â  We remand to the trial 
  court for a determination of the amount of expenses incurred by Laura, including 
  expenses related to her having to assume debt to pay for school, which remained 
  after her receipt of scholarships and grants.Â  The parties shall be responsible 
  for this amount pursuant to the division set forth in this opinion, and the 
  trial court shall enter an order setting forth the amount owed by each party.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  When Payment Required
The agreement does not provide a time frame for 
  paying education costs.Â  It simply requires payment of the expenses.Â  At the 
  time of the hearing, Laura had completed two years of schooling and incurred 
  two years worth of debt and expenses, which should have been paid by Amy and 
  Michael.Â  It was error for the court not to require immediate payment of any 
  amount owed by Michael for the years already completed by Laura.
According to Amyâ€™s brief, Laura graduated 
  from college in the spring of 2004.Â  Therefore, we rule that the parties shall 
  make payment of the known expenses immediately.Â  Upon remand, the family court 
  is to determine with certitude the amount owed by each party in accordance with 
  this opinion, and that amount shall be due immediately.Â Â  
III.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Amy contends the trial court erred in 
  failing to award her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We find the trial court failed to properly 
  consider the relevant factors and explain its reasoning in denying attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.
The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is at the 
  sound discretion of the family court.Â  See Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  295 S.C. 412, 368 S.E.2d 901 (1988).Â  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s 
  fees, the family court should consider: (1) the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their 
  own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; (3) the respective 
  financial conditions of the parties; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s 
  standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992); 
  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 536 S.E.2d 427 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Our 
  supreme court has identified the following factors for determining a reasonable 
  attorneyâ€™s fee: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the 
  time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; 
  (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6) customary 
  legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 
  403 S.E.2d 313 (1991). 
The courtâ€™s order simply stated:Â  â€œI further find 
  that both parties shall be responsible for their own attorney fees and costs 
  associated with this action.â€Â  This succinct and brief statement fails to provide 
  any evidence the trial court considered the appropriate factors in reaching 
  its decision. 
Further, we conclude that South Carolina law controls 
  concerning the consideration of an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, because this action 
  was instituted and initiated for the purpose of enforcing an Illinois court 
  order in the State of South Carolina.Â  All activities and proceeding in this 
  regard have occurred within the jurisdiction of South Carolina.Â  Regardless, 
  the factors to be considered in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees under Illinois law 
  are substantially the same as, if not identical to, the factors announced in 
  E.D.M. and Glasscock.Â  See In re Marriage of Landfield, 
  567 N.E.2d 1061 (Ill. App. Ct. 1991) (listing the factors considered in making 
  determination of attorneyâ€™s fees award as skill and standing of attorneys employed; 
  nature of controversy; novelty and difficulty of questions at issue; amount 
  and importance of subject matter, especially from family law standpoint; degree 
  of responsibility involved in management of case; time and labor required; usual 
  and customary charge in community; and benefits resulting to client); 750 Ill. 
  Comp. Stat. 5/508.Â  
Accordingly, the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees is remanded 
  to the trial court for adequate and proper consideration of the appropriate 
  factors consistent with the results reached in this opinion.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court correctly determined costs 
  associated with Lauraâ€™s ownership of a vehicle are not included in the amount 
  covered by the parties.Â  However, the court erred in its determination that 
  Laura must apply for loans to pay for her schooling prior to the rise of any 
  obligation to pay by Amy or Michael.Â  Further, we conclude the trial court erred 
  in deducting Lauraâ€™s income, either during school or during break, from the 
  amount owed by the parties.Â  We hold the parties shall divide the expenses of 
  Lauraâ€™s education 66% to Michael and 34% to Amy.Â  
We remand to the trial court for an order setting 
  forth the amount of college expenses, including any expenses related to Laura 
  incurring debt to pay for school, which are to be covered by the parties.Â  The 
  family court shall require immediate payment by the parties.Â  Finally, the court 
  shall reconsider the award of attorneyâ€™s fees in accordance with this opinion.Â  
  This case is affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded to the trial court 
  for entry of an order consistent with this opinion.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  and REMANDED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â

title: BPS v. Worthy
description: In this civil action, the Appellant, BPS, Inc., appeals the granting of summary judgment to Respondent, William M. Worthy, II, as to his individual liability.  BPS is a company processing insurance claims as a third party administrator for corporations.  Carolina Benefit Administrators of SC, Inc. (CBA) processes insurance claims as a third party administrator for self-funded ERISA plans.  Worthy is president of CBA.  The gravamen of this action relates to an alleged agreement by CBA to purchase BPS, Inc.  On appeal, the appellate court must decide whether genuine issues of material fact exist as to the personal and individual liability of the Respondent.  Additionally, this case involves the authority of a circuit judge to review an order of a retired circuit judge.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
BPS, Inc.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William M. Worthy, II and Carolina Benefit Administrators of SC, Inc.,       
Defendants,
Of Whom William M. Worthy, II, is the       
Respondent.
      
    
  

and

  
    
      
William M. Worthy, II, and Carolina Benefit Administrators of SC, 
        Inc.,        Third-Party Plaintiffs,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Robert J. Dickey,       
Third-Party Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3921
Heard December 7, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  10, 2005

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
John D. Hawkins, of Spartanburg, A. Camden Lewis, Mark 
  W. Hardee and Thomas A. Pendarvis, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Ginger D. Goforth, Matthew E. Cox and Walter M. 
  White, all of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  BPS, Inc. appeals from a 
  circuit court order granting summary judgment to William M. Worthy, II and from 
  an order denying its motion to alter or amend. Â We reverse and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
BPS, Inc. (BPS) is a company 
  which processes insurance claims as a third party administrator for corporations.Â  
  Carolina Benefit Administrators of SC, Inc. (Carolina Benefit) administers insurance 
  claims as a third party administrator for self-funded ERISA plans.Â  In the summer 
  of 2000, Robert J. Dickey, president of BPS, and William M. Worthy, II, president 
  of Carolina Benefit, entered into negotiations for the sale of BPSâ€™s assets 
  to Carolina Benefit.Â  Around September 22, 2000, Carolina Benefit and BPS executed 
  a letter of intent.Â  Attorneys for both companies then began drafting an Asset 
  Purchase Agreement.
Although no written agreement 
  existed between the parties, Carolina Benefit provided an earnest money deposit 
  of $100,000 to BPS in November of 2000.Â  Thereafter, a transition team of BPS 
  employees began working out of Carolina Benefitâ€™s offices, though they remained 
  BPS employees.Â  Dickey declared that Carolina Benefit received â€œaccess to computer 
  and paper files containing information relating to the operations of BPS, Inc., 
  including pricing, renewals and other information concerning customers of BPS, 
  Inc.â€
In November of 2000, Carolina 
  Benefit learned that various accounts in BPSâ€™s portfolio were leaving BPS.Â  
  On November 22, 2000, Dickey signed a version of the Asset Purchase Agreement, 
  making handwritten changes before signing it.Â  Worthy was on vacation at that 
  time.Â  Upon his return, Worthy was informed that BPSâ€™s largest account would 
  not be renewed for the coming year.Â  Worthy refused to sign the agreement.Â  
  Dickey averred that at that time Carolina Benefit had already â€œtaken possession 
  of the BPS assets, employed its employees and begun servicing its clients.â€
In December of 2000, BPS filed 
  a lawsuit against Carolina Benefit and Worthy seeking injunctive relief and 
  damages.Â  The amended complaint alleged causes of action for breach of contract, 
  breach of contract accompanied by fraudulent act, promissory estoppel, quantum 
  meruit, violation of the Unfair Trade Practices Act, intentional interference 
  with a contract, fraud, negligent misrepresentation, and fraud in the inducement.Â  
  Carolina Benefit and Worthy answered and filed a counterclaim against BPS and 
  a cross-claim against Dickey.
BPS sought an injunction to prevent 
  Carolina Benefit

from using the assets and name 
  of BPS, Inc., from employing persons now or formerly employed by BPS, Inc., 
  from contacting or otherwise doing business with any current or former client 
  or customer of BPS, Inc., from utilizing any proprietary information, trade 
  secret or other information obtained from BPS, Inc. in the course of its negotiations 
  and purchase of assets from BPS, Inc., from entering into any contracts of any 
  kind with clients, customers, employees or others now or formerly associated 
  with Plaintiff . . . .

BPS filed various affidavits in 
  support of the request for the temporary restraining order along with the complaint.Â  
  A temporary restraining order was issued.Â  Thereafter, a temporary injunction 
  was ordered.Â  The parties subsequently entered into a consent agreement in which 
  Carolina Benefit agreed not to use BPSâ€™s assets and name or to use proprietary 
  information or trade secrets obtained from BPS or its employees in the course 
  of its negotiations for the purchase of BPSâ€™s assets.Â  By order of the circuit 
  judge, the â€œPlaintiff shall maintain the disputed $100,000 earnest money deposit 
  in an interest-bearing escrow account until further order of this Court.â€
Worthy moved to dismiss the action 
  against him individually.Â  He filed an affidavit in support of his motion, as 
  well as excerpts from the depositions of Worthy and Dickey.Â  The motion was 
  heard before Judge Gary E. Clary on August 14, 2002.Â  The trial court instructed 
  counsel for Worthy to prepare a proposed order granting the motion to have Worthy 
  dismissed as a defendant.Â  The proposed order, mailed on August 27, 2002, noted: 
  â€œWhere matters outside the pleadings are presented to and not excluded by the 
  Court, the motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed 
  of as provided in Rule 56.Â  See Rule 12(b), SCRCP.â€
On August 30, before Judge Clary 
  signed the order, BPSâ€™s attorney wrote to the court objecting to the conversion.Â  
  Counsel for BPS argued that if the motion was to be treated as a motion for 
  summary judgment, the entire depositions should be placed into the record.Â  
  A complete copy of Dickeyâ€™s deposition was attached to the letter.
Judge Clary did not reply to 
  this letter, but directed that the letter from BPSâ€™s attorney and Dickeyâ€™s deposition 
  be â€œfiled in the Court file.â€Â  Counsel for Carolina Benefit and Worthy did not 
  object.Â  Nonetheless, Judge Clary signed the order as proposed on September 
  6, 2002.Â  The order referenced the depositions of both Worthy and Dickey in 
  setting forth the facts, but stated: â€œ[BPS] failed to submit any affidavits 
  so the facts before the Court are those as set forth by the Affidavits and Deposition 
  excerpts provided by Defendant/Third-Party Plaintiff Worthy.â€Â  The order granted 
  Worthyâ€™s motion for summary judgment as to individual liability.
BPS filed a motion to alter or 
  amend.Â  In the interim, Judge Clary left the bench.Â  The motion to alter or 
  amend was heard before Judge Larry Patterson.Â  Judge Patterson denied the motion.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a 
  summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which 
  governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper 
  when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party 
  is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  White v. J.M. Brown Amusement 
  Co., 360 S.C. 366, 601 S.E.2d 342 (2004); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. 
  Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 603 S.E.2d 629 (Ct. App. 2004); Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship 
  v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 581 S.E.2d 496 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In determining 
  whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which 
  can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.Â  Medical Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 
  S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004); McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 499 
  S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go to 
  the jury.Â  Baril v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 573 S.E.2d 
  830 (Ct. App. 2002); Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 
  S.C. 714, 511 S.E.2d 413 (Ct. App. 1999).
Summary judgment is appropriate 
  where the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions 
  on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment 
  as a matter of law.Â  Belton v. Cincinnati Ins. Co., 360 S.C. 575, 602 
  S.E.2d 389 (2004); McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C. 
  372, 597 S.E.2d 181 (Ct. App. 2004); Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Higgins 
  v. Medical Univ. of South Carolina, 326 S.C. 592, 486 S.E.2d 269 (Ct. App. 
  1997) (noting that when ruling on motion for summary judgment, trial judge must 
  consider all of the documents and evidence within the record, including pleadings, 
  depositions, answers to interrogatories, admissions on file, and affidavits).Â  
  All ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must 
  be construed most strongly against the moving party.Â  Schmidt v. Courtney, 
  357 S.C. 310, 592 S.E.2d 326 (Ct. App. 2003); Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001); see also 
  Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 563, 564 
  S.E.2d 94, 96 (2002) (â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the 
  appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising 
  in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.â€).
Summary judgment is not appropriate 
  where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the 
  application of the law.Â  Brockbank v. Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 
  534 S.E.2d 688 (2000); Hawkins v. City of Greenville, 358 S.C. 280, 594 
  S.E.2d 557 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Summary judgment should not be granted even when 
  there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts if there is disagreement concerning 
  the conclusion to be drawn from those facts.Â  Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary 
  Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 534 S.E.2d 672 (2000); Ellis v. Davidson, 
  358 S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, when plain, palpable, 
  and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary 
  judgment should be granted.Â  Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 
  348 S.C. 340, 559 S.E.2d 327 (Ct. App. 2001); Pye v. Aycock, 325 S.C. 
  426, 480 S.E.2d 455 (Ct. App. 1997).
The purpose of summary judgment 
  is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact 
  finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003); Rumpf 
  v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 593 S.E.2d 183 (Ct. App. 
  2004).Â  Because it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously 
  invoked to ensure that a litigant is not improperly deprived of a trial on disputed 
  factual issues.Â  Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 
  S.C. 631, 594 S.E.2d 455 (2004); Hawkins, 358 S.C. at 289, 594 S.E.2d 
  at 561-62; Murray v. Holnam, Inc., 344 S.C. 129, 542 S.E.2d 743 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
BPS argues that: (1) Judge Clary 
  erred in granting summary judgment to Worthy; (2) summary judgment should not 
  have been granted until discovery was complete; and (3) Judge Patterson erred 
  â€œin his determination that he had no authority to alter and amend the summary 
  judgment order of Judge Clary.â€
I.Â  SUMMARY JUDGMENT
A.Â  Basis and Reasons 
  for the Summary Judgment
Order in Case Sub 
  Judice
The dispositive issue is whether 
  the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Worthy.Â  BPS contends 
  Judge Claryâ€™s order erroneously found that BPS had failed to submit any affidavits 
  in opposition to Worthyâ€™s motion to dismiss, and thus based its findings solely 
  on Worthyâ€™s affidavits.Â  We agree.
Here, the affidavits in support of the temporary injunction 
  were filed with the complaint.Â  It is undisputed that the affidavits were in 
  the record at the time the motion was heard.Â  Furthermore, Judge Clary inserted 
  Dickeyâ€™s full deposition into the record before he signed the order.Â  Worthy 
  did not object to this action.Â  Judge Clary had the excerpts from the deposition 
  testimony in the submissions from Worthy.Â  Thus, the circuit court erred in 
  refusing to consider all of the evidence in the record, and in failing to view 
  the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.
Clearly, many issues in the case remained in dispute.Â  
  BPS brought nine causes of action in addition to the request for an injunction.Â  
  Worthy should not have been dismissed from the action unless it was clear that 
  BPS could not establish prima facie liability on any of them.
Worthy claims that as an officer of Carolina Benefit, 
  he is immune from liability.Â  He cites Hunt v. Rabon, 275 S.C. 475, 272 
  S.E.2d 643 (1980), for this proposition.Â  In Hunt, the Supreme Court 
  articulated:

Generally the reason for the creation of a corporation 
  is to limit liability.Â  While there are instances in which directors and/or 
  trustees and officers may be personally liable, an officer or a director of 
  a corporation is not, merely as a result of his standing as such, personally 
  liable for torts of corporate employees.Â  To incur liability he must ordinarily 
  be shown to have in some way participated in or directed the tortious act. . 
  . . .

We find the following relevant rule in 19 Am. Jur. 
  2d Corporations, 4, Liability for Torts:

Â§ 1382.Â  Generally.
A director or officer of a corporation does not incur personal liability for 
  its torts merely by reason of his official character; he is not liable for torts 
  committed by or for the corporation unless he has participated in the wrong.Â  
  Accordingly, directors not parties to a wrongful act on the part of other directors 
  are not liable therefor.Â  If, however, a director or officer commits or participates 
  in the commission of a tort, whether or not it is also by or for the corporation, 
  he is liable to third persons injured thereby, and it does not matter what liability 
  attaches to the corporation for the tort . . . .
Â§ 1383.Â  Liability for acts of subordinate officers, agents, or employees.Â  

Ordinarily, a director is not liable for the tortious acts of officers, agents, 
  or employees of the corporation, unless he participated therein or authorized 
  the wrongful act.Â  It is held that directors cannot be held liable for the acts 
  of subordinateÂ  officers which they neither participated in nor sanctioned, 
  and where they could not, in the exercise of ordinary and reasonable supervision, 
  have detected the wrongdoing of such subordinate officers . . . .

In 19 C.J.S. Corporations Â§ 845-Torts, the 
  rule is stated in this way:

â€œA director, officer, or agent is not liable for torts of the corporation or 
  of other officers or agents merely because of his office.Â  He is liable for 
  torts in which he has participated or which he has authorized or directed.â€

Id.  at 477-78, 272 S.E.2d at 644.
Nothing in the law shields Worthy from direct liability 
  in tort for his own actions.Â  See Rowe v. Hyatt, 321 S.C. 366, 
  369, 468 S.E.2d 649, 650 (1996) (â€œAn officer, director, or controlling person 
  in a corporation is not, merely as a result of his or her status as such, personally 
  liable for the torts of the corporation. To incur liability, the officer, director, 
  or controlling person must ordinarily be shown to have in some way participated 
  in or directed the tortious act.â€).Â  Worthy is personally liable for any tortious 
  acts he participated in or directed.
Additionally, Worthy is liable for unfair trade practices 
  that he personally committed.Â  â€œ[I]n private actions under the UTPA, directors 
  and officers are not liable for the corporationâ€™s unfair trade practices unless 
  they personally commit, participate in, direct, or authorize the commission 
  of a violation of the UTPA.â€Â  Plowman v. Bagnal, 316 S.C. 283, 286, 450 
  S.E.2d 36, 38 (1994) (emphasis added); see also Donsco, Inc. v. Casper 
  Corp., 587 F.2d 602 (3rd. Cir. 1978) (finding that corporate officer is 
  individually liable for unfair competition in which he participates); Moy 
  v. Schreiber Deed Sec. Co., 535 A.2d 1168 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1988) (stating 
  that corporate president could be held individually liable under the participation 
  theory for acts of unfair competition which he personally committed); Great 
  Am. Homebuilders, Inc. v. Gerhart, 708 S.W.2d 8 (Tex. App. 1986) (determining 
  that corporate officer who knowingly participates in deceptive trade practice 
  may be held individually liable).
Similarly, the corporate veil does not protect Worthy 
  from liability for his own actions.Â  Section 33-6-220(b) (1999) of the South 
  Carolina Code states: â€œUnless otherwise provided in the articles of incorporation, 
  a shareholder of a corporation is not personally liable for the acts or debts 
  of the corporation except that he may become personally liable by reason 
  of his own acts or conduct.â€ (Emphasis added).
Worthy asserts that even if the claims apply to him, 
  BPS failed to establish liability based on the evidence presented.Â  Viewing 
  the evidence in the light most favorable to BPS, we conclude there is sufficient 
  evidence in the record to survive summary judgment.Â  First, two of the affidavits 
  of BPS employees alleged that â€œMr. Worthy got what he wanted without having 
  to pay.â€Â  Second, there was evidence that Worthy and Carolina Benefit took possession 
  of BPS assets, employed its employees, and began servicing its clients while 
  intending not to execute the agreement.Â  Third, some files and a computer were 
  taken after Dickey had been assured the parties had reached an agreement.Â  The 
  verbiage and language of the order of the circuit judge reveals indubitably 
  that the court did not consider any of this evidence or give efficacy to the 
  complete depositions of Worthy and Dickey.Â  Therefore, the circuit court erred 
  in granting summary judgment to Worthy.
B.Â  Discovery
BPS maintains the granting of summary judgment was 
  improper because discovery was incomplete.Â  Summary judgment must not be granted 
  until the opposing party has had a full and fair opportunity to complete discovery.Â  
  Doe v. Batson, 345 S.C. 316, 548 S.E.2d 854 (2001); Baughman v. American 
  Tel. & Tel. Co., Â  306 S.C. 101, 410 S.E.2d 537 (1991); see also 
  Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 319, 592 S.E.2d 326, 331 (Ct. App. 
  2003) (â€œBecause summary judgment is a drastic remedy, it must not be granted 
  until the opposing party has had a â€˜full and fair opportunity to complete discovery.â€™â€).
There may exist a possible query as to whether 
  this issue was raised to the circuit court either during the hearing or during 
  the Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion.Â  That conundrum is answered directly and completely 
  in the actions and positions taken and argued before the circuit court issued 
  the order granting summary judgment.Â  Specifically, BPS was faced with a motion 
  to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, dated July 26, 2002.Â  On August 
  30, 2002, BPS objected to the conversion of the 12(b)(6) motion to a motion 
  for summary judgment.Â  Despite the objection posed by BPS, the circuit judge 
  treated the original 12(b)(6) motion as a motion for summary judgment under 
  Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  Without utilizing completion of discovery as a ground for opposition 
  to the conversion activity of the circuit judge, BPS voiced a position in contra 
  to the ruling of the circuit judge that encapsulates the need for further discovery 
  activities.Â  BPS submitted Dickeyâ€™s complete deposition as an active response 
  to the conversion of the original 12(b)(6) motion.
The Rule 59(e) motion filed by BPS professed:

1.Â  On Page 3 of Judge Claryâ€™s Order he states that 
  â€œthe motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed of as 
  provided in Rule 56.Â  See Rule 12(b), SCRCP.â€Â  However, no notice that the motion 
  would be converted from a Motion to Dismiss to a Motion for Summary Judgment 
  was given.
2.Â  â€œ. . . Summary judgment is not appropriate where 
  further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application 
  of the law.â€
 . . . .
6.Â  Mr. John Hawkins, co-counsel for the Plaintiff 
  and Third-Party Defendant, wrote to Judge Clary on August 30, 2002, asking that 
  if indeed the Court intended to convert this matter to a Motion for Summary 
  Judgment, the Plaintiff and Third-Party Defendant should be allowed a â€œreasonable 
  opportunity to present all material made pertinent to such a motion by Rule 
  56.â€Â  Rule 12(b), SCRCP.Â  As stated in the accompanying affidavit of 
  Mr. Hawkins, a review of the Court file shows that Judge Clary granted his request 
  that the deposition of Mr. Dickey be placed in the record.Â  (Emphasis added).

Luculently, this issue is encompassed within 
  the virginal, continuing, and briefed factual and legal occurrences depicted 
  in the record on appeal in its entirety.
The circuit judge committed reversible error 
  in proceeding to consider and convert the initial Rule 12(b)(6) motion to a 
  motion for summary judgment without giving BPS adequate and reasonable opportunity 
  and time to present all materials pertinent to a Rule 56 motion.
II.Â  MOTION 
  TO ALTER OR AMEND
BPS avers that Judge Patterson erred in refusing to 
  reach the merits in denying BPSâ€™s motion to alter or amend.Â  Because we find 
  that summary judgment was improper, we do not reach this issue.Â  Regardless 
  of how the circuit court ruled on the motion to alter or amend, the fact that 
  the issues were raised and a ruling obtained was sufficient to preserve them 
  for appeal.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, we REVERSE the circuit courtâ€™s order granting 
  summary judgment to Worthy and REMAND this case for trial.
REVERSED and REMANDED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Donahue v. Multimedia, Inc.
description: In this contract case applying New York law, Donahue appeals, arguing the trial court erred in (1) failure to render a contract non-assignable due to its status as a personal services contract, (2) concluding a stock sale was not a contract assignment, and (3) interpreting the contract's right of first refusal.

Donahue v. Multimedia, 12667
<!--

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Phillip J. Donahue,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Multimedia, Inc., Multimedia Entertainment, Inc., Gannett Co., Inc., 
        and Universal Television Enterprises, Inc.,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3922
Heard November 16, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  10, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Steven E. Farrar, Jack H. Tedards, Jr., William B. Swent 
  and William J. Watkins, Jr., all of Greenville, for Appellant.
Donald A. Harper, N. Ward Lambert, Cynthia Buck Brown,Â  James 
  B. Pressley, Jr., Brent O. Clinkscale, all of Greenville and Robert C. Bernius, 
  of Washington, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Phillip J. Donahue 
  appeals a grant of summary judgment in favor of Multimedia, Inc., Multimedia 
  Entertainment, Inc., Gannett Co., Inc., and Universal Television Enterprises, 
  Inc. (â€œRespondentsâ€), arguing the trial court erred in interpreting a longstanding 
  contract between the parties under the applicable law of New York.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The facts as set forth by the trial court 
  are as follows:

Th[is] action arises from a 1982 contract between . . . Phillip 
  J. Donahue and [Respondents] . . . providing for Mr. Donahueâ€™s performance as 
  Master of Ceremonies on a television talk show.
On April 15, 1982, [Donahue] entered into a Contract 
  for Services with Multimedia Program Production, Inc. (the former name of the 
  Defendant MEI).Â  This contract cancelled and superseded a 1978 contract between 
  the parties.
Under the terms of the 1982 contract, [Donahue] 
  agreed to serve as â€œMaster of Ceremonies on the television program presently 
  entitled â€˜Donahueâ€™ (the â€˜Programâ€™).â€Â  The parties further agreed in Section 
  10(q) of the contract that the laws of the State of New York govern its terms.Â  
  The contract was subsequently amended four times.Â  The amendments primarily 
  adjusted the amount of remuneration due to [Donahue] and extended the contractâ€™s 
  â€œterm.â€Â  Each iteration of the contract was for a definite term.Â  The last amendment 
  was entered into on October 12, 1994.Â  Pursuant to that final amendment, the 
  contractâ€™s term expired on August 31, 1996:
  
 Extended Term: The term of the Contract shall 
  be extended so that, as extended, it shall expire at midnight on August 31, 
  1996.Â  (1994 amendment to Contract, Section 2)
  
The final amendment also provided that discussions between 
  the parties regarding the continuation of any programming beyond the expiration 
  date were to be commenced on or before May 31, 1995.
. . . .
Sometime before May 31, 1995, [Donahue] decided 
  not to renew his contract with MEI beyond its August 31, 1996 expiration date.
In July 1995 . . . Gannet Co., Inc. (â€œGannettâ€) 
  submitted, and the Board of Directors of Multimedia approved, a proposal for 
  Gannettâ€™s purchase of the stock of Multimedia.Â  Multimedia shareholders approved 
  the proposal at a special meeting on November 15, 1995.Â  Pursuant to that transaction, 
  [Donahue] received a substantial payment for his Multimedia shares.
Following Gannettâ€™s acquisition of Multimedia stock, 
  MEI continued to produce the â€œDonahueâ€ program, and [Donahue] continued to perform 
  his duties as its master of ceremonies.Â  The last program was taped on April 
  29, 1996.Â  The â€œextended termâ€ of the contract expired on August 31, 1996 pursuant 
  to its explicit terms.
Almost three months later, on November 21, 1996 
  . . . Universal Television Enterprises, Inc. (â€œUniversalâ€) purchased the assets 
  of MEI.Â  Those assets included a group of videotapes of the â€œDonahueâ€ program, 
  characterized as the â€œDonahue Library.â€
(Trial Court Order dated August 15, 2002).

Section 6 of the contract, entitled â€œSale 
  and Assignment,â€ contains the following language:

Donahue agrees that Multimedia shall have the right 
  to sell and assign this contract at any time during the term hereof . . . .
Notwithstanding the foregoing, Multimedia agrees 
  that it will not so enter into a binding commitment during the term hereof . 
  . . for any assignment of rights and interests of Multimedia in the Program 
  and in the distribution in syndication thereof which includes an assignment 
  of this Contract without first consulting with Donahue and specifying and giving 
  Donahue the option to meet the price and other related terms and conditions 
  contained in the offer . . . .

In 2001, Donahue brought a breach of contract 
  action against Respondents, arguing the Gannett and Universal transactions each 
  constitute a violation of the contractâ€™s assignment clause and Donahueâ€™s right 
  of first refusal.Â  Donahue petitioned the court to have the transactions voided 
  and sought exclusive ownership rights in the Donahue library.Â  After reviewing 
  voluminous materials submitted in support of both partiesâ€™ positions, the trial 
  court granted summary judgment in favor of Respondents.Â  Following a Rule 59(e) 
  motion by Donahue to alter or amend the trial courtâ€™s initial order, the decision 
  to grant summary judgment was reiterated in a lengthy second order.Â  This appeal 
  followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW AND APPLICABLE 
  LAW
The contract provides that its terms shall 
  be subject to and construed in accordance with New York law. Because New York 
  contract law does not violate South Carolina public policy, we find its application 
  appropriate.Â  See Standard Register Co. v. Kerrigan, 238 S.C. 
  54, 70, 119 S.E.2d 533, 541-542 (1961) (finding the laws of other jurisdictions, 
  when deemed applicable by agreement, are generally enforceable in South Carolina 
  unless repugnant to the public policy of this state).
The purpose of summary judgment is to 
  expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact 
  finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003); 
  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  Summary 
  judgment is proper only when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact 
  and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Laurens 
  Emergency Med. Specialists, PA v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 355 S.C. 
  104, 108, 584 S.E.2d 375, 377 (2003).Â  In determining whether any triable issue 
  of fact exists, the evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be 
  viewed in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party. Sauner v. Public 
  Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003); 
  Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 353 S.C. 449, 455-56, 578 S.E.2d 711, 714 
  (2003).Â Â  
New York law is consistent with South 
  Carolina law with respect to summary judgment evidentiary standards.Â  See 
  Dougherty v. Kinard, 626 N.Y.S.2d 554, 555 (N.Y. App. Div. 1995) (â€œWhere 
  there are no material and triable issues of fact, [a] motion for summary judgment 
  should be granted.â€).
LAW / ANALYSIS
I. The Gannett Transaction
Donahue argues that Gannettâ€™s 1.7 billion 
  dollar purchase of Multimediaâ€™s stock violated his contract with MEI because 
  the transaction constitutes an unauthorized â€œassignmentâ€ of the contract.Â  We 
  disagree.
In regard to this issue, we adopt the 
  following sound analysis of the trial court:

There is no question that the 1995 stock purchase 
  transaction was between Gannett and Multimedia, the parent corporation of MEI.Â  
  MEI was not a party to the transaction.Â  After Gannett purchased Multimediaâ€™s 
  stock, MEI continued as a wholly owned subsidiary of Multimedia, and MEIâ€™s contract 
  with [Donahue] continued as it had before the transaction.Â  [Donahue] acknowledges 
  that there were no changes in the daily operation of his program, in the persons 
  to whom he reported, in the production of the program, or in his contract with
MEI.
An assignment consists of three elements: (1) an 
  assignor, (2) an assignee, and (3) transfer of control of the thing assigned 
  from the assignor to the assignee.Â  Leon v. Martinez, 84 N.Y.2d 83, 88 
  (N.Y. 1994); see also Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 317 
  (1981) (â€œAn assignment of a right is a manifestation of the assignorâ€™s intention 
  to transfer it by virtue of which the assignorâ€™s right to performance by the 
  obligor is extinguished in whole or in part and the assignee acquires a right 
  to such performance.â€).
The transfer of the stock of a corporation, however, 
  does not constitute an assignment of a contract of that corporation.Â  See 
  Dennisâ€™ Natural Mini-meals, Inc. v. 91 Fifth Ave. Corp., 568 N.Y.S.2d 
  740, 743 (N.Y. App. Div. 1991); Rubenstein Bros. v. Ole of 34th [St., Inc.], 
  421 N.Y.S.2d 534, 538 (N.Y. Civ. Ct. 1979); In re Pearl-Wick Corp., 15 
  B.R. 143, 147 (Bankr. S.D.N.Y. 1981), affâ€™d without opinion, 697 F.2d 
  295 (2d Cir. 1982).Â  Here, Gannett did not purchase the stock of MEI, the party 
  to the contract.Â  Rather, Gannett bought the stock of Multimedia, the corporate 
  parent of the contracting entity.Â  Since the transfer of the stock of a corporation 
  does not constitute an assignment of the corporationâ€™s contract, the transfer 
  of the stock of the parent of a contracting corporation can hardly constitute 
  an assignment of its subsidiaryâ€™s contract.
(Trial Court Order dated August 15, 2002).

We find nothing in the language of Donahueâ€™s 
  contract or the particularities of this transaction that would warrant, as Donahue 
  argues on appeal, an interpretation of â€œassignmentâ€ which, in contravention 
  to New York common law, would bar the sale of Mutimediaâ€™s stock to Gannett.Â  
  As such, Gannettâ€™s purchase of Multimediaâ€™s stock did not breach any terms or 
  conditions of the 1982 contract between MEI and Donahue.
II. The Universal Transaction

A. The Assignment Clause

Pursuant to Section 2 of Donahueâ€™s 
  contract, as amended in 1994, the agreementâ€™s general term expired on August 
  31, 1996.Â  In November 1996, MEI sold its assets, including the Donahue library, 
  to Universal.Â  Donahue argues this transaction violated the contract because 
  his right of first refusal under Section 6 survived the contractâ€™s termination 
  date and was not honored.Â  We disagree, and again adopt the trial courtâ€™s analysis:

Section 6 of the contract governs the sale or assignment 
  â€œduring the term hereofâ€ of the â€œrights and interests of Multimedia [the designation 
  of MEI in this contract] in the Program and in the distribution in syndication 
  thereof which includes an assignment of this Contract.â€Â  As discussed [in the 
  fact section of this opinion], this section afforded [Donahue] the â€œoption to 
  meet the price and other related terms and conditions contained in the offer 
  of purchase of the Program and this Contract.â€Â  Notwithstanding that Section 
  6 specifically applies only â€œduring the termâ€ of the contract, [Donahue] argues 
  that since certain other provisions of the contract provided for â€œperpetualâ€ 
  rights, Section 6 should also be construed to bind MEI in perpetuity.Â  An examination 
  of the contract as a whole shows that such an interpretation is not tenable.
. . . .
While Sections 2(c) and 2(d) provide for royalty 
  payments for any reruns of the â€œDonahueâ€ program, those limited provisions do 
  not extend other terms of the contract.Â  [Donahue] had no continuing obligation 
  to perform as master of ceremonies for MEI, and MEI had no continuing obligation 
  to produce and distribute the â€œDonahueâ€ program without him.
The language of the Contract is unambiguous: it 
  provided that the â€œtermâ€ of the Contract ended on a date certain, and that Plaintiffâ€™s 
  â€œright of first refusalâ€ lasted only during the term of the Contract:
  
The term of the Contract shall be extended so that, as extended, 
  it shall expire at midnight, August 31, 1996. (Contract, October 1994 amendment, 
  Â¶ 2).
Notwithstanding the foregoing, [MEI] agrees that it will not 
  so enter into a binding commitment during the term hereof . . . without 
  first consulting with Donahue . . . (Contract Â§ 6, emphasis added).
  
Section 6 of the contract and the Plaintiffâ€™s rights thereunder 
  expired when the contractâ€™s â€œextended termâ€ expired on August 31, 1996.Â  After 
  that date, MEI was free to sell and assign its rights in the Donahue Library 
  as it saw fit.
(Trial Court Order dated August 15, 2002).

It is this courtâ€™s duty to enforce the 
  plain language of Donahueâ€™s contract.Â  Wallace v. 600 Partners Co., 634 
  N.Y.S.2d 669, 671 (N.Y. 1995) (â€œIt is axiomatic that a contract is to be interpreted 
  so as to give effect to the intention of the parties as expressed in the unequivocal 
  language employed . . . clear, complete writings should generally be enforced 
  according to their terms.â€).Â  Donahueâ€™s right of refusal, as outlined in Section 
  6, is expressly limited to â€œthe termâ€ of the contract, which expired in August 
  1996.Â  The fact that the parties expressly agreed certain provisions of the 
  contract would last â€œin perpetuityâ€ creates no ambiguity in terms expressly 
  limited to the contractâ€™s general term.Â  We therefore agree with the trial court 
  that, as a matter of law, the transfer of MEI assets to Universal was in no 
  way precluded by Donahueâ€™s right of first refusal as agreed upon in Section 
  6 of the contract.

B. Contract for Personal Services

Donahue also argues the trial court erred 
  in determining the contract, at the time of the Universal transaction, lacked 
  the indicia of a personal services contract.Â  It is his contention that because 
  MEIâ€™s right of assignment was, like Donahueâ€™s right of first refusal, limited 
  to the contract term, New York common law applies by default to all transactions 
  occurring after the contractual termination date.Â  He asserts that because the 
  contract should be interpreted as one for personal services, New York law bars 
  its assignment; thus, the Universal transaction is void.Â  We disagree.
New York law, like that of many jurisdictions, 
  employs an exception to the general rule of assignability of contracts when 
  the contract is for â€œpersonal services.â€Â  Jennings v. Foremost Dairies, Inc., 
  235 N.Y.S.2d 566, 573 (N.Y. Sup. Ct. 1962); In re Compass Van & Storage 
  Corp., 65 B.R. 1007, 1010 (Bankr. E.D.N.Y. 1986) (â€œThe nonassignability 
  imprint of personal service contracts is firmly established New York law.â€). 
  Even a personal services contract, however, may be assigned if the contract 
  provides for assignment.Â  Preferred Oncology Networks of America, Inc. v. 
  Bottino, 1997 WL 305253, at *2 (S.D.N.Y. 1997) (â€œDefendants represent to 
  this Court that New York law does not recognize assignment of an obligation 
  to provide personal services, yet neglect to inform the court that this prohibition 
  is inapplicable when the parties expressly provide for assignability.â€).Â  
Here, it is clear the parties contemplated 
  possible assignment when entering into the agreement. During its entire fourteen-year 
  term, Donahueâ€™s contract expressly granted MEI the right to assign, subject 
  only to Donahueâ€™s option to meet any offered purchase price.Â  These minimal 
  restrictions on assignment lend little weight to the notion that the parties 
  intended MEIâ€™s obligations to be of a â€œpersonalâ€ unassignable nature once the 
  contract expired.Â  See In re Compass Van & Storage Corp., 
  65 B.R. at 1011 (â€œPersonal service contracts synthesize into those consensual 
  agreements of ineluctable genre and distinctive characteristics that commit 
  to a special knowledge, unique skill or talent, singular judgment and taste.â€)Â Â Â  

Donahue presents to this court the proposition 
  that exclusive distribution contracts are per se personal service contracts 
  under the law of New York.Â  In support of this position, he cites American 
  Can Co. v. AB Dick Co., 1983 WL 2198 (S.D.N.Y. 1983), a case dealing with 
  an exclusive distribution contract that expressly barred assignment and 
  never mentions the term â€œpersonal service contract.â€Â  Without addressing this 
  personal service contract â€œper seâ€ argument, we conclude, as did the 
  trial court, that Donahueâ€™s contract, following the expiration of its term, 
  lacked the qualities of an exclusive distribution contract.
Section 10(f) of Donahueâ€™s contract grants 
  MEI a perpetual, vested, and exclusive right in all â€œmaterialâ€ arising from 
  the contractâ€™s performance.Â  As such, MEI owned all right, title and interest 
  in the Donahue library prior to the Universal transaction, provided they pay 
  Donahue his percentage of any proceeds from its sale.Â  According to Section 
  3 of the contract, MEI alone had the sole and exclusive right to distribute 
  reruns of the program.Â  As stated by the trial court:

The Contract is not one . . . whereby MEI or Universal serve 
  as distribution agents for [Donahue].Â  Unlike agency distribution arrangements, 
  where party B acts as a distributor of goods belonging to party A, in this case 
  one party â€“ MEI â€“ distributes its own goods, and has full discretion 
  to distribute the tapes or not, as it alone sees fit.Â  MEIâ€™s only duty, and 
  [Donahueâ€™s] only corresponding right, is to the transfer of a percentage of 
  any proceeds realized from MEIâ€™s marketing efforts.Â  That is all [Donahue] bargained 
  for, and it is all the Contract gives to him.Â  For this conceptual reason, in 
  addition to the clear terms of the Contract, the agency cases relied upon by 
  [Donahue] are simply irrelevant.
(Trial Court Order dated September 30, 2002).

Donahue downplays this proprietary distinction 
  and calls our attention to two New York cases he asserts reflect that ownership 
  of the product does not control the existence of an agency distribution contract.Â  
  On the contrary, we find these cases take careful steps to establish the distributor 
  did not have a true property interest in the subject matter of the contracts.Â  
  See Andrian v. Unterman, 118 N.Y.S.2d 121, 127-28 (N.Y. App. div. 
  1952), affâ€™d, 306 N.Y. 771 (N.Y. 1954) (holding a trademark, the subject 
  of the distribution contract at issue, is â€œnot the subject of property except 
  in connection with an existing businessâ€ and â€œno property existedâ€ in the use 
  of oneâ€™s name for the marketing of a product);Â  Bentley v. Textile Banking 
  Co., Inc., 271 N.Y.S.2d 417, 419 (N.Y. App. Div. 1966) (â€œ[D]espite the words 
  used describing the transactions as sales, no transfer of title [to the subject 
  of the contract] was intended or took place.â€).Â  Because Donahueâ€™s contract 
  granted MEI ownership of the tape library and all material arising from the 
  contract, the contract ceased to operate as an exclusive distributorship upon 
  the expiration of the contractâ€™s general term.Â  We therefore find his arguments 
  regarding its status as a contract for personal services to be without merit.
CONCLUSION
Because we conclude the Gannett 
  and Universal transactions did not violate New York law or breach any terms 
  or conditions of the 1982 contract between MEI and Donahue, the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.
