title: Whiteâ€™s Mill Colony, Inc. v. Williams
description: This appeal concerns multiple issues arising from competing claims of various land owners to access an abutting man-made body of water.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Whiteâ€™s Mill Colony, Inc., Appellant/Respondent,
v.
Arthur Williams, Leonard Boseman, Jr., and Jerry Rouse,
Respondents,
and
Leodel Mitchell, Jimmie Johnson, Leon Kelly, Lillian Davis and Richard 
        Weeks, Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Walter G. Newman, Special Referee

Opinion No. 3923
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  18, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Kenneth R. Young, Jr.,Â  of Sumter, for Appellant/Respondent.
Arthur Williams and Jerry Rouse, both of Sumter, and Leonard Boseman, of Prince 
  George, for Respondents.
A.P. Weissenstein, Jr., and James David Weeks, both of Sumter, for Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.: In this appeal, we are asked to determine whether an 
  owner of subaqueous land is entitled to exclusive use of a non-navigable body 
  of water created by the ownerâ€™s predecessor in title as against other, abutting 
  property owners.Â  Addressing this and other questions below, the special referee 
  enjoined abutting landowners from making any use of the privately owned body 
  of water.Â  We affirm this ruling to the extent Whiteâ€™s Mill Colony, Inc. (the 
  â€œColonyâ€) owns the subaqueous land, but vacate that portion of the judgment 
  related to damages and remand the matter for determination of the precise property 
  boundaries and, concomitantly, reconsideration of the damage awards.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The parties are 
  neighboring property owners whose land surrounds a pond.Â  The core issue in 
  this case is the question of who among these landowners has the right to access 
  and use the pond.Â  On one side of the pond is the Colony, which claims its members 
  have the right to exclusive use of the pond.Â  On the other side of the pond 
  are several individual property owners whose land abuts the pond (the â€œabutting 
  landownersâ€).Â  They claim they too have a right to access and use the pond.Â  
  Briefly outlined below are the relevant facts concerning the pond, how the parties 
  came into ownership of the land surrounding the pond and the pond bed, and the 
  order of the special referee from which the present appeal arises.
The Pond
At the center of this dispute is an eighty-eight acre body of water in Sumter 
  County known as â€œWhiteâ€™s Mill Pond.â€Â  The pond is man madeâ€”created sometime 
  in the late nineteenth century when a dam was constructed at the point where 
  two streams converged, forming a third, larger stream. Neither the pond nor 
  any of the incoming or outgoing streams are listed on maps of navigable waters 
  prepared by the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control.Â  
  Â Testimony was presented from various witnesses describing the pond and 
  the character of the surrounding area.Â  From this evidence, it appears the pond 
  is an essentially isolated body of water. 
Title to the Pond and the Present Dispute
Prior to 1950, title to the pond, including the pond bed, had been vested in 
  the predecessors in title to the parties in this case.Â  In 1955, the Colony 
  obtained title to the land located to the north and east of the pond.Â  The Colony 
  also obtained title to the entirety of, or at least a substantial portion of, 
  the bed of the pond itself. Â Land along the south and west sides of the 
  pond subsequently came into the possession of the defendants in this case: Arthur 
  Williams, Leonard Boseman, Jr., Jerry Rouse, Leodel Mitchell, Jimmie Johnson, 
  Leon Kelly, Lillian Davis, and Richard Weeks.Â  Â None of the deeds to 
  these landowners granted any right of access to the pond. However, there is 
  testimony suggesting some of the abutting landowners also have title to parts 
  of the pond bed.Â  
The Colony filed suit against the abutting landowners alleging some of them 
  used Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond in a variety of ways, including fishing, boating, dredging 
  soil, removing trees from along the side of the pond, and building docks into 
  the pond.Â  The abutting landowners counterclaimed, alleging their use and enjoyment 
  of their property had been disturbed by the Colony.Â  The matter was referred 
  to a special referee for a determination of the partiesâ€™ respective rights.
The Special Refereeâ€™s Order
In his order, the special referee determined the case turned on two key issues: 
  first, whether Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond is a navigable watercourse under South Carolina 
  law giving rise to a public right of access to the pond; and, second, 
  whether the abutting landowners held any private right to access and 
  use the pond arising from their putative status as riparian or littoral owners.Â  
  The special referee found neither right existed. [1] Â  The abutting landowners were therefore enjoined 
  from boating or fishing on Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond, dredging or interfering with the 
  pondâ€™s bed, cutting any timber from the bed of the pond, or building any structures 
  on the bed of the pond, unless the structures were over property owned by the 
  abutting landowners.Â  Additionally, the special referee awarded damages against 
  the various landowners in amounts ranging from $500 to $5,500.Â  
It is important 
  to note, however, that the referee did not make a determination as to the property 
  lines.Â  Despite contradictory evidence regarding the precise location of the 
  line between the pond bed and the abutting landownersâ€™ property, the referee 
  found that such determination was not necessary to address the questions presented. 

The abutting landowners 
  now appeal the special refereeâ€™s findings that the pond is not a publicly accessible 
  navigable waterway and that they have no right to access the pond as riparian 
  or littoral owners. Â The Colony and several of the abutting property owners 
  also appeal the special refereeâ€™s award of damages.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen legal and equitable actions are maintained in one suit, each retains 
  its own identity as legal or equitable for purposes of the applicable standard 
  of review on appeal.â€ Key Corporate Capital, Inc. v. County of Beaufort, 
  360 S.C. 513, 516, 602 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Kiriakides 
  v. Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc., 338 S.C. 572, 580, 527 S.E.2d 371, 
  375 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  In actions at equity, this court can find facts in accordance 
  with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Id.; West v. 
  Newberry Elec. Co-op., 357 S.C. 537, 542, 593 S.E.2d 500, 502 (Ct. App. 
  2004).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, the appellate court standard 
  of review extends only to the correction of errors of law. Id.; Okatie 
  River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 
  S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSISÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In the discussion 
  below, we address separately the three issues that determine this appeal: (I) 
  whether Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond is a navigable watercourse under South Carolina law; 
  (II) whether the abutting landowners possess any riparian or littoral rights 
  to access and use the pond; and (III) whether the special refereeâ€™s award of 
  damages was proper.
I.Â  Navigable Waters
The right of 
  public access to navigable waters is guaranteed by our state constitution: â€œAll 
  navigable waters shall forever remain public highways free to the citizens of 
  the State. . . .â€Â  S.C. Const. art. XIV, Â§ 4. South Carolina Code section 49-1-10 
  (1986) similarly provides that â€œ[a]ll streams which have been rendered or can 
  be rendered capable of being navigated by rafts of lumber or timber by the removal 
  of accidental obstructions and all navigable watercourses and cuts are hereby 
  declared navigable streams and such streams shall be common highways and forever 
  free. . . .â€Â  In upholding this constitutional and statutory mandate, our courts 
  look to whether the waterway in question has the capacity to support â€œvaluable 
  floatage.â€Â  If the waterway can support such use, it is deemed navigable and 
  thus open to the public.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
â€œValuable floatageâ€ 
  is not determined by resort to generic guidelines as to what specific size or 
  class of vessel or object can achieve buoyancy in the waterway.Â  Rather, the 
  term is defined broadly to include any â€œlegitimate and beneficial public use.â€ 
  Medlock v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 289 S.C. 445, 450, 346 S.E.2d 
  716, 719 (1986).Â  Such public use includes all varieties of commercial traffic, 
  ranging from passage of the largest freighter to the floating of raw timber 
  downstream to mill. See id. at 449, 346 S.E.2d at 719.Â  Recreational 
  uses are no less importantâ€”boating, hunting, and fishing have been found to 
  fall within the ambit of valuable floatage.Â  See Hughes v. Nelson, 
  303 S.C. 102, 105, 399 S.E.2d 24, 25 (Ct. App. 1990). Â In this vein, considerations 
  such as whether the waterway is natural or man-made or whether it is impassable 
  by any vessel at certain times of year have been found to have no bearing on 
  the question of navigability. See State v. Head, 330 S.C. 79, 
  90-91, 498 S.E.2d 389, 394-95 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The focus remains strictly on 
  capacity, irrespective of actual use.
Of course, not every body of water is â€œnavigable.â€Â  The concept of 
  navigability encompasses more than the capacity to support valuable floatage 
  in a single, secluded spot.Â  Rather, to be properly categorized as navigable, 
  the watercourse in question must also be connected to other navigable bodies 
  of water such that it forms a means of transportation or conveyance beyond an 
  isolated locality.Â  This requirement of a navigable connection to a broader 
  system of waterways has been at the heart of the navigability concept since 
  its earliest application in this jurisdiction and others.Â  
Beginning with the early cases addressing the public right to navigable waters 
  in our stateâ€™s jurisprudence, the express policy underlying that right was to 
  protect, above all, the free flow of commerce. See, e.g., State 
  v. Columbia Water Power Co., 82 S.C. 181, 186, 63 S.E. 884, 887 (1909) (noting 
  that â€œwater is navigable when in its ordinary state it forms by itself or its 
  connection with other waters a continued highway over which commerce is or may 
  be carriedâ€).Â Â  Rivers and streams were essential means for conveying goods 
  and raw materials from place to place.Â  If private landowners had been able 
  to prevent passage over their stream and river beds, the flow of commerce would 
  have been seriously hindered, if not made impossible.Â  Implicit, therefore, 
  in this early concept of navigability is the requirement that the status of 
  a body of water as navigable hinged upon its utility as a mode of transport 
  for people and goods.
Though the definition of navigability has expanded to include recreational 
  uses in addition to commercial ones, the need to demonstrate a connection beyond 
  an isolated locus to other navigable waters remains.Â  Otherwise, we confront 
  the untenable result that any backyard pond would necessarily be navigable.Â  
  Indeed, it would be difficult to imagine any body of water of noticeable size 
  that would not be navigable and therefore subject to public use and enjoyment.
This common-sense approach to navigability is supported in our stateâ€™s 
  law.Â  First, we note the proclamation of section 49-1-10 thatÂ  all navigable 
  streams shall remain forever free as â€œcommon highwaysâ€ for all to use.Â  This 
  important language leaves little doubt that the nub of the purpose behind leaving 
  our navigable waterways open is to ensure citizens can move freely about the 
  state without interference and without fear of being unavoidably subject to 
  trespass actions by traveling on our waterways.Â  
We also find support for this view in our case law. Â In a seminal case setting 
  forth the modern test for navigability, Heyward v. Farmersâ€™ Mining Co., 
  our supreme court emphasized the primary policy objective that navigable waters 
  remain open to ensure ease of travel, whether for commerce or recreation:

It is not every small creek in which a fishing skiff or 
  gunning canoe can be made to float at high water which is deemed navigable; 
  but, in order to have this character, it must be navigable for some purpose 
  useful to trade or agriculture. But this language is applied to the capacity 
  of the stream, and is not intended to be a strict enumeration of the uses to 
  which it must be actually applied in order to give it that character. Navigable 
  streams are highways; and a traveler for pleasure is as fully entitled to protection 
  in using a public way, whether by land or water, as a traveler for business. 


42 S.C. 138, 155, 19 S.E. 963, 972 (1894).
More recently, in State v. Head, 330 S.C. 79, 498 S.E.2d 389 (Ct. App. 
  1997), the court examined whether a 246 acre lake was navigable.Â Â  In that criminal 
  trespass action, the court considered whether a fisherman was entitled to access 
  the lake.Â  The State argued the lake was not navigable because it was sealed 
  off from any other navigable waters.Â  Id. at 91, 498 S.E.2d at 395.Â  
  We rejected that argument under the specific facts of the case because the lake 
  in question was separated from other navigable waters by a dam, an obstruction 
  our courts have held does not render a waterway non-navigable. Id. at 
  90-91, 498 S.E.2d at 394-95 (citing State ex rel. Guste v. Two Oâ€™Clock Bayou 
  Land Co., 365 So.2d 1174 (La. App. 1978); 65 C.J.S. Navigable Waters 
  Â§ 5(3) (1966)).Â  In our analysis, however, we recognized and distinguished from 
  the facts of Head the rule that a small inland lake having no navigable 
  outlet is not navigable.Â  Id. at 91 fn. 3, 498 S.E.2d at 395 fn. 3. 
Indeed, other jurisdictions have declined to extend the reach of navigability 
  to isolated inland lakes and ponds.Â  For example, in Lakeside Park Co. v. 
  Forsmark, 153 A.2d 486 (Pa. 1959), the Pennsylvania Supreme Court addressed 
  whether a nearly 150 acre lake with no outlet was navigable.Â  Applying a standard 
  for determining navigability similar to our own, the court found the lake was 
  not navigable, opining:

We think that the concept of navigability should not be 
  limited alone by lake or river, or by commercial use, or by the size of water 
  or its capacity to float a boat. Rather it should depend upon whether water 
  is used or usable as a broad highroad for commerce and the transport in quantity 
  of goods and people, which is the rule naturally applicable to rivers and to 
  large lakes, or whether with all of the mentioned factors counted in the water 
  remains a local focus of attraction, which is the rule sensibly applicable to 
  shallow streams and to small lakes and ponds. The basic difference is that between 
  a trade-route and a point of interest. The first is a public use and the second 
  private.

Id. at 489; see also, e.g., Adirondack League 
  Club, Inc. v. Sierra Club, 706 N.E.2d 1192, 1195 (N.Y. 1998) (holding that 
  â€œthe central premise of the common-law rule remains the sameâ€”in order to be 
  navigable-in-fact, a river must provide practical utility to the public as a 
  means for transportation. Thus, while the purpose or type of use remains important, 
  of paramount concern is the capacity of the river for transport, whether for 
  trade or travel.â€).
After thoroughly canvassing the record before us, we find no evidence to suggest 
  Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond serves any useful purpose for transport or travelâ€”whether 
  for commerce or recreationâ€”beyond the immediate perimeter of its banks. The 
  testimony of Richard Wheeler, a South Carolina Department of Natural Resources 
  officer, indicates the streams flowing into and out ofÂ  the pond are not capable 
  of supporting valuable floatage.Â Â  Furthermore, this testimony is bolstered 
  by that of a member of the Colony who testified he had personally walked up 
  and down the incoming and outgoing streams and they were non-navigable.Â  Therefore, 
  we conclude the special referee correctly determined Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond is not 
  a navigable waterway under South Carolina law.Â  Accordingly, the pond is not 
  subject to a general right of the public to access its waters.
II.Â  Riparian or Littoral RightsÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
Having found there is no right of the general public to access Whiteâ€™s Mill 
  Pond as a navigable watercourse, we must next decide whether the abutting landowners 
  have any independent riparian or littoral property rights to access the pond.Â  
  These landowners claim they have such rights to access and make reasonable use 
  of the pond.Â  The Colony, on the other hand, claims its purported ownership 
  of the entire bed of the pond entitles it to exclusive control over the use 
  of the pondâ€™s surface waters.Â Â Â Â  
Under the common law, owners of land along rivers, streams, lakes and other 
  bodies of water possess a property right incident to their ownership of the 
  bank and bed of a watercourse that is distinct from those rights that may be 
  enjoyed by the public at large.Â  In general, these special rights allow abutting 
  landowners to make â€œreasonable useâ€ of the body of water for any lawful purpose, 
  whether for commerce or recreation.Â  Lowe v. Ottaray Mills, 93 S.C. 420, 
  428, 77 S.E. 135, 136 (1913).Â  These rights are subject to the limitation that 
  the use may not interfere with the like rights of those above, below, or on 
  the opposite shore. See Mason v. Apalache Mills, 81 S.C. 554, 
  559, 62 S.E. 399, 401 (1908).Â  With regard to these rights, there is a distinction 
  in classification that our courts have indicated a desire to strictly observe:Â  
  owners of land along rivers and streams are said to hold â€œriparianâ€ rights, 
  while owners of land abutting oceans, seas, or lakes, are said to hold â€œlittoralâ€ 
  rights. [2] Â  Because Whiteâ€™s 
  Mill Pond falls into the latter category, our discussion will address whether 
  the abutting landowners possess any â€œlittoralâ€ rights.
Though our state has recognized the general right of access enjoyed by littoral 
  property owners, the question presented in this case regarding who may control 
  the surface waters of a private, man-made, non-navigable pond, when the pond 
  bed is owned entirely by an adjoining landowner has not been addressed by our 
  courts.Â  See generally, Lowcountry Open Land Trust v. State, 
  347 S.C. 96, 109, 552 S.E.2d 778, 785 (Ct. App. 2001) (opining that â€œ[t]he extent 
  of littoral rights in this jurisdiction is an unanswered questionâ€).Â  Therefore, 
  we first resort to the law of other states to understand whether littoral rights 
  obtain in these circumstances.
Canvassing the case law in this area, it appears two views have emerged on 
  this issue: one is generally termed the â€œcommon law rule,â€ while the other is 
  known as the â€œcivil law rule.â€
Under the common law rule, â€œthe owners of the fee in land underlying the surface 
  waters of a man-made, nonnavigable lake are entitled to the exclusive control 
  of that portion of the lake lying over the land as to which they own the fee.â€ 
  Wehby v. Turpin, 710 So.2d 1243, 1247 (Ala. 1998).Â  Consequently, owners 
  of all or part of a pond or lake bed have the right to exclude others from accessing 
  or using the surface waters above their property. 
A seminal case, cited repeatedly across jurisdictions as a thoughtful application 
  of the common law rule, is Anderson v. Bell, 433 So. 2d 1202 (Fla. 1983).Â  
  The facts of Anderson are similar to the circumstances surrounding the 
  present dispute over Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond.Â  In that case, the plaintiff, Anderson, 
  purchased a tract of land traversed by a small, non-navigable creek.Â  He later 
  excavated the low-lying areas of the property and constructed an earthen dam.Â  
  This damming resulted in the creation of a â€œsubstantialâ€ lake that partially 
  flooded several adjoining parcels.Â  Two of the neighboring property owners whose 
  land had been flooded, Lewis and Watson, sued Anderson for the damage caused 
  to their property.Â  A settlement agreement was reached whereby Lewis and Watson 
  conveyed to Anderson a flowage easement that allowed Anderson the right and 
  privilege to flood their land.Â  The easement, however, expressly reserved to 
  Lewis and Watson the title and beneficial use of their land. Lewis and Watson 
  later sold their property to Bell.Â  Anderson brought action to enjoin Bell from 
  fishing and boating upon the surface waters above the bottom land owned by Anderson. 
  Id. at 1202-1203.Â  The Florida Supreme Court found Bell could be excluded 
  from the surface waters above Andersonâ€™s property, holding:

the owner of property that lies adjacent to or beneath a 
  man-made, non-navigable water body is not entitled to the beneficial 
  use of the surface waters of the entire water body by sole virtue of the fact 
  that he/she owns contiguous lands. . . . this is the established rule in other 
  jurisdictions as well as the common law.

Id. at 1204 (emphasis in original).Â  The Anderson court opined 
  that its decision to follow the common law rule was rooted in the recognition 
  that â€œa lake developerâ€™s expectations in his investmentâ€ must be preserved:

Because the construction of a man-made water body often 
  involves the expenditure of substantial sums of money and the expense is not, 
  as a rule, divided proportionately among the various abutting owners, the individual 
  making the expenditure is justified in expecting that superior privileges will 
  inure to him in return for his investment.

Id. at 1205.Â  The court therefore concluded that: 

[W]e believe a contrary rule may serve to dissuade Florida 
  homeowners and investors from making improvements that not only increase property 
  values but also aesthetically improve adjacent lands, since they would run the 
  risk of losing some of their property rights to other people merely because 
  the water body touches anotherâ€™s property. In the event that the water happens 
  to take a course that would result in the flowage over public lands, the entire 
  water body would become accessible to numerous piscators, bathers and boaters, 
  thereby destroying the property ownersâ€™ investment benefits.

Id. at 1205-1206.Â  The common law rule has been adopted by numerous 
  other state appellate courts, including courts in Alabama, Indiana, Georgia, 
  Mississippi, Virginia, and New Jersey, and which is acknowledged in at least 
  two states as the majority rule. See, e.g., Wehby v. Turpin, 
  710 So.2d 1243, 1249 (Ala. 1998) (deciding that â€œ[w]e are bound to follow the 
  majority common law rule . . . and hold that the owners of land extending 
  beneath artificial or man-made lakes, not navigable as a matter of law, have 
  surface-water rights only in the surface waters above their landâ€) (emphasis 
  added); Berger Farms, Inc. v. Estes, 662 N.E.2d 654, 656 (Ind. Ct. App. 
  1996) (holding that â€œ[i]t is well established that the owner of land, upon which 
  there is located a nonnavigable lake, owns and has the right to control the 
  surface of the lakeâ€); Lanier v. Ocean Pond Fishing Club, Inc., 322 S.E.2d 
  494, 496 (Ga. 1984) (holding that â€œGeorgia follows the common law rule . . . 
  that the owner of a bed of a nonnavigable lake has the exclusive right to the 
  use of the surface of the waters above and may exclude other bed owners and 
  fence off his portionâ€); Black v. Williams, 417 So. 2d 911, 912 (1982) 
  (following â€œthe majority rule . . . that owners of the fee in the land 
  beneath [an artificial or man-made] lake, in the absence of some statute or 
  covenant or agreement to the contrary, have exclusive control over the water 
  over their respective portionsâ€) (emphasis added); Wickouski v. Swift, 
  124 S.E.2d 892, 895 (Va. 1962) (holding that â€œcontrol of the water above the 
  land is an incident to the ownership of the land,â€ entitling property owners 
  to â€œexclusive control and use of the waters above their portion of the bed of 
  the pondâ€); Baker v. Normanoch Assn., Inc., 136 A.2d 645 (N.J. 1957) 
  (holding that â€œ[t]he rule in [New Jersey] is that the general public [has] no 
  rights to the recreational use of a private lake, such rights being exclusive 
  in the owner of the bed . . . .â€).Â  Some treatises have also referenced the 
  common law rule as the predominant view.Â  See, e.g, 78 Am. Jur. 
  2d Waters Â§ 37 (2002) (commenting that â€œthe general rule is that riparian 
  rights do not ordinarily attach to artificial water bodies or streams. . . . 
  The owner of property that lies adjacent to or beneath a manmade, nonnavigable 
  water body is not entitled to the beneficial use of the surface waters of the 
  entire water body by the sole virtue of the fact that he or she owns contiguous 
  lands.â€); C.C. Marvel, Annotation, Rights of Fishing, Boating, Bathing, or 
  the Like in Inland Lakes, 57 A.L.R.2d 569 (Supp. 2003) (noting that â€œ[i]t 
  has been held or recognized that there are no riparian rights of fishing, boating, 
  bathing, or the like, as the case may be, in a lake the bed of which is owned 
  by one other than the riparian ownerâ€).
Under the â€œcivil law ruleâ€ adopted by other jurisdictions, an owner 
  of land contiguous to a lake or pond is, purely by virtue of littoral rights, 
  entitled to the reasonable use and enjoyment of the entireÂ  body of waterâ€”whether 
  navigable or not. See Johnson v. Seifert, 100 N.W.2d 689, 696-97 
  (Minn. 1960) (expressly rejecting the common law rule and holding that an â€œabutting 
  or riparian owner of a lake . . . has a right to make such use of the lake over 
  its entire surface, in common with all other abutting owners . . . regardless 
  of the navigable or public character of the lake and regardless of the ownership 
  of the bed thereofâ€).Â  States applying the civil law rule emphasize the importance 
  of promoting the beneficial use and enjoyment of lakes and ponds as a recreational 
  resource. See, e.g., id. at 695 (opining that â€œstates which 
  like Minnesota have extensive waters of recreational or commercial value hold 
  that an abutting or riparian owner has a right of reasonable use of the entire 
  overlying water, and no distinction is made between navigable and nonnavigable, 
  meandered or unmeandered, or public or private lakesâ€).
A recent application of the civil law rule may be found in Ace 
  Equipment Sales, Inc. v. Buccino, 848 A.2d 474 (Conn. App. 2004).Â  The material 
  facts of Ace Equipment largely mirror those of the present case. At the 
  center of that case was a twenty acre non-navigable, man-made pond surrounded 
  by several parcels of property held by various owners.Â  The pond bed was owned 
  entirely by one of the abutting property owners, who sought to exclude the other 
  adjoining landowners from any access to the pond waters. Id. at 476-77. 
  The court concluded that â€œowners of subaqueous land under a pond or lake may 
  not prevent the use, by abutting owners, who control the existence of the pond 
  itself, for recreational purposes of the surface water above the bed of a pond 
  that they own.â€ Id. at 480. [3] Â  
Based on our review of these cases, we follow the common law rule 
  as set out above.Â  First, we note that, as a general rule, South Carolina law 
  in the area of water rights generally hews closely to the common law. See, 
  e.g., Lowcountry Open Land Trust, 347 S.C. at 110, 552 S.E.2d 
  at 785-86 (adopting common law rule regarding the ability of riparian owners 
  to wharf over navigable waters); Horry County v. Woodward, 282 S.C. 366, 
  369-70, 318 S.E.2d 584, 586 (Ct. App. 1984) (recognizing â€œthe general common 
  law rule that accretions by a natural alluvial action to riparian or littoral 
  lands become the property of the riparian or littoral owner whose lands are 
  added toâ€); McCullough v. Wall, 38 S.C.L. (4 Rich.) 68, 86 (1850) (adopting 
  and applying the common law rule that the owner of the soil over which a non-navigable 
  stream or river flows has the exclusive right of fishing unless some other person 
  can show a grant or prescription in â€œderogation of the right naturally attached 
  to the ownership of the soilâ€); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-1-50 
  (1976) (providing that â€œ[a]ll, and every part, of the common law of England, 
  where it is not altered by the Code or inconsistent with the Constitution or 
  laws of this State, is hereby continued in full force and effect in the same 
  manner as before the adoption of this sectionâ€).Â  Therefore, we think that, 
  when confronted with a decision whether to follow a common law approach or follow 
  a civil law rule, our courtsâ€”absent any other considerationsâ€”would generally 
  follow the common law rule.
Second, we think the underlying policy of protecting the financial 
  investments and expectations of individuals who make capital improvements to 
  their propertyâ€”a policy compellingly articulated in Anderson v. Bell 
  and other cases adopting the common law ruleâ€”is in accord with the general jurisprudence 
  of our state. [4] Â  Property owners should be able make improvements 
  to their real property without fear that their investment will be diminished 
  should they create a body of water that touches upon the property line of a 
  neighboring landowner.Â  Of course, neighboring property owners are not foreclosed 
  from gaining access to an abutting non-navigable, man-made body of water.Â  Any 
  such abutting property owner is free to bargain with the owner of the pond or 
  lake for the conveyance of an easement or some other right of access to its 
  waters.
For these reasons, we apply the common law rule to the present case.Â  Therefore, 
  to the extent the Colony is the fee simple owner of the pond bed, it has the 
  exclusive right to the use of the surface waters above its property and may 
  exclude all others from access to those waters.
III.Â  Land Boundaries and Damages
The special referee declined to adjudicate the unsettled boundaries between 
  the parties.Â  There is at least some contradiction in the boundaries advanced 
  between the Colony and the abutting landowners.Â  In light of our determination 
  that a mere abutting landowner does not have any right to use the pond, it is 
  necessary to determine if they are simply abutting landowners or if they hold 
  title to land that is covered by portions of the pond.Â  If they hold title to 
  portions of the bed of the pond, then those landowners have the right to use 
  those portions of the pond immediately above their titled property.Â  Similarly, 
  they have the right to exclude others from those portions of the lake.Â  See 
  generally South Carolina Elec. & Gas v. Hix, 306 S.C. 173, 
  410 S.E.2d 582 (1991).Â  They also have the right to cut down trees and brush 
  over the land to which they have title.Â  If, however, they do not have title 
  to the land, the Colony can maintain its suit for trespass.Â  See Spigener 
  v. Cooner, 42 S.C.L. (8 Rich.) 301, 304-305 (1855)
Settlement of the boundaries between the various parties is not only necessary 
  to delineate the respective rights of the landowners to use of the pond, but 
  it is also essential for the establishment of damages.Â  In declining to set 
  the precise boundaries between the parties, the referee opted instead to utilize 
  the term â€œoverlap property.â€Â  Such a vague description leaves unanswered the 
  rights, if any, of the abutting property owners to use the pond and further 
  renders the damage awards effectively unreviewable.Â  We are compelled therefore 
  to vacate the damage awards.Â  
We remand to the trial court to determine the precise property lines of the 
  owners of property abutting the pond. The trial court shall reconsider the matter 
  of damages in light of the true boundary lines.Â  Damages, if any, should be 
  ascertained on the existing record. 
  [5]   
CONCLUSION
We find: (1) Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond is not a publicly accessible 
  navigable watercourse under South Carolina law; (2) the abutting landowners 
  do not possess any littoral right of access to the pond; and (3) the question 
  of damages cannot be determined absent a determination of the precise property 
  boundaries.Â  The order of the special referee is therefore affirmed in part, 
  vacated in part and the case is remanded for a determination of boundaries and 
  damages.
AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED 
  IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, 
  J., concur.

 
  [1] Â The special referee also found as fact that â€œ[t]he water in Whiteâ€™s Mill 
    Pond belongs to the State of South Carolina as do the fish contained therein.â€Â  
    This finding is wholly incongruous with the express holding that the pond 
    is not a navigable watercourse under South Carolina law to which the general 
    public would enjoy a right of access.Â  Though this finding is not explicitly 
    appealed by either party, we conclude it would be inappropriate to bind the 
    resolution of this matter based on this finding under the â€œlaw of the caseâ€ 
    doctrine.Â  See Charleston Lumber Co., Inc. v. Miller Housing Corp., 
    338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (stating an unappealed ruling 
    is the law of the case).
  In construing a judgeâ€™s 
    order, we must do so in light of the judgeâ€™s intent as discerned from the 
    order as a whole.Â  See Weil v. Weil, 299 S.C. 84, 90, 382 S.E.2d 
    471, 474 (Ct. App. 1989) (holding that â€œ[t]he determinative factor is the 
    intent of the court, as gathered, not from an isolated part thereof, but from 
    all the parts of the judgment itself. Hence, in construing a judgment, it 
    should be examined and considered in its entiretyâ€).Â  Adhering to this principle, 
    this court has refused to hold parties bound by language in a lower court 
    order that we found was not necessary to the decision of the issues presented.Â  
    Id. at 89, 382 S.E.2d at 473. (refusing to apply the â€œdoctrine of the 
    law of the caseâ€ toÂ  language found to be â€œmere dicta, an expression or statement 
    by the court on a matter not necessarily involved in the case nor necessary 
    to a decision thereofâ€).
  Viewing the special refereeâ€™s order as a whole, therefore, 
    the finding that the water and fish of Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond belong to the state 
    stands as a non-sequitur in the otherwise coherent analysis.Â  At the outset 
    of his order, the special referee stated that the case turned on two issuesâ€”â€œwhether 
    Whiteâ€™s Mill Pond is a navigable watercourseâ€ and â€œwhether the [abutting landowners] 
    have riparian rights.â€Â  The special refereeâ€™s subsequent discussion of the 
    applicable law only addresses these issues.Â  No legal principle is cited or 
    discussed in the order which supports a finding that the water and fish in 
    the pond belong to the state.Â  Indeed, when questioned by this court at oral 
    argument, counsel for both parties were unable to explain how this 
    finding related to the special refereeâ€™s explicit determinations.Â  We are 
    left with no choice, therefore, but to view this isolated language as an anomaly 
    that is most probably the product of a labyrinthine factual and legal landscape 
    rather than view it as a finding necessary to the refereeâ€™s decision.Â Â  

 
  [2] See Lowcountry Open Land Trust 
    v. State, 347 S.C. 96, 108, 552 S.E.2d 778, 785 (Ct. App. 2001) (noting 
    that â€œ[Riparian] is sometimes used as relating to the shore of the sea or 
    other tidal water, or of a lake or other considerable body of water not having 
    the character of a watercourse. But this is not accurate. The proper word 
    to be employed in such connections is â€˜littoral.â€™â€) (quoting Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 
    1327 (6th ed. 1990)).

 
  [3]  But see Ace Equip. Sales, 
    848 A.2d at 482-85 (Schaller, J., dissenting) (One member of the appellate 
    panel forcefully argued in dissent that the common law rule should be followed 
    in Connecticut).

 
  [4]  A prominent example of an area of property 
    law where the courts give substantial consideration to a property ownersâ€™ 
    financial investment in their property is in the field of the governmentâ€™s 
    power of eminent domain.Â  When analyzing whether the government has effected 
    a compensable taking of private land for public use, a key factor the court 
    must consider is the property ownerâ€™s â€œreasonable investment-backed expectations.â€Â  
    McQueen v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 354 S.C. 142, 148, 580 S.E.2d 
    116, 119 (2003).

 
  [5]  We recognize that additional evidence may 
    be required, as deemed appropriate by the trial court, to clarify if an alleged 
    trespass was committed upon property owned by the Colony.Â  The taking of additional 
    evidence is for clarification purposes only, not the expansion of the Colonyâ€™s 
    damage claims.

title: Tallent v. SCDOT
description: The South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) appealed the circuit court's determination that its actions constituted an actionable taking of Elisha Tallent's property.  SCDOT argued the enactment of section 57-5-1050 of the South Carolina Code (1991) alleviates SCDOT's necessity to compensate Tallent for an actionable taking of her property.  The appellate court found this argument not preserved for review.  Additionally, SCDOT alleged its actions did not constitute an actionable taking because Tallent's property does not abut any street to which access was affected by SCDOT construction project.  The appellate court disagreed, finding Tallent demonstrated a special injury sufficient to entitle her to compensation regardless of whether her property abutted any section of affected street.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Elisha B. Tallent, d/b/a Elishaâ€™s California Hair,
Respondent,
v.
South Carolina Department of Transportation, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 3924
Heard December 13, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Beacham O. Brooker, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Robert C. Childs, III, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  The South Carolina Department of Transportation 
  (SCDOT) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s determination that its actions constituted 
  an actionable taking of Elisha Tallentâ€™s property.Â  We affirm.
FACTSÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Elisha 
  Tallent purchased commercial property located at 1801 Old Easley Bridge Road 
  in Greenville, and opened a hair salon and tanning facility known as Elishaâ€™s 
  California Hair.Â  Tallent erected a second structure on the property where she 
  operated a consignment shop.Â  Prior to the construction undertaken by SCDOT, 
  Tallentâ€™s property had immediate access to Highway 123 via Old Easley Bridge 
  Road.Â  
SCDOT began construction of a controlled-access highway interchange 
  on White Horse Road and the intersection between White Horse Road and Old Easley 
  Bridge Road.Â  During construction, SCDOT erected a fence along Old Easley Bridge 
  Road, removed the traffic light from the intersection, and closed the road to 
  through traffic.Â  As a result, the access points linking Highway 123 and Old 
  Easley Bridge Road were closed, severing Tallentâ€™s access to Highway 123 via 
  Old Easley Bridge Road.Â  Tallentâ€™s only remaining access to Highway 123 was 
  by means of a series of secondary roads. 
Tallent 
  sued SCDOT under a theory of inverse condemnation alleging a taking of access 
  rights by the actions of SCDOT.Â  The circuit court ordered the proceedings bifurcated 
  with the issue of a taking to be tried by the master-in-equity.Â  At the conclusion 
  of the proceedings, the master found the actions of SCDOT constituted a compensable 
  taking.Â  SCDOT timely appealed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A proceeding to determine whether Tallent was deprived of a property 
  right entitling her to just compensation is an equitable action.Â  See 
  Hardin v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 359 S.C. 244, 249, 597 S.E.2d 
  814, 816 (Ct. App. 2004) (cert. pending) (concluding that an inverse condemnation 
  proceeding to determine whether a taking has occurred is equitable in nature). 
  [1] Â  â€œOn appeal from an action in equity, the appellate court has authority 
  to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â 
See id.Â Â 
ISSUES

  
    
    
      
         I. 
         
  Whether section 57-5-1050 of the South Carolina Code (1991) precludes compensation 
  for SCDOTâ€™s taking of a landownerâ€™s access rights?
      
      
         II.
         
  Does the fact Tallentâ€™s property does not abut the affected section of Highway 
  123 preclude a determination that the actions of SCDOT constituted an actionable 
  taking?
      
      
         III.  
         
  Did the master properly find Tallent had suffered a special injury?
      
    
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.                  
  Section 57-5-1050 of the South Carolina Code
SCDOT argues the enactment of section 57-5-1050 of the South Carolina 
  Code (1991) alleviates SCDOTâ€™s necessity to compensate Tallent for an actionable 
  taking of her property.Â  We find this argument has not been properly preserved 
  for our review.
A party cannot use a motion to reconsider, alter or amend 
  a judgment to present an issue that could have been raised prior to the judgment 
  but was not.Â  Kiawah Prop. Owners Group v. Public Serv. Commâ€™n, 359 S.C. 
  105, 113, 597 S.E.2d 145, 149 (2004); see also MailSource, LLC v. 
  M.A. Bailey & Assoc., 356 S.C. 370, 374, 588 S.E.2d 639, 641 (Ct. App. 
  2003) (â€œA party cannot raise issue for first time in Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion 
  which could have been raised at trial.â€).
The first time SCDOT argued the enactment of section 57-5-1050 
  alleviates DOTâ€™s necessity to compensate Tallent for an actionable taking of 
  her property was in its motion for reconsideration under Rules 52 and 59, SCRCP.Â  
  In the motion, SCDOT asserted section 57-5-1050 in the nature of a defense, 
  which would abrogate the requirement to pay compensation for any actionable 
  taking of Tallentâ€™s property.Â  However, section 57-5-1050 was never raised as 
  a defense at trial.Â  Therefore, because SCDOT failed to do so, the issue is 
  not preserved.Â  See, e.g., Kiawah Prop. Owners Group, 359 S.C. 
  at 113, 597 S.E.2d at 149.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
  II.              
Non-abutting property 
   
SCDOT argues the master erred in finding an actionable taking occurred.Â  
  Specifically, SCDOT alleges its actions do not constitute an actionable taking 
  of Tallentâ€™s property because her property does not abut any street to which 
  access was affected by SCDOT construction project.Â  We disagree.
In order to find an inverse condemnation, the landowner must demonstrate: 
  (1) an affirmative, positive, aggressive act on the part of a governmental agency, 
  (2) resulting in a taking, (3) for a public use, (4) with some degree of permanence.Â  
  See Gray v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways and Public Transp., 
  311 S.C. 144, 149, 427 S.E.2d 899, 902 (Ct. App. 1992). The only element in 
  dispute here is that of a taking. 
An actual physical taking is not necessary to entitle a property owner 
  to just compensation under the constitutional prohibition against taking private 
  property for public use without just compensation to the property owner.Â  Gasque 
  v. Town of Conway, 194 S.C. 15, 8 S.E.2d 871, 873 (1940), overruled on 
  other grounds by McCall by Andrews v. Batson, 285 S.C. 243, 247, 
  329 S.E.2d 741, 743 (1985) (overruling Gasque to the extent it held that 
  an action may not be maintained against the State without its consent).Â  In 
  Gasque, the supreme court held:

The Constitution of this State (Art. 1, Sec. 17) provides that 
  â€˜private property shall not be taken . . .Â  for public use without just compensation 
  being first made therefor.â€™Â  In construing this provision of the Constitution, 
  we have held, along with many other courts, that an actual physical taking of 
  property is not necessary to entitle its owner to compensation. A manâ€™s property 
  may be taken, within the meaning of this provision, although his title and possession 
  remain undisturbed. To deprive him of the ordinary beneficial use and enjoyment 
  of his property is, in law, equivalent to the taking of it, and is as much a 
  â€˜takingâ€™ as though the property itself were actually appropriated.
Property in a thing consists not merely in its ownership and 
  possession, but in the unrestricted right of use, enjoyment, and disposal. Anything 
  which destroys one or more of these elements of property to that extent destroys 
  the property itself. It must be conceded that the substantial value of property 
  lies in its use.Â  If the right of use be denied, the value of the property is 
  annihilated, and ownership is rendered a barren right.Â  
The constitutional prohibition against taking private property 
  for public use without just compensation must have been intended to protect 
  all the essential elements of ownership which make property valuable, including, 
  of course, the right of user, andÂ Â  the right of enjoyment.

194 S.C. at Â­Â­21, 8 S.E.2d at 873 (citations omitted). 
Moreover, 
  South Carolina courts have directly addressed the rights of a non-abutting landowner.Â  
  In City of Rock Hill v. Cothran, 209 S.C. 357, 40 S.E.2d 239 (1946), 
  the supreme court established the rights of a landowner to recover damages for 
  impairment of access when the landownerâ€™s property does not immediately abut 
  the part of the street closed.Â  The Cothran court held:

The test is, not whether the property abuts, but whether there 
  is a special injury, and the first practical question which presents itself 
  is whether one whose property does not abut immediately on the part of the street 
  vacated . . . is so specially injured as to be entitled to recover compensation 
  on the ground that his access is cut off in one direction, but not in the opposite 
  direction.

209 S.C. at 368, 40 S.E.2d 
  at 243-44.Â  See also Hardin v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 
  359 S.C. 244, 251, 597 S.E.2d 814, 817 (Ct. App. 2004) (restating the Cothran 
  test for recovery is not whether the land abuts the affected road but rather 
  has the landowner suffered a special injury); Gray, 311 S.C. at 152, 
  427 S.E.2d at 903-04 (â€œUnder the Cothran decision, the lack of a physical 
  entry upon Gray's leasehold is not dispositive of the â€˜takingâ€™ issue. The critical 
  question was whether the closing of the intersection affected the value of Grayâ€™s 
  property in some special way not common to the other property in the area.â€).
In the present action, Tallentâ€™s property does not abut any part of 
  the affected Highway 123; however, her property abuts Old Easley Bridge Road, 
  a portion of which was closed as a result of SCDOT construction project.Â  Old 
  Easley Bridge Road provided Tallent immediate access to Highway 123, which was 
  terminated by the construction of SCDOT.Â  Therefore, under the Cothran 
  test, we reject SCDOTâ€™s contention there can be no actionable taking because 
  Tallentâ€™s property does not abut the affected Highway 123.Â  Rather, to determine 
  whether an actionable taking occurred, we must resolve whether Tallent suffered 
  a special injury, as a non-abutting landowner, due to the construction by SCDOT.
  III.          
Special 
  Injury  
SCDOT argues Tallent did not demonstrate a special injury entitling 
  her to compensation.Â  We disagree.
The Cothran court defined what constitutes a special injury 
  in South Carolina:Â  

It is well settled that an owner is not entitled to recover damages 
  unless he has sustained an injury different in kind and not merely in degree 
  from that suffered by the public at large.Â  If it appears that there is a special 
  injury, the owner may recover damages notwithstanding his property does not 
  abut, as in this case, on the part of the street vacated, because this amounts 
  to a â€œtakingâ€.

Cothran, 209 S.C. 
  at 368, 40 S.E.2d at 243 (citations omitted).Â  â€œAn injury for which damages 
  must be paid is injury to the property itself.Â  The property itself must suffer 
  some diminution in substance, or be rendered intrinsically less valuable by 
  reason of public use.â€Â  Gray, 311 S.C. at 151, 427 S.E.2d at 903 (citation 
  omitted).Â  The fact that access to property is not cut off in either direction 
  by the actions of a governmental agency does not affect the issue of taking, 
  provided special injury is shown, but is to be considered in determining damages.Â  
  See Cothran, 209 S.C. at 370, 40 S.E.2d at 244.
Tallent presented 
  two witnesses, a licensed real-estate broker and an expert in the appraisal 
  of commercial real estate to establish special injury.Â  The testimony established 
  the damages suffered by Tallent as a result of SCDOT construction and removal 
  of access to Highway 123 were different in kind from those suffered by the public 
  at large.Â  Both the expert appraiser and realtor testified the access closure 
  affected Tallentâ€™s property differently from other commercial properties because 
  she lost â€œwalk-inâ€ business.Â  The expert appraiser also testified that her business 
  losses differed from those in the area because the other entities were â€œdestinationâ€ 
  businesses, such that people will seek them out regardless of the lack of immediate 
  access from Highway 123.Â  Both witnesses also testified that while the surrounding 
  residential area benefited from the actions of SCDOT, the value of Tallentâ€™s 
  commercial property had been adversely affected.Â  The realtor further testified 
  that there had been no interest in the property due to the current lack of access 
  to Highway 123.Â  
Tallentâ€™s 
  witnesses demonstrated that she suffered special injury different in kind and 
  not merely degree sufficient to satisfy the Cothran test.Â  Specifically, 
  the public at large lost mere access to Highway 123 by means of Old Easley Bridge 
  Road, while Tallent was deprived of both access and property value.Â  Therefore, 
  we find Tallent entitled to just compensation for the actionable taking of her 
  property and the decision of the master is hereby
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  But see Sea Cabins on the Ocean IV 
    Homeowners Assâ€™n, Inc. v. City of North Myrtle Beach, 337 S.C. 380, 388, 
    523 S.E.2d 193, 197-98 (â€œAn action brought by a property owner against a municipality 
    for the taking of the ownerâ€™s property without just compensation is an action 
    at law.â€).Â Â  In an action at law, we must affirm the masterâ€™s factual findings 
    unless there is no evidence reasonably supporting them.Â  Id.Â

title: State v. Michael Governor
description: Determines that a violation of the Department of Public Safety's guidelines concerning the handling of evidence does not, in and of itself, require suppression of the evidence at trial.
text:
State v. Governor



  
    
      
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
The State, Appellant,
v.
Michael T. Governor, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3925
Heard December 8, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  24, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry 
  Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy 
  Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman 
  Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington of Charleston, 
  for Appellant.
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  The State appeals the trial courtâ€™s suppression of seized 
  drugs the State intended to admit in this drug prosecution.Â  We reverse.Â  
BACKGROUND
On Friday, June 7, 2002, South Carolina Highway Patrol Troopers 
  Anthony Bokern and Marty Housand arrested Michael Governor for open container 
  and trafficking crack cocaine.Â  Governor was a passenger in a vehicle stopped 
  for a window tint violation.Â  While Housand dealt with the driver, who was driving 
  under suspension, Bokern attempted to secure the scene.Â  When Bokern began placing 
  Governor under arrest for an open container violation, Governor reached for 
  his back pocket to pull out a bag.Â  Bokern seized the brown paper bag from Governorâ€™s 
  pocket, glanced inside to make certain there was no weapon, and handed it to 
  Housand.Â  
The bag contained multiple clear plastic baggies.Â  Housand weighed and field-tested 
  the contents and obtained a positive result for crack cocaine.Â  Housand did 
  not have a BEST evidence bag with him at the time of the arrest so he placed 
  the drugs in an unsealed evidence bag in the trunk of his patrol car. 
  [1] Â  The drugs remained there over the weekend.Â  On the following Monday 
  morning when he returned to work, Housand placed the drugs in a BEST evidence 
  bag.Â  On Wednesday when he was visiting a fellow officer at a hospital in Columbia, 
  he gave the drugs to the evidence custodian.Â  The custodianâ€™s supervisor had 
  set up a separate room in the hospital for the custodian to accept evidence 
  while the officers were visiting their fellow patrolman in the hospital.Â  The 
  custodian transported the drugs to SLED that same day.Â  
Governor was indicted for possession of cocaine with intent to distribute and 
  possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute.Â  The trial court held 
  a suppression hearing regarding the drug evidence seized by the police.Â  The 
  trial court suppressed the evidence â€œbased on [the officersâ€™] failure to comply 
  with their own guidelines.â€Â  This appeal followed.Â  
DISCUSSION
The State claims the trial court erred in suppressing evidence of seized drugs 
  because it established a sufficient chain of custody for the drugs.Â  We agree.
A party offering fungible items, such as drugs, as evidence must establish 
  a chain of custody as far as practicable.Â  State v. Joseph, 328 S.C. 
  352, 364, 491 S.E.2d 275, 281 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Where the substance passed through 
  several hands, the evidence must not leave to conjecture who had it and what 
  was done with it between the seizure and the analysis.Â  â€œWhile the proof of 
  chain of custody need not negate all possibility of tampering, it must establish 
  a complete chain of evidence as far as practicable.â€Â  Id.Â  In 
  applying this rule, our courts have found evidence inadmissible â€œonly where 
  there is a missing link in the chain of possession because the identity of those 
  who handled the [evidence] was not established at least as far as practicable.â€Â  
  State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419, 424, 544 S.E.2d 835, 837 (2001).Â  By contrast, 
  where the identity of those who handled the evidence is established, â€œevidence 
  regarding its care goes only to the weight of the specimen as credible evidenceâ€ 
  and not to its admissibility.Â  Id.; see also State v. Taylor, 
  360 S.C. 18, 25, 598 S.E.2d 735, 738 (Ct. App. 2004) (en banc) (holding where 
  the identity of each person in the chain handling evidence is established and 
  the manner of handling is reasonably demonstrated, suppression of the evidence 
  is abuse of discretion, absent proof of tampering, bad faith, or ill motive).Â  

In State v. Smith, 326 S.C. 39, 40, 482 S.E.2d 777, 778 (1997), a police 
  officer took a seized vial of blood home with him and placed it in his refrigerator.Â  
  He did not submit the vial to SLED until two days later.Â  At trial, each person 
  who handled the blood samples testified.Â  Id. at 41, 482 S.E.2d at 779.Â  
  Because there was no evidence the sample was tampered with in any manner and 
  the police officer testified the sample was in the same condition when he submitted 
  it to SLED as when he received it, our supreme court held the storage of the 
  blood sample in the police officerâ€™s home went to the weight of the evidence, 
  not its admissibility.Â  Id. at 41-42, 482 S.E.2d at 779.Â  
In this case, the 
  State produced evidence of each person in the chain of custody and the manner 
  in which the drugs were handled.Â  Bokern testified he handed the drugs to Housand 
  who then weighed and field-tested them.Â  Housand then placed them inside his 
  trunk, where they remained until Monday morning.Â  Housand testified no one else 
  had keys to his patrol car, and no one else drove the vehicle that weekend.Â  
  Furthermore, he did not â€œalter or mess with the substance in anyway.â€Â  Additionally, 
  Housand testified that on the day of the hearing the drugs were in substantially 
  the same condition as they were the day of the arrest.Â  Lastly, Dayle Blackmon, 
  the evidence custodian, testified Housand gave her the drugs at the hospital 
  on Wednesday, June 12, 2002, and she delivered them to SLED.Â  
The trial court 
  did not find any missing link in the custodial chain or proof of tampering, 
  bad faith, or ill motive.Â  Instead, the court suppressed the evidence based 
  on the officersâ€™ failure to comply with the Department of Public Safetyâ€™s policy 
  directives on evidence.Â  The directives require â€œ[a]ll property/evidence [to] 
  be submitted to the evidence custodian by the end of the shift or as soon as 
  possible thereafter.â€Â  In Section IX, the directives also require â€œ[a]ll controlled 
  substances . . . [to] be transported for analysis within 72 hours of the seizure.â€Â  
  Furthermore, the â€œ[e]vidence/property shall not be stored in the patrol vehicle 
  except when being transported from the scene to the place of storage . . . . 
  [and] shall not remain with the officer for a prolonged period of time.â€Â  
Obviously, Housand 
  did not comply with these department directives.Â  However, although this failure 
  was the proper subject of cross-examination of the witness for credibility, 
  it was not a proper basis for suppression.Â  Because the State presented a complete 
  chain of custody, the trial court abused its discretion in suppressing the drug 
  evidence.Â  State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 620-21, 582 S.E.2d 426, 429 
  (2003) (holding rulings regarding the admissibility of evidence are within the 
  trial courtâ€™s discretion and will not be reversed absent an abuse of that discretion).Â  

REVERSED.
 ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â  All controlled substances sent to SLED for analysis must be in a BEST 
    evidence bag.Â
