title: Brenco v. SCDOT
description: Affirms the trial court's denial of the request to rescind a deed, but remands for receipt of evidence of damages on an inverse condemnation claim.
text:
Brenco v. SC Dep't of Transportation


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Brenco, A General Partnership, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Transportation, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master In Equity

Opinion No. 3926
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  24, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED 
  


  
    
      
Howell V. Bellamy, Jr. and Douglas M. Zayicek, both of Myrtle 
  Beach, for Appellant.
John B. McCutcheon, Jr., Mary Ruth M. Baxter, and Arrigo P. Carotti, all of 
  Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Brenco brought this action against the South Carolina 
  Department of Transportation (SCDOT), seeking deed rescission and claiming inverse 
  condemnation.Â  The trial court refused to rescind the deed and found Brenco 
  failed to prove damages related to the inverse condemnation.Â  We affirm in part, 
  reverse in part, and remand.
BACKGROUND
Brenco owns property located along Highway 501 in Horry County.Â  
  The property was formerly the site of a Brendleâ€™s store, which closed in 1997.Â  
  In 1998, SCDOT purchased 6,689 square feet of Brencoâ€™s parking lot in order 
  to build a frontage road.Â  The negotiations and deed referenced aspects of SCDOTâ€™s 
  August 18, 1993 road plans for development of the frontage road including the 
  creation of â€œcontrolled access facilitiesâ€ as needed.Â  
After initially alerting them of the project, SCDOTâ€™s appraiser, 
  Clyde Ratchford, met with Brenco representatives at the property and provided 
  them with a plan sheet.Â  Although Ratchford admitted the plans could be confusing, 
  the plan sheet showed the propertyâ€™s direct access to Highway 501 would be eliminated 
  and, after construction, access would be to the frontage road.Â  The plan sheet 
  provided to Brenco also was narrow in scope and did not show the plans related 
  to the nearby intersection of George Bishop Parkway and Highway 501, an original 
  alternate means of accessing Brencoâ€™s property from the highway.Â  According 
  to Ratchford, the plans indicated the grade of the road, and thus the propertyâ€™s 
  visibility from the highway, would remain unchanged.Â  
The appraisal valued the property taken at $34,700.Â  A diagram attached as 
  an exhibit to the appraisal showed only the property and the portion being taken 
  for the frontage road.Â  It did have an indication of the existing access point, 
  which originally led to Highway 501, but did not specifically show any proposed 
  change.Â  However, language in the appraisal information indicated access would 
  be to the frontage road.Â  Brenco accepted the appraisal and agreed to sell the 
  6,689 square feet for $34,700.Â  
The final project was completed pursuant to updated 2000 plans instead of the 
  1993 plans.Â  Rather than being left at grade, Highway 501 was elevated, rendering 
  Brencoâ€™s property less visible from the highway.Â  
Brenco then brought this action to rescind the deed on the ground of negligent 
  misrepresentation or unilateral or mutual mistake.Â  Additionally, Brenco sought 
  damages for inverse condemnation.Â  
At trial, Brenco representatives maintained they knew nothing of their loss 
  of access directly onto Highway 501.Â  They asserted they were led to believe 
  they would retain access across the frontage road.Â  However, at least one representative 
  admitted no one asked about access to and from Highway 501 onto the property.Â  
  Additionally, Brenco questioned whether SCDOT knew about the change in grade 
  or the possibility of such a change and failed to alert Brenco during the 1998 
  negotiations.Â  
Ratchford indicated he never told Brenco representatives they would 
  retain access to Highway 501.Â  He maintained he showed them the portion of the 
  plan sheet covering their property, which showed the elimination of direct access 
  and provided access to their property only onto the frontage road.Â  In addition, 
  SCDOT offered testimony that although grade studies were being conducted, they 
  learned the project would require elevating the road only after concluding the 
  Brenco transaction.Â  
Brenco offered testimony of two experts regarding the condition and 
  value of the property.Â  Engineer Steve Powell testified the highest and best 
  use for the property was dramatically and negatively impacted as a result of 
  the change in grade of the road and the elimination of direct access.Â  Appraiser 
  Jim Jayroe testified the property would no longer be usable for retail space, 
  but would instead be classified as light industrial.Â  He testified the negative 
  change in value of the property from before the original taking (the 1998 deed) 
  until after the completion of the project was approximately $1.5 million.Â  However, 
  when asked for a figure of the monetary damage between the 1993 plans and the 
  2000 plans, he responded:Â  â€œI donâ€™t know.â€Â  
A second appraiser for SCDOT, Woodrow Willard, testified there was 
  no change in the propertyâ€™s value after Brenco deeded the frontage.Â  He testified 
  any change in grade of the roadâ€”the only change he found subsequent to the signing 
  of the deedâ€”was offset by improved access to the property through the use of 
  the frontage road.Â  
In its first order, the trial court refused to rescind the deed, 
  citing Brencoâ€™s failure to prove any of its alleged grounds.Â  As to mistake, 
  the court concluded although Brenco representatives may have had an incorrect 
  impression of what access the property would have to Highway 501 after the conveyance, 
  the documents they received from SCDOT established the property would no longer 
  enjoy direct access to the highway.Â  The court also found SCDOT was not then 
  aware the highwayâ€™s grade would change and thus there was no basis to rescind 
  the deed for negligent misrepresentation.Â  
The court did not dispose of the inverse condemnation action in its 
  first order.Â  Instead, the court sent a letter to counsel indicating it was 
  struggling with the issue of damages and requested a conference on the issue.Â  
  At the conference, the court considered taking additional testimony regarding 
  damages, and counsel for both parties agreed the court could reopen the record 
  to receive additional testimony.Â  Brenco later moved to reopen the case to offer 
  additional evidence of damages. Â In a memorandum in support of the motion, 
  Brencoâ€™s counsel noted the trial court mentioned during the damages conference 
  that it wanted to hear specific testimony as to the changes between the August 
  18, 1993 plans and the 2000 implemented plans.Â  
The court later issued an order in which it concluded Brenco 
  failed to establish any damages necessary to prove an inverse condemnation as 
  a result of the deviation from the 1993 to the 2000 plans.Â  The court found 
  Brencoâ€™s evidence of monetary damages related solely to the inverse condemnation 
  deficient.Â  Consequently, the court found the only evidence on damages resulting 
  from the change in grade was from SCDOTâ€™s appraiser who opined that any damage 
  resulting therefrom was offset by improved access.Â  The court also declined 
  to reopen the case for additional testimony on the issue.Â  Brenco filed motions 
  for reconsideration of both of the courtâ€™s orders, which were denied after hearings.Â  

DISCUSSION
I.Â  Deed Rescission
Brenco argues the trial court erred in refusing to rescind the deed.Â  
  We disagree.
An action to set aside a deed is a matter in equity.Â  See 
  Bullard v. Crawley, 294 S.C. 276, 278, 363 S.E.2d 897, 898 (1987).Â  On 
  appeal in an equity action, we may find facts in accordance with our own view 
  of the evidence, but are not required to disregard the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  
  Pinckney v. Warren, 344 S.C. 382, 387, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001).Â  Moreover, 
  our scope of review does not relieve the appellant of its burden to demonstrate 
  the courtâ€™s findings were in error.Â  Id. at 387-88, 544 S.E.2d at 623.
A.Â  Mistake
We find no basis for rescinding the deed on the ground of unilateral 
  or mutual mistake.
To rescind an instrument on the ground of mistake, the evidence must 
  be clear and convincing.Â  Truck South, Inc. v. Patel, 339 S.C. 40, 49, 
  528 S.E.2d 424, 429 (2000).Â  To rescind an instrument on the ground of unilateral 
  mistake, the mistake must be accompanied (1) by proof it was induced by fraud, 
  deceit, misrepresentation, concealment, or imposition of the opposing party 
  and without negligence on the part of the party seeking rescission, or (2) by 
  very strong and extraordinary circumstances which would make it a great wrong 
  to enforce the agreement.Â  Id.
A contract may be rescinded on the ground of mutual mistake where 
  the parties have made a common mistake of fact causing each to do what neither 
  intended.Â  Young v. Cooler, 347 S.C. 362, 366, 555 S.E.2d 410, 412-13 
  (Ct. App. 2001).
At trial, Brenco maintained two primary grounds for mistake:Â  (1) 
  the loss of direct access to Highway 501 from the property and (2) the change 
  in the grade of the road.Â  They asserted they were led to believe they would 
  retain access across the frontage road directly onto Highway 501.Â  However, 
  at least one representative admitted no one asked about access to and from Highway 
  501 onto the property.Â  The deed, which references the 1993 plans, specifies 
  the consideration paid to Brenco was for the â€œ6,689 square feet of land, and 
  all improvements thereon, if any, including rights of access as may be needed 
  for controlled access facilities.â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â  Although they argue 
  SCDOTâ€™s representative covertly put this language into the deed, they do not 
  deny they had an opportunity to review the deed.Â  Additionally, SCDOTâ€™s appraiser 
  testified he showed Brenco representatives the plan sheets, which detailed where 
  the property would access the frontage road and that its direct access to Highway 
  501 was being eliminated.Â  
Brenco presented no evidence of fraud or misrepresentation by SCDOT 
  with regard to the access.Â  Their argument was that representatives were under 
  a different impression regarding the access.Â  â€œAn erroneous impression taken 
  up from the suggestion of the partyâ€™s own mind does not relieve him from the 
  contract.â€Â  Richardsonâ€™s Rests., Inc. v. Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina, 
  304 S.C. 289, 297, 403 S.E.2d 669, 673 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Accordingly, there 
  is no ground for rescission based upon unilateral mistake.Â  
Brenco also failed to establish any mutual mistake regarding the access the 
  property would have to Highway 501 under the 1993 plans.Â  As to direct access, 
  SCDOT offered significant proof it intended to allow access only to the frontage 
  road and not to Highway 501. [1] Â  
  As to access by way of the intersection of Highway 501 and George Bishop Parkway, 
  Brenco asserts both its representatives and Ratchford, acting as a SCDOT representative, 
  mistakenly believed the intersection would be unchanged under the 1993 plans.Â  
  They cite to a passage in Ratchfordâ€™s deposition in which Brencoâ€™s counsel asked 
  whether under the 1993 plans a westbound traveler on Highway 501 would have 
  been able to reach Brencoâ€™s property by turning right onto George Bishop Parkway 
  and then left onto the frontage road.Â  Although Ratchford answered in the affirmative, 
  no follow-up questions were asked to determine if the intersection would remain 
  unchanged.Â  At trial, Ratchford explained that under the 1993 plan the intersection 
  of Highway 501 with George Bishop Parkway was closed, but an exit ramp from 
  the highway terminated at George Bishop Parkway and the frontage road.Â  Thus, 
  his deposition testimony was correct as far as it went.Â  Two questions that 
  were neither asked nor answered were whether eastbound travelers would have 
  been able to exit directly from Highway 501 onto George Bishop Parkway, and 
  whether any traveler would have been able to exit Brencoâ€™s property directly 
  onto Highway 501 in either direction.Â  
As to the elevation, Brenco asserted SCDOT knew about the change in grade but 
  failed to alert them during the initial negotiations.Â  SCDOT offered testimony 
  that although grade studies were being conducted, it was not until after the 
  signing of the deed that they learned the project would require raising the 
  grade of the road.Â  All evidence in the record indicates that when the deed 
  was signed, both parties believed and intended the highway would remain at grade.Â  
  Also, Brenco has failed to demonstrate how they were intentionally misled by 
  SCDOT.Â  That elevation studies were being conducted does not demonstrate SCDOT 
  knew the grade would be altered.Â  There is no evidence SCDOT intentionally withheld 
  knowledge the grade would be raised due to construction concerns.
B.Â  Negligent Misrepresentation
We also find no basis for Brencoâ€™s allegation SCDOT negligently misrepresented 
  the propertyâ€™s loss of direct access to the highway or the highwayâ€™s grade change.Â  

To prove negligent misrepresentation, Brenco was required to show 
  SCDOT made a false representation to Brenco, had a pecuniary interest in making 
  the representation, owed Brenco a duty of care to communicate truthful information 
  to Brenco, and breached that duty of care.Â  Additionally, Brenco was required 
  to establish it justifiably relied on the representation and suffered a pecuniary 
  loss as a proximate result.Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 
  354 S.C. 397, 407, 581 S.E.2d 161, 166 (2003).
As discussed above, all documentation provided to Brenco indicates 
  access would be restricted and would not be directly to Highway 501.Â  Additionally, 
  the record shows SCDOT did not intend to raise the grade of the road to its 
  resulting height when it purchased the property from Brenco.Â  Because Brenco 
  failed to prove SCDOT made any false representation regarding either the propertyâ€™s 
  access to Highway 501 or the grade of the highway, the trial court properly 
  refused to rescind the deed under a theory of negligent misrepresentation.
II.Â  Inverse Condemnation
Brenco argues 
  the trial court erred in bifurcating the case and refusing to reopen the record 
  to accept additional damages.Â  Alternatively, it argues the court erred in failing 
  to award damages for inverse condemnation.Â  Under the peculiar facts of this 
  case, we hold the court should have allowed additional evidence of damages to 
  the property caused by the changes made to the road project not reflected in 
  the deed from Brenco to SCDOT or the 1993 project plans. [2] 
The decision whether to reopen a record for additional evidence is 
  within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Wright v. Strickland, 306 S.C. 187, 
  188, 410 S.E.2d 596, 597 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  In Wright, this court affirmed 
  a trial courtâ€™s refusal to reopen a record where counsel for the party seeking 
  to reopen did not proffer any testimony or make any showing the evidence would 
  make any difference to the outcome of the case.Â  This court reasoned the trial 
  court properly declined the partyâ€™s attempt at a â€œfishing expedition.â€Â  Id.
In this case, 
  Brenco submitted evidence the changes from the 1993 plans to the final completed 
  project caused substantial pecuniary damage to their property.Â  However, at 
  trial Brenco also alleged it was unaware that because of the conveyance of frontage 
  to SCDOT and the 1993 plans, the property would lose direct access to the highway 
  and that a nearby intersection providing alternate access to the highway would 
  be closed.Â  Because of these additional allegationsâ€”directed at setting aside 
  the deedâ€”Brencoâ€™s expert calculated damages based on the propertyâ€™s before and 
  after value.Â  
The trial court expressed concern about the issue of damages in the inverse 
  condemnation action in a letter announcing its ruling on the deed rescission 
  claim.Â  It was only after this letter and the resulting damages conference that 
  Brenco realized it needed to establish damages in a different fashion.Â  As a 
  result, counsel asked to reopen the case.Â  However, the court later announced 
  both its refusal to reopen the case and its ruling on inverse condemnation in 
  a single letter requesting SCDOT draft an appropriate order.Â  In the letter, 
  the court stated it was â€œtruly uncomfortableâ€ with its rulings and did not know 
  when a case had given the court â€œso much concern as this one.â€Â  Unlike the party 
  in Wright, Brenco attempted at the reconsideration hearing to proffer 
  evidence the trial court found it had failed to establish at trial.Â  Even at 
  this hearing, the trial court openly struggled with the issue of damages and 
  seriously considered allowing the testimony.Â  Under these peculiar circumstances, 
  where the evidence of what was contemplated at each stage of the road project 
  was so complex and the inverse condemnation calculations were contingent on 
  the outcome of another theory of the case, we believe the trial court abused 
  its discretion in not reopening the record for additional evidence of damages.Â  
  Thus we remand the case to the trial court for additional testimony limited 
  to the damages, if any, caused by the changes in the project as envisioned by 
  the August 18 1993 plan and as referenced in the deed from Brenco to SCDOT, 
  and the final project as built.
AFFIRMED IN PART, 
  REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED. 
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Brenco contends the trial court erred in finding the parol evidence rule barred 
    its representativeâ€™s testimony regarding their belief surrounding the access 
    of the property to Highway 501.Â  We agree, but even considering the testimony, 
    we find Brenco failed to prove the deed should be rescinded due to unilateral 
    or mutual mistake.Â  See S. Realty & Constr. Co. v. Bryan, 
    290 S.C. 302, 309, 350 S.E.2d 194, 198 (Ct. App. 1986) (holding parol evidence 
    is admissible to show mistake).

 
   [2] In addition to increasing the grade of the highway, SCDOTâ€™s third exhibit 
    shows an exit ramp was moved from the 1993 plans to the 2000 plans.Â  Brenco 
    asserts this negatively affects the ability of westbound travelers to recognize 
    the property in time to take the appropriate exit.Â

title: Carolina Marine Handling v. Lasch
description: In this breach of contract action, the court of appeals affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of Appellantâ€™s counterclaim and third-party claim on the basis that it was barred by the three-year statute of limitations.  The court found that the contract had not been made one â€œunder sealâ€ within the meaning of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-520(b) â€“ and thus subject to a twenty-year statute of limitations â€“ based on Appellantâ€™s sole reliance on the general contract language stating, â€œIN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have hereunto set their hands and seals.â€
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Carolina Marine Handling, Inc., Plaintiff,
v.
Warren Frank Lasch; Duane Grantham; Jack C.
Sprott; Richard Lee Tapp, 
        R. Keith Summey, Douglas McKay, III, Robert N. King, Don J. Hayes; W. 
        Kurt Taylor; Gussie C. Greene; Stephen R. Ayer; Samuel L. Hart; A.C.
Mitchum; 
        Charlotte Gillespie; Dorothy K. Williams; Phoebe Miller; F. Browne Gregg; 
        City of North Charleston; Charleston Naval Complex Redevelopment Authority; 
        South Carolina State Budget and Control Board; S.C. State Ports Authority; 
        Charleston Shipbuilders, Inc.; Charleston International Projects, Inc.; 
        Charleston International Ports, LLC, Opportunity Research, Inc., Defendants,
Charleston Shipbuilders, Inc., Third-Party Plaintiff,
v.
Herbert R. â€œJockâ€ Stender, Third-Party Defendant,
Of Whom:Â  Charleston Shipbuilders, Inc. is Appellant,
and Carolina Marine Handling, Inc. and Herbert R. â€œJockâ€ Stender are
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3927
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David J. Parrish and Stephen P. Groves, Sr., both of Charleston, for Appellant.
M. Dawes Cooke, Jr. and John W. Fletcher, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  In this breach of contract action involving a non-sealed 
  instrument, the circuit court dismissed Appellantâ€™s counterclaim and third party 
  claim on the basis that the claims were barred by the general three-year statute 
  of limitations. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  Relying 
  solely on the generic contract provisionâ€”â€œIN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have 
  hereunto set their hands and sealsâ€â€”Appellant seeks to invoke the twenty-year 
  statute of limitations applicable to â€œsealed instruments.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  15-3-520(b) (Supp. 2003).Â  We concur with the circuit court and find the parties 
  to the contract did not intend the contract to be under seal.Â  The circuit court, 
  therefore, properly applied the general three-year statute of limitations and 
  dismissed Appellantâ€™s claims.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Carolina Shipbuilders, Inc. (CSI) leased property on the former Charleston 
  Naval Base Shipyard in December 1996 from the Charleston Naval Complex Redevelopment 
  Authority (RDA).Â  CSI later subleased the property to Carolina Marine Handling, 
  Inc. (CMH).Â  Among other things, the lease contract required CMH to make monthly 
  rent payments to CSI.Â  
RDA terminated its lease with CSI in May 1999, alleging CMH failed to make 
  all required rent payments.Â  CMH brought the present action against CSI and 
  others in May 2002.Â  In November 2002, CSI answered and counterclaimed against 
  CMH, alleging CMH breached its contract by failing to pay rent to RDA, resulting 
  in RDAâ€™s termination of its lease with CSI.Â  CSI also filed a third party complaint 
  against Herbert R. Stedner, CMHâ€™s sole owner.Â  
CMH and Stedner sought dismissal based on the general three-year 
  statute of limitations.Â  CSI countered with the argument that the lease contract 
  was made under seal and was subject to the twenty-year statute of limitations.Â  
  The circuit court found the contract was subject to the three-year statute of 
  limitations and dismissed CSIâ€™s claims.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
I.
The lease provides 
  in part: â€œIN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have hereunto set their hands and 
  seals this ____ day of December, 1996.â€Â  The date of the contractâ€™s execution 
  was written in the appropriate blank space, and the parties signed the contract. 
  Â In essence, CSI asserts this language, standing alone, evidences the partiesâ€™ 
  intent to seal the contract as provided by South Carolina Code section 15-3-520(b) 
  of the South Carolina Code. [1] Â  
  We disagree.
As a general rule, a 
  three-year statute of limitations applies to contract actions in South Carolina.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  Section 15-3-520 provides a twenty-year 
  statute of limitations for certain actions.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-520 (Supp. 
  2003). It is the â€œsealed instrumentâ€ provision of section 15-3-520(b) on which 
  CSI rests its hopes to avoid application of the standard statute of limitations. 
  Section 19-1-160 provides:

Whenever it shall appear from the attestation clause or from 
  any other part of any instrument in writing that it was the intention of the 
  party or parties thereto that such instrument should be a sealed instrument 
  then such instrument shall be construed to be, and shall have the effect of, 
  a sealed instrument although no seal be actually attached thereto.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-1-160 
  (1976).
The clear language of 
  section 19-1-160 imposes a statutory rule of evidence and requires that the 
  determinationâ€”of whether a non-sealed instrument should be considered a sealed 
  instrumentâ€”be gleaned from the instrument.Â  If it appears from a non-sealed 
  instrument that the parties intended for the contract to be sealed, it will 
  be deemed sealed.Â  We recognize that a non-sealed instrument may include provisions 
  and indicia that evidence an intent that the contract â€œbe construed [as] a sealed 
  instrument.â€Â  Id.Â  Two decisions of this court have found the requisite 
  intent where no seal was placed on the contract.
In Treadway v. Smith, 325 S.C. 367, 479 S.E.2d 849 (Ct. App. 1996), 
  we considered whether a non-sealed separation agreement entered into by former 
  spouses was intended to be a sealed instrument, and thus subject to the twenty-year 
  statute of limitations. [2] Â  The agreement included future, contingent 
  obligations, especially as related to Smithâ€™s responsibility for a portion of 
  the partiesâ€™ childrenâ€™s educational expenses.Â  The agreement further contained 
  the standard attestation clauseâ€”â€œIn WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have hereunto 
  set their respective Hands and Sealsâ€â€”found in many contracts.Â  Id. at 
  378, 479 S.E.2d at 855.Â  Immediately following this standard language in conspicuous 
  type, was:Â  

SIGNED SEALED AND DELIVERED 
  IN THE PRESENCE OF
[signatures of parties and witnesses]

Id.Â  We concluded that the language manifested the partiesâ€™ intent to 
  create a sealed instrument. 
We similarly construed a non-sealed instrument in South 
  Carolina Department of Social Services v. Winyah Nursing Homes, Inc., 282 
  S.C. 556, 320 S.E.2d 464 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Following the standard languageâ€”â€œthe 
  parties hereto have set their hands and sealsâ€â€”the contract noted â€œL.S.â€ adjacent 
  to the contracting partiesâ€™ signatures.Â  Id. at 561, 320 S.E.2d at 467.Â  
  The inclusion of L.S. was a significant feature in Winyah Nursing Homes, 
  for L.S. is an abbreviation for Locus sigilli, which means â€œthe 
  place of the seal; the place occupied by the seal of written instruments.â€Â  
  L.S. usually appears on documents in place of, and serves the same purpose as, 
  a seal.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary, 948 (6th ed. 1990); see 
  68 Am. Jur. 2d Seals Â§ 6 (2004) (Use of the notation â€œL.S.â€ is generally 
  held as applicable to replace a physical seal on a document).Â Â  Accordingly, 
  we found the parties intended the contract in Winyah Nursing Homes to 
  be a sealed instrument. [3] 
In the case before us, we find the parties did not intend to create 
  a sealed instrument.Â  The sophisticated parties to this lease arrangement could 
  have easily manifested an intent to create a sealed instrument if they were 
  so inclined.Â  We recognize that CSI, by necessity of the posture of the case, 
  must advance the argument that the standard attestationâ€”â€œIN WITNESS WHEREOF, 
  the parties have hereunto set their hands and seals,â€ 
  [4]  compels a finding that the parties intended to create a sealed instrument.Â  
  We further recognize, however, that such generic language is common in non-sealed 
  contracts of all types.Â  Were we to construe this boilerplate attestation clause, 
  by itself, as requiring a finding of intent to create a sealed instrument 
  in an otherwise non-sealed instrument, we would likely transform the twenty-year 
  statute of limitations into the standard period of limitations for contract 
  actions in this state.Â  We adhere to our general three-year statute of limitations 
  for most contract actions and acknowledge the availability of the twenty-year 
  limitations period where the contract clearly evidences an intent to create 
  a sealed instrument. [5] 
â€œStatutes of limitations embody important public policy considerations in that 
  they stimulate activity, punish negligence, and promote repose by giving security 
  and stability to human affairs.â€Â  Moates v. Bobb, 322 S.C. 172, 176, 
  470 S.E.2d 402, 404 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The cornerstone policy consideration underlying 
  statutes of limitations is the laudable goal of law to promote and achieve finality 
  in litigation.Â  See Webb v. Greenwood County, 229 S.C. 267, 276, 
  92 S.E.2d 688, 691 (1956); City of Myrtle Beach v. Lewis-Davis, 360 S.C. 
  225, 231, 599 S.E.2d 462, 464 (Ct. App. 2004).Â Â  Significantly, â€œ[s]tatutes 
  of limitations provide potential defendants with certainty that after a set 
  period of time, they will not be hailed [sic] into court to defend time-barred 
  claims.â€Â  In re Elkay Indus., Inc., 167 B.R. 404, 408 (D.S.C. 1994).Â  
  â€œMoreover, limitations periods discourage plaintiffs from sitting on their rights.â€Â  
  Id.Â  at 408-09.Â  Statutes of limitations are, indeed, fundamental to 
  our judicial system. 
The result we reach today, we believe, harmonizes the intent of the Legislature 
  with respect to the general three-year statute of limitations in section 15-3-530 
  with the ability of contracting parties to create sealed instruments pursuant 
  to section 19-1-160 and thereby invoke the twenty-year limitations period in 
  section 15-3-520(b). 
II.
Â CSI alternatively argues 
  that its claim against Stender remains viable notwithstanding the three-year 
  limitations period.Â  We affirm the dismissal of CSIâ€™s third party complaint 
  against Stender pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  
  Maher v. Tietex Corp., 331 S.C. 371, 376-77, 500 S.E.2d 204, 207 (Ct. 
  App. 1998) (â€œThe discovery rule determines the date of accrual for a breach 
  of contract action[,]â€ and â€œ[p]ursuant to the discovery rule, a breach of contract 
  action accrues not on the date of the breach, but rather on the date the aggrieved 
  party either discovered the breach, or could or should have discovered the breach 
  through the exercise of reasonable diligenceâ€);Â  Rumpf v. Mass. Mut. Life 
  Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 394-95, 593 S.E.2d 183, 187 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting 
  that the â€œexercise of reasonable diligenceâ€ means â€œthat the injured party must 
  act with some promptness where the facts and circumstances of an injury place 
  a reasonable person of common knowledge and experience on notice that a claim 
  against another party might existâ€); Republic Contracting Corp. v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Trans., 332 S.C. 197, 208, 503 S.E.2d 
  761, 767 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œThe statute of limitations begins to run when a plaintiff 
  knows or should know of a potential claim against another party, not when the 
  plaintiff develops a full-blown theory of recovery.â€). [6] 
CONCLUSION
We find the 
  presence of a standard attestation clauseâ€”such as, â€œIN WITNESS WHEREOF, the 
  parties have hereunto set their hands and sealsâ€â€”in an instrument which is neither 
  sealed nor required to be sealed is insufficient, standing alone, to create 
  a sealed instrument under section 19-1-160.Â  We, therefore, find the parties 
  to the December 1996, non-sealed contract did not intend to create a sealed 
  instrument.Â  Consequently, we find the claims of CSI barred by the general three-year 
  statute of limitations under section 15-3-530.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s dismissal 
  of CSIâ€™s claims against CMH and Stender is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, and BEATTY, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  CSI makes no argument that its counterclaim is timely under 
    the three-year statute of limitations.Â  

 
   [2]  The separation agreement in Treadway 
    retained its separate contractual character because it was executed prior 
    to our supreme courtâ€™s decision in Mosley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 
    306 S.E.2d 624 (1983).Â  In Mosley, the court held that jurisdiction 
    for all subsequent domestic matters, whether by decree or agreement, vested 
    in the family court.Â  Id. at 353, 306 S.E.2d at 627.Â  Mosley 
    further recognized that previously executed separation agreements which were 
    incorporated, but not merged, into a divorce decree retained their separate 
    contractual character.Â  Id.

 
   [3]  Our supreme court addressed a similar issue 
    in Cook v. Cooper, 59 S.C. 560, 38 S.E. 218 (1901), although for purposes 
    unrelated to the applicable statute of limitations.Â  In Cook, the validity 
    of a deed was at stake, and appellants argued the â€œdeed is void for the reason 
    that it is not under seal.â€Â  Id.Â  at 560, 38 S.E.2d at 219.Â  While 
    the deed lacked a seal â€œupon its face,â€ the following three features were 
    present: (1) the deed provided an attestation, â€œIn witness whereof I hereunto 
    sed [sic] my hand and seal thisâ€¦;â€ (2) immediately adjacent to the grantorâ€™s 
    signature was the word â€œseal;â€ and (3) the deed concluded with â€œSigned, Sealed 
    and Delivered in the presents [sic] of [names of witnesses].â€Â  Id.Â  
    The supreme court relied in part on the predecessor to section 19-1-160 and 
    found that a sealed instrument had been intended.

 
   [4]  The parties did not â€œsetâ€ their â€œsealsâ€ 
    on the contract, and the contract does not otherwise evidence an intent to 
    create a sealed instrument.Â  Similarly, the parties executed a hold harmless 
    agreement which contained the following attestation clause:Â  â€œWITNESS the 
    following signatures and seals.â€Â  Only signatures followed, and again, the 
    related hold harmless agreement contains no evidence the parties intended 
    to create a sealed instrument.

 
   [5]  We have previously rejected other efforts 
    to escape the barring effect of the standard three-year statute of limitations 
    for contact actions.Â  For example, in Republic Contracting Corp. v. South 
    Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Trans., 332 S.C. 197, 503 S.E.2d 
    761 (Ct. App. 1998), appellant argued the presence of â€œsealed instruments 
    because [one of the parties] placed its professional engineer seal and endorsement 
    on the plans pursuant to statutory requirement.â€Â  Id. at 205, 503 S.E. 
    at 766.Â  The suggestion that a statutorily mandated seal created a sealed 
    instrument for statute of limitations purposes was dismissed, as we held that 
    â€œ[n]othing in the text of [the statute] leads to the inference that a purpose 
    of the mandate for affixing a seal . . . is to extend the time in which an 
    action can be brought . . . .â€Â  Id. at 205-06, 503 S.E.2d at 766 (citing 
    Landmark Engâ€™g, Inc. v. Cooper, 222 Ga. App. 752, 476 S.E.2d 63 (1996)) 
    (holding that a statute requiring the stamp of a registered surveyor on certain 
    documents ensures only that the surveyor takes responsibility for the work 
    but does not allow a plaintiff to bring an action within the limitations period 
    prescribed for documents under seal).

 
   [6]  The claim of CSI against Stender is one 
    to pierce the corporate veil.Â  We recognize that an attempt to pierce the 
    corporate veil often occurs post-judgment, and the issue comes to us in somewhat 
    of an unusual posture.Â  Our summary disposition of this issueâ€”the attempted 
    application of the discovery rule to toll the commencement of the statute 
    of limitationsâ€”is simply a response to the narrow issue as framed in the circuit 
    court and on appeal.Â Â

title: Cowden Enterprises v. East Coast Millwork Distributors
description: In this appeal of a contribtution award, the court analyzes whether a national class action settlement shields a joint tortfeasor from claims for contribution under the South Carolina Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act.
text:
Cowden v. East Coast Millwork Distributors, et al.


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Cowden Enterprises, Inc., Respondent,
v.
East Coast Millwork Distributors, f/k/a Arndt and Herman Lumber Co., 
        Builders Firstsource-Southeast Group, Inc., f/k/a Pelican Companies, Inc., 
        Agee-McCoy, Inc., Senergy, Inc., Floyd B. Conner, Jr., d/b/a FBC Construction 
        Co., and J.F. Bihlear Construction, Inc., Defendants,
Of Whom Senergy, Inc. is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No.Â  3928
Heard December 14, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  24, 2005Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
D. Andrew Williams and Curtis L. Ott, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Albert A. Lachour, III, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  In this civil action, Senergy, Inc., appeals a circuit 
  court order holding it liable to Cowden Enterprises, Inc., on a claim for contribution.Â  
  We reverse.
FACTSÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Cowden Enterprises acted as general contractor on a home constructed for John 
  and Dawn Thomas in 1994.Â  In February 2000, the Thomases brought suit against 
  Cowden, alleging the home developed moisture intrusion problems as a result 
  of several flaws in the homeâ€™s exterior, including defective exterior cladding.Â  
  The faulty cladding used on the home was manufactured by Senergy, Inc., and 
  marketed as â€œEIFSâ€ (Exterior Insulation and Finish System).Â  Cowden promptly 
  settled the Thomasesâ€™ entire claim relating to the residence for $81,328 and 
  brought subsequent contribution claims against all other manufacturers, suppliers 
  and subcontractors involved in the construction of the homeâ€™s exterior, including 
  Senergy.Â  Cowden resolved its claims against all joint tortfeasors except Senergy, 
  which asserted as its defense a class action settlement that allegedly resolved 
  all claims relating to EIFS defects.Â  
In 1998, Senergy entered into a national class action settlement entitled Ruff, 
  et al. v. Parex, et al., 96 CVS 0059 (N.C. Supp. Ct. Div. 1998).Â  The Ruff 
  Settlement Agreement, approved for fairness by the North Carolina Superior Court 
  after prolonged litigation and negotiation, set forth the following definition 
  of the settlement class:

Settlement Class means 
  a class composed of all Persons who, as of the Notice Date, have owned or own 
  Property in the United States clad, in whole or in part with the Settling Defendantsâ€™ 
  EIFS.Â  

The North Carolina Special Superior Court Judge for Complex Business Cases 
  noted, in approving the national settlement class and notice plan, that he was 
  â€œparticularly attuned to the fact that this was a nationwide settlement and 
  made a special effort to see that the Notice Plan targeted homeowners in those 
  parts of the country in which [Synergy] sold [its] products.â€Â  Written notice 
  was mailed to all ascertainable settlement class members, and all were given 
  the option to â€œopt outâ€ of the class by August 1998. 
It is undisputed that the Thomases were the owners of the residence 
  on the settlementâ€™s notice date, but they neither made a claim for compensation 
  prior to the agreementâ€™s four-year cut off date, nor opted out of the settlement 
  class.Â  Accordingly, Senergy made no payments under the Ruff agreement 
  for damage to the Thomas residence.Â  Senergy nevertheless asserted at trial 
  that the settlement agreement, and its accompanying release by the entire settlement 
  class, barred Cowdenâ€™s contribution claim.Â  The parties stipulated that if Senergy 
  is not protected by the Ruff settlement agreement, the sum due to Cowden 
  as Senergyâ€™s pro-rata share of the damages is $17,500.Â  Â 
The circuit court held Senergy was not protected by the Ruff 
  settlement agreement and awarded Cowden $17,500 under its claim for contribution.Â  
  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed facts, an appellate court 
  is free to review whether the trial court properly applied the law to those 
  facts.Â  WDW Prop. v. City of Sumter, 342 S.C. 6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 631, 
  632 (2000).Â  In such cases, the appellate court is not required to defer to 
  the trial courtâ€™s legal conclusions.Â  Scott v. Brunson, 351 S.C. 313, 
  316, 569 S.E.2d 385, 387 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Senergy argues the circuit court erred in finding it was not protected 
  from contribution claims arising from alleged EIFS defects by the Ruff 
  settlement agreement. Â We agree.
Since no right to contribution among joint tortfeasors existed in South Carolina 
  common law, Cowdenâ€™s claim arises solely under the South Carolina Contribution 
  Among Tortfeasors Act (â€œthe Actâ€), S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-38-10 to -70 (Supp. 
  2003).Â  See M&T Chemicals, Inc. v. Barker Indus., Inc., 296 
  S.C. 103, 106, 370 S.E.2d 886, 888 (Ct. App. 1988) (reluctantly finding no common 
  law right to contribution in South Carolina prior to the Actâ€™s 1988 enactment).Â  
  â€œBecause the Act is in derogation of the common law, it must be strictly construed.â€ 
  G & P Trucking v. Parks Auto Sales Serv. & Salvage, Inc., 357 
  S.C. 82, 87, 591 S.E.2d 42, 44 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Cowdenâ€™s only claim against 
  Senergy is for contribution and, accordingly, may only succeed if it meets the 
  strictly construed requirements set forth in the Act.
According to the Act, where two or more persons become jointly or 
  severally liable in tort for the same injury to property, a right of contribution 
  arises among them, even if judgment has not been recovered against all or any 
  of them.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-20(A) (Supp. 2003); Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, 
  Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 68, 518 S.E.2d 301, 309 (Ct. 
  App. 1999).Â  In these situations, the right of contribution exists only in favor 
  of a tortfeasor who, like Cowden, has paid more than his pro rata share of the 
  common liability.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-20(B) (Supp. 2003); Vermeer, 
  336 S.C. at 68, 518 S.E.2d at 309.Â  This right to contribution, however, is 
  subject to certain limitations set forth in the Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-20(A) 
  (Supp. 2003). 
One such limitation is laid out in section 15-38-50, which reads, 
  â€œ[w]hen a release . . . is given in good faith to one of two or more persons 
  liable in tort for the same injury . . . (2) it discharges the tortfeasor to 
  whom it is given from all liability for contribution to any other tortfeasor.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-50 (Supp. 2003).Â  The plain language of this limitation 
  on contribution yields only one interpretation, namely that once a joint tortfeasor 
  obtains a release from a plaintiff, he is no longer liable for contribution 
  claims arising from injuries subject to that release. [1] Â  See South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank v. 
  Stone, 749 F. Supp. 1419, 1430 (D.S.C. 1990) (â€œ[A] Settling Defendant is 
  insulated from later contribution claims by co-tortfeasors if he obtains a good 
  faith release . . . from the Plaintiff.â€); see also Restatement 
  Third, Torts: Apportionment of Liability, Â§ 23(a) (2000) (â€œ[When one joint tortfeasor 
  discharges the liability of another], the person discharging the liability is 
  entitled to recover contribution from the other, unless the other previously 
  had a valid settlement and release from the plaintiff.â€ (emphasis added)).Â  

As previously noted, the Thomases were the owners of record on the 
  notice date for the national class action settlement and did not opt out of 
  the settlement class.Â  In its order approving the Ruff agreement, the 
  North Carolina Court stated the following:

â€œAll persons falling within the definition of the Settlement Class who did not 
  timely and validly request exclusion . . . are Settlement Class Members and 
  are bound by Settlement Agreement, the settlement and releases contained 
  therein, and the Final Order and Judgment, and do not have any further opportunity 
  to opt out of the settlement class.â€

Ruff, et al. v. Parex, et al., 96 CVS 0059 (N.C. Supp. Ct. Div. 1998).Â  
  The Ruff agreement states, under the heading Releases and Assignments, 
  â€œeach settlement class member . . . does hereby release and forever discharge 
  [Senergy] . . . from any and all Settled Claims . . . [e]ach Releasing Party, 
  upon entry of the Final Order and Judgment . . . shall be deemed to and hereby 
  does release and discharge [Senergy] of and from any and all Settled Claims.â€Â  
  Furthermore, the court specifically found â€œthe parties have reached accord with 
  respect to a Settlement that provides substantial benefits to Settlement Class 
  Members, in return for a release and dismissal of the claims . . . .â€ 
  Id. (emphasis added).Â  Under the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the 
  United States Constitution, we may not disregard the judicial proceedings of 
  the North Carolina Court, even as they relate to a national class action lawsuit.Â  
  U.S. Const. Art. IV, Â§ 1; See Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co. v. Epstein, 
  516 U.S. 367, 374 (1996) (â€œ[A] judgment entered in a class action, like any 
  other judgment entered in a state judicial proceeding, is presumptively entitled 
  to full faith and credit.â€); Hospitality Management Assoc., Inc. v. Shell 
  Oil Co., 356 S.C. 644, 591 S.E.2d 611 (2004) (granting full faith and credit 
  to two nationwide class action settlements from other state courts as they apply 
  to local members of the national settling classes).Â  We therefore conclude the 
  Thomases, as settlement class members, were bound by the terms of the national 
  class action settlement granting Senergy a release from liability.
Cowden puts much stake in the fact that builders and contractors 
  were expressly excluded as members of the settlement class by the terms of the 
  Ruff settlement agreement.Â  We are not swayed by its arguments based 
  on this exclusion.Â  The fact that Cowden and other contractors were excluded 
  from filing claims under the settlement in no way alters the unambiguous release 
  granted to Senergy by the terms of the Ruff settlement.Â  Cowdenâ€™s claim 
  arises under a statutory contribution scheme which this court is bound to strictly 
  follow.Â  While we recognize the unfortunate outcome the Act demands in this 
  case, we nevertheless conclude Senergy received a good faith release from the 
  Thomases under the Ruff settlement prior to Cowdenâ€™s payment of the entire 
  claim. Senergy, therefore, is insulated from Cowdenâ€™s contribution claim under 
  Section 15-38-50(2) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003).
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is
 REVERSED.
 HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

 
   [1]  Cowden asserts on appeal that subsection (1) of 
    section 15-38-50 requires an actual monetary payment to the plaintiff by the 
    party asserting a release in order for that release to insulate them from 
    contribution claims.Â  As subsection (1) refers only to liability of other 
    joint tortfeasors following a valid release by one jointly liable party, we 
    do not adopt Cowdenâ€™s interpretation.Â Â  Although subsection (1) does outline 
    a setoff Cowden was possibly entitled to assert against the Thomases, it does 
    not speak to the contribution liability of Senergy, the party asserting the 
    defense of a good faith release. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-38-50(1) (Supp. 
    2003) (â€œ[When a release is given to a joint tortfeasor,] it does not discharge 
    any of the other tortfeasors from liability for the injury . . . but it reduces 
    the claim against the others to the extent of any amount stipulated by the 
    release . . . or in the amount of the consideration paid for it, whichever 
    is the greater.â€).

title: Coakley v. Horace Mann Insurance Co.
description: In this appeal from a declaratory judgment action, Horace Mann Insurance Co. argues the trial court erred in finding coverage under three different automobile policies.
text:
Coakley v. Horace Mann Insurance Company


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
J. Samuel Coakley, individually and as Trustee of a Special Needs Trust 
        for Christian Coakley, Respondent,
v.
Horace Mann Insurance Co., Scott Andrew Mitchell, Christopher N. Mitchell 
        and Claudia Dee Dee Mitchell, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3929
Heard November 17, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Phillip E. Reeves, and 
  Jennifer D. Eubanks, both of Greenville, for Appellants.
Benjamin C. Harrison, and David H. Tyner, both of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Respondent filed this declaratory judgment action to determine 
  the applicability of certain automobile liability policies issued by Horace 
  Mann Insurance Company (Horace Mann).Â  The circuit court found coverage under 
  all three policies.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On August 19, 1994, sixteen-year-old Christian Coakley was 
  a passenger in a car being driven by seventeen-year-old Scott Andrew Mitchell.Â  
  As they were traveling towards a friendâ€™s house, Scott lost control and the 
  car slammed into a tree.Â  The force of the impact shattered a vertebra in Christianâ€™s 
  neck, partially severing his spinal cord.Â  As a result of these injuries, Christian 
  is a permanent quadriplegic.Â  
The automobile, a 1984 Mazda RX-7, belonged to Scottâ€™s older 
  brother Christopher Mitchell and was titled in Christopherâ€™s name.Â  Christopher, 
  a student at Clemson University, resided in an apartment in Clemson, normally 
  kept the car with him, and was its primary user.  [1] Â  Prior to the accident, Christopher went on 
  a trip to California and left the car at his motherâ€™s house.Â  Christopher was 
  on the way back from California when the accident occurred.Â  Scott was a high 
  school student and lived with his mother in Spartanburg, South Carolina. [2] Â  Claudia â€œDee Deeâ€ Mitchell, Scott and Christopherâ€™s 
  mother, testified in her deposition that Scott had permission to use the car.Â  

The car was insured through Horace Mann, with Dee Dee being 
  the named insured.Â  The policy provided liability limits of $50,000.00 for personal 
  injury.Â  Dee Dee also maintained policies on three other vehicles.Â  Two of these 
  policies carry liability limits of $50,000.00, and the third has a liability 
  limit of $250,000.00.Â  None of these other policies provided primary coverage 
  for the vehicle involved in the accident.Â Â Â  
The special needs trust (the Trust) created on behalf of 
  Christian commenced this action seeking compensation for Christianâ€™s injuries. [3] Â  The Trust sought recovery under 
  the policy covering the RX-7, as well as excess coverage under the policies 
  on the other three cars.Â  Horace Mann initially denied liability, but following 
  discovery, the parties entered into a covenant not to execute.Â  Pursuant to 
  the covenant, Horace Mann paid out the liability limits on the policy covering 
  the RX-7.Â  The covenant also allowed the Trust to bring a declaratory judgment 
  action to determine the applicability of the three additional policies.Â  In 
  exchange for permission to bring the action, the Trust agreed that recovery, 
  if any, would be limited to $350,000.00â€”the combined total of the three policies.Â  

The Trust then filed this declaratory judgment action alleging 
  that although the other policies do not provide primary coverage on the RX-7, 
  they provide excess coverage for â€œnon-ownedâ€ vehicles.Â  The Trust argued the 
  RX-7 was a non-owned vehicle because Christopher owned the car and was not a 
  relative within the meaning of the policies.Â  
The parties agreed to transfer the litigation to a non-jury 
  docket and the case was submitted upon memoranda of authority, copies of the 
  policies in dispute, and the deposition testimony of the Mitchell defendants.Â  
  On March 5, 2003, the trial court issued its order, in which it found excess 
  liability coverage was available to Christian under all three policies.Â  Accordingly, 
  judgment was entered in the amount of $350,000.00.Â  Horace Mann, Scott, Christopher, 
  and Dee Dee (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€) have appealed from that Order.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A declaratory judgment action to determine coverage under an automobile 
  liability policy is an action at law.Â  Travelers Indem. Co. v. Auto World 
  of Orangeburg, Inc., 334 S.C. 137, 140, 511 S.E.2d 692, 694 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
  In an action at law tried by a judge without a jury, the judgeâ€™s findings will 
  not be disturbed on appeal unless no reasonable evidence supports the judgeâ€™s 
  conclusions.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 
  86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  Since Appellants have admitted that no facts 
  are in dispute in this case, this court can review conclusions of law based 
  on those facts.Â  Midland Guardian Co. v. Thacker, 280 S.C. 563, 568, 
  314 S.E.2d 26, 29 (Ct. App. 1984).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. The Insurance Policy
â€œInsurance policies are subject to general rules of contract construction.â€Â  
  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Calcutt, 340 S.C. 231, 234, 530 S.E.2d 
  896, 897 (Ct. App. 2000) (citations omitted).Â  Accordingly, courts â€œshould give 
  policy language its plain, ordinary and popular meaning.â€Â  Id.Â  Furthermore, 
  courts should not rewrite policy language or torture its meaning to extend coverage 
  never intended by the parties.Â  Torrington Co. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 
  264 S.C. 636, 643, 216 S.E.2d 547, 550 (1975).Â  When an insurance contract is 
  unambiguous, clear, and explicit, it must be construed according to the terms 
  the parties have used.Â  Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders, Inc., 
  348 S.C. 559, 565, 561 S.E.2d 355, 358 (2002).Â  However, â€œ[a]mbiguous or conflicting 
  terms in an insurance policy must be construed liberally in favor of the insured 
  and strictly against the insurer.â€Â  Stewart v. State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. 
  Co., 341 S.C. 143, 151, 533 S.E.2d 597, 601 (Ct. App. 2000).
In the instant case, all four Horace Mann policies issued to Dee Dee Mitchell 
  contain identical policy language.Â  The policies extend liability coverage to 
  payment of damages which an insured becomes legally liable to pay because of 
  bodily injury to others caused by or resulting from the ownership, maintenance 
  or use of the covered vehicle.Â  Scott is an â€œinsuredâ€ under the policy because 
  he is a relative of Dee Dee.Â  
The policies also extend 
  liability coverage to the use of other cars by an insured.Â  The pertinent language 
  provides as follows:Â  â€œBodily Injury and Property Damage Liability coverages 
  extend to the use, by an insured, of . . .Â  a non-owned car while being used 
  with the permission of the owner.â€Â  (emphasis omitted).Â  The policies further 
  provide that if there is other coverage, the applicable policy will be excess:Â  
  â€œIf an insured is using a . . .Â  non-owned car, our liability insurance will 
  be excess over other collectible insurance.â€Â  (emphasis omitted). 
The definition of â€œnon-owned carâ€ has been replaced by an amendatory endorsement.Â  
  As amended, the definition provides as follows:
Non-owned car means a private passenger car . . . not:

  
    
    
      
         1.  
         
  owned by;
      
      
         2. 
         
  registered in the name of; or
      
      
         3.   
         furnished or available for the regular use of you or your relatives.Â  The use 
  must be within the scope of consent of the owner or person in lawful possession 
  of it.
      
    
    
  

The policies define â€œrelativeâ€ as follows:Â  â€œRelative means a person related 
  to you by blood, marriage or adoption who lives with you.Â  It includes your 
  unmarried and dependent child who is away at school.â€Â  (emphasis omitted). 
Horace Mann has conceded liability on the liability policy covering the RX-7 
  and tendered the limits on that policy.Â  The other three policies do not cover 
  the RX-7, but they do cover non-owned vehicles.Â  These policies specifically 
  provide that if there is other coverage on a non-owned vehicle, they provide 
  excess coverage.Â  The heart of the issue is whether the RX-7 was a non-owned 
  vehicle, and that question turns on whether Christopher owned the car or was 
  a relative within the meaning of the policy.
II. Ownership of the Car
Appellants first argue the RX-7 could not have been a non-owned car because 
  Dee Dee Mitchell, not Christopher, was the owner of the vehicle.Â  The trial 
  court found Christopher owned the car and this finding will not be disturbed 
  on appeal unless no reasonable evidence supports the courtâ€™s conclusions.Â  Townes, 
  266 S.C. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 775.Â  We note that Scott, Dee Dee, and Christopher 
  admitted in their Answer that Christopher owned the RX-7.Â  The Covenant Not 
  to Execute also states that Christopher is the owner.Â  Appellants assert in 
  their brief that the facts in this case are not in dispute and Dee Dee testified 
  that the car is titled in Christopherâ€™s name.Â  Therefore, we find sufficient 
  evidence in the record to sustain the trial courtâ€™s finding that Christopher 
  owned the car, not Dee Dee Mitchell.
III. Status of Christopher in Relation 
  to Dee Dee Mitchell
Since the RX-7 was not â€œowned byâ€ or â€œregistered in the name ofâ€ Dee Dee Mitchell, 
  the named insured, the car could only be a non-owned vehicle if it was not â€œfurnished 
  or available for the regular use ofâ€ Dee Dee Mitchell or her â€œrelatives.â€Â  It 
  is undisputed that the RX-7 was not available for the regular use of Scott at 
  the time of the accident.Â  Additionally, the trial court found, and Appellants 
  have not disputed, that the car was not available for the regular use of Dee 
  Dee at the time of the accident.Â  Therefore, the car qualifies as a non-owned 
  vehicle unless Christopher was a relative of Dee Dee under the policies.
The determination of resident relative status is a question of fact.Â  Auto 
  Owners Ins. Co. v. Langford, 330 S.C. 578, 581, 500 S.E.2d 496, 497 (Ct. 
  App. 1998).Â  The trial court found that Christopher did not reside with Dee 
  Dee, nor was he dependent on her at the time of the accident.Â  This finding 
  must be affirmed unless no evidence reasonably supports it.Â  Townes, 
  266 S.C. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 775.
Christopher qualifies as a relative under the policy if he is (1) â€œrelated 
  toâ€ her and (2) â€œlives withâ€ her.Â  The first prong of the test is easily satisfied.Â  
  Christopher is Dee Deeâ€™s son.Â  Therefore, he is related to her by blood.Â  The 
  second prong, whether Christopher â€œlives withâ€ Dee Dee, contains an additional 
  qualification.Â  He is deemed to live with her if he is her â€œunmarried and dependent 
  child who is away at school.â€Â  Christopher was not married and was â€œaway at 
  school.â€Â  At issue, then, is whether Christopher was a â€œdependent childâ€ of 
  Dee Dee at the time the accident occurred.Â  
Although there is evidence in the record which would support an inference that 
  Christopher was dependent on his mother, there is also evidence to support the 
  trial courtâ€™s finding that â€œif [Christopher] were dependent on either of his 
  parents, it was the father to whom he was dependent.â€ [4] Â  For instance, although Dee Dee testified in her deposition 
  that she provided some financial support to Christopher, such as money for groceries, 
  gas, and insurance, she also admitted that Christopherâ€™s father paid the majority 
  of his tuition.Â  Christopher explained that his father provided him with a lump 
  sum payment of $3500.00 every semester for tuition and living expenses.Â  
Some of the testimony in this regard was conflicting.Â  Dee Dee testified that 
  she and Christopherâ€™s father paid for Christopherâ€™s rent while he was living 
  in an apartment in Clemson.Â  Christopher, however, testified he did not receive 
  income, help with tuition, or rent money from Dee Dee.Â  Christopher stated that 
  his father paid for these expenses.Â  Similarly, although Dee Dee testified she 
  paid for gasoline and repairs on Christopherâ€™s car, Christopher testified that 
  he paid these expenses.Â  When conflicting testimony is presented, the trial 
  court is in a better position to determine credibility.Â  See Epperly 
  v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 414, 440 S.E.2d 884, 885-886 (1994).Â  Therefore, 
  we find there is evidence which supports the trial courtâ€™s ruling that Christopher 
  was not a dependent of Dee Dee. [5] 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The trial courtâ€™s ruling that Christopher did not â€œlive withâ€ Dee Dee is supported 
  by our case law.Â  The residency test in South Carolina is found in Buddin 
  v. Nationwide Mutual Ins. Co., 250 S.C. 332, 157 S.E.2d 633 (1967).Â  In 
  Buddin, the supreme court noted that a â€œresident of the same household 
  is one, other than a temporary or transient visitor, who lives together with 
  others in the same house for a period of some duration, although he may not 
  intend to remain there permanently.â€Â  Id. at 339, 157 S.E.2d at 636 (citations 
  omitted).Â  Because Christopher did not live in the same household as Dee Dee, 
  he would not qualify as a resident relative under this test.Â  Several cases 
  have elaborated on the Buddin test, but none of them would have found 
  Christopher to reside with Dee Dee. 
  [6] Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding that he was not her 
  dependent, and he did not live with her for purposes of the policies.
Because there is evidence in the record to support its conclusion, we agree 
  with the trial court that the RX-7 was a â€œnon-owned carâ€ within the meaning 
  of the policies.Â  It is undisputed that upon such a finding, the other three 
  policies become applicable as excess coverage.Â  Thus, the only remaining issue 
  is the amount of coverage.Â  
IV. Amount of Coverage
The trial court found that all three policies applied and could be stacked.Â  
  The general rule is that stacking of liability coverage is permitted unless 
  limited by statute or by a valid policy provision.Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. 
  Ins. Co. v. Moorer, 330 S.C. 46, 60, 496 S.E.2d 875, 883 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
  A policy provision that purports to limit stacking of statutorily required coverage 
  is invalid.Â  Id.Â  Although liability coverage is required, non-owned 
  vehicle coverage is not and, therefore, may be limited by contract.Â  Id.Â  
  Therefore, the question is whether the policy language effectively prohibited 
  stacking.
The trial court based its ruling on a plain reading of the policy provisions 
  located in the amendatory endorsements under the heading â€œIf There is Other 
  Coverageâ€ reproduced below:

  
    
    
      
         1.  
         
  Policies Issued by Us to You
      
      
        If two or more vehicle liability policies issued by us 
  to you apply to the same accident, the total limits of liability 
  under all such policies shall not exceed that of the policy with the highest 
  limit of liability.
      
      
         2.
         
  Other Liability Coverage Available From Other Sources
      
      
        Subject to item 1, if other vehicle liability coverage applies, 
  we are liable only for our share of the damages.Â  
  Our share is the percent that the limit of liability of this policy 
  bears to the total of all vehicle liability coverage applicable to the accident.
      
      
        3.    
        Temporary Substitute Car, Non-Owned Car, Trailer 
      
      
        If a temporary substitute car, a non-owned car or 
  a trailer designed for use with a private passenger car 
  or utility vehicle has other vehicle liability coverage on it, 
  then this coverage is excess.Â 
      
    
    
  

(emphasis in original).Â  
Specifically, the trial court found these provisions clearly and unambiguously 
  provided excess coverage for non-owned vehicles.Â  In so ruling, the trial court 
  read paragraph three as being independent of the limitation contained in paragraph 
  one.Â  The court reasoned that if the drafters of the policy intended the limitations 
  of paragraph one to apply to paragraph three, they would have expressly included 
  the limitation, or some reference to it, in paragraph three.Â  Alternatively, 
  the trial court held that if it was possible to read paragraph one as qualifying 
  paragraph three, then it was just as reasonable to read paragraph three as qualifying 
  paragraph one.Â  Thus, the court reasoned that when an insurance policy is ambiguous 
  it must be construed in a light most favorable to the insured.Â  Accordingly, 
  the trial court held that the policies provided liability coverage for Scott 
  in the amount of $350,000.Â  
Appellants, on the other hand, argue that the limitation of paragraph one qualifies 
  the non-owned coverage provided by paragraph three.Â  According to the Appellants, 
  even if the trial court found the policies provided excess coverage, because 
  Horace Mann issued all three policies to Dee Dee, coverage should have been 
  limited to the policy with the highest limit or $250,000.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note this court considered similar policy language in Moorer 
  and found in that case it effectively prohibited stacking of non-owned coverage.Â  
  However, while the policy language in Moorer is identical to that in 
  the current policies, there are a number of significant differences in the two 
  cases.Â  Id. at 59, 496 S.E.2d at 882.Â  For instance, in Moorer, 
  only the first and third paragraphs are excerpted.Â  In addition, the heading 
  of the third paragraph, while couched in the same language as the current policies, 
  is neither bolded nor italicized as it is in the policies under consideration.Â  
  Id.
We find these differences make the cases distinguishable.Â  As the trial court 
  noted, the second paragraph concerning â€œOther Liability Coverageâ€ specifically 
  references the limitation of paragraph one.Â  Thus reading the provisions together 
  one could easily come to the conclusion that because paragraph two references 
  the limitation and paragraph three does not, paragraph three is not subject 
  to the limitation.Â  In addition, because the heading of paragraph three in the 
  current case is in bold print and italicized, it supports the trial courtâ€™s 
  interpretation that it is intentionally set off from the other provisions and 
  meant to be read as existing independently.Â  Accordingly, we agree with the 
  trial courtâ€™s interpretation of the policies.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find sufficient evidence in the record 
  to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the additional policies provided excess 
  coverage for Christianâ€™s injuries.Â Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s ruling is
 AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY, J., concurs.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
HEARN, C.J., dissents in a separate opinion.
 HEARN, C.J., dissenting:Â  I respectfully dissent 
  and would hold that Christopher was a resident relative of his mother at the 
  time of the accident.
The majorityâ€™s decision to affirm is largely driven by our 
  standard of review in a law case, i.e. whether there is any evidence to support 
  the trial judgeâ€™s decision.Â  While I agree there is evidence supporting the 
  trial judgeâ€™s decision that Christopher was dependant on his father, I would 
  hold the trial judge erred in not finding him dependant on his mother as well.Â  

The uncontroverted evidence reflects that 
  at the time of the accident in 1994, Christopher was a student at Clemson who 
  relied on both his mother and father for financial support.Â  Specifically, the 
  record demonstrates that his mother contributed to his rent and was a guarantor 
  on his lease.Â  Although Christopher testified his father gave him a lump sum 
  of money each semester for his tuition, the record also clearly shows that his 
  mother contributed toward his tuition, groceries, and automobile expenses.Â  
  In fact, Christopher testified that he had no idea about the insurance on his 
  vehicle because he simply didnâ€™t â€œhandle that.â€Â  His mother testified without 
  contradiction that she paid the premium on Christopherâ€™s car insurance.Â  She 
  also paid the property taxes on the vehicle, claimed Christopher as a dependent 
  on her tax returns, and maintained a room for him in her home.Â  Christopher 
  received his mail at her address and came home approximately every two weeks 
  while he was at Clemson to do his laundry.Â  Christopher testified that he had 
  not stayed in his fatherâ€™s home overnight since 1992.Â  
Although I believe the record actually shows that Christopher 
  was more dependent on his mother than on his father, I recognized there is some 
  evidence, albeit slight, to support the trial judgeâ€™s decision that Christopher 
  may have been more financially dependent on his father than on his mother.Â  
  Nevertheless, it is simply irrelevant that Christopher may have been more dependent 
  on one parent than the other.Â  In either case, he still qualifies as a resident 
  relative under the plain and ordinary language of the policy.Â  The policy at 
  issue defines relative thusly:Â  â€œRelative means a person related to you by blood, 
  marriage or adoption who lives with you.Â  It includes your unmarried and dependent 
  child who is away at school.â€Â  In my view, Christopher falls squarely within 
  this definition of resident relative.Â  
To the extent the trial judge interpreted the policy provision 
  to mean that Christopher could only be dependent upon one of his parents and 
  found he was not dependent upon his mother, he erred as a matter of law.Â  Thus, 
  I would reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision that Christopher was not his motherâ€™s 
  resident relative.Â  

 
   [1]  Horace Mann contested ownership of the RX-7, but 
    the Answer filed on behalf of Scott, Christopher, and Dee Dee in the underlying 
    litigation admits that Christopher owned the car.Â  

 
   [2]  Scott and Christopherâ€™s parents divorced in the 
    1980â€™s.

 
   [3]  By Order dated July 28, 1998, the court established 
    a Supplemental Needs Trust for Christian to receive funds to assist him with 
    his extraordinary care needs.Â  

 
   [4] Â  The dissent bases its opinion largely on its 
    interpretation of the trial courtâ€™s order and this statement in particular.Â  
    The dissent believes the trial court â€œinterpreted the policy provision to 
    mean that Christopher could only be dependent on one of his parentsâ€ and, 
    therefore, erred as a matter of law.Â  We do not believe the trial court made 
    such a finding.Â  When considering the trial courtâ€™s treatment of this issue 
    as a whole, we believe it found Christopher was not dependent on either of 
    his parents.Â  The trial courtâ€™s statement simply asserts that if he were dependent 
    on either of the parents, it would be the father.Â Â Â  

 
   [5]  Appellants also make much of the fact that Dee 
    Dee listed Christopher as a dependent on her income tax return the year of 
    the accident.Â  However, as the trial court noted, she has claimed both children 
    as dependents on her income taxes since she and their father divorced in the 
    1980s, as she was permitted to do by court order.Â  Such an order issued in 
    relation to a divorce proceeding does not amount to a determination of dependency.Â  
  

 
   [6]  See Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Langford, 
    330 S.C. 578, 500 S.E.2d 496 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding that a granddaughter 
    was not a resident relative with her grandmother where she usually lived with 
    her mother, and only stayed with her grandmother when she and her mother fought); 
    Richardson v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 233, 519 S.E.2d 
    120 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding that a daughter was not a resident relative of 
    her parentsâ€™ household where she had moved away as a graduate student several 
    years before, maintained her own residence in another town and only kept a 
    few items at her parentsâ€™ home); Auto-Owners Ins. Co. v. Horne, 356 
    S.C. 52, 586 S.E.2d 865 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding that a daughter was not a 
    resident-relative of her father, the non-custodial parent, for purposes of 
    stacking UIM coverage where she lived with her mother in Conway and only occasionally 
    visited her father in Saluda).
