title: Lenz v. Walsh
description: James L. Walsh and Martha L. Walsh appeal from an order denying them recovery on their counterclaims against William A. Lenz, an unlicensed residential builder.  On appeal, they argue the master-in-equity's order effectively violates the South Carolina statute that prohibits an unlicensed residential builder from enforcing a construction contract.
text:
Lenz v. Walsh


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
William A. Lenz, Respondent,
v.
James L. Walsh, individually and as Trustee of the James L. Walsh Revocable 
        Trust, and Marsha L. Walsh, individually and as Trustee of the Marsha 
        L. Walsh Revocable Trust, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â Ralph F. Cothran, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 3930
Heard December 14, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles Craig Young, of Florence, and J. Calhoun Land, IV, of Manning, for Appellants.
Marvin E. McMillan, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  James L. Walsh and Marsha L. Walsh appeal from the masterâ€™s 
  ruling denying them recovery on their counterclaims against William A. Lenz, 
  an unlicensed residential builder who was hired to construct their home.Â  The 
  Walshes contend the master erred in finding they could not recover on their 
  counterclaims because they failed to prove damages in excess of the amount of 
  the final unpaid draw due Lenz under the contract.Â  They argue the masterâ€™s 
  finding effectively violates the South Carolina statute that prohibits an unlicensed 
  residential builder from enforcing a construction contract.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On March 30, 1996, the Walshes entered into a contract with Lenz 
  to construct their home in the Wyboo Plantation subdivision of Manning, South 
  Carolina.Â  Lenz signed the document listing himself as the â€œcontractor.â€Â  The 
  contract price was $120,960.00, with payments to be made in regular installments 
  or â€œdraws.â€Â  The house was to be constructed according to plans and specifications 
  attached to the contract.Â  Lenz granted the Walshes allowances for the purchase 
  of certain items used in construction of the home, such as cabinets, flooring, 
  countertops, and appliances.Â  The Walshes were responsible for paying any amount 
  over the stated allowance.Â  All other materials were included in the contract 
  price.Â Â Â  
Lenz obtained a building permit on April 10, 1996 and began construction 
  on the home.Â  During construction, the Walshes made changes in some of the materials 
  for the home and often purchased items themselves without going through Lenz.Â  
  Some of the materials the Walshes purchased, such as plumbing fixtures, light 
  fixtures, and cabinets, were provided for either as part of the contract price 
  or as a stated allowance.Â  Lenz and the Walshes had some disagreements, and 
  Lenz eventually halted construction after the Walshes failed to pay the amount 
  he requested in a June 1997 letter for overages incurred for additional work 
  and materials.Â  The Walshes never paid the fifth and final draw of $18,000.00 
  due on the contract.Â  The Walshes prohibited Lenz from coming on the property 
  when the house was approximately ninety-five percent complete.Â  The Walshes 
  thereafter spent $2,792.65 on labor and $1,267.91 on materials to complete the 
  house.Â  
In August 1997, Lenz filed a notice for a mechanicâ€™s lien and a complaint 
  for foreclosure of the lien and breach of contract.Â  Lenz sought $14,377.58 
  for unpaid amounts due for construction of the home.Â Â Â  
The Walshes answered, denying any amount was due, and counterclaimed for damages 
  for breach of contract, fraud, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  
  They sought to recover amounts they personally expended for the construction 
  of the house and also sought damages for alleged delays in construction.Â Â Â  

The Walshes subsequently moved for summary judgment as to Lenzâ€™s complaint 
  on the ground he was not a licensed residential builder as required by the South 
  Carolina Code and was, therefore, statutorily prohibited from enforcing the 
  contract.Â  By order filed March 22, 1999, circuit court Judge Howard P. King 
  granted the Walshesâ€™ motion and held Lenz was prohibited by then-section 40-59-130 
  of the South Carolina Code [1]  
  from pursuing any claim against the Walshes on the contract because he was not 
  a licensed residential builder when he entered the contract.Â Â Â  
The case was thereafter referred to a master-in-equity, Ralph F. 
  Cothran, who held a hearing and thereafter concluded in an order dated January 
  22, 2002 that the Walshes were not entitled to recover on any of their counterclaims.Â Â Â Â Â  

The master found Lenz had provided labor and materials in the amount of $13,695.58 
  that remained unpaid.Â  He also noted there was no dispute concerning the Walshesâ€™ 
  failure to pay the $18,000.00 final draw due on the contract.Â  Because the Walshes 
  refused to allow Lenz to complete the house, the master prohibited the Walshes 
  from recovering the amounts they paid for labor and materials to complete construction.Â  
  The master further found many of the items the Walshes purchased were provided 
  for as allowances in the contract or were items outside the contract that they 
  voluntarily purchased.Â  The master concluded â€œ[t]hat the damages alleged and 
  proven by the [Walshes] do not exceed the unpaid amount of the final draw in 
  the amount of $18,000.00 and the [Walshes] therefore are not entitled to any 
  recovery on their counterclaim.â€Â  The Walshes filed a motion to alter or amend 
  the judgment, which was denied.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, the Walshes contend the master erred in finding they are 
  not entitled to recover on their counterclaims because any damages they sustained 
  did not exceed the final payment of $18,000.00.Â  They argue this finding effectively 
  allows Lenz to recover under the contract in violation of South Carolina statutory 
  law that prohibits an unlicensed residential builder from enforcing a construction 
  contract.Â  We disagree.
Former section 40-59-130 proscribed an unlicensed residential builder from 
  enforcing a construction contract.Â  The statute provided in relevant part as 
  follows:

Any residential builder or residential specialty contractor who undertakes or 
  attempts to undertake the business of residential building or residential specialty 
  contracting without first having procured a valid license or registered with 
  the commission as required . . . is guilty of a misdemeanor . . . . 
A residential builder who does not have a license or residential specialty contractor 
  who is not registered as required may not bring any action either at law 
  or in equity to enforce the provisions of any contract for residential building 
  or residential specialty contracting which he entered into in violation 
  of this chapter. [2] 

South Carolina courts have held that, pursuant to the statute, a 
  builder who is not licensed at the time he enters into a contract for residential 
  construction may not bring an action to enforce the provisions of the contract. 
  [3] Â  The purpose of the statute is to protect homeowners. 
  [4] Â  Our supreme court has stated that, because the statute is plain and 
  unambiguous, it should be applied literally; thus, where a builder has no license, 
  he may not enforce the contract. [5] 
  Â  
Although our courts have decided the aforementioned cases involving 
  attempts by unlicensed contractors to enforce residential construction contracts, 
  this state has never addressed whether a homeowner may recover payments made 
  to an unlicensed builder under a residential construction contract.Â  North Carolina 
  has considered the question, however, and held in Hawkins v. Holland [6]  that such payments are not recoverable.Â Â Â  

In a case of first impression involving the consolidation of several suits 
  presenting the same issue, the Court of Appeals of North Carolina observed in 
  Hawkins that the grounds for the holdings in other jurisdictions are 
  (1) the statutes requiring licenses do not specifically authorize the recovery 
  of money paid; (2) such laws are penal in nature and must be strictly construed; 
  (3) the specification of particular penalties precludes the addition of other 
  penalties by judicial interpretation; (4) allowing the recovery of such payments 
  is not necessary to effectuate the policy of licensing statutes; and (5) equity 
  and the principles of restitution do not require that unlicensed contractors 
  be completely uncompensated or that contracting homeowners receive the completed 
  construction without cost. [7] Â Â Â  
South Carolina case law provides support for the same reasoning. 
  [8] Â Â Â  We, therefore, find Hawkins persuasive and agree with its 
  determination that, generally, a homeowner may not recover payments already 
  made to an unlicensed contractor merely because the contractor did not hold 
  a license when the contract was executed.
In the current appeal, it is undisputed that Lenz may not bring an action to 
  enforce the contract pursuant to former section 40-59-130 since he was not licensed 
  at the time the contract was entered into.Â  At issue now is the Walshesâ€™ counterclaims.Â  
  The Walshes argue the masterâ€™s ruling that they could not recover on their counterclaims 
  because they failed to prove damages in excess of the final unpaid draw effectively 
  allows Lenz to bring an action to enforce the contract in contravention of the 
  statute.Â  
We hold this situation is analogous to Hawkins, wherein the homeowners 
  were seeking reimbursement for payments previously made.Â  The Walshes voluntarily 
  paid for many items that were either outside the contract or were to be purchased 
  by the builder under the contract.Â  Regardless of whether they paid for these 
  items out of pocket or paid the builder a draw under the contract, the sums 
  spent by the Walshes went towards materials provided for in the contract and 
  those used in construction of the house.Â  Allowing the Walshes to recover these 
  sums would be indistinguishable from allowing them to recover money paid directly 
  to the builder to purchase construction materials.Â  Consequently, the decision 
  of the master is
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and WILLIAMS, J., concur.

 
   [1] Â All references in this opinion are to former 
    section 40-59-130, which at the time of the courtâ€™s order was codified at 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-59-130 (Supp. 1999).Â  Section 40-59-130 has since been 
    amended and recodified by 2002 Act No. 359, Â§ 1 and is now found at S.C. Code 
    Ann. Â§ 40-59-30 (Supp. 2004). 

 
   [2] Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-59-130 (Supp. 1999) (emphasis added).

 
   [3]  See, e.g., Columbia Pools, Inc. v. Moon, 
    284 S.C. 145, 325 S.E.2d 540 (1985); Duckworth v. Cameron, 270 S.C. 
    647, 244 S.E.2d 217 (1978); Wagner v. Graham, 296 S.C. 1, 370 S.E.2d 
    95 (Ct. App. 1988).

 
    [4]  See Burry & Son Homebuilders, Inc. 
    v. Ford, 310 S.C. 529, 426 S.E.2d 313 (1992).

 
   [5]  Duckworth, 270 S.C. at 649, 244 S.E.2d at 218.Â  

 
   [6]  Â 388 S.E.2d 221 (N.C. Ct. App. 1990).

 
   [7] Â Id. at 222-23.

 
   [8] Â See, e.g., Hodges v. Rainey, 341 
    S.C. 79, 86, 533 S.E.2d 578, 582 (2000) (â€œThe canon of construction â€˜expressio 
    unius est exclusio alteriusâ€™ or â€˜inclusio 
    unius est exclusio alteriusâ€™ holds that â€˜to express 
    or include one thing implies the exclusion of another, or of the alternative.â€™â€ 
    (quoting Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 602 (7th ed. 1999))); Rorrer v. P.J. Club, 
    Inc., 347 S.C. 560, 556 S.E.2d 726 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating it is well 
    established that penal statutes must be strictly construed).

title: State v. Hackett
description: In this probation revocation case, the court addresses the novel question of whether a probationer's probationary period may be tolled when he absconds from supervision.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Samuel Hackett, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No.Â  3931
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  24, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa A. Knox, Legal Counsel Tommy Evans, 
  Jr., and Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, South Carolina Department of Probation, 
  Parole, and Pardon Services, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  This appeal presents the novel question of whether a probationerâ€™s 
  probationary period may be tolled when he absconds from supervision.Â  Appellant, 
  Samuel Hackett, was sentenced to fifteen years suspended with five years of 
  probation for second-degree burglary, and ten years suspended with five years 
  probation for larceny.Â  Hackett was twice brought before the court for probation 
  violations, at which times he was found to be in violation of his probation 
  conditions, and in both instances his probation was ordered tolled from the 
  issuance of the warrant.Â  On the third time Hackett was brought before the court 
  for violating his probation, the trial court revoked Hackettâ€™s probation in 
  full.Â  Hackett appeals.Â  We affirm.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On November 9, 1993, Hackett pled guilty to burglary and grand larceny and 
  received concurrent sentences of fifteen and ten years respectively, suspended 
  with five years probation.Â  The probation order transferred Hackettâ€™s probation 
  to Oregon and required Hackett to pay restitution.Â  
On January 5, 1995, an arrest warrant was issued that charged Hackett with 
  violating his probation by, among other things, failing to report to Oregon 
  authorities, and absconding from supervision.Â  Because Hackett could not be 
  located, he was not served with this warrant until October 1, 1998.Â  Thereafter, 
  a probation citation was issued on October 16, 1998 charging Hackett with violation 
  of his probation subsequent to the issuance of his January 5, 1995 warrant, 
  for being sentenced to prison on January 13, 1995 for robbery in Oregon.Â  Hackett 
  appeared before the court for a hearing on February 5, 1999, at which time the 
  trial court continued his probation and ordered the probationary period be tolled 
  from the issuance of the warrant on January 5, 1995 until the hearing date, 
  February 5, 1999.Â  
On May 4, 1999, another arrest warrant was issued that charged Hackett with 
  violating the terms of his probation by, among other things, failing to report, 
  failing to pay restitution, and failing to notify his agent of his arrest for 
  DUI, DUS, open container violation, violation of the seatbelt law, and child 
  endangerment.Â  On October 8, 2001, the trial court again continued Hackettâ€™s 
  probation, but ordered Hackett to attend the restitution center and again ordered 
  the probationary period be tolled from the issuance of the warrant on May 4, 
  1999 until the date of the order, October 8, 2001.Â  
Hackett was admitted to the Spartanburg Restitution Center on November 6, 2001.Â  
  On January 11, 2002, Hackett absconded from the center following an incident 
  at the center after he was fired from his job that day.Â  A warrant was issued 
  on January 16, 2002 charging Hackett with violating his probation by, among 
  other things, failing to complete the restitution center by absconding, failing 
  to work diligently at a lawful occupation, and disrupting the facility and threatening 
  conduct.Â  Hackett was arrested in Georgia on July 8, 2002 and transported back 
  to South Carolina on July 18, 2002, at which time he was served with the January 
  16, 2002 warrant.Â  Thereafter, a probation citation was issued and served on 
  September 19, 2002, charging Hackett with a probation violation for leaving 
  the state without permission.Â  
Hackett appeared 
  at a probation revocation hearing on December 12, 2002 concerning the January 
  16, 2002 warrant and September 19, 2002 citation.Â  At that hearing, Hackett 
  argued the maximum period of probation is five years and his probationary term 
  expired on November 8, 1998.Â  He asserted the five-year period could not be 
  interrupted unless his probation had been revoked and he was sent back to prison.Â  
  Accordingly, he asked that his warrant and citation be dismissed for lack of 
  subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The trial court found Hackettâ€™s period of probation 
  was properly tolled in both instances and the court therefore had subject matter 
  jurisdiction.Â  Following the taking of testimony on the merits, the trial court 
  found Hackett to be in violation of his probation and revoked Hackettâ€™s probation 
  in full.Â  This appeal follows. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hackett argues the trial court erred in revoking his November 1993 probation 
  in December 2002 because the probationary period could not exceed five years.Â  
  Â He asserts S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-440 does not allow a period of probation 
  to exceed five years, and probation may not be extended absent a partial revocation.Â  
  Accordingly, Hackett maintains his probation could not be extended beyond November 
  8, 1998, and the February 5, 1999 order tolling his probation was therefore 
  invalid.2Â  We disagree. 
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 24‑21‑440 (Supp. 2003) provides as follows:Â  
  â€œThe period of probation or suspension of sentence shall not exceed a period 
  of five years and shall be determined by the judge of the court and may be continued 
  or extended within the above limit.â€Â  A trial courtâ€™s order extending probation 
  beyond the five-year period authorized by statute is an illegal sentence requiring 
  reversal.Â  State v. Sumpter, 334 S.C. 369, 371, 513 S.E.2d 373, 374 (Ct. 
  App. 1999).Â  
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate 
  the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Elmore v. Ramos, 327 S.C. 507, 
  510, 489 S.E.2d 663, 665 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œIn construing a statute, its words 
  must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced 
  construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.â€ Adkins v. Comcar 
  Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 411, 475 S.E.2d 762, 763 (1996). 
  â€œIf a statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite 
  meaning, there is no occasion for employing rules of statutory interpretation 
  and the court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.â€Â  State 
  v. Smith, 330 S.C. 237, 240, 498 S.E.2d 648, 650 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
  â€œWhere a statute is complete, plain, and unambiguous, legislative intent must 
  be determined from the language of the statute itself.â€Â  Id.Â  On the 
  other hand, â€œ[c]ourts will reject the plain and ordinary meaning of statutory 
  language when to accept it would lead to a result so absurd that it could not 
  possibly have been intended by Legislature, or would defeat plain legislative 
  intention; if possible we will construe a statute so as to escape an absurd 
  result and carry the legislative intention into effect.â€Â  State v. Gordon, 
  356 S.C. 143, 152-53, 588 S.E.2d 105, 110 (2003).Â Â  Â  
Construing the plain and ordinary meaning of the 
  words of Â§24-21-440, we find no prohibition for the tolling of a probationary 
  sentence under these circumstances.Â  In the instant case, the trial court did 
  not attempt to continue or extend probation beyond the five-year 
  limit imposed by Â§24-21-440.Â  Rather, the court tolled the probationary period 
  from running during the time Hackett absconded from supervision.Â  Thus, Â§ 24-21-440 
  does not explicitly prohibit the tolling of time during which a probationary 
  term runs.Â  
Further, even if the â€œplain and ordinary meaning of the 
  statuteâ€ does not specifically authorize tolling of probation, we find tolling 
  is proper to reflect the legislative intent.Â  â€œThe primary concern in interpreting 
  a statute is to determine the intent of the legislature if it reasonably can 
  be discovered in the language when construed in the light of its intended purpose.â€Â  
  Clemson Univ. v. Speth, 344 S.C. 310, 312-13, 543 S.E.2d 572, 573 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).Â  The courts will reject a meaning when to accept such would lead 
  to a result so plainly absurd that the Legislature could not possibly have intended 
  it.Â  Id.Â  at 313, 543 S.E.2d at 573-74.Â  In interpreting statutes, the 
  courtâ€™s â€œsole function is to determine and, within constitutional limits, give 
  effect to the intention of the legislature, with reference to the meaning of 
  the language used and the subject matter and purpose of the statute.â€Â  State 
  v. Cobb, 355 S.C. 98, 101 n.4, 584 S.E.2d 371, 373 n.4 (2003); State 
  v. Ramsey, 311 S.C. 555, 561, 430 S.E.2d 511, 515 (1993).
The trial court logically determined Hackett should not 
  receive credit against the five-year probationary period when he was not under 
  the supervision of a probation officer.Â  Hackett habitually violated the terms 
  of his probation, and while he may have been spared the courtâ€™s harsh decision 
  to revoke probation on two occasions, the court properly determined probation 
  should be tolled during the time between the issuance of the probation arrest 
  warrant on January 5, 1995 and the time Hackett actually appeared before the 
  court on that warrant on February 5, 1999.Â  Clearly, Hackett was not reporting 
  and was not under probationary supervision during this time period, and the 
  time during which he absconded from supervision should not be included within 
  the five-year probationary period to which he was sentenced.Â  To allow a probationer 
  who is initially spared from revocation of probation to then abscond from supervision 
  and to escape any further punishment, free and clear of all consequences, as 
  long as he manages to elude apprehension for a set amount of time would lead 
  to an absurd result.Â  
We find further support for our position in the federal case law 
  arena.Â  In United States v. Green, 429 F. Supp. 1036 (W.D. Tex. 1977), 
  Green asserted that a probationary period running past five years from the start 
  of her probation was in violation of the federal statute that provided, â€œThe 
  period of probation, together with any extension thereof, shall not exceed five 
  years.â€Â  Id.Â  at 1038.Â  The district court held her contention must fall 
  because the period of time during which Green was in violation of her probation 
  tolled the running of the probationary term.Â  Id.Â  There, the court found, 
  â€œIt would be unreasonable to conclude that a probationer could violate conditions 
  of probation and keep the clock running at the same time, thereby annulling 
  both the principle and purpose of probation.â€Â  Id.Â  Additionally, in 
  the fourth circuitâ€™s opinion in United States v. Workman, 617 F.2d 48 
  (4th Cir. 1980) the court, in discussing prior decisions regarding 
  the computation of the federal five-year limitation period of probation, noted 
  as follows:Â  â€œThe unifying principle implicit in the resulting decisions is 
  that a probationer can not obtain credit against the five-year period for any 
  period of time during which he was not, in fact, under probationary supervision 
  by virtue of his own wrongful act.â€Â  Id. at 51.Â  It observed the focus 
  was not on a simple mathematical computation of a five-year period from the 
  beginning date of probation, but was on whether the probationerâ€™s wrongful acts 
  resulted in termination of probationary supervision.Â  Id.Â  
Finally, we note that in the Florida case of Ware v. State, 474 So.2d 
  332 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1985), the Florida District Court of Appeal was also 
  faced with the novel issue of whether probation may be tolled during the period 
  of time a probationer absconds from supervision.Â  There, the appellantâ€™s three 
  year probationary period began on May 7, 1979.Â  On July 23, 1980, an affidavit 
  of violation of probation was filed alleging appellant had absconded from jurisdiction.Â  
  On April 6, 1984, appellant pled guilty to second-degree murder.Â  Thereafter, 
  an amended affidavit of violation of probation and an amended warrant were filed 
  on May 31, 1984.Â  Following a hearing on July 13, 1984, the trial court revoked 
  appellantâ€™s probation.Â  Id.Â  at 333.Â  On appeal, appellant asserted the 
  court lacked jurisdiction to entertain the amended affidavit filed in 1984 which 
  included a violation that occurred after his probation had expired.Â  Id.Â  
  Noting it found no Florida case law directly on point, the court, citing several 
  cases including Workman and Green, held â€œcase law of other jurisdictions, 
  as well as simple logic, indicates that where a probationer â€˜absconds from supervision,â€™ 
  the probationary period is tolled until he is once more placed under probationary 
  supervision.â€Â  Id.Â  at 333-34.Â Â  
For the foregoing reasons, we find the trial court properly tolled Hackettâ€™s 
  period of probation from January 5, 1995 to February 5, 1999, and thereafter 
  had jurisdiction to revoke Hackettâ€™s probation during the five-year period of 
  Hackettâ€™s active supervision.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is 

 AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
  2 The only issue on appeal is the propriety of the tolling 
    of Hackettâ€™s probation from January 5, 1995 to February 5, 1999 as per the 
    courtâ€™s order dated February 5, 1999.Â  A finding that this tolling was proper 
    would necessarily mean Hackett was still on probation on September 19, 2002, 
    when the probation citation was issued.

title: State v. Frey
description: Timothy Scott Frey appeals his conviction for driving under the influence, arguing the circuit court improperly admitted evidence of the results of a blood-alcohol test. We reverse in part and remand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


The South Carolina Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Timothy Scott Frey, Appellant.
      
    
  

The Honorable Reginald I. Lloyd
Spartanburg County
Trial Court Case No.Â Â  2002-GS-42-02919

ORDER

 PER CURIAM:Â  The State has petitioned for a rehearing and 
  argues our prior opinion was incorrect in several particulars. While we deny 
  the petition for rehearing, we briefly address the Stateâ€™s contentions.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The State argues initially that the record establishes its compliance 
  with the statutory mandate requiring that â€œ[b]lood and urine samples must be 
  obtained by physicians licensed by the State Board of Medical Examiners, registered 
  nurses licensed by the State Board of Nursing, and other medical personnel trained 
  to obtain the samples in a licensed medical facility.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 
  (a) (Supp. 2003).Â  We disagree, for we remain firmly convinced that this record 
  fails to establish that Scott Darragh is either a licensed physician, registered 
  nurse or is otherwise properly qualified under the statute.Â  
The State further argues that it would have been unduly burdensome 
  to â€œutilize the out-of-state subpoena process, and expend Spartanburg Countyâ€™s 
  limited financial resources, to secure the testimony ofâ€ Darragh.Â  Assuming 
  Darragh has moved to another state as alleged, the suggestion that Darraghâ€™s 
  qualifications could be established only by his presence and testimony 
  at trial is specious.Â  
We also view as meritless the Stateâ€™s newly asserted efforts to recast 
  the issue as one of â€œchain of custody.â€Â  
The State finally contends that a remand to the trial court is the appropriate 
  remedy.Â  While we agree that a remand is appropriate under the circumstances, 
  we do not adopt the Stateâ€™s expansive proposal for the taking of new evidence.Â  
  We have reviewed the cases cited by the State for the proposition that it is 
  entitled to a second bite of the apple to establish Darraghâ€™s qualifications: 
  State v. Primus, 312 S.C. 256, 440 S.E.2d 128 (1994) (case remanded to 
  lower court to conduct an initial Jackson v. Denno hearing to determine 
  whether the defendant was â€œin custodyâ€ for Miranda purposes when he made 
  statements to a police officer); State v. Williams, 258 S.C. 482, 189 
  S.E.2d 299 (1972) (case remanded to trial court to consider defendantâ€™s motion 
  to strike the in-court identification testimony where the trial court â€œoverruled 
  the motion without going fully into whether or not there had, in fact, been 
  improper prior confrontations, and whether, in fact, either or both of the in-court 
  identifications were perchance the tainted product of any such unlawful confrontationâ€); 
  State v. Sampson, 317 S.C. 423, 454 S.E.2d 721 (Ct. App. 1995) (court 
  declined on appeal to rule on motion to suppress, instead remanding to the trial 
  court to conduct an initial hearing on the sufficiency of a search warrant affidavit).Â  
  These cases represent remands to trial courts to address issues that were not 
  fully addressed and developed during the original trial.Â  Remand in such circumstances 
  is far removed from the request hereâ€”allowing the State a second evidentiary 
  hearing.Â  We conclude the remand should be limited to the existing record for 
  the trial court to determine whether the Stateâ€™s failure to establish the qualifications 
  of Darragh per section 56-5-2950(a) â€œmaterially affected the accuracy or reliability 
  of the tests results or the fairness of the testing procedure.â€ S.C. Code Ann.Â  
  Â§ 56-5-2950 (e) (Supp. 2003).Â  
The original opinion, therefore, is withdrawn and 
  the attached opinion is substituted therefore.Â

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Timothy Scott Frey, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 3878
Submitted September 15, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  October 25, 2004
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled January 
  25, 2005

REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED
 

  
    
      
Ricky Keith Harris, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and SolicitorÂ  
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Timothy Scott Frey appeals his conviction for driving 
  under the influence.Â  Frey seeks a new trial, contending the circuit court improperly 
  admitted evidence of the results of a blood-alcohol test.Â  We reverse in part 
  and remand.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On December 
  21, 2001, Frey, while driving a pick-up truck in Spartanburg County, collided 
  with two Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s Office vehicles.Â  Frey was injured in 
  the accident and transported to the Spartanburg Regional Medical Center.Â  The 
  police officer investigating the accident, Trooper L.D. Smith of the South Carolina 
  Highway Patrol, met Frey at the hospital emergency room.Â  After Trooper Smith 
  advised Frey of his rights under the Implied Consent Laws, Frey consented to 
  a blood sample being taken for blood-alcohol level analysis. 
Trooper Smith prepared a standard-form SLED Blood Collection Report in connection 
  with obtaining the blood sample from Frey. According to the report, the blood 
  was drawn from Frey by an individual named â€œScott Darragh.â€Â  Darragh signed 
  the form in the space labeled â€œlicensed or trained collector,â€ and the form 
  was admitted in evidence over Freyâ€™s hearsay objection.Â  The report, however, 
  does not indicate what position Darragh held at the hospital nor did the State 
  offer any evidence to show what, if any, medical training or licensure Darragh 
  had that would qualify him to obtain the blood sample. 
At trial, Frey sought to suppress the admission of the blood-alcohol 
  test results on the grounds the State did not present any evidence that the 
  blood sample was drawn by a qualified individual as required under the implied 
  consent statute.Â  The circuit court denied Freyâ€™s request and admitted the test 
  results.Â Â  Frey was convicted and sentenced.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit or exclude evidence is within his discretion 
  and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Elledge 
  v. Richland/Lexington Sch. Dist. Five, 352 S.C. 179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 
  792 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSISÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Frey argues the 
  circuit court erred in the admission of the blood-alcohol analysis test results.Â  

Under the Implied Consent Statute, an arresting 
  officer may direct that a blood sample be collected from a person arrested for 
  DUI if that person is unable to submit to a breathalyzer test for medical reasons.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (Supp. 2003).Â  The statute requires, however, that 
  blood samples be collected by qualified medical personnel: â€œBlood and urine 
  samples must be obtained by physicians licensed by the State Board of Medical 
  Examiners, registered nurses licensed by the State Board of Nursing, and other 
  medical personnel trained to obtain the samples in a licensed medical facility.â€ 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a).Â  The circuit court found there was enough â€œcircumstantial 
  evidenceâ€ to establish statutory compliance based upon the fact that, following 
  the trooperâ€™s request, Darragh appeared in the emergency room wearing â€œhospital 
  like scrubs.â€ 
We disagree with the reasoning of the circuit court.Â  With any question regarding 
  statutory construction and application, the court must always look first to 
  the legislative intent as determined from the plain language of the statute.Â  
  State v. Scott, 351 S.C. 584, 588, 571 S.E.2d 700, 702 (2002); State 
  v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 365-66, 574 S.E.2d 203, 206 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â  
  The plain language of section 56-5-2950 requires that, when an officer directs 
  a blood sample be collected from a person arrested for DUI, the sample â€œmustâ€ 
  be obtained by trained, qualified medical personnel.Â  Our courts have consistently 
  held that use of words such as â€œshallâ€ or â€œmustâ€ indicates the Legislatureâ€™s 
  intent to enact a mandatory requirement. See, e.g., South Carolina 
  Police Officers Ret. Sys. v. City of Spartanburg, 301 S.C. 188, 191, 391 
  S.E.2d 239, 241 (1990) (noting that statutory prescriptions couched in language 
  such as â€œshallâ€ and â€œmustâ€ are mandatory in application and effect); Starnes 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 342 S.C. 216, 221, 535 S.E.2d 665, 
  667 (Ct. App. 2000) (same).Â  The plain language of section 56-5-2950 demands 
  that the State offer some evidence to establish compliance with this statutory 
  requirement.
The plain language of section 56-5-2950 further requires that we reject the 
  Stateâ€™s suggestion that the mere appearance of Scott Darragh in the emergency 
  room is sufficient, for the statute mandates that the blood sample â€œmustâ€ be 
  obtained by a trained medical professional.Â  Oneâ€™sÂ  mere appearance in a hospital 
  wearing generic hospital attire is not evidence of oneâ€™s medical training.Â  
  We likewise reject the Stateâ€™s assertion that Darraghâ€™s signature on the SLED 
  form in the space labeled â€œlicensed or trained collectorâ€ is sufficient to establish 
  compliance with the statute.Â  Simply signing a preprinted form does not provide 
  any indicia that the signatoryâ€™s qualifications meet the specific licensing 
  or training requirements of section 56-5-2950. 
  [1] Â  To hold otherwise would render the minimal foundational requirement 
  of section 56-5-2950 without any meaningful force or effect. In light of the 
  Stateâ€™s failure to satisfy this basic requirement, we are constrained to find 
  the circuit court erred in finding the foundational requirements of section 
  56-5-2950 had been satisfied. [2] 
  
The State alternatively 
  asserts that, assuming Darragh was not qualified under the statute to collect 
  the blood sample, suppression would not be warranted.Â  Specifically, the State 
  contends Frey was not prejudiced by the failure to comply with the statute.Â  
  The State bases its argument on the principle that where a statute is silent 
  about the admissibility of evidence, the â€œexclusion of evidence should be limited 
  to violations of constitutional rights and not to statutory violations, at least 
  where the appellant cannot demonstrate prejudice at trial resulting from the 
  failure to follow statutory procedures.â€ State v. Sheldon, 344 S.C. 340, 
  343, 543 S.E.2d 585, 586 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting State v. Chandler, 
  267 S.C. 138, 226 S.E.2d 553 (1976)). 
Recent revisions 
  to section 56-5-2950 are in accord with the Stateâ€™s position.Â  The statute was 
  amended in 2003 to include the addition of subsection (e), [3]  which provides, in pertinent part: 

The failure to follow any of these policies, procedures, 
  and regulations, or the provisions of this section, shall result in the exclusion 
  from evidence any tests results, if the trial judge or hearing officer 
  finds that such failure materially affected the accuracy or reliability of 
  the tests results or the fairness of the testing procedure. 

S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 56-5-2950 (e) (Act No. 61, 2003 S.C. Acts 689) (emphasis added).
Since the statutory 
  mandate in question is inextricably connected to the accuracy and reliability 
  of the blood test results, we remand to the trial court.Â  We are persuaded that 
  in the first instance the issue of prejudice should be addressed by the trial 
  court.Â  We find instructive the case of State v. Sheldon, 344 S.C. 340, 
  543 S.E.2d 585 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Sheldon, a then on-duty state trooper, was 
  charged with reckless homicide.Â  The Highway Patrol participated in the accident 
  investigation, in violation of a statute.Â  As a result of the statutory violation, 
  the trial court granted Sheldonâ€™s motion to suppress evidence gathered or prepared 
  by the Highway Patrolâ€™s Multi-disciplinary Accident Investigation Team (MAIT).Â  
  The State appealed, and this court noted that evidence obtained in violation 
  of a statute â€œis not necessarily inadmissible absent a demonstration of prejudice 
  resulting from the violation.â€ Id. at 344, 543 S.E.2d at 586.Â  We remanded 
  to the trial court since â€œ[i]t did not make any findings on whether Sheldon 
  would be prejudiced by MAITâ€™s investigation of the collision.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
  Here, the trial court on remand shall, on the existing record, determine whether 
  the Stateâ€™s failure to comply with section 56-5-2950 (a) â€œmaterially affected 
  the accuracy or reliability of the tests results or the fairness of the testing 
  procedure.â€Â  Cf. State v. Huntley, 349 S.C. 1, 6, 562 S.E.2d 472, 
  474 (2002) (noting that, in a DUI prosecution, breathalyzer operator error did 
  not impact the accuracy of the breath test results, concluding â€œ[t]here is no 
  question the breathalyzer machine was operating properly and its results were 
  reliableâ€);Â  State v. Chandler, 267 S.C. 138, 142, 226 S.E.2d 553, 555 
  (1976) (holding that evidence seized at nighttime was properly admitted pursuant 
  to warrant authorizing a search â€œin the daytime onlyâ€ since the court determined 
  the violation had no impact on the reliability or probative value of the evidence).
CONCLUSION
Because the 
  State failed to establish Freyâ€™s blood sample was obtained by a licensed physician, 
  registered nurse, or â€œother medical personnel trained to obtain the samples 
  in a licensed medical facilityâ€ as mandated by section 56-5-2950, we remand 
  to the trial court to determine whether â€œsuch failure materially affected the 
  accuracy or reliability of the tests results or the fairness of the testing 
  procedure.â€Â Â Â  An answer in the affirmative shall entitle Frey to a new trial, 
  but otherwise, the admission of the blood test results and resulting conviction 
  shall stand affirmed. Â 
 REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED. 
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.

 
   [1] Â We reject the Stateâ€™s argument to the extent it relies on 
    the signature of Darragh as substantive evidence of his qualifications to 
    collect the blood sample.Â  We find guidance on this point in the manner our 
    Rules of Criminal Procedure address the admission of a report of chemical 
    analysis to establish the physical evidence of a controlled substance.Â  Under 
    narrowly limited circumstances, such a report signed by the chemist or analyst 
    who performed the test may be admitted for chain of custody and substantive 
    purposes. Rule 6(a), SCRCrimP.Â  However, if the defendant timely objects to 
    the admission of the report, the signed report alone is insufficient to establish 
    that the tests were performed by a SLED-certified chemist and were conducted 
    pursuant to SLED-approved procedures.Â  The rule instead requires that, in 
    the face of a proper objection to the report,Â  â€œthe trial judge shall require 
    the chemist or analyst to be present at trial for the purpose of personally 
    testifying.â€Â Â  In the present case, the admission of the blood collection 
    report to establish the qualifications of Darragh was hotly contestedâ€”subject 
    to repeated defense objections.Â  While the SLED form here may maintain its 
    efficacy for chain of custody purposes, we decline to find that the medical 
    training and qualification requirements mandated under section 56-5-2950 may 
    be proven by the mere signature on the form.

 
   [2] Â We are mindful of the legitimate concern of the trial court that law 
    enforcement officers who request blood samples should not be required to demand 
    detailed background information about the hospital employee who shows up to 
    take the sample.Â  This concern, however, is misplaced.Â  There is no basis 
    to find fault with the actions of Trooper Smith.Â  Law enforcement officers 
    may generally rely on the implicit and explicit assurances of medical providers 
    regarding the qualifications of personnel who are assigned to assist them 
    in their investigation.Â  The failure of proof in this case is directly attributable 
    to the Stateâ€™s failure to establish the qualifications of Scott Darragh.Â  
  

 
   [3]  The 2003 revisions to Â§ 56-5-2950 became effective 
    shortly after the trial of this case.Â  Because subsection (e) addresses procedural 
    rather than substantive rights, it is remedial in nature, and therefore retroactive 
    in its application. See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue v. Rosemary 
    Coin Machs., Inc., 339 S.C. 25, 28, 528 S.E.2d 416, 418 (2000) (noting 
    that â€œstatutes that are remedial or procedural in nature are generally held 
    to operate retrospectivelyâ€).Â

description: In this domestic relations case, appellant contends that the Guardian ad Litemâ€™s recommendation was not the product of an independent, balanced, and impartial investigation pursuant to Patel v. text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Majid Nasser-Moghaddassi, Respondent,
v.
Farideh Gerami Moghaddassi, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Amy C. Sutherland, Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3932
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005

AFFIRMED

    

  
    
      
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, 
  for Appellant.
Kimberly Fisher Dunham, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this domestic relations action, Mrs. Farideh Gerami 
  Moghaddassi (Mother) appeals the family court order awarding custody of the 
  coupleâ€™s children to Mr. Majid Nasser-Moghaddassi (Father).Â  Additionally, Mother 
  appeals the distribution of the marital estate and the award of the marital 
  residence to Father.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUNDÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The Moghaddassis, who were married in February of 1983, have three 
  minor children: a daughter who was sixteen at the time of the final hearing, 
  a son who was thirteen, and another daughter who was seven.Â  Mother and Father 
  are both natives of Iran and were both educated in England.Â  They have been 
  in the United States since 1986, when Father, an engineer, found employment 
  here.Â  
According to Fatherâ€™s trial testimony, the parties argued frequently.Â  When 
  their oldest daughter was nearing her teenage years, Father and Motherâ€™s arguments 
  progressed into physical altercations.Â  Father recounted one instance where 
  Mother became upset because their daughter and her friends were in a room without 
  adult supervision, while Father and Mother were in another part of the house:

My wife. . . . she started pushing me around that, Youâ€™re not doing anything 
  as a father.Â  Sheâ€™s up to no good in there and thereâ€™s a boy in the room. 
I said, Hey, they are all teenagers, they are friends.Â  But she pushed me around, 
  pushed me around and got physical with me and she hit me with aâ€”a childrenâ€™s 
  recorder on the floor she picked up and she hit me in the wrist.Â  And it was 
  very painful.Â  I went down on my knees and she hit me in the head. . . . 

As a result of the incident, Mother was charged with criminal domestic violence 
  and spent several days in jail.Â  Father related another episode: â€œwe had a little 
  argument and that wasâ€”when that was over, I was sitting and working with the 
  computer and suddenly she approached me from the back and poured hot coffee 
  on my head.â€Â  He further averred that when angry, Mother would scratch his face, 
  and that she has broken his eyeglasses on five occasions.Â  Frequently, the children 
  were present during these encounters.Â  
The relationships between the children and their mother are strained.Â  
  Father stated that his wife would call their sixteen-year-old daughter â€œbitch, 
  prostitute, . . . whoreâ€ in front of her friends.Â  Additionally, Father testified 
  to seeing his wife abusing their daughter, â€œ[p]hysically pulling her hair, pushing 
  her around.â€Â  During the year preceding trial the oldest daughter refused to 
  see her mother.Â  According to Father, Mother mistreated the younger children 
  as well, including â€œslapping around, pushingâ€ their son.Â  
A Guardian ad Litem (GAL or guardian) was appointed to represent the interests 
  of the three minor children.Â  She prepared a report which discusses her interviews 
  with, among other persons, the partiesâ€™ children.Â  The report describes the 
  childrenâ€™s accounts of Motherâ€™s behavior:  

The oldest child . . . . relayed to me that her parents have had lots of fights.Â  
  Her mother always insults her father.Â  She also related that her mother always 
  instigates and starts the fights with her father. . . . She describes her mother 
  as yelling and cursing. . . .Â  She also related to me that her mother has continually 
  called her a whore, has hit her and her father on many occasions.
. . . She does not want to see her mother at all.
. . . [T]he thirteen year old son . . . . relayed to me that his mother always 
  starts the fights.Â  That he has had to call the Police two times.Â  He related 
  how recently his mother hit his father with the broom and was clawing at him. 
  . . . He described his mother to me as â€œmom is abusiveâ€.Â  He described an incident 
  where the mother hit him with a metal pole and pushed him onto some stairs. 
  . . . 
I then spoke with . . . the six year old. . . . She said her mother fus[s]ed 
  a lot at her dad and broke his glasses and hit him a lot with the broom, a flashlight 
  and rock. . . . She told me that she was scared of her mother, she hits everybody 
  in the family. . . .Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Father initiated divorce proceedings.Â  The family court: (1) granted a divorce 
  on one yearâ€™s separation; (2) awarded custody of the three minor children to 
  Father; (3) ordered Father to pay $1,300 per month in permanent, periodic alimony; 
  (4) apportioned the marital estate 60% to Father, 40% to Mother; and (5) distributed 
  the marital residence to Father as part of his share of the marital estate.Â  
  The issues before this Court relate to custody of the children and division 
  of the marital assets.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from 
  the family court, this Court may find facts in accordance with its own view 
  of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 
  603 S.E.2d 598 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 
  S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992)).Â  However, this broad scope of review does 
  not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 
  349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 
  195, 522 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial 
  judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry 
  v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 280 S.E.2d 541 (1981); Murdock v. Murdock, 
  338 S.C. 322, 526 S.E.2d 241 (Ct. App. 1999); see also Dorchester 
  County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. 
  App. 1996) (ruling that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for 
  direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to the family 
  courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).Â  An appellate court 
  â€œshould be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence on child 
  custody for that of the trial court.â€  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 
  7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve 
  appellant of her burden to convince this Court the family court committed error.  
  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
ISSUES

  
    
    
      
         I.
         
  Was the Guardian ad Litemâ€™s recommendation the product of an independent, balanced, 
  and impartial investigation, well documented and supported by the facts?
      
      
         II.
         
  Did the family court err in ordering Mother to pay a portion of the Guardian 
  ad Litem fees?
      
      
         III. 
        Was the distribution of the marital estate fair and equitable in light of the 
  facts of this case?
      
      
         IV. 
         Did the 
  family court err in awarding Father title to the marital residence?
      
      
         V. 
         
  Does the evidence support the family courtâ€™s denial of an award of personal 
  property to Mother?
      
      
         VI.
         Did the 
  family court err by not awarding Mother attorneyâ€™s fees and costs?
      
    
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother asserts 
  six exceptions to the family court order.Â  We disagree with Motherâ€™s contentions 
  and affirm the family courtâ€™s decision.
I.Â  The GALâ€™s Recommendation
Mother first 
  argues the GALâ€™s recommendation was not the product of an independent, balanced, 
  and impartial investigation.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The paramount and controlling 
  factor in every custody dispute is the best interests of the children.Â  Shirley 
  v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 2000); Paparella 
  v. Paparella, 340 S.C.186, 189, 531 S.E.2d 297, 299 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In 
  Shirley, we articulated the South Carolina rule governing custody cases:

In all custody controversies, the controlling considerations are the childâ€™s 
  welfare and best interests.Â  In reaching a determination as to custody, the 
  family court should consider how the custody decision will impact all areas 
  of the childâ€™s life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, 
  familial, emotional, and recreational aspects.Â  Additionally, the court must 
  assess each partyâ€™s character, fitness, and attitude as they impact the child.

342 S.C. at 330, 536 S.E.2d 
  at 430 (citations omitted).Â  When determining the best interests of a child, 


the family court should consider several factors, including: 
  who has been the primary caretaker; the conduct, attributes, and fitness of 
  the parents; the opinions of third parties (including the guardian, 
  expert witnesses, and the children); and the age, health, and sex of the children.Â  
  Rather than merely adopting the recommendation of the guardian, the court, by 
  its own review of all the evidence, should consider the character, fitness, 
  attitude, and inclinations on the part of each parent as they impact the child 
  as well as all psychological, physical, environmental, spiritual, educational, 
  medical, family, emotional and recreational aspects of the childâ€™s life.Â  

Pirayesh v. Pirayesh, 
  359 S.C. 284, 296, 596 S.E.2d 505, 512 (Ct. App. 2004) (emphasis added) (citations 
  omitted). Â 
In the landmark 
  opinion, Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 555 S.E.2d 386 (2001), our supreme

  the â€œdisputes and irritants do not linger,â€ because disposition of the home 
  is final.Â  See Johnson, 285 S.C. at 311, 329 S.E.2d at 445 (â€œIf 
  possible, all issues between the parties should be resolved . . . so that disputes 
  and irritants do not linger and present further incentives to litigation.â€).
We hold the 
  family court did not abuse its discretion by awarding Father the home as part 
  of his equitable distribution of the estate.Â  First, we reject Motherâ€™s contention 
  that the award to Father delays her realization of equity in the house, thereby 
  imposing a burden upon her.Â  Motherâ€™s 40% interest in the equity was recognized 
  and accounted for in the family courtâ€™s distribution of the assets.Â  Of the 
  $83,609 estate, Mother was awarded cash and property valued at $33,443, or 40% 
  of the estate.Â  She has been awarded her share of the equity in the marital 
  residence.Â  
Furthermore, 
  Motherâ€™s citations to Johnson and Morris are inapplicable as those 
  cases address awards of exclusive use of the marital home as incident of support.Â  
  Father was not awarded use of the residence as incident of support; he was awarded 
  title to the house as part of his share of the marital estate.Â  Donahue 
  and Craig control, and those cases establish that a judge may award the 
  marital home as part of the distribution of the estate.Â  
Finally, we 
  reject Motherâ€™s assertion that she should have been given use of the home as 
  an incident of support.Â  The compelling circumstances involving shelter for 
  children do not apply because Mother was not awarded custody of the children.Â  
  Similarly, we do not find that Mother is handicapped, or is otherwise unable 
  to find suitable housing.Â  At the time of the hearing she resided in an apartment, 
  and her then-monthly income of $702 is now being supplemented by the family 
  courtâ€™s award of $1,300 per month in alimony to her.Â  She has not made a sufficient 
  showing to justify an award of use of the house as an incident of support.Â  

V.Â  Award of Personal 
  Property
Mother 
  argues the family court erred in failing to award her separate personal property.Â  
  We disagree.Â  Mother did not offer a marital asset addendum or other evidence 
  concerning the identity or value of the personal household property she now 
  claims.Â  The family court evenly apportioned the household furnishings and granted 
  Mother the full amount of her jewelry.Â  We can find no abuse of discretion requiring 
  an alteration of this award.
VI. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Lastly, Mother alleges the family court erred in failing to award attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  We disagree.
The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is at the sound discretion of the family court.Â  
  See Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 368 S.E.2d 901 (1988).Â  
  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider: 
  (1) the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fees; (2) the beneficial results obtained 
  by counsel; (3) the respective financial conditions of the parties; and (4) 
  the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 
  307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992); Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 
  536 S.E.2d 427 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Our supreme court has identified the following 
  factors for determining a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee: (1) the nature, extent, 
  and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) 
  professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial 
  results obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock 
  v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991). 
In this matter, both 
  parties succeeded on some aspects of their respective claims.Â  Father received 
  custody and sole financial responsibility for the support of the three minor 
  children.Â  Further, the partiesâ€™ fiscal situations are comparable.Â  After factoring 
  in Fatherâ€™s alimony obligation, both partiesâ€™ monthly expenses outweigh their 
  monthly income.Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion 
  in deciding each party would bear his or her own attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
  As a result, we affirm the courtâ€™s determination.
CONCLUSION
We hold the 
  guardian in the instant case conducted a fair and unbiased investigation, and 
  we affirm the family courtâ€™s award of custody.Â  Further, we find no abuse of 
  discretion in the allocation of responsibility for the GALâ€™s fees.Â  We approve 
  the family courtâ€™s order in regard to equitable distribution of the marital 
  property and the award of the residence to Father as part of his share of the 
  estate.Â  The court adequately allocated the partiesâ€™ personal property and properly 
  denied attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the family court is hereby
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, 
  JJ., concur.
