title: State v. Crawford
description: In this criminal case, appellant contends that the trial testimony was not sufficient to withstand a directed verdict on the charge of criminal conspiracy.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Bernard Crawford, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3933
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry 
  Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy 
  Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold 
  M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Bernard Crawford (Appellant) was convicted of criminal 
  conspiracy and sentenced to five years in prison.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial 
  judge erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the night of August 20, 2002, John Crawford (John) awoke 
  his son, Jonathan Crawford (Jonathan), and demanded Jonathan take him to get 
  something to eat.Â  John is Appellantâ€™s brother, and Jonathan is Johnâ€™s son, 
  Appellantâ€™s nephew.Â  Jonathan testified at Appellantâ€™s trial that his father 
  was drunk and irate.Â  Jonathan acquiesced, and on their way to a fast-food restaurant, 
  John and Jonathan picked up Appellant, who had been walking along the side of 
  the road.Â  According to Jonathanâ€™s testimony, the three of them proceeded to 
  a fast-food restaurant.Â  John then directed Jonathan to drive to an apartment 
  complex, but suddenly demanded that Jonathan stop the vehicle so he could urinate 
  behind a building.Â  Jonathan stopped the car at Sunbelt Rentals.Â  Shortly after 
  John exited the vehicle, Jonathan heard glass break from the direction of Sunbelt 
  Rentals.Â  
In his statement to police, Jonathan averred Appellant exited the vehicle upon 
  hearing the glass break.Â  He saw John and Appellant carrying stolen saws from 
  the store to the car.Â  According to his sworn statement, John and Appellant 
  loaded the saws into the car and demanded Jonathan drive away.Â  
Officer Jenkins witnessed the vehicle, with its headlights off, pulling out 
  of the parking lot of Sunbelt Rentals.Â  The officer, who had been traveling 
  in the opposite direction of the Crawfords, turned around to follow Jonathanâ€™s 
  vehicle.Â  Jonathan sped up, and the officer activated his blue lights.Â  Officer 
  Jenkins testified that it appeared as though objects were being thrown out of 
  the sunroof.Â  In his statement, Jonathan claimed that upon seeing the police 
  car, Appellant handed John the saws from the backseat, and John threw the saws 
  out of the vehicleâ€™s passenger side window.Â  Appellant ran from police once 
  the vehicle was stopped.Â  Bolt cutters, gloves, and newly purchased flashlights 
  were found in the vehicle.Â  
The police charged Jonathan, John, and Appellant with conspiracy, 
  burglary, and grand larceny.Â  All charges against Jonathan subsequently were 
  dropped.Â  John pled guilty to all the charges and was sentenced to a total of 
  fifteen years in prison.Â  At Appellantâ€™s trial, John claimed full responsibility 
  for the crimes: â€œ[n]either one of them . . . had really anything to do with 
  it. . . . [I]f he would have helped me or somebody would have helped me, I wouldnâ€™t 
  have gotten caught.â€Â  According to John, neither Jonathan nor Appellant knew 
  his intention to break into Sunbelt Rentals.Â Â Â Â Â  
Jonathanâ€™s trial testimony differs substantially from the statement 
  he gave to police.Â  In court, Jonathan proclaimed:Â  â€œ. . . I donâ€™tÂ  know if 
  Bernard Crawford got out of the car between the time that he ran in the building 
  and came back.â€ He stated further: â€œI had tunnel vision.Â  I didnâ€™t look around 
  and look back.Â  I didnâ€™t see anything â€˜til my father put the saws in the back 
  seat and jumped in the front seat and said, â€˜Letâ€™s go.â€™â€Â  Jonathan testified 
  that John slapped him and may have slapped at Appellant as well.Â  John yelled 
  at them both demanding they obey his orders.Â  Jonathan remembered Appellant 
  telling John: â€œyou basically just got us in trouble, you know, for your stupidity.â€Â  

When the State rested its case, Appellant moved for a directed verdict as to 
  all charges.Â  The trial court denied the motion, concluding that substantial 
  evidence was extant in the record from which the jury could infer that the State 
  had proven the elements of each of the offenses, focusing particularly on Jonathanâ€™s 
  previous statement to police about Appellantâ€™s involvement.Â  The jury found 
  Appellant guilty of criminal conspiracy and acquitted him of the remaining charges.Â  
  The trial court sentenced Appellant to five years in prison.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict in a criminal case, an appellate 
  court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State 
  v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004); State v. Al-Amin, 
  353 S.C. 405, 578 S.E.2d 32 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Morgan, 
  352 S.C. 359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When ruling on a motion for a 
  directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence 
  of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Cherry, Op. No. 25902 (S.C. Sup. 
  Ct. filed Nov. 29, 2004) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 46 at 28); State v. Wilds, 
  355 S.C. 269, 584 S.E.2d 138 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. McLauren, 
  349 S.C. 488, 563 S.E.2d 346 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  If there is any direct evidence 
  or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt 
  of the accused, this Court must find the case was properly submitted to the 
  jury.Â  State v. Rosemond, 356 S.C. 426, 589 S.E.2d 757 (2003); 
  State v. Lindsey, 355 S.C. 15, 583 S.E.2d 740 (2003); see also 
  State v. Ballington, 346 S.C. 262, 551 S.E.2d 280 (Ct. App. 
  2001) (stating judge should deny motion for directed verdict if there is any 
  direct or substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove 
  accusedâ€™s guilt, or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced). 
  On the other hand, a defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State 
  fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  State v. McKnight, 
  352 S.C. 635, 576 S.E.2d 168 (2003); State v. McCluney, 357 S.C. 
  560, 593 S.E.2d 509 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 
  268, 580 S.E.2d 159 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The appellate court may reverse the trial 
  judgeâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict only if there is no evidence 
  to support the judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 
  555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002).Â  
 
  LAW/ANALYSISÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Appellant claims the trial court erred in denying 
  his motion for a directed verdict because the State failed to introduce substantial 
  evidence he was guilty of conspiracy.Â  We disagree.
I.Â  Prior Inconsistent Statement as Substantive Evidence
State v. Copeland, 278 S.C. 572, 300 S.E.2d 63 (1982), established that 
  testimony of prior inconsistent statements may be used as â€œsubstantive evidence 
  when the declarant testifies at trial and is subject to cross examination.â€Â  
  Id. at 581, 300 S.E.2d at 69; accord State v. Smith, 309 
  S.C. 442, 424 S.E.2d 496 (1992); State v. Ferguson, 300 S.C. 408, 388 
  S.E.2d 642 (1990); State v. Caulder, 287 S.C. 507, 339 S.E.2d 876 (Ct. 
  App. 1986).Â  In this case, Jonathan gave a statement to police following his 
  arrest asserting that Appellant participated in the grand larceny and burglary.Â  
  However, at trial Jonathan testified that he was unsure whether Appellant exited 
  the vehicle, and that Appellant objected to Johnâ€™s actions once John was back 
  in the car.Â  The contradiction between Jonathanâ€™s sworn statement to police 
  and his later testimony in court is a matter of weight for the jury to decide.Â  
  Copeland at 582, 300 S.E.2d at 69.Â  The later testimony does not obviate 
  the efficacy of the first statement made closer in time to the event in question.Â  
  Id.Â  
II.Â  Flight Evidence
Once Jonathan stopped the car, Officer Jenkins instructed John, Jonathan, and 
  Appellant to remain in the vehicle until backup arrived.Â  With another officer 
  present, Officer Jenkins had each individual step out of the car, one at a time.Â  
  He provided the following description of the arrests:

  
    
    
      
        A.  
         The last person I pulled out was Bernard, which was the subject seated 
  in the passenger side rear.Â  I had him exit and also patted him down for weapons.
      
      
        Q.
         All right.Â  And at that point what happened?
      
      
        A. 
         As soon as I began patting Bernard down for weapons, he jerked away 
  from me and took off running down Ebenezer.
      
    
    
  

After a short chase, 
  Officer Jenkins returned to John and Jonathan to place them under arrest.Â  Additional 
  law enforcement personnel soon arrived and Officer Jenkins resumed the search 
  for Appellant.Â  He explained:

  
    
    
      
        A.
         . . . [W]e got a call of a subject around some apartments on Ebenezer 
  Avenue . . .
      
      
        
         . . . .
      
      
        
        At that time, I did proceed to that area and I did locate Bernard Crawford hiding 
  in the bushes in the front.Â  It was myself and an officer from Winthrop.
      
      
        Q. 
         All right.Â  And at that time were you able to apprehend him?
      
      
        A.  
         No, I was not.Â  I ordered him out from the bushes.Â  At that time I was 
  at the rear of the bushes.Â  He exited out through the front of the bushes, ran 
  and jumped over another fence and continued on.
      
    
    
  

Eventually, Appellant was apprehended. 
â€œFlight from prosecution is admissible as evidence of guilt.â€Â  State v. 
  Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 413, 578 S.E.2d 32, 36-37 (Ct. App. 2003); 
  see also State v. Ballenger, 322 S.C. 196, 200, 
  470 S.E.2d 851, 854 (1996) (stating flight is â€œat least some evidenceâ€ of defendant's 
  guilt); State v. Freely, 105 S.C. 243, 89 S.E. 643 (1916) (declaring 
  the flight of one charged with crime has always been held to be some evidence 
  tending to prove guilt).Â  Evidence of flight has been held to constitute evidence 
  of defendant's guilty knowledge and intent.Â  See State v. Beckham, 
  334 S.C. 302, 513 S.E.2d 606 (1999); Town of Hartsville v. Munger, 
  93 S.C. 527, 77 S.E. 219 (1913); State v. Brownlee, 318 S.C. 34, 
  455 S.E.2d 704 (Ct. App. 1995); see also State v. Thompson, 
  278 S.C. 1, 292 S.E.2d 581 (1982), overruled on other grounds by State 
  v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (finding evidence 
  of flight admissible to show guilty knowledge, intent, and that defendant sought 
  to avoid apprehension); State v. Grant, 275 S.C. 404, 407, 272 
  S.E.2d 169, 171 (1980) (â€œ[A]ttempts to run away have always been regarded as 
  some evidence of guilty knowledge and intent.â€) (internal quotation marks omitted); 
  State v. Davis, 354 S.C. 348, 580 S.E.2d 778 (Ct. App. 2003) (noting 
  that circumstances of defendantâ€™s flight from police after they attempted traffic 
  stop allowed reasonable inference of guilty conduct). Flight, when unexplained, 
  is admissible as indicating consciousness of guilt, for it is not to be supposed 
  that one who is innocent and conscious of that fact would flee.Â  See 
  State v. Williams, 350 S.C. 172, 564 S.E.2d 688 (Ct. App. 
  2002) (citing 29 Am. Jur. 2d Evidence Â§ 532 (1994)).
The critical factor to the admissibility of evidence of flight is 
  whether the totality of the evidence creates an inference that the defendant 
  had knowledge that he was being sought by the authorities.Â  Beckham, 
  334 S.C. at 315, 513 S.E.2d at 612. It is sufficient that circumstances justify 
  an inference that the accusedâ€™s actions were motivated as a result of his belief 
  that police officers were aware of his wrongdoing and were seeking him for that 
  purpose. Id. (citing Commonwealth v. Jones, 457 Pa. 563, 
  319 A.2d 142 (1974)).Â  Flight or evasion of arrest is a circumstance to go to 
  the jury.Â  See Beckham, 334 S.C. at 315, 513 S.E.2d 
  at 612; State v. Turnage, 107 S.C. 478, 93 S.E. 182 (1917); see 
  also State v. Byers, 277 S.C. 176, 284 S.E.2d 360 (1981) 
  (recognizing that evidence of flight is proper and that it is oftentimes appropriate 
  for counsel to argue to the jury the inferences growing out of flight); Grant, 
  275 S.C. at 408, 272 S.E.2d at 171 (stating that while a jury charge on flight 
  as evidence of guilt is improper, admission of evidence and argument by counsel 
  concerning it are allowed).
Testimony established that Appellant fled the scene when police attempted 
  to arrest him.Â  In South Carolina, Appellantâ€™s flight constitutes evidence of 
  his guilt.
III.Â  Criminal Conspiracy
Criminal conspiracy is statutorily defined as â€œa combination between two or 
  more persons for the purpose of accomplishing an unlawful object or a lawful 
  object by unlawful means.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-410 (2003); accord 
  State v. Gordon, 356 S.C. 143, 588 S.E.2d 105 (2003); State v. Follin, 
  352 S.C. 235, 573 S.E.2d 812 (Ct. App. 2002) cert. denied, State v. 
  Horne, 324 S.C. 372, 478 S.E.2d 289 (Ct. App. 1996); cf. LaMotte 
  v. Punch Line of Columbia, 296 S.C. 66, 370 S.E.2d 711 (1988) (comparing 
  civil conspiracy, which is a combination of two or more persons joining for 
  the purpose of injuring plaintiff and causing special damage to plaintiff, with 
  criminal conspiracy). 
This statutory pronouncement is declaratory of the common law definition of 
  conspiracy.Â  See State v. Fleming, 243 S.C. 265, 133 S.E.2d 800 
  (1963) (observing the predecessor to Â§ 16-17-410 was declaratory of the common 
  law definition).Â  The crime of conspiracy has long been recognized in this state.Â  
  See, e.g., State v. De Witt, 20 S.C.L. (2 Hill) 282 (1834) (affirming 
  conspiracy as a viable common law offense and discussing the breadth of its 
  applicability). 
Historically, conspiracy was a misdemeanor.Â  See State v. Ferguson,Â  
  221 S.C. 300, 306, 70 S.E.2d 355, 358 (1952) (â€œConspiracy is a common-law offense 
  and is a misdemeanor.â€).Â  Currently, conspiracy is a felony and carries a maximum 
  sentence of $5,000 or five years imprisonment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-410 (2003).Â  
  â€œA person who is convicted of the crime of conspiracy must not be given a greater 
  fine or sentence than he would receive if he carried out the unlawful act contemplated 
  by the conspiracy and had been convicted of the unlawful act contemplated by 
  the conspiracy . . . .â€Â  Id.  
The gravamen of the offense of conspiracy is the agreement, or combination.Â  
  State v. Dasher, 278 S.C. 454, 298 S.E.2d 215 (1982); see also 
  State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 323, 555 S.E.2d 402, 405 (2001) (â€œThe 
  essence of a conspiracy is the agreement.â€).Â  â€œIn criminal conspiracy it is 
  not necessary to prove an overt act.Â  The gist of the crime is the unlawful 
  combination.Â  The crime is then complete, even though nothing further is done.â€Â  
  Ferguson at 303, 70 S.E.2d at 356 (citing State v. Ameker, 73 
  S.C. 330, 53 S.E. 484 (1906)).Â Â  
A formal or express agreement need not be established.Â  Horne at 381, 
  478 S.E.2d at 293.Â  â€œA tacit, mutual understanding, resulting in the willful 
  and intentional adoption of a common design by two or more persons is sufficient, 
  provided the common purpose is to do an unlawful act either as a means or an 
  end.â€Â  Id. (citation omitted).Â  Professor McAninch explains: â€œThe mere 
  fact that two persons happened to be doing the same thing at the same time does 
  not compel the conclusion that there was a conspiracy.â€Â  William Shepard McAninch 
  & W. Gaston Fairey, The Criminal Law of South Carolina, 476 (4th 
  ed. 2002).Â  In State v. Ameker, 73 S.C. 330, 53 S.E. 484 (1906), our 
  supreme court placed its approbation on the following explanation of conspiracy 
  given by the trial judge:

â€œ[S]uppose, Mr. Foreman, 
  that you and the gentleman on your left would go out in the streets of Orangeburg 
  and commit an assault and battery on some other person, that would be an unlawful 
  act, but it would not be a conspiracy, unless there was an agreement between 
  you to do the act before doing it.Â  It is an agreement to do an unlawful 
  act that is the gist of the whole matter.â€

Id.  at 339, 53 S.E. at 487.Â  
In State v. Mouzon, 321 S.C. 27, 467 S.E.2d 122 (Ct. App. 1995), the 
  defendant appealed his conviction for conspiracy to distribute crack cocaine.Â  
  One witness testified that on the night in question, several individuals, including 
  the defendant, were present where drug transactions were taking place.Â  Id. 
  at 32, 467 S.E.2d at 125.Â Â  We reversed the conviction, holding: 

[T]o prove conspiracy, it is not enough that a group of people separately intend 
  to distribute drugs in a single area, nor enough that their activities occasionally 
  or sporadically place them in contact with each other. What is needed is proof 
  they intended to act together for their shared mutual benefit 
  within the scope of the conspiracy charged.

Id. at 32-33, 467 S.E.2d at 125 (internal quotation marks and citation 
  omitted); see also State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 437 S.E.2d 75 
  (1993) (holding it is not enough for the offense of conspiracy that a group 
  of people separately intend to distribute drugs in a single area, nor that their 
  activities occasionally or sporadically place them in contact with each other). 

Because it takes at least two persons to enter into an agreement, 
  there must be at least two members of a conspiracy.Â  See State v. 
  Jackson, 7 S.C. (7 Rich.) 283 (1876).Â  â€œYet they need not all be indicted 
  or named.Â  Indeed, an indictment charging that the named defendant and â€˜other 
  persons unknown . . . did . . . conspireâ€™ was approved in State v. Hightower, 
  221 S.C. 91, 94, 69, S.E.2d 363, 366 (1952)[.]â€Â  McAninch & Fairey 481. 
  In Hightower, there was â€œample evidence that the conspirators, though 
  unknown, did exist.â€Â  McAninch & Fairey 481.Â  
A conspiracy to commit a crime does not merge with the completed 
  offense.Â  State v. Rutledge, 232 S.C. 223, 101 S.E.2d 289 (1957); see 
  also Ferguson at 303-04, 70 S.E.2d at 356-57 (observing that a conspiracy 
  does not merge with a completed crime, â€œbut is a distinct offense in itself 
  and punishable as such, notwithstanding that the object of the conspiracy has 
  been accomplished).Â  
 State v. Wells, 249 S.C. 249, 153 S.E.2d 904 (1967) recognized 
  the existence of Whartonâ€™s Rule in South Carolina, but denied its application 
  under the facts of Wells.Â  Whartonâ€™s Rule states that where 

co-operation or 
  concert between two or more persons is essential to the commission of a substantive 
  crime and there is no ingredient of an alleged conspiracy that is not present 
  in the substantive crime, it is held that the persons necessarily involved cannot 
  be charged with conspiracy to commit the substantive offense and also with the 
  substantive crime itself.

Id. at 256, 153 S.E.2d at 907-08; see also Ferguson at 
  303, 70 S.E.2d at 356 (â€œIt is true that in some cases where concerted action 
  is necessary, as for example in certain sexual offenses, it is not permitted 
  to charge one in the same indictment with a conspiracy and also with the substantive 
  crime.â€).Â  Thus, 

if the substantive offense requires by definition the concerted 
  action of two persons, as for example the crime of adultery, then those persons 
  cannot be convicted of conspiracy to commit the offense because this would merely 
  be a subterfuge to increase the legislatively authorized punishment for the 
  substantive offense.Â  

McAninch & Fairey 482.
Once an agreement has been reached, the crime of 
  conspiracy has been committed; no further act need take place.Â  â€œConspiracy 
  is an inchoate offense, and is a crime in and of itself.â€ Â 15A C.J.S. Conspiracy 
  Â§ 98 (2002) (footnotes omitted); see Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1108 
  (7th ed. 1999) (defining â€œinchoate offenseâ€ as â€œ[a] step toward the commission 
  of another crime, the step in itself being serious enough to merit punishment.â€).Â  
  â€œProhibition of conspiracy serves two distinct purposes: the punishment of group 
  behavior and the control of inchoate activities.â€Â  15A C.J.S. Conspiracy 
  Â§ 98.Â Â  

The basis of conspiratorial liability is not to punish the 
  agreement per se, but, rather, like other inchoate crimes, to punish the firm 
  purpose to commit a substantive crime, while hopefully preventing the actual 
  commission thereof.

Id.; see also McAninch & Fairey 474 (â€œThe 
  basic rationale of conspiracy seems to be that the combination of two or more 
  persons makes it more likely that the criminal objective will be achieved, because 
  the co-conspirators may offer each other encouragement and support, thereby 
  rendering it less likely that the project will be abandoned.â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
â€œIt need not be shown that either the object or the means agreed upon is an 
  indictable offense in order to establish a criminal conspiracy.Â  It is sufficient 
  if the one or the other is unlawful.â€Â  Fleming at 274, 133 S.E.2d at 
  805.Â  Ameker demonstrates the breadth of activity that can give rise 
  to an indictment for conspiracy.Â  73 S.C. 330, 53 S.E. 484 (1906).Â  In 
  Ameker, the defendant was convicted of â€œunlawfully, feloniously, and 
  willfully conspir[ing] . . . for the purpose of hindering, preventing, and obstructing 
  certain citizens . . . [who were] engaging in social intercourse and peaceable 
  pastimes, such as are commonly enjoyed at picnics. . .â€Â  Id. at 332-33, 
  53 S.C. at 484-85.Â  The action arose when a group of picnickers was disturbed 
  by the defendant and several co-conspirators. Â â€œAbe Ameker began playing his 
  banjo, while Cleveland Hooker danced and cursed. . . . One of the defendants 
  had a paddle in his hand, and the inevitable pistol was also in hand.â€ Id. 
  at 337, 53 S.E. at 486.Â  One man was struck with the boat paddle, and knives 
  and guns were drawn before the engagement subsided.Â  Id.Â  The court upheld 
  Amekerâ€™s conviction.Â  
Our supreme court, in State v. Amerson, noted that â€œa single conspiracy 
  may be established by completely different aggregations of proof so that there 
  appears to be several conspiracies.â€Â  311 S.C. at 319, 428 S.E.2d at 873 (1993) 
  (citation omitted).Â  Consequently, â€œa multi-pronged flexible â€˜totality of the 
  circumstancesâ€™ test is applied to determine whether there were two conspiracies 
  or merely one.â€Â  Id.Â  The test considers:

(1) the time periods covered by the alleged conspiracies; (2) the places where 
  the conspiracies are alleged to have occurred; (3) the persons charged as conspirators; 
  (4) the overt acts alleged to have been committed in furtherance of the conspiracies, 
  or any other descriptions of offenses charged which indicate the nature and 
  scope of the activities being prosecuted; and (5) the substantive statutes alleged 
  to have been violated.

Id.Â Â  
Once a conspiracy has been established, evidence establishing beyond a reasonable 
  doubt the connection of a defendant to the conspiracy, even though the connection 
  is slight, is sufficient to convict him with knowing participation in the conspiracy.Â  
  Horne, 324 S.C. at 382, 478 S.E.2d at 294 (citing State v. Sullivan, 
  277 S.C. 35, 282 S.E.2d 838 (1981)).Â  
Generally, the conspiracy is proven by overt acts committed in furtherance 
  of the conspiracy.Â  Amerson, 311 S.C. at 319-20, 428 S.E.2d at 873.Â  
  However, overt acts are not necessary for a conspiracy conviction.Â  â€œIt is axiomatic 
  that a conspiracy may be proved by direct or circumstantial evidence or by circumstantial 
  evidence alone.â€Â  Horne, 324 S.C. at 381, 478 S.E.2d at 294 (citing State 
  v. Childs, 299 S.C. 471, 385 S.E.2d 839 (1989)).Â  Indeed, State v. Miller, 
  223 S.C. 128, 74 S.E.2d 582 (1953), notes: â€œOften proof of conspiracy is necessarily 
  by circumstantial evidence alone.â€Â  Id. at 133, 74 S.E.2d at 585 (citation 
  omitted).Â  Because the actus reus of conspiracy is the agreement, the evidence 
  must prove the agreement, not the object thereof.Â  McAninch observes, â€œThe agreement 
  might be difficult to establish by direct evidence if none of the co-conspirators 
  will talk.Â  Consequently, the cases in this jurisdiction, as well as others, 
  which hold that the agreement can be established by circumstantial evidence 
  are legion.â€Â  McAninch & Fairey 476 (citations omitted).Â  The State â€œis 
  permitted great latitude in the introduction of circumstantial evidence to establish 
  the existence of a conspiratorial agreement.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 315 S.C. 
  289, 294, 433 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1993).Â  
State v. Oliver, 275 S.C. 79, 267 S.E.2d 529 (1980), exemplifies the 
  sufficiency of circumstantial evidence to convict on conspiracy.Â  Oliver was 
  indicted along with two other individuals for conspiracy to commit housebreaking 
  and grand larceny.Â  Id. at 79, 267 S.E.2d at 530.Â  The defendants were 
  accused and convicted of breaking into two houses.Â  Upon conviction, Oliver 
  appealed, asserting the evidence was insufficient and his motion for a directed 
  verdict should have been granted.Â  Id. at 79-80, 267 S.E.2d at 530.Â  
  Evidence showed Oliverâ€™s codefendant, Willie Williams, rented a U-Haul truck 
  a few weeks before the crimes.Â  On the day of the break-ins, Williams purchased 
  gasoline in the U-Haul truck approximately forty or fifty miles from the crime 
  scene, and a receipt for the gas purchase was found near one of the houses.Â  
  A neighbor of one of the homes observed the U-Haul parked in the neighborhood.Â  
  A filling station attendant and the neighbor both testified to seeing three 
  men wearing dark clothes in the truck.Â  Similar shoe tracks were found at both 
  houses, â€œindicating that the same individuals entered both places.â€Â  Id. 
  at 81, 267 S.E.2d at 531.Â  Finally, a law enforcement officer arrested the defendants 
  approximately three miles from the scene of one of the homes.Â  The defendants 
  were in the U-Haul truck and matched the descriptions given by the station attendant 
  and neighbor.Â  The court found this evidence â€œreasonably tended to establish 
  the guilt of appellants, and the trial judge properly denied their motions for 
  a directed verdict.â€Â  Id. at 82, 267 S.E.2d at 531.Â  The court stated:

Although there is no direct evidence that appellants and their 
  codefendant had a mutual understanding to commit housebreaking and larceny, 
  the facts and circumstances are susceptible to the reasonable inference that 
  they did in fact conspire to commit the unlawful acts.Â  

Id. at 80, 267 S.E.2d at 530.Â  
State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998), involved the sufficiency 
  of evidence for a criminal conspiracy conviction.Â  The appellant, Kelsey, and 
  several other individuals spent the day of July 11, 1994, building pipe bombs.Â  
  That night, they picked up the victim and took her to a party.Â  Several hours 
  later the defendants offered to take the victim home.Â  The court described the 
  events leading to the victimâ€™s death:

Defendants and [victim] then got into Leeâ€™s car, ostensibly to take [victim] 
  home.Â  Lee was driving, Kelsey was in the passenger seat, and Payne and [the 
  victim] were in the backseat.Â  Although [the victim] had given them directions 
  to her house, Lee detoured in the opposite direction. . . . Lee turned around 
  and saw that Payne had [victim] in a â€œstrangle hold type position.â€Â  Lee continued 
  to drive.Â  A few minutes later, Lee â€œheard two quick, empty thud type sounds.â€ 
  . . . Kelsey testified that he had also turned around and saw that [victimâ€™s] 
  body was limp, her face was pale, and her lips were blue.
Lee once again drove away from the bridge.Â  He got approximately 100 feet down 
  the road when Payne told him to stop the car.Â  Defendants pulled [victim] out 
  of the car and carried her into the woods and up an embankment where they placed 
  her on the ground.Â  Lee returned to the car.Â  Payne and Kelsey remained by [victim]â€™s 
  body.

Kelsey testified that while he was standing over [victim]â€™s body, 
  Payne instructed him to place a pipe bomb into [victim]â€™sÂ  mouth.Â  Kelsey complied.Â  
  Payne then lit the fuse, and the two ran.Â  A few seconds later, the bomb exploded.Â  
  Defendants returned to Kirchner's house where they fell asleep.
Id. at 59-61, 502 S.E.2d 67-68.Â  
The court 
  upheld the conspiracy conviction under the following analysis:

In State v. Childs, 299 S.C. 471, 385 S.E.2d 839 (1989), the defendant 
  argued that the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict 
  on a conspiracy charge. We disagreed, finding that the following facts tended 
  to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt: evidence that defendant knew codefendant; defendant 
  was seen running from the area where the victimâ€™s body was found; bloodhounds 
  had tracked the victimâ€™s scent to the codefendantâ€™s house; and defendant had 
  given a written statement stating that he agreed to be a lookout for codefendant.
In this case, evidence indicated that Kelsey was instrumental in constructing 
  the pipe bombs at Kirchnerâ€™s house; that Kelsey was with Lee and Payne on the 
  night of the murder; that Kelsey helped Payne carry [victim] into the woods; 
  that Kelsey and Payne were alone together in the woods with [victim]â€™s body; 
  and that Kelsey placed the pipe bomb into [victim]â€™s mouth. We therefore find 
  the evidence was sufficient to submit the conspiracy charge to the jury.

Id. at 63-64, 502 S.E.2d at 70.
In State v. Follin, 352 S.C. 235, 573 S.E.2d 812 (Ct. App. 2002), cert. 
  denied, Follin was convicted of aiding and abetting embezzlement, obtaining 
  goods and services by false pretenses, and conspiracy.Â  One of her issues on 
  appeal was that her motion for a directed verdict should have been granted on 
  the conspiracy charge.Â  The facts underlying Follin involved â€œthe diversion 
  of nearly $2.5 million from Sumter County School District 17 (District 17) by 
  Adolph Joseph Klein, the Assistant Superintendent in charge of Financial Affairs 
  for District 17.â€Â  Id. at 240, 573 S.E.2d at 814.Â  Follin was a travel 
  agent and owner of Follin Travel who handled the travel arrangements for District 
  17.Â  From 1987 to 1997, Klein diverted nearly $1.5 million in personal travel 
  expenses for himself and his friends and family by booking luxury vacations 
  through Follin, which were paid for by District 17.Â  The Follin court 
  explained, 

In 1995, Klein learned that if travel plans made one week were cancelled before 
  the Friday of that same week, no payment would be required on the trip, the 
  invoice would be voided, and the invoice number would no longer appear in Follin's 
  computerized accounting system.Â  He began using invoices to get District 17 
  to pay for his junket travel.Â  Klein would request an invoice from Follin for 
  what appeared to be legitimate travel for a school group or a District 17 employee.Â  
  Klein would then request that Follin void the invoice prior to the Friday of 
  that week. Follin would cancel the trip in her computer and stamp â€œvoidâ€ on 
  her copy of the invoice.Â  However, Klein submitted his clean copy of the invoice 
  to District 17 for payment.Â  Klein called these invoices â€œspecial invoicesâ€ 
  for the junket travel.Â  After the check was issued to Follin on the special 
  invoice, Klein would attach a note to the check identifying for Follin the invoice 
  number to which she should apply the check. The invoice number did not match 
  the number on the special invoice submitted to District 17 for payment but matched 
  the invoice number of another of Klein's junket trips.

Id. at 240-41, 573 S.E.2d at 814-15.Â  When District officials began 
  investigating Kleinâ€™s travel expenses, Follin attempted to cover up the scheme 
  by asserting the District had a refund credit.Â  
We found sufficient evidence to support the denial of a directed 
  verdict on criminal conspiracy:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, Klein would not 
  have been able to proceed with his travel scheme without Follinâ€™s assistance.Â  
  Despite the fact that there was not a spoken agreement between the two to defraud 
  District 17, the uncontradicted evidence showed that Follin knowingly assisted 
  Klein by creating false records indicating District 17 had a credit.Â  Klein 
  testified that he and Follin conspired through their actions.Â  Although the 
  agreement was not written or verbalized, evidence was presented that an arrangement 
  was reached between Klein and Follin to defraud District 17.Â  Because there 
  was evidence that reasonably tended to prove Follin conspired with Klein, the 
  trial judge properly denied Follinâ€™s motion for a directed verdict as to this 
  charge. 

Id. at 267, 573 S.E.2d at 829-30.Â  See also State v. Clark, 
  286 S.C. 432, 334 S.E.2d 121 (1985) (finding â€œample evidence . . . to support 
  appellantâ€™s conviction of conspiracyâ€ to housebreak where appellant was found 
  near the crime scene; was apprehended as he drove away with his headlights off; 
  originally denied knowing his codefendant, who was later determined to be his 
  cousin; and admitted his codefendant told him of the larceny plans, but denied 
  any participation in them). 
In the instant case, sufficient evidence exists to support the trial 
  judgeâ€™s denial of Appellantâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  Appellant was 
  in the vehicle immediately after the burglary was perpetrated, and he fled when 
  Jonathan stopped the car.Â  Jonathanâ€™s statement contradicts his trial testimony, 
  and it was the responsibility of the jury to weigh both his statement and his 
  testimony.Â  According to his statement, Jonathan witnessed Appellant (1) carrying 
  stolen saws from the store to the car; (2) loading saws into the car; and (3) 
  handing John the saws from the backseat.Â  Furthermore, the police found bolt 
  cutters, gloves, and flashlights in the vehicleâ€”items that could give rise to 
  an inference that John, Jonathan, and Appellant planned the burglary.Â  Additionally, 
  though Jonathan testified that they proceeded through the drive-through at the 
  restaurant rather than eating inside, the police did not find any trash from 
  the fast-food restaurant in the vehicle.Â  As in Oliver, although this 
  evidence does not constitute direct evidence of an agreement, the facts and 
  circumstances are susceptible to the reasonable inference that Appellant conspired 
  to commit the unlawful acts.Â  Ample evidence exists from which a jury could 
  infer either an express plan, or a tacit, mutual understanding to commit the 
  burglary.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is affirmed.
IV.Â  Coercion/Duress
In State v. Robinson, 294 S.C. 120, 363 S.E.2d 104 (1987), 
  the South Carolina Supreme Court explained the defense of coercion:

To excuse a criminal act, the degree of coercion must be present, imminent, 
  and of such a nature as to induce a well-grounded apprehension of death or serious 
  bodily harm if the act is not done.Â  Coercion is no defense if there is any 
  reasonable way, other than committing the crime, to escape the threat of harm.Â  
  The fear of injury must be reasonable.Â  

Id. at 121-22, 363 S.E.2d at 104 (citations omitted).Â  Similarly, in 
  State v. Benjamin, 345 S.C. 470, 549 S.E.2d 258 (2001), our supreme court 
  provided the following definition of duress:

To establish duress which will excuse a criminal act, the degree 
  of coercion must be present, imminent, and of such a nature as to induce a well-grounded 
  apprehension of death or serious bodily harm if the act is not done.Â  Coercion 
  is no defense if there is any reasonable way, other than committing the crime, 
  to escape the threat of harm.Â  The fear of injury must be reasonable.

Id. at 474 n.3, 549 S.E.2d at 260 n.3. Â â€œCoercion and duress envision 
  a third person compelling another by threat of immediate physical violence to 
  commit a crime against someone else or someone elseâ€™s property.â€Â  State v. 
  Holliday, 333 S.C. 585, 588, 510 S.E.2d 436, 438 (Ct. App. 1998) (citations 
  omitted).
Our review of this record convinces us that the evidence in regard 
  to coercion and duress is de minimis.Â  Additionally, the issues of coercion 
  and duress were factual issues to be decided by the trial jury.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Dixon v. Ford
description: In this civil action, the appellant contends the Circuit Judge erred:  (1) in charging the jury that a purchaser of an infested home has no right to rely on favorable answers on the wood infestation report given to the purchaser at the closing; and (2) in admitting the testimony of a witness in regard to prior sale conversations and activities.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Raymond Capers Dixon, Robert Marshall Dixon and Kirsten Dixon,
Appellants,
v.
Clinton Karl Ford, Jimmy F. Hughes, Jr., d/b/a J&D Pest Control,
Defendants,
Of whom Clinton Karl Ford is the Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3934
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Kenneth R. Young, Jr. and Edgar R. Donald, Jr., both of Sumter, for Appellants.
M. M. Weinberg, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: 
Raymond Capers 
  Dixon, Robert Marshall Dixon, and Kirsten Dixon (the Dixons) purchased a house 
  from Clinton Ford.Â  After the sale, the Dixons discovered substantial termite 
  damage to the house.Â  The Dixons initiated this action, and a verdict was rendered 
  for Ford.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Ford acquired a house at 9 Loring Mill Road as investment 
  property, which he eventually decided to renovate and sell.Â  A pest control 
  company inspected the home prior to the renovations and provided an undated 
  CL-100 report in July 1999.Â  South Carolina Code of Laws regulation 27-1085(k) 
  requires a current CL-100, one completed within the last thirty days, at any 
  real estate closing.Â  
In March 2000, the Dixons purchased 9 Loring Mill 
  Road from Ford.Â  Ford furnished the July 1999 CL-100 report at the closing.Â  
  Importantly, the original CL-100 report identified the existence of termite 
  damage and stated: â€œthis damaged area has will been [sic] repaired by another 
  contractor.â€Â  The word â€œwillâ€ is written in small font above and between the 
  words â€œhasâ€ and â€œbeen.â€Â  The CL-100 provided at closing is identical except 
  that the word â€œwillâ€ is scratched over so that the report reads: â€œthis damaged 
  area has been repaired.â€Â  
The real estate contract contained the following 
  â€œas isâ€ clause:

19.Â Â Â Â  CONDITION OF PROPERTY:Â  (A) . . . Buyer acknowledges 
  the Seller, except as provided in subparagraphs (B)-(G) of this section, gives 
  no guarantee or warranty of any kind, expressed or implied, as to the physical 
  condition of the property or to the conditions of or existence of improvements, 
  services, appliances or system thereto, or as to merchantability or fitness 
  for a particular purpose as to the property or improvements thereof, and any 
  implied warranty is hereby disclaimed by the Seller. . . .Â  (D) Seller shall, 
  at their expense, have the property inspected and shall obtain a Wood Infestation 
  Report (CL100) from a licensed and bonded pest control operator that the residential 
  dwelling and attached garage is free and clear from termites, fungus, excess 
  moisture in the crawl space, wet or dry rot, and other wood destroying organisms. 
  . . . If any infestation or structural damage is found, Seller agrees to have 
  it corrected, at Sellerâ€™s expense.Â  

After purchase, the Dixons 
  discovered substantial uncorrected termite damage.Â  Robert Dixon testified that 
  he and his brother first came upon the dilapidation while preparing to install 
  a new heat pump:

I started to remove some 
  of the lapboard that was right there by the electrical panel box and thatâ€™s 
  when the electrical panel box fell down and just was dangling there by the wires 
  and thatâ€™s when I called my brother over there and said, â€œDavid, I think weâ€™ve 
  got a real problem here.â€Â  And we pulled off more of the boards and sure enough 
  as I suspected the electrical panel box was supposed to been . . . of course 
  it was supposed to been put into the studs and secured that way.Â  The studs 
  were completely termite riddled.Â  As we tore off more we realized that more 
  of it was done.Â  We got to the corner of the house on the back porch and then 
  we realized that the whole corner of the two . . . the two by fours there was 
  holding up the corner had completely been eaten away with termites and my brother 
  and I looked at each other and said what are we going to do now because it looks 
  like the roof is going to fall in.Â  

The Dixons found similar 
  damage to the floors and other areas of the house and responded by filing a 
  suit against Ford and the pest control company that issued the CL-100.Â  Summary 
  judgment was granted to the pest control company, leaving Ford as the sole defendant, 
  and fraud as the only remaining cause of action.Â  The case went to trial, and 
  the jury found in favor of Ford.Â  The Dixons filed post-trial motions for judgment 
  non obstante veredicto and alternatively for a new trial.Â  These motions were 
  based on the grounds that the court (1) gave an erroneous jury charge, and (2) 
  allowed irrelevant and prejudicial testimony into evidence.Â  Both motions were 
  denied, and the Dixons appeal.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  The Contested Jury Charge
The Dixons argue the court improperly charged the 
  jury that they had no right to rely on the wood infestation report supplied 
  at closing.Â  We agree.
 A.Â Â Â Â Â  Efficacy of the Charge
After explaining the elements of fraud, the court 
  charged the jury: 

A fraudulent act is characterized 
  by dishonesty in fact, unfair dealing or unlawful appropriation of anotherâ€™s 
  property by design.Â  One cannot rely upon a misstatement of facts if the truth 
  is easily within the reach of another.Â  I would also tell you that a purchaser 
  of a home . . . an infested home has no right to rely on favorable answers on 
  the wood infestation report given the purchaser at the closing where the purchaser 
  elected to close or failed to comply with a recommendation on the report that 
  he investigate for structural damages.

(Emphasis added).Â  
â€œWhen instructing the jury, the trial judge is 
  required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.â€Â  Cohens 
  v. Atkins, 333 S.C. 345, 349, 509 S.E.2d 286, 289 (Ct. App. 1999); see 
  also Brown v. Smalls, 325 S.C. 547, 554-555, 481 S.E.2d 444, 448 (Ct. 
  App. 1997) (â€œOrdinarily, a trial judge has a duty to give a requested instruction 
  that correctly states the law applicable to the issues and evidence.â€).Â  However, 
  when reviewing a jury charge for alleged error, the appellate court must consider 
  the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  
  Daves v. Cleary, 355 S.C. 216, 224, 584 S.E.2d 423, 427 (Ct. App. 
  2003).Â  If the charge is reasonably free from error, isolated portions which 
  might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.Â  Id.Â  â€œTo warrant 
  reversal for refusal to give a requested instruction, the refusal must have 
  not only been erroneous, but prejudicial as well.â€Â  Cohens, 333 S.C. 
  at 349, 509 S.E.2d at 289; see also Daves at 224, 584 S.E.2d at 
  427 (stating a circuit courtâ€™s refusal to give a properly requested charge is 
  reversible error only where the requesting party can demonstrate prejudice from 
  the refusal).
The language charged by the 
  court came from Nine v. Henderson, 313 S.C. 309, 312-13, 437 S.E.2d 182, 
  184 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Specifically, the verbiage emanates from a parenthetical 
  explanation of Bostick v. Orkin Exterminating Co., Inc., 806 F.2d 504 
  (4th Cir. 1986).Â  The trial court, in the case sub judice, defended the 
  controverted charge, explaining: 

The quote is directly from the case of Nine v. Henderson, 
  . . . with the exception that that dealt with powder post beetles which I thought 
  was a comment on the facts and I took that comment about powder post beetles 
  out of it and I also took that part out of that particular language that said 
  a South Carolina regulation because thereâ€™s no testimony in the record regarding 
  the South Carolina regulation.Â  But other than that that is a direct quote from 
  that case . . . . 

The Nine courtâ€™s citation to Bostick, 
  and the sentence it supports, reads in full:
We also agree, however, with the trial court that Nine, under 
  the circumstances here, had no reasonable right to rely on Hendersonâ€™s 
  representations regarding the extent of termite damage to the building in question.Â  
  See Bostick v. Orkin Exterminating Co., Inc., 806 F.2d 504, 508-09 
  (4th Cir. 1986) (construing South Carolina law and holding a purchaser of a 
  home infested by powder post beetles had no right to rely on favorable answers 
  on a wood infestation report given the purchaser at the closing where the purchaser 
  elected to close and failed to comply with a recommendation in the report and 
  a South Carolina regulation that he investigate for structural damage).
Nine, 313 S.C. at 312-13, 437 S.E.2d at 184 
  (emphasis added).Â  
A close reading of both Nine and Bostick 
  reveals that the charge given in the instant case is a misstatement of the applicable 
  law and should not have been charged.Â  In Nine, the dispositive question 
  on appeal related to whether Nine, the buyer of a house, had a right to rely 
  on the sellerâ€™s representation regarding termite infestation on the property 
  he was purchasing.Â  313 S.C. at 310, 437 S.E.2d at 183.Â  Nine â€œknew from the 
  very start the property had termite problems.â€Â  Id. at 313, 437 S.E.2d 
  at 184.Â  For example, during negotiations, the seller â€œdisclosed to Nine that 
  a termite inspection done the previous May revealed the presence of termites 
  in the eaves of the house and in the window sills and doors of the garage.â€Â  
  Id. at 311, 437 S.E.2d at 183.Â  Prior to closing, Nine rented and occupied 
  the house, and he â€œpersonally repaired the termite-damaged eaves on the side 
  of the house and repaired some additional damage that he discovered along the 
  front of the house.â€Â  Id.Â  
The Nine court explicated:

At the closing, which Nine attended accompanied by his attorney, 
  Henderson furnished Nine with three wood infestation reports.Â  These reports 
  were made the day after the parties signed the contract of sale by the same 
  termite inspector who made the May inspection.Â  They separately detailed inspections 
  that the termite inspector made of the three improvements located on the subject 
  property.Â  They also set forth the inspectorâ€™s conclusions regarding the presence 
  of termites and other wood-destroying insects in each of the buildings.
The report relating to the house expressly noted there had 
  been a previous infestation of termites and there was evidence of prior termite 
  treatment. . . . The report cautioned â€œ[t]here is possible hidden old termite 
  damage to the inside walls.â€Â  A graph attached to the report concerning the 
  house advised of â€œsubterranean termites,â€ â€œprobable hidden damage,â€ and â€œpossible 
  hidden termite damage in walls.â€
The report relating to the cottage also cautioned â€œ[t]here 
  is possible hidden termite damage behind the kitchen cabinets from previous 
  infestation and along [the] baseboard by window.â€Â  A graph attached to this 
  report advised of â€œsubterranean termites,â€ â€œprobable hidden damage,â€ and â€œprobable 
  hidden old termite damage behind [the] kitchen cabinets and baseboard.â€
All three reports counseled Nine:
  
    
      
      
        
          f there is evidence of active or past infestation of termites 
  . . . , it must be assumed that there is some damage to the building caused 
  by this infestation.
        
        
           . . . .
        
        
           . . . [Y]ou may wish to call a qualified 
  . . . expert in the building trade to ascertain their [sic] opinion as to whether 
  there is structural damage to this property.
        
      
      
    
  

Id. at 309, 437 S.E.2d at 183-84 (alterations 
  in original).
Based on these facts, the court concluded: â€œBy choosing not to postpone the 
  closing and electing instead to proceed with it, [buyer] ignored, if not outright 
  rejected, advice to have a qualified person ascertain whether the improvements 
  on the property had sustained structural damage. . . .â€Â  Nine at 313, 
  437 S.E.2d at 184.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
In Bostick, an extermination company prepared 
  a wood infestation report stating there were â€œvisible damaged structural membersâ€ 
  caused by a beetle infestation, but that there was â€œno visible structural damage.â€Â  
  Bostick, 806 F.2d at 505.Â  Subsequently, the home purchaser discovered 
  extensive structural damage and filed suit against the extermination company.Â  
  Yet, disclaimers on the report stated structure that was not visible or accessible 
  was not inspected.Â  Id. at 506.Â  Additionally, the court observed South 
  Carolina regulations governing wood infestation reports provide that a report 
  â€œcannot be viewed as a structural damage report.â€Â  Id. at 507 (quoting 
  S.C. Code Ann. Reg. Â§ 27-1085(k)).Â  The regulation reads, â€œIf visual evidence 
  of wood-destroying organisms or damage is noted in this report, further investigation 
  for structural damage by qualified building experts is recommended.â€Â  Id.Â  
  The court found that Bostickâ€™s case was built upon the cornerstone that he had 
  relied on the report as a record of structural damage.Â  Id. at 508-09.Â  
  This was impermissible under the regulations, and, therefore, his fraud action 
  failed.Â  Id.  
The charge, â€œ[A purchaser of] an infested home 
  has no right to rely on favorable answers on the wood infestation report given 
  the purchaser at the closing where the purchaser elected to close,â€ is an inaccurate 
  statement of South Carolina law.Â  Nine held that under the circumstances 
  presented in that case the buyer had no right to rely and cited Bostickâ€”another 
  case in which the particular facts nullified the right to relyâ€”as support.Â  
  However, our courts have not pronounced a per se rule holding, as a matter of 
  law, that the purchaser of an infested home may not rely on a CL-100 report 
  given at closing.Â  To the contrary, as the Nine opinion recites, â€œ[T]he 
  question of whether reliance is justified in a given situation requires an evaluation 
  of the circumstances involved, including the positions and relations of the 
  parties.â€Â  313 S.C. at 312, 437 S.E.2d at 184 (citing Elders v. Parker, 
  286 S.C. 228, 332 S.E.2d 563 (Ct. App. 1985)).Â  The charge given by the trial 
  court took from the jury its responsibility to evaluate the Dixonsâ€™ actions 
  and to determine whether they were justified in relying on the CL-100.Â  
Further, Nine and 
  Bostick are factually inapposite to the Dixonsâ€™ case.Â  Nine received 
  wood infestation reports showing damage and elected to go forward with the claims.Â  
  Bostick sought to sue the exterminator for fraud, but he relied on the report 
  in a manner the court ruled was impermissible because of disclaimers and state 
  regulations.Â  The Dixons, in contrast, were given a clear CL-100, which may 
  have been tampered with.Â  Charging the Nine language instructed that 
  the Dixons could not have relied on the report if it suggested an investigation 
  for structural damage and the purchaser did not comply.Â  The issue in this case 
  was not that the Dixons knew of damage and did not diligently investigate its 
  extent; instead, the Dixons were informed that the damaged areas had been repaired.Â  
  Ford and the Dixons contractually agreed that Ford would (1) be responsible 
  for procuring an independent third party to certify that the house is free from 
  termite infestation and damage, and (2) correct any infestation or damage at 
  his own expense.Â  Whether the Dixons were justified in their reliance under 
  the facts of this case is a question for the jury, and it was error for the 
  court to give the charge.Â  
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Impact of the â€œAs Isâ€ Clause
MacFarlane v. Manly, 274 S.C. 392, 264 S.E.2d 
  838 (1980), establishes that an â€œas isâ€ clause does not preclude a suit for 
  fraud.Â  MacFarlane involved an action for fraud in the sale of a house 
  that suffered from termite and water damage.Â  The contract included an â€œas isâ€ 
  clause.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to sellers on the basis that 
  the sellers â€œas a matter of law had no duty to disclose any matter to the Plaintiffs.â€Â  
  Id. at 392, 264 S.E.2d at 839.Â  Reversing, our supreme court announced:

The â€œas isâ€ clause of the contract does not constitute an 
  absolute defense to an action for fraud and deceit.Â  The inclusion of â€œas isâ€ 
  clauses is usually an effort on the part of the seller to assure application 
  of the caveat emptor rule. . . . 
In years gone by, the tendency of the law was to let the 
  buyer beware in real estate transactions.Â  The more recent trend at the law 
  is to hold the seller to a more strict accountability.Â  

Id. at 395-96, 264 S.E.2d at 840. 
Furthermore, the â€œas isâ€ clause in this 
  case provided that no guarantee or warranty was given â€œexcept as provided 
  in subparagraphs (B)-(G)[.]â€Â  In subparagraph (D), Ford agreed to procure 
  a clean CL-100 and to correct any infestation or damage at his expense.Â  Consequently, 
  the â€œas isâ€ clause does not protect Ford from the Dixonsâ€™ claim of fraud.
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Prejudice Resulting from the 
  Erroneous Charge
Notwithstanding the impropriety of the charge, 
  to warrant reversal, the charge must have prejudiced the Dixons.Â  See 
  Cohens v. Atkins, 333 S.C. 345, 349, 509 S.E.2d 286, 289 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
  We find that the charge given substantially prejudiced the Dixonsâ€™ case.Â  
In order to prevail on their claim for fraud, the 
  Dixons had to prove all nine of the elements of fraud in South Carolina.Â  See 
  Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 473, 581 S.E.2d 496, 503-04 
  (Ct. App. 2003) cert. denied (â€œThe elements of an action for fraud based 
  on a representation include: (1) a representation; (2) falsity; (3) its materiality; 
  (4) knowledge of the falsity or a reckless disregard of its truth or falsity; 
  (5) intent that the representation be acted upon; (6) the hearer's ignorance 
  of its falsity; (7) the hearer's reliance upon the truth; (8) the hearer's right 
  to rely thereon; and (9) the hearer's consequent and proximate injury.â€).Â  By 
  giving the erroneous charge, the court effectively determined that the Dixons 
  had no right to rely as a matter of law; therefore, they were precluded from 
  proving one of the essential elements of fraud.Â  The erroneous charge here is 
  the quintessential prejudicial charge because it established, as a legal conclusion, 
  that the Dixons could not prevail on an element of their cause of action.Â  Pellucidly, 
  the charge prejudiced the Dixons, and the case must be remanded for retrial.Â  

D.Â Â Â Â Â  Preservation of the Objection to the Charge
Ford seeks to circumvent the erroneous charge by 
  arguing the issue was not preserved because the objection was not on the grounds 
  that the charge did not match the facts.Â  However, after the charge, the Dixonsâ€™ 
  counsel did object to the offending language:

The Court:Â  Additions or exceptions to the charges, 
  Mr. Young?
Mr. Young:Â  Yes, sir. . . . . You gave a charge that 
  in effect commented on the termite letter and whether or not if a buyer proceeded 
  with an infected house or that they did so at their own peril just about and 
  thatâ€™s the essence of what youâ€™re saying and they had to follow the directions 
  on the letter to get a structural engineer to that effect, the letter that was 
  in this particular case was in fact a clear letter because the letter was presented 
  at closing showed that the work had been completed by another contractor therefore 
  any damage that was found would have been corrected as what Mr. Stoddard said 
  that it was a clear letter, my clients thought it was a clear letter, thatâ€™s 
  the reason they proceeded with closing. . . . 

When the court defended the language as originating 
  from Nine, counsel argued that in Nine, the purchaser â€œmade an 
  informed decision knowing that the wood infestation report showed [infestation].Â  
  They still went through with the closing.Â  Thatâ€™s not what we have here.â€Â  The 
  court referred to language from the report in this case, noting the report did 
  not consider structural damage.Â  Counsel rejoined, â€œBut it was repaired.Â  Thatâ€™s 
  under repairs.â€Â  This colloquy reveals that the Dixonsâ€™ counsel did raise the 
  salient issue: the language from Nine does not fit the facts and issues 
  raised in this case.Â  Accordingly, the issue was raised to the trial court and 
  preserved for our review.
Ford contends that the subject matter of an objection 
  regarding a jury instruction is not preserved where an objection is made prior 
  to the charge and not renewed after the charge is given but prior to the juryâ€™s 
  retiring to deliberate.Â  To support this proposition, he refers the court to 
  Creighton v. Coligny Plaza Ltd., 334 S.C. 96, 119, 512 S.E.2d 510, 522 
  (Ct. App. 1998).Â  However, the Dixons did object after the jury was charged, 
  but prior to the jury beginning its deliberations.Â  Thus, this argument is inappropriate.Â  

Nonetheless, we take this opportunity to remind 
  the bar that Rule 51, SCRCP, does not require that the objection to a charge 
  be renewed after the charge is given and prior to the juryâ€™s retiring to deliberate.Â  
  Instead, it only requires an objection on the record, opportunity for discussion, 
  and a specific ruling by the trial court on the jury charge issue.Â  Keaton 
  ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hospital System, 334 S.C. 488, 494-95, 514 
  S.E.2d 570, 573-74 (1999), addresses whether an objection to a jury charge was 
  properly preserved.Â  In Keaton, the plaintiff did not object to the pertinent 
  jury charge prior to the initial jury charge reading.Â  The court charged the 
  jury, but accidentally left out the charge at issue.Â  The defendants then objected 
  to the courtâ€™s omission of the charge; the judge agreed that the charge should 
  have been given.Â  At this point, the plaintiff objected to the charge for the 
  first time.Â  The court overruled the objection, brought the jury back into the 
  courtroom, and read the charge.Â  The Keaton court explained:

[Plaintiffâ€™s] on the record explanation of his objection 
  to the hindsight jury charge along with the trial judgeâ€™s ruling on that issue 
  is sufficient to preserve the objection for appeal.Â  The objection is preserved 
  despite [plaintiff] not objecting to the charge after it was read to the jury.Â  
  Our recent decision of State v. Johnson, 333 S.C. 62, 64 n.1, 508 S.E.2d 
  29, 30 n.1 (1998), observed that the majority and dissenting opinions in State 
  v. Whipple, 324 S.C. 43, 476 S.E.2d 683 (1996), were â€œbeing read to hold 
  that where a partyâ€™s jury charge objections or requests are denied on-the-record 
  after a pre-charge conference, the party must renew those objections or requests 
  subsequent to the courts instructions to the jury.Â  The majority opinion in 
  Whipple, however, did not establish such a rule.â€Â  Id.Â  Johnson 
  clarified the confusion in Whipple by stating, â€œwhere a party requests 
  a jury charge and, after opportunity for discussion, the trial judge declines 
  the charge, it is unnecessary, to preserve the point on appeal, to renew the 
  request at [the] conclusion of the courtâ€™s instructions.â€Â  Id. . . . 
  Like the petitioner in Johnson, [plaintiff] objected on the record and 
  the trial judge specifically ruled on the objection.Â  

334 S.C. at 494-95, 514 S.E.2d at 573.
II.Â  Testimony of William Brunson
The Dixons argue the testimony of William Brunson 
  should not have been admitted because it was irrelevant and overly prejudicial.Â  
  We decline to address this issue.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed 
  above, the decision of the trial court is 
REVERSED AND REMANDED 
  FOR A NEW TRIAL.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.
