title: Collins Entertainment v. White
description: In this contract action, Appellants assert the trial court erred by granting summary judgment in favor of Respondents.
text:
Collins Entertainment, Inc. v. White et. al.


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Collins Entertainment, Inc. f/k/a Collins Entertainment Corp.,
Respondent,
v.
Gary White, Gary Couillard, all individually, and d/b/a Montego Bay,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3935
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William Gary White, III, 
  of Columbia, for Appellants.
James B. Van Osdell and Charles B. Jordan, Jr., both of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Collins Entertainment, Inc. brought this breach of contract 
  action against Gary White, Gary Couillard, both individually, and d/b/a Montego 
  Bay (collectively Appellants) seeking to collect license fees.Â  The trial court 
  granted Collins a directed verdict on Appellantsâ€™ counterclaims, and the jury 
  returned a verdict in favor of Collins on its breach of contract claim.Â  We 
  affirm. [1] 
FACTS
In 1997, Collins signed a contract with the proprietors of Montego 
  Bay to place its video gaming machines in the establishment.Â  Shortly before 
  beginning operations, White and Couillard became the main partners of Montego 
  Bay and assumed the rights and obligations under the contract.Â  The contract 
  provided:Â  â€œCollins shall provide for all machine licenses and/or taxes the 
  costs of which shall be divided equally (50%/50%) between Proprietor and Collins.Â  
  Proprietor shall reimburse Collins for its share of such costs immediately upon 
  demand.â€Â  
Collins placed machines in Montego Bay for various periods of time.Â  
  Appellants were charged a pro rata share of the license fees, but Collins never 
  received payment.Â  According to a Collins employee, Appellants owed $18,687.32 
  in licensing fees to Collins.Â  
Collins brought the underlying breach of contract action against 
  Appellants, seeking to collect the unpaid fees.Â  Appellants answered and counterclaimed 
  for breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, 
  unfair trade practices, and violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt 
  Organizations Act (RICO). [2] Â  
  The answers did not specifically plead any affirmative defenses.Â  Collinsâ€™ complaint 
  was amended to seek pre-judgment interest.
On March 29, 2001, Appellants filed a motion to compel discovery 
  and served it on Collinsâ€™ former legal office along with Appellantsâ€™ First Request 
  to Admit.Â  Collins did not respond to the request to admit due to its service 
  on a location at which no attorneys worked.Â  On May 15, 2001, Appellants filed 
  a motion to dismiss as a result of Collinsâ€™ failure to respond.Â  
On May 25, 2001, Mr. Youmans, who along with Mr. Mongilo was Collinsâ€™ 
  in-house counsel until 2000, filed a motion to be relieved as counsel and set 
  forth an appropriate address at which he could be reached.Â  On May 31, 2001, 
  Appellants served a Second Request to Admit.Â  Again, they served the former 
  office of Collinsâ€™ in-house counsel.Â  
On June 29, 2001, Collinsâ€™ new counsel filed a motion to answer the First Request 
  to Admit.Â  On the same date, an affidavit from Mr. Mongilo was filed with the 
  court indicating no one practiced at the previous address.Â  After a hearing 
  before Judge Baxley, Collins was allowed to answer the First Request to Admit.Â  
  Specifically, Judge Baxley found:Â  â€œAt the time [Appellants] served these requests, 
  neither Mr. Youmans nor Mr. Mongilo, nor any other attorney operated at that 
  office.â€Â  Additionally, the court concluded:Â  â€œThis Court recognizes the confusion 
  and difficulty within [Collinsâ€™] organization occasioned by the demise of video 
  poker in South Carolina, and the resulting layoffs of the attorneys working 
  within the company.â€Â  
The court went on to find that Collinsâ€™ failure to respond was unintentional 
  and allowed Collins to respond.Â  At no time during this hearing did Appellants 
  make Collins or Judge Baxley aware of the Second Request to Admit.Â  Collins 
  did not timely respond to the request by the hearing date, and Appellants knew 
  it was served at the same address as the first.Â  
The first time Appellants made Collins aware of the Second Request to Admit 
  was at the start of trial.Â  The trial court ruled the requests were not deemed 
  admitted for the same reason Judge Baxley ruled the First Request to Admit was 
  not deemed admitted.Â  He found Appellants should have made the court and Collins 
  aware of the second set of requests and, under the specific circumstances, found 
  the requests would not be used to admit damages.Â  
Additionally, before trial began, the court ruled White could not operate as 
  an attorney and serve as a witness in the case under Rule 3.7 of the Professional 
  Rules of Conduct.Â  The court found it would be prejudicial for him to serve 
  as a witness regarding the contested issue of damages while serving as an attorney 
  for Couillard.Â  
At trial, Bill LaHart, a Collins employee, testified regarding the arrangement 
  between Collins, Montego Bay, and Appellants.Â  He testified the machines were 
  placed in Montego Bay pursuant to the contract, and Appellants were charged 
  a pro rated share of the license fee for each machine while it was in the establishment.Â  
  He testified the total owed by Appellants for the machinesâ€™ license fees amounted 
  to $18,687.32.Â  
Couillard testified the license fees were not required to be paid because of 
  a separate agreement reached with another Collins employee named Marshall Armstrong.Â  
  He testified Collins was attempting to extort money from Appellants.Â  Additionally, 
  he testified Appellants would have shut the machines down and given them back 
  to Collins had they been responsible for the license fees and taxes on the machines.Â  

Couillard testified he maintained a spreadsheet of all of his out-of-pocket 
  expenses.Â  The spreadsheet, however, was not presented at trial.Â  Couillard 
  also asserted he and White would both contribute money whenever it was needed 
  to keep the business afloat, though he did not know the exact amount, nor did 
  he have the checks to support his claims.Â  At one point, however, Couillard 
  did assert that Whiteâ€™s contribution may have been â€œ22, 25,000, something like 
  thatâ€ and that his â€œwas actually a little bit more.â€Â  
Collins moved for directed verdict as to Appellantsâ€™ counterclaims, alleging 
  they failed to offer any proof of damages.Â  The court agreed and directed a 
  verdict on all counterclaims.Â  
Appellants moved to amend the answer to include the 
  affirmative defense of estoppel.Â  Appellants attempted to argue the language 
  used in their breach of contract with fraudulent intent claim could support 
  a defense of estoppel.Â  In the alternative, Appellants sought to amend to conform 
  to the issues raised at trial.Â  The motion was denied.Â  Appellants also moved 
  for directed verdict as to Collinsâ€™ breach of contract claim on the grounds 
  Collins failed to produce documents and witnesses, the contract was illegal, 
  and for failing to prove damages.Â  The motion was denied.Â  
Collinsâ€™ claim for breach of contract went to the jury, 
  which returned a verdict in the amount of $18,687.32.Â  After post-trial motions 
  were filed, the court entered an award in favor of Collins in the amount of 
  $18,687.32 in actual damages, $6,758.58 in pre-judgment interest, and $14,227.65 
  in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn ruling on motions for directed verdict or judgment notwithstanding the 
  verdict, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences 
  that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party 
  opposing the motions.Â  The trial court must deny the motions when the evidence 
  yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.â€Â  Steinke v. 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Reg., 336 S.C. 373, 386, 
  520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999).Â  
â€œAn action for breach of contract seeking money damages is an action at law.â€Â  
  Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 
  (1992); R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 
  S.C. 424, 430, 540 S.E.2d 113, 117 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on 
  appeal of a case tried by a jury, the jurisdiction of this Court extends merely 
  to the correction of errors of law, and a factual finding of the jury will not 
  be disturbed unless a review of the record discloses that there is no evidence 
  which reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs. Ltd. v. City 
  of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â Â  
ISSUES ON APPEAL

  
    
    
      
        I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
         Did the trial court err in refusing to deem Appellantsâ€™ Second Request 
  to Admit admitted when Collins failed to respond?
      
      
        II.Â Â Â Â Â  
         Did the trial court err in refusing to publish both Appellantsâ€™ first 
  and second requests to admit to the jury?
      
      
        III. 
        
         Did the trial court err in granting Collinsâ€™ motion for directed verdict 
  as to Appellantsâ€™ counterclaims?
      
      
        IV.     
         Did the trial court err in failing to dismiss Collinsâ€™ claim for breach 
  of contract because the contract was an illegal gambling contract under S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 32-1-40 (Supp. 2003)?
      
      
        V.Â Â Â Â Â  
         Did the trial court err in failing to allow Appellants to amend their 
  answer to add the affirmative defense of estoppel?
      
      
        VI.   
        
         Did the trial court err in failing to find Collinsâ€™ claim barred by 
  the doctrines of laches or estoppel?
      
      
        VII.Â Â Â  
         Did the trial court err in prohibiting White from testifying as a witness 
  when he was also acting as an attorney?
      
    
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I & II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Request 
  to Admit
Appellants contend 
  the trial court erred in failing to deem their second request to admit as admitted 
  when Collins failed to respond.Â  Additionally, they aver the trial court erred 
  in refusing to publish the admittances to the jury.Â  We disagree.
Rule 36(a), SCRCP, provides:Â  â€œA party may serve upon any other party 
  a written request for the admission . . . of the truth of any matters within 
  the scope of Rule 26(b) . . . .â€Â  However, an admission may be withdrawn upon 
  application to the court:Â  

Any matter admitted under this rule is conclusively established unless the court 
  on motion permits withdrawal or amendment of the admission.Â  Subject to the 
  provisions of Rule 16 governing amendment of a pre-trial order, the court may 
  permit withdrawal or amendment when the presentation of the merits of the action 
  will be subserved thereby and the party who obtained the admissions fails to 
  satisfy the court that withdrawal or amendment will prejudice him in maintaining 
  his action or defense on the merits.Â Â Â Â Â  

Rule 36(b), SCRCP.
In the instant case, Judge Baxley previously found Appellantsâ€™ First 
  Request to Admit was filed at an office no longer in use and this constituted 
  a sufficient reason for refusing to deem the requests admitted and to allow 
  Collins to file late answers.Â  At the time of the hearing, Appellantsâ€™ Second 
  Request to Admit was outstanding and the time for Collins to file an answer 
  had expired.Â  Instead of informing the court and Collins of the outstanding 
  request, Appellants waited until the beginning of trial to mention the outstanding 
  requests to Collins and the new judge.Â  We find Appellants cannot now complain 
  of being prejudiced by the refusal to deem the requests admitted because they 
  could have raised the issue before Judge Baxley.Â  State v. Brannon, 341 
  S.C. 271, 275, 533 S.E.2d 345, 347 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œA party cannot complain 
  of an error induced by the partyâ€™s own conduct.â€) (citation omitted). 
Collinsâ€™ attorney denied any damages existed and also denied ever seeing the 
  request to admit.Â  Specifically, he stated:Â  â€œWe donâ€™t admit the amount of his 
  damages.Â  If he begins on damages, Your Honor, that is highly contested as far 
  as weâ€™re concerned.â€Â  The court did not prevent Appellants from offering proof 
  of their damages.Â  It simply required Appellants to offer the actual proof and 
  not rely upon the Second Request to Admit.Â  Therefore, Appellants were not prejudiced 
  by the refusal to deem the requests admitted.Â  Under the circumstances, we find 
  the trial court properly ruled on the issue.Â  
Appellants then sought to introduce into evidence the fact that the First Request 
  to Admit was not answered by Collins and, therefore, was deemed admitted prior 
  to Collins being granted the right to respond late to the request.Â  They also 
  sought to introduce the Second Request to Admit, asserting it had been admitted 
  by Collinsâ€™ failure to respond.Â  We find the trial court properly refused to 
  allow Appellants to publish to the jury Collinsâ€™ failure to respond.
Appellants rely on Tuomey Regional Medical Center, Inc. v. McIntosh, 
  315 S.C. 189, 432 S.E.2d 485 (1993), for the holding:

Once an answer to a Request for Admissions is amended under Rule 36, both the 
  initial answer and the amended answer may be published to the jury.Â  The jury 
  may consider the initial answers as evidence, while the party who made such 
  answers â€œis free to explain why it was made and [amended].â€

Id.  at 191, 432 S.E.2d at 487 (citing Wright & Miller, Federal 
  Practice and Procedure:Â  Civil Â§ 2264 at 745 (1970) (footnotes omitted)).Â  

In Tuomey, the requests were admitted by the partyâ€™s initial 
  answer.Â  The admitting party, however, then sought to amend its answer asserting 
  it inadvertently provided incorrect information.Â  The trial court granted the 
  amendment, but allowed both sets of answers to be submitted to the jury.Â  Id. 
  at 190-191, 432 S.E.2d at 486.Â  Tuomey is not similar to the present 
  case where the admission, which was subsequently withdrawn, arose solely from 
  the failure to make a timely response.
In any event, the Tuomey case relied on Wright and Millerâ€™s 
  Federal Practice and Procedure for the rule cited.Â  The full explanation 
  of the rule as it appears in Federal Practice and Procedure states:

The general rule with regard to a pleading that has been withdrawn 
  is that it can no longer be used as a conclusive judicial admission but that 
  it is admissible in evidence at the instance of the adversary as an evidentiary 
  admission, with the party who made the admission free to explain why it was 
  made and withdrawn. The cases have not focused on this question as it applies 
  to a Rule 36 admission. There would be reason to hold that an express admission, 
  later withdrawn, should be treated in the same fashion as a pleading, but 
  that if the court has permitted an admission through failure to make timely 
  response to be withdrawn, the admission should pass out of the case entirely. 


Wright & Miller, Federal 
  Practice and Procedure:Â  Civil Â§ 2264 at 579 (1994) (footnotes omitted) 
  (emphasis added).
We find where 
  an admission is made solely by the failure to make a timely response, such admission 
  being later withdrawn, the party is not allowed to publish the admission to 
  the jury.Â  The party may publish the late-filed response, but may not assert 
  before the jury that the requests were previously admitted.Â  Accordingly, we 
  conclude the trial court properly refused to allow Appellants to publish to 
  the jury the fact that Collins admitted the requests by failing to make a timely 
  response.
III.Â Â Â  Collinsâ€™ Motion for Directed Verdict
Appellants maintain the trial court erred in granting Collinsâ€™ motion 
  for directed verdict on the ground that they failed to prove damages.Â  We disagree 
  and find the record is devoid of evidence from which the jury could calculate 
  damages without resulting to speculation or conjecture.
First, we note Appellants only address the breach of contract claim 
  in their discussion of evidence of damages.Â  Accordingly, we find they have 
  abandoned their other counterclaims against Collins.Â  See Bell v. 
  Bennett, 307 S.C. 286, 294, 414 S.E.2d 786, 791 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding 
  an issue which is not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned on appeal); Rule 
  208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is not set 
  forth in the statement of the issues on appeal.â€).
â€œIn a breach 
  of contract action, damages serve to place the nonbreaching party in the position 
  he would have enjoyed had the contract been performed. . . . In the normal case, 
  the damage will consist of two distinct elements:Â  (1) out-of-pocket costs actually 
  incurred as a result of the contract; and (2) the gain above costs that would 
  have been realized had the contract been performed.â€Â  South Carolina Fed. 
  Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby Dev. Co., Inc., 303 S.C. 74, 77, 399 S.E.2d 
  8, 10-11 (Ct. App. 1990). Â â€œGenerally, in order for damages to be recoverable, 
  the evidence should be such as to enable the court or jury to determine the 
  amount thereof with reasonable certainty or accuracy.Â  While neither the existence, 
  causation nor amount of damages can be left to conjecture, guess or speculation, 
  proof with mathematical certainty of the amount of loss or damage is not required.â€Â  
  Whisenant v. James Island Corp., 277 S.C. 10, 13, 281 S.E.2d 794, 796 
  (1981).
Couillard testified 
  he kept a spreadsheet detailing some of the expenses he and White shared as 
  a result of their business dealings with Collins.Â  What he did not testify to, 
  however, was the amounts listed on the spreadsheet, nor did he present the spreadsheet 
  into evidence.Â  He merely stated that he and White would contribute $125 for 
  one thing or $500 for another.Â  Similarly, Couillard asserted he would write 
  checks for $7,000 or $1,000 or $1,500, but never explained why he wrote the 
  checks or how they came about as a result of Collinsâ€™ breach of the contract. 
  Â 
Finally, Couillard testified 
  that Whiteâ€™s out of pocket business expenses were â€œabout 22, 25,000, something 
  like that,â€ although he admitted he did not know an exact amount.Â  According 
  to Couillard, his contribution would have been more, but again did not offer 
  a specific dollar amount. Â As before, he failed to relate any of the 
  expenses to damages resulting from a breach of contract by Collins.Â  He simply 
  stated they were out-of-pocket expenses for the business, not that they were 
  expenses related to a breach of contract. 
Any calculation of damages 
  by the jury would have been pure speculation.Â  The Second Request to Admit was 
  properly excluded from evidence and none of the testimony presented provided 
  any evidence of an amount of damages attributable to any breach of contract 
  by Collins.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly granted the directed 
  verdict motion.
IV.Â Â Â  Illegal Contract
Appellants contend the contract was an illegal contract under section 
  32-1-40 of the South Carolina Code.Â  We disagree.
Section 32-1-40 is entitled â€œNotes or other securities or conveyances 
  given to secure wagers are void.â€Â  The section specifically provides:

All notes, bills, bonds, judgments, mortgages or other securities or conveyances 
  whatsoever given, granted, entered into or executed by any person whatsoever 
  when the whole or any part of the consideration of such conveyances or securities 
  shall be (a) for any money or valuable thing whatsoever won by cockfighting, 
  horse racing or by gaming or playing at cards, dice tables, tennis, bowls, or 
  other game whatsoever or by betting on the sides or hands of such as do game 
  at any of the games aforesaid or any other game or games or (b) for the reimbursing 
  or repaying any money knowingly lent or advanced at the time and place of such 
  cockfighting, horse racing or play to any person (i) so gaming or betting as 
  aforesaid or (ii) that shall, during such cockfighting, horse racing or play, 
  so bet shall be utterly void, frustrate and of none effect to all intents and 
  purposes whatsoever.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-1-40 (1991).
This section does not apply to the contract at 
  hand.Â  Collins did not lend money to Appellants for the purpose of gambling, 
  nor were securities or conveyances made using gambling proceeds.Â  The contract 
  provision required Appellants to pay one-half of the licensing fees due to the 
  State of South Carolina under section 12-21-2720 of the South Carolina Code.
Additionally, enforcement of the contract does not violate public 
  policy.Â  While the contract was in full effect, video poker was a legal enterprise 
  in South Carolina.Â  The obligations, which arose as a result of operating the 
  machines, were created when the games were legal.Â  Enforcement of a provision 
  requiring the payment of license fees, which were properly collected and remitted 
  to the State of South Carolina, is not in derogation of public policy. 
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Amendment of Answer
Appellants assert the trial court erred in refusing to allow them 
  to amend their answer to allege the affirmative defense of estoppel.Â  We disagree.
Rule 15, SCRCP, allows for the amendment of pleadings:

(a) Amendments.Â  A party may amend his pleading once as a matter of course at 
  any time before or within 30 days after a responsive pleading is servedÂ Â  . 
  . . .Â  Otherwise a party may amend his pleading only by leave of court or by 
  written consent of the adverse party; and leave shall be freely given when justice 
  so requires and does not prejudice any other party. . . . 
(b) Amendments to Conform to the Evidence.Â  When issues not raised by the pleadings 
  are tried by express or implied consent of the parties, they shall be treated 
  in all respects as if they had been raised in the pleadings.Â  Such amendment 
  of the pleadings as may be necessary to cause them to conform to the evidence 
  and to raise these issues may be made upon motion of any party at any time, 
  even after judgment . . . the court may allow the pleadings to be amended and 
  shall do so freely when the presentation of the merits of the action will be 
  subserved thereby and the objecting party fails to satisfy the court that the 
  admission of such evidence would prejudice him in maintaining his action or 
  defense upon the merits. 

It is well established that a motion to amend is addressed to the 
  discretion of the trial judge, and the party opposing the motion has the burden 
  of establishing prejudice.Â  Tanner v. Florence County Treasurer, 336 
  S.C. 552, 558-59, 521 S.E.2d 153, 156 (1999).Â  The prejudice that Rule 15 envisions 
  is a lack of notice that the new issue is to be tried and a lack of opportunity 
  to refute it.Â  Id.Â  Amendments to conform to the proof should be liberally 
  allowed when no prejudice to the opposing party will result.Â  Soil & 
  Material Engâ€™rs, Inc. v. Folly Assocs., 293 S.C. 498, 501, 361 S.E.2d 779, 
  781 (Ct. App. 1987).
Appellants assert the issue of estoppel was raised in the pleadings 
  under the arguments for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  
  We disagree and find that estoppel must be affirmatively pled as a defense and 
  cannot be bootstrapped onto another claim.Â  See Rule 8, SCRCP; Provident 
  Life & Accident Ins. Co. v. Driver, 317 S.C. 471, 478, 451 S.E.2d 924, 
  929 (Ct. App. 1994) (finding estoppel is an affirmative defense).
Additionally, we find the issue was not tried by consent of the parties.Â  
  While Appellants contend the comments and assurances made by Marshall Armstrong 
  form the basis of their estoppel claim and these were raised at trial, they 
  also were the grounds of the claim for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent 
  act.Â  Collins prepared to defend the breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent 
  act claim and not a claim of estoppel.Â  Accordingly, Collins sufficiently demonstrated 
  the prejudice envisioned by Rule 15, requiring the court to deny a motion to 
  amend.Â  See Tanner, 336 S.C. at 559, 521 S.E.2d at 156.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find the trial court properly denied Appellantsâ€™ motion to amend the pleadings.
VI.Â Â Â  Laches and Estoppel
Appellants contend the trial court erred in failing to dismiss the 
  claim as being barred by the doctrines of laches and/or estoppel.Â  We disagree.
As we found above, Appellants failed to plead estoppel as an affirmative 
  defense and the court properly denied their motion to include it as a defense.Â  
  Additionally, laches is an affirmative defense which must be specifically pled.Â  
  Rule 8(c), SCRCP.Â  The failure to plead an affirmative defense is deemed a waiver 
  of the right to assert it.Â  E.g., Adams v. B & D, Inc., 297 
  S.C. 416, 419, 377 S.E.2d 315, 317 (1989).Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court 
  properly refused to dismiss Collinsâ€™ claims under either theory.
VII.Â Â  White as Attorney 
  and Witness
Appellants also contend the trial court erred in finding White could 
  not act as both an attorney for Couillard and as a fact witness in this case.Â  
  We disagree.
Rule 3.7 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, provides:

(a) A lawyer shall not act as advocate at a trial in which the lawyer is likely 
  to be a necessary witness except where:
(1) The testimony relates to an uncontested issue;
(2) The testimony relates to the nature and value of legal services rendered 
  in the case; or
(3) Disqualification of the lawyer would work substantial hardship on the client.

Here, White sought to act as attorney for Couillard as well as a 
  witness regarding damages allegedly incurred as a result of Collinsâ€™ breach 
  of contract.Â  Collins contested the issue and denied it owed any money to White 
  or Couillard because it denied any breach existed.Â  Therefore, the first exception 
  does not apply.Â  The second exception also does not apply, as the testimony 
  was not in regards to Whiteâ€™s service as attorney.Â  â€œThe roles of an advocate 
  and of a witness are inconsistent; the function of an advocate is to advance 
  or argue the cause of another, while that of a witness is to state facts objectively.â€Â  
  State v. Capps, 276 S.C. 59, 65, 275 S.E.2d 872, 875 (1981) (Lewis, C.J., 
  dissenting) (quoting Ethical Consideration 5-9 of the Code of Professional Responsibility).Â  
  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in requiring White to choose 
  whether to act as counsel or to be called as a witness during trial.
Finally, the court determined no substantial hardship would be caused by White 
  acting only as a witness and Mr. Robert Rushing, Whiteâ€™s law partner, acting 
  as counsel for all involved.Â  Specifically, the court found the case was continued 
  several times due to Mr. Rushingâ€™s absence.Â  Mr. Rushing took an active role 
  in at least one motion hearing in addition to being involved in the trial.Â  
  Thus, we find no hardship would be created if Mr. Rushing were required to take 
  over Couillardâ€™s representation.Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J. and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

 
   [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  18 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 1961 et seq.

title: Rife v. Hitachi Construction
description: In this products liability case, three causes of action are pled:  (1) negligence; (2) strict liability â€“ manufacturing defect; and (3) strict liability- failure to warn.  The appellant was injured while operating a Hitachi EX100 excavator.  The excavator was designed, manufactured, and sold by Hitachi Construction Machinery Co., Ltd. in Japan for the Japanese market and sold originally to a Japanese customer.  The excavator was sold by American Equipment Company to the employer of the appellant in the United States.  The trial judge granted summary judgment:  (1) to Hitachi on the ground that it was not foreseeable that the EX100 would arrive in the United States and injure an American worker; and (2) to American Equipment Company on the ground that the failure to have a seat belt was not sufficient to establish that the excavator was either defective or unreasonably dangerous. The issues posited on appeal:  (1) whether it was foreseeable that the failure of Hitachi to equip the excavator with a seat belt would lead to an ejection injury to someone OR whether the injuries sustained by appellant were the foreseeable consequence of any alleged negligence of Hitachi because the excavator was manufactured according to Japanese standards, sold in the Japanese market, and there was no proof as to its introduction into the American market; and (2) whether the omission of the optional safety equipment â€“ seat belt â€“ caused the excavator to be in a defective condition and unreasonably dangerous to the user at the time it was sold by American Equipment Company.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Richard Rife, Appellant,
v.
Hitachi Construction Machinery Co., Ltd., Euclid-Hitachi Heavy Equipment, 
        Ltd., Deere-Hitachi Construction Machinery Corporation, Hitachi Construction 
        Machinery (America) Corporation, American Equipment Company, and Does 
        1-5 Inclusive, Defendants, of whom Hitachi Construction Machinery Co., 
        Ltd. and American Equipment Company are Respondents. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Benjamin H. Culbertson, Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3936
Heard January 11, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William Stuart Duncan, of Georgetown, for Appellant.
N. Ward Lambert, of Greenville, for Respondent American 
  Equipment Company, Inc.
J. Calhoun Watson, of Columbia, for Respondent Hitachi 
  Construction Machinery Co., Ltd.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this products liability case, Richard Rife 
  appeals the trial courtâ€™s orders granting summary judgment to Hitachi Construction 
  Machinery Co., Ltd. (Hitachi) and American Equipment Company (American Equipment).Â  
  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On June 25, 1999, Rife sustained an injury while operating a 1992 Hitachi EX100 
  Excavator (EX100).Â  When Rife pushed the controls of the excavator to drive 
  off an embankment, the EX100 suddenly lurched forward and then abruptly stopped.Â  
  The sudden stop ejected Rife through the front window of the operatorâ€™s cab, 
  injuring him.
When the accident occurred, Rife worked for Armand Berube d/b/a Dirty 
  Works, Inc., a grading contractor.Â  In March of 1998, Dirty Works purchased 
  the used EX100 from American Equipment as-is.Â  Berube knew the excavator was 
  a â€œgray marketâ€ machine.Â  Machinery sold on the â€œgray marketâ€ consists of equipment 
  designed, manufactured, and marketed for use in a foreign country, but which 
  is imported into the United States.Â  Hitachi designed and manufactured the EX100 
  at issue solely for sale and use in Japan according to Japanese specifications 
  that differ significantly from American specifications.Â  Hitachi sold the EX100 
  in Japan to a Japanese purchaser for use in Japan.Â  The EX100 was never intended 
  for use in the United States.
At the time of the accident, the EX100 had no seat belt.Â  When Hitachi 
  manufactured the EX100, a seat belt was an available option in accordance with 
  the Japanese safety standards.
Rife filed this action against Hitachi and American Equipment alleging (1) 
  negligence; (2) strict liability based on a manufacturing defect; and (3) strict 
  liability based on a failure to warn of the defect.Â  After answering, Hitachi 
  and American Equipment filed motions for summary judgment.Â  The trial court 
  granted both motions.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the 
  appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under 
  Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue 
  as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter 
  of law.Â  White v. J.M. Brown Amusement Co., 360 S.C. 366, 601 S.E.2d 
  342 (2004); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 603 S.E.2d 
  629 (Ct. App. 2004); Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 581 
  S.E.2d 496 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact 
  exists, the evidence and all inferences which can reasonably be drawn therefrom 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Medical 
  Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004); 
  McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 499 S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  If 
  triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.Â  Baril v. Aiken Regâ€™l 
  Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 573 S.E.2d 830 (Ct. App. 2002); Young v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 S.C. 714, 511 S.E.2d 413 (Ct. App. 1999).
Summary judgment is appropriate where the pleadings, depositions, 
  answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, 
  if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that 
  the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Belton v. Cincinnati 
  Ins. Co., 360 S.C. 575, 602 S.E.2d 389 (2004); McCall v. State Farm Mut. 
  Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C. 372, 597 S.E.2d 181 (Ct. App. 2004); Rule 56(c), 
  SCRCP; see also Higgins v. Medical Univ. of South Carolina, 326 
  S.C. 592, 486 S.E.2d 269 (Ct. App. 1997) (noting that when ruling on a motion 
  for summary judgment, the trial judge must consider all of the documents and 
  evidence within the record, including pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, 
  admissions on file, and affidavits).Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary 
  judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and 
  inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the 
  non-moving party below.â€Â  Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 
  349 S.C. 558, 563, 564 S.E.2d 94, 96 (2002); see also Schmidt v. Courtney, 
  357 S.C. 310, 592 S.E.2d 326 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating that all ambiguities, 
  conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most 
  strongly against the moving party).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry 
  into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  
  Brockbank v. Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 534 S.E.2d 688 (2000); 
  Hawkins v. City of Greenville, 358 S.C. 280, 594 S.E.2d 557 (Ct. App. 
  2004).Â  Summary judgment should not be granted even when there is no dispute 
  as to evidentiary facts if there is disagreement concerning the conclusion to 
  be drawn from those facts.Â  Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 
  341 S.C. 320, 534 S.E.2d 672 (2000); Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 
  595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, when plain, palpable, and indisputable 
  facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary judgment should 
  be granted.Â  Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 340, 
  559 S.E.2d 327 (Ct. App. 2001); Pye v. Aycock, 325 S.C. 426, 480 S.E.2d 
  455 (Ct. App. 1997).
The party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly 
  establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.Â  McCall, 
  359 S.C. at 376, 597 S.E.2d at 183.Â  Once the party moving for summary judgment 
  meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the 
  opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials 
  contained in the pleadings.Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 
  582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Rather, the nonmoving party must come forward 
  with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial.Â  Ellis, 
  358 S.C. at 518-19, 595 S.E.2d at 822; Peterson v. West American Ins. Co., 
  336 S.C. 89, 518 S.E.2d 608 (Ct. App. 1999); Rule 56(c), SCRCP.
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do 
  not require the services of a fact finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 
  58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003); Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 
  357 S.C. 386, 593 S.E.2d 183 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Because it is a drastic remedy, 
  summary judgment should be cautiously invoked to ensure that a litigant is not 
  improperly deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues.Â  Helena Chem. 
  Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 594 S.E.2d 455 (2004); 
  Hawkins, 358 S.C. at 289, 594 S.E.2d at 561-62; Murray v. Holnam, 
  Inc., 344 S.C. 129, 542 S.E.2d 743 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Doctrinal Analysis/Products Liability
A products liability case may be brought under several theories, 
  including negligence, strict liability, and warranty.Â  Small v. Pioneer Mach., 
  Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 494 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 1997); Bragg v. Hi-Ranger, 
  Inc., 319 S.C. 531, 462 S.E.2d 321 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  In a products 
  liability action, regardless of the theory on which the plaintiff seeks recovery, 
  he must establish three elements: (1) he was injured by the product; (2) the 
  injury occurred because the product was in a defective condition, unreasonably 
  dangerous to the user; and (3) the product, at the time of the accident, was 
  in essentially the same condition as when it left the hands of the defendant.Â  
  Small, 329 S.C. at 462-63, 494 S.E.2d at 842; Bragg, 319 S.C. 
  at 539, 462 S.E.2d at 326; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-73-10(1) (1977) 
  (â€œOne who sells any product in a defective condition unreasonably dangerous 
  to the user or consumer or to his property is subject to liability for physical 
  harm caused to the ultimate user or consumer, or to his property . . . .â€).Â  
  Further, liability for negligence requires, in addition to the above, proof 
  that the manufacturer breached its duty to exercise reasonable care to adopt 
  a safe design.Â  Allen v. Long Mfg. NC, Inc., 332 S.C. 422, 505 S.E.2d 
  354 (Ct. App. 1998); Madden v. Cox, 284 S.C. 574, 328 S.E.2d 108 (Ct. 
  App. 1985).
Under any products liability theory, a plaintiff must prove the product defect 
  was the proximate cause of the injury sustained.Â  Bray v. Marathon Corp., 
  356 S.C. 111, 588 S.E.2d 93 (2003); Small, 329 S.C. at 463, 494 S.E.2d 
  at 842; see also Livingston v. Noland Corp., 293 S.C. 521, 362 
  S.E.2d 16 (1987) (finding proximate cause is an element of strict liability 
  claim); Young v. Tide Craft, Inc., 270 S.C. 453, 242 S.E.2d 671 (1978) 
  (holding proximate cause is an essential element common to the alternative theories 
  of negligence, breach of implied warranty, and strict liability in tort); S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-715(2)(b) (2003) (providing that consequential damages resulting 
  from sellerâ€™s breach include injury to person or property proximately resulting 
  from any breach of warranty).
A plaintiff suing under a products liability cause of action can recover all 
  damages that were proximately caused by the defendantâ€™s placing an unreasonably 
  dangerous product into the stream of commerce.Â  Small, 329 S.C. at 464, 
  494 S.E.2d at 843; Parr v. Gaines, 309 S.C. 477, 424 S.E.2d 515 (Ct. 
  App. 1992).Â  Proximate cause requires proof of causation in fact and legal cause.Â  
  Bray, 356 S.C. at 116-17, 588 S.E.2d at 95; Trivelas v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  Causation in fact is proved by establishing the injury would not have occurred 
  â€œbut forâ€ the defendantâ€™s negligence.Â  Small, 329 S.C. at 463, 494 S.E.2d 
  at 842.Â  Legal cause is proved by establishing foreseeability.Â  Bray, 
  356 S.C. at 117, 588 S.E.2d at 95; Small, 329 S.C. at 463, 494 S.E.2d 
  at 842.
The touchstone of proximate cause in South Carolina is foreseeability.Â  Koester 
  v. Carolina Rental Ctr., Inc., 313 S.C. 490, 443 S.E.2d 392 (1994); Small, 
  329 S.C. at 463, 494 S.E.2d at 842.Â  The test of foreseeability is whether some 
  injury to another is the natural and probable consequence of the complained-of 
  act.Â  Id.Â  For an act to be a proximate cause of the injury, the injury 
  must be a foreseeable consequence of the act.Â  Small, 329 S.C. at 463, 
  494 S.E.2d at 842-43.Â  Although foreseeability of some injury from an act or 
  omission is a prerequisite to establishing proximate cause, the plaintiff need 
  not prove that the actor should have contemplated the particular event which 
  occurred.Â  Whitlaw v. Kroger Co., 306 S.C. 51, 410 S.E.2d 251 
  (1991); Sims v. Hall, 357 S.C. 288, 592 S.E.2d 315 (Ct. App. 2003).
Proximate cause is the efficient or direct cause of an injury.Â  Small, 
  329 S.C. at 464, 494 S.E.2d at 843.Â  Proximate cause does not mean the sole 
  cause.Â  Bishop v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 331 S.C. 
  79, 502 S.E.2d 78 (1998); Small, 329 S.C. at 464, 494 S.E.2d at 843.Â  
  The defendantâ€™s conduct can be a proximate cause if it was at least one of the 
  direct, concurring causes of the injury.Â  Sims, 357 S.C. at 299, 592 
  S.E.2d at 320; Small, 329 S.C. at 464, 494 S.E.2d at 843.
An intervening force may be a superseding cause that relieves an actor from 
  liability.Â  Small, 329 S.C. at 467, 494 S.E.2d at 844.Â  However, the 
  intervening cause must be a cause that could not have been reasonably foreseen 
  or anticipated.Â  Mickle v. Blackmon, 252 S.C. 202, 166 S.E.2d 
  173 (1969); Small, 329 S.C. at 467, 494 S.E.2d at 844.
II.Â  Summary Judgment â€“ Hitachi Construction Machinery Co., Ltd. 
Rife argues the judge erred in granting summary judgment to Hitachi.Â  
  We disagree.
The trial court 
  granted summary judgment to Hitachi on the ground that Rifeâ€™s injuries were 
  not the foreseeable consequences of Hitachiâ€™s failure to equip the EX100 with 
  a seat belt because it was designed and manufactured solely for distribution 
  and use in Japan.
Uncontroverted testimony indicated Hitachi intended the EX100 only 
  for the Japanese market, sold the EX100 to a Japanese customer, and manufactured 
  the EX100 in accordance with Japanese safety standards.Â  The EX100 was not constructed 
  according to United States standards and was never intended for sale in the 
  United States.Â  Some third party imported the EX100 into the United States and 
  sold it on the â€œgray market.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines â€œgray marketâ€ 
  as a â€œmarket in which the seller uses legal but sometimes unethical methods 
  to avoid a manufacturerâ€™s distribution chain and thereby sell goods (esp. imported 
  goods) at prices lower than those envisioned by the manufacturer.â€Â  Blackâ€™s 
  Law Dictionary 989 (8th ed. 2004).Â  â€œGray marketâ€ products include â€œâ€˜goods 
  produced abroad with authorization and payment but which are imported into unauthorized 
  markets.â€™â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 989 (quoting Ralph H. Folsom & 
  Michael W. Gordon, International Business Transactions Â§ 20.8 (1995)).
There is no evidence regarding how many people owned the EX100 prior 
  to its purchase by Dirty Works or whether anyone altered the EX100 in any way.Â  
  Under these facts, Hitachi could not reasonably foresee the EX100, designed 
  for use in Japan, would injure a person in the United States.Â  Any foreseeability 
  link was severed when the EX100 was imported into the United States.Â  Therefore, 
  as a matter of law, Hitachi is not liable for Rifeâ€™s injuries.
III.Â  Summary Judgment â€“ American Equipment Company 
Rife contends the judge erred in granting summary judgment to American 
  Equipment on Rifeâ€™s theories of liability: strict liability, negligent design 
  and manufacture, and failure to warn of a defect.Â  We disagree.
The trial court based its decision to grant summary judgment to American 
  Equipment on the holding of the factually similar case, Marchant v. Mitchell 
  Distrib. Co., 270 S.C. 29, 240 S.E.2d 511 (1977).Â  In Marchant, the 
  plaintiff sustained an injury when a cable snapped, causing a bucket connected 
  to a hydraulic craneâ€™s telescoping boom to fall.Â  The plaintiff brought an action 
  against Mitchell Distributing, the equipment distributor who sold the crane 
  to the plaintiffâ€™s employer, alleging negligence, breach of express and/or implied 
  warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose, and strict 
  liability.Â  The actions averring breach of warranty and strict liability were 
  based on the theory that the absence of a safety attachment called an anti-blocking 
  device rendered the crane unfit for its intended purpose and in a defective 
  condition unreasonably dangerous to the user.Â  Id. at 32, 240 S.E.2d 
  at 511-12.Â  The safety device was an available option purchasable for an additional 
  price.Â  The plaintiffâ€™s employer did not purchase the device.Â  Id.
In concluding the trial court correctly granted the summary judgment 
  motion as to Mitchell Distributing, the Marchant court explained:

Marchant argues that his showing supports the inference that the crane, 
  absent the optional safety device, was a defective product unreasonably dangerous.Â  
  We think however, that the fact the crane was without the optional safety device, 
  does not tend to prove that it was defective.Â  Most any product can be made 
  more safe.Â  Automobiles would be more safe with disc brakes and steel-belted 
  radial tires than with ordinary brakes and ordinary tires, but this does not 
  mean that an automobile dealer would be held to have sold a defective product 
  merely because the most safe equipment is not installed.Â  By a like token, a 
  bicycle is more safe if equipped with lights and a bell, but the fact that one 
  is not so equipped does not create the inference that the bicycle is defective 
  and unreasonably dangerous.

Id. at 35-36, 240 S.E.2d at 513.Â  The court further articulated:

By bringing the action under section 15-73-10, Marchant has assumed 
  the burden of presenting evidence which tends to prove that the crane was in 
  a defective condition unreasonably dangerous, which proximately caused his injury.Â  
  The fact that the injury occurred and the fact that the crane could have been 
  more safe is not sufficient to support a finding that the crane was unreasonably 
  dangerous.

Id. at 36, 240 S.E.2d at 514.
Rife asserts American Equipment marketed and sold the EX100 in an 
  unreasonably dangerous condition because it lacked an optional safety device, 
  a seat belt.Â  Applying Marchant, we find Rife failed to present any evidence 
  demonstrating the EX100 was unreasonably dangerous.Â  Evidence the EX100 could 
  have been made more safe with the installation of a seat belt is insufficient 
  to support a finding the EX100 was defective.Â  There is some danger incident 
  to the use of most any product.Â  A product can certainly cause injury if used 
  improperly.Â  No doubt there are products which require safety devices to eliminate 
  dangers.Â  This is not one of them.
In addition, we rule the trial court correctly held there was no 
  evidence upon which a jury could conclude American Equipment was negligent in 
  the design or manufacture of the EX100.Â  In Marchant, the plaintiff alleged 
  Mitchell Distributing was negligent in marketing, selling, and/or distributing 
  a defective crane.Â  In upholding summary judgment in favor of Mitchell Distributing, 
  the court declared: â€œIt is beyond question that Mitchell had nothing to do with 
  designing or assembling the crane.â€Â  Id. at 37, 240 S.E.2d at 514.Â  The 
  court in Marchant determined Mitchell could not be liable on the theory 
  of negligent design.Â  Id.Â  Similarly, American Equipment had no involvement 
  in the design or manufacture of the EX100.Â  Factually, American Equipment did 
  not have any input regarding whether a seat belt was installed.Â  Rife knew the 
  EX100 did not have a seat belt prior to the accident.Â  See Marchant, 
  270 S.C. at 37, 240 S.E.2d at 514 (stating that failure to give warnings was 
  inconsequential where plaintiff admitted he knew the dangers prior to the accident 
  at issue).Â  In his deposition, Rife answered counselâ€™s questions:

  
    
    
      
        Q.
         And between that point in time, the time of the meeting, and the day your 
  accident occurred, between the two, did you have occasion to operate this EX-100 
  track hoe?
      
      
        A.
         Yes
      
      
        Q.Â 
         Okay.Â  And did you notice then that it did not have a seat belt?
      
      
        A.
         Yes.
      
    
    
  

The trial court did not err in granting summary 
  judgment to American Equipment on all causes of action.
CONCLUSION
Rifeâ€™s injuries were not the foreseeable consequences 
  of Hitachiâ€™s failure to equip the EX100 with a seat belt because it was designed 
  and manufactured in compliance with Japanese standards solely for use in Japan.Â  
  Hitachi could not reasonably foresee the EX100 would injure a user in a foreign 
  market.Â  Any foreseeability link or concatenation was severed when the EX100 
  was imported into the United States.Â  Furthermore, the exclusion of the seat 
  belt on the EX100 was NOT the proximate cause of Rifeâ€™s injuries.
The absence of a seat belt does not factually or 
  legally prove the EX100 was unreasonably dangerous.Â  Concomitantly, the seller, 
  American Equipment, is not liable under any products liability theory.Â  Finally, 
  American Equipment, a seller with absolutely no involvement in the design or 
  manufacture of the EX100, cannot be held liable for a design or manufacturing 
  defect.
Accordingly, the orders of the trial court granting 
  summary judgment to Hitachi and American Equipment are
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.
