title: State v. Thompson
description: Nepolean Thompson appeals his convictions for drug related offenses, arguing evidence was seized under an invalid search warrant.  This court affirms the trial courtâ€™s denial of Thompsonâ€™s motion to suppress certain evidence obtained under the warrant.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Nepolean Thompson, III, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3937
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Trent Neuell Pruett, of Gaffney, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  and Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.: 
Nepolean Thompson appeals 
  his convictions for drug related offenses, arguing evidence was seized under 
  an invalid search warrant.Â  The questions presented are (1) whether the warrant 
  sufficiently described the person or things to be seized; (2) whether the warrant 
  was issued based on stale information; and (3) whether the warrant authorized 
  an unreasonable bodily intrusion. We affirm.  
FACTS
Officer A.B. Phillips of the Blacksburg Police Department was assigned to the 
  Cherokee County Metro Narcotics Task Force.Â  InÂ  2002, Phillips was investigating 
  possible illegal drug activities involving Thompson.Â  After the investigation 
  had been ongoing for several months, Phillips received a tip from a confidential 
  informant that the informant had seen illegal narcotics in Thompsonâ€™s possession. 
  Based on this information, Phillips prepared an affidavit and obtained a search 
  warrant from a magistrate.Â  The affidavit read:

Affiantâ€™s belief is based upon information received from 
  a confidential reliable informent [sic], who has provided information in the 
  past that has proven true and correct and led to the arrest and conviction of 
  those involved in illegal drug trade.Â  This C.R.I. states that he or she has 
  seen a quantity of crack cocaine on the above described person within the past 
  72 hours.Â  Affiantâ€™s [sic] knows this C.R.I. to know crack cocaine when seen 
  by past information received from C.R.I.Â Â  

The warrant issued described the permitted search as follows:
Description of 
  Premises (Person, Place or Thing) To Be Searched

One, Napoleon [sic] Thompson III, aka Buster, is to be searched.Â  
  A black male, DOB 5-29-79, DL number 0011405948, HGT 5-10, WGT 145lbs, address 
  207 E. Seven Springs St., Blacksburg SC. The search will include all 
  clothing, shoes, hats, socks, under garments, jackets, scarfs [sic], bandannas, 
  any vehicle and or any means of transportation that Mr. Napoleon [sic] Thompson 
  III may be traveling in or on, and Mr. Napoleon [sic] Thompsonâ€™s mouth.Â  The 
  search will also include any types of luggage, small or large in Mr. Thompsons 
  [sic] poss. Â 

Officer Phillips promptly undertook efforts to execute the 
  warrant.Â  The day after the warrant was issued, Phillips received information 
  that Thompson â€œwould be traveling down South Charleston Street [in Blacksburg] 
  with crack cocaine and marijuana in his possession.â€Â  This information was disseminated 
  to officers in the area, and shortly thereafter, a police officer spotted Thompsonâ€™s 
  car traveling on South Charleston Street.Â  When Officer Phillips arrived on 
  South Charleston Street, Thompson had parked his car and entered a convenience 
  store.Â  When Thompson returned to his car, he was confronted by the officers.Â  
  After being informed of the search warrant, Thompson stepped out of his car 
  as instructed by the officers.Â  Thompson then pulled two small plastic bags 
  out of his pocket, threw them in the air, and attempted to flee.Â  Phillips grabbed 
  Thompson before he could get away and detained him. 
  [1] Â  The plastic bags Thompson had tossed away were recovered by 
  police and held as evidence. Subsequent analysis revealed the bags contained 
  marijuana and crack cocaine.
Thompson was taken to the police department and searched.Â Â  
  The only additional evidence the search produced was $2,654 cash found in Thompsonâ€™s 
  wallet.Â 
Thompson was charged with possession with intent to distribute crack 
  cocaine and possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine within a half 
  mile of a school.Â  Before trial, Thompson moved to suppress the crack cocaine 
  and the marijuana evidence.Â  Thompson claimed the drug evidence was inadmissible 
  because it was obtained under an invalid search warrant.Â  Specifically, Thompson 
  argued the warrant was void because: (1) the warrant impermissibly permitted 
  the search of Thompsonâ€™s person and was otherwise overbroad with regard to the 
  places and things it authorized law enforcement to search; (2) the affidavit 
  submitted to obtain the warrant recited stale information insufficient to support 
  a finding of probable cause; and (3) the warrant permitted an unreasonable bodily 
  intrusion or strip search of Thompson.Â  The trial court disagreed and denied 
  the motion.Â  Thompson was ultimately convicted of possession of crack cocaine.Â Â  
  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State 
  v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001). This court is bound 
  by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous. State 
  v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 452, 527 S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000).Â  A deferential 
  standard of review likewise applies in the context of a Fourth Amendment challenge 
  to a trial courtâ€™s fact-driven affirmation of probable cause.Â  State v. Brockman, 
  339 S.C. 57, 65-66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 665-666 (2000) (holding that whether a search 
  violated the parameters of the Fourth Amendment depends upon â€œa number of antecedent 
  determinations, each of which is inherently fact-specificâ€ and â€œentails an inquiry 
  into the totality of the circumstancesâ€ and the appellate court must affirm 
  if there is â€œany evidenceâ€ to support the ruling).Â  This appeal presents both 
  factual and legal challenges to the rulings of the trial court concerning the 
  search warrant.Â  Following Brockman, we adhere to the â€œany evidenceâ€ 
  standard of review with respect to the factual findings of the trial court. 

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Permissible Scope of Search Authorized Under the Warrant
We first address Thompsonâ€™s claim the warrant failed to describe 
  with sufficient particularity the person, place, or thing to be searched.Â  Though 
  we conclude there is sufficient evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s finding 
  that some portions of the warrant are overbroad, we further concur with the 
  trial court and find this fact does not render the entire warrant void or require 
  suppression of the evidence seized in this case.
Under both the United States and South Carolina constitutions, 
  search warrants may not be issued except â€œupon probable cause, supported by 
  Oath or affirmation,â€ and particularly describing the place to be searched and 
  the persons or things to be seized. U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. art. 
  I, Â§ 10.Â  Following these constitutional requirements, South Carolina Code section 
  17-13-140 (2003) requires a search warrant be issued â€œonly upon affidavit sworn 
  to before the magistrate [or other judicial officer]â€ and only if the magistrate 
  â€œis satisfied that the grounds for the application exist or that there is probable 
  cause to believe that they exist . . . .â€Â  The magistrate issuing the search 
  warrant must â€œmake a practical, common-sense decision whether, given all the 
  circumstances set forth in the affidavit . . . there is a fair probability that 
  contraband or evidence of a crime will be found in a particular place.â€ Illinois 
  v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213, 238 (1983). In reviewing the validity of a warrant, 
  an appellate court may consider only information brought to the magistrateâ€™s 
  attention.Â  State v. Martin, 347 S.C. 522, 527, 556 S.E.2d. 706, 709 
  (Ct. App. 2001).
The specific requirement that a search warrant particularly describe 
  the person, place, or thing to be searched â€œis aimed at preventing general warrantsâ€”those 
  authorizing â€˜a general, exploratory rummaging in a personâ€™s belongings.â€™â€ State 
  v. Williams, 297 S.C. 404, 407, 377 S.E.2d 308, 310 (1989) (quoting Coolidge 
  v. New Hampshire, 403 U.S. 443, 467 (1971)). â€œâ€˜By limiting the authorization 
  to search to the specific areas and things for which there is probable cause 
  to search, the requirement ensures that the search will be carefully tailored 
  to its justifications, and will not take on the character of the wide-ranging 
  exploratory searches the Framers intended to prohibit.â€™â€ Id. (quoting 
  Maryland v. Garrison, 480 U.S. 79 (1987)).Â 
Thompson claims the warrant issued in the present case veers 
  from the particularity requirement in three respects.Â  First, Thompson argues 
  that, by permitting the search of his â€œperson,â€ the warrant granted law enforcement 
  unlimited discretion to search him wherever or whenever they desired.Â  Specifically, 
  Thompson suggests that warrants may only authorize the search of â€œplacesâ€ and 
  â€œthings,â€ not individuals.Â  This argument is without merit.
Though not as common as warrants for the search of places, 
  the propriety of warrants authorizing the search of persons is well settled 
  in the law.Â  South Carolina Code section 17-13-140, our state statute governing 
  the issuance and execution of search warrants, clearly authorizes the search 
  of a person. This section provides that â€œ[t]he property described in this section, 
  or any part thereof, may be seized from any place where such property may be 
  located, or from the person, possession or control of any person who 
  shall be found to have such property in his possession or under his control.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003) (emphasis added).Â  Indeed, the United States 
  Supreme Court has held that warrants authorizing the search of a person are 
  constitutional provided that â€œa search or seizure of a person must be supported 
  by probable cause particularized with respect to that person.â€ Ybarra v. 
  Illinois, 444 U.S. 85, 91 (1979).Â  Thus, there is no basis to conclude the 
  search warrant was invalid because it authorized the search of Thompsonâ€™s â€œperson.â€
Thompsonâ€™s second and third exceptions to the particularity of the 
  warrant concern two specific items subject to possible search and seizure under 
  the warrant.Â  Thompson claims the language contained in the warrant authorizing 
  the search of any transportation that he was riding in or on and any type of 
  luggage in his possession was not supported by probable cause.Â  We agree.Â 
As quoted above, Phillipsâ€™ affidavit stated that his belief Thompson 
  was in possession of contraband was based on information from a confidential 
  informant that Thompson had been seen in the past 72 hours with quantity of 
  crack cocaine on his â€œperson.â€Â  No further information was provided in the affidavit, 
  and Phillips testified that the only additional information he provided the 
  magistrate was the fact that Thompson was the subject of an ongoing narcotics 
  investigation.Â 
There is a substantial basis to support the trial courtâ€™s determination 
  that the warrant was overbroad in its authorization 
  to search Thompsonâ€™s vehicle or luggage.Â  The information provided to the magistrate 
  only related to seeing crack cocaine on Thompsonâ€™s person. There was 
  no basis upon which the magistrate could conclude that probable cause existed 
  to search any vehicle Thompson was traveling in or on or any luggage in Thompsonâ€™s 
  possession.
We now turn to the legal question posed as a result of the finding 
  that the warrant was overly broad with respect to these specific provisions 
  concerning transportation and luggage.Â  We do not believe this finding renders 
  the search warrant invalid on the whole.Â  A contrary conclusion would mean that 
  the seizure of certain items, even though proper if viewed separately, must 
  be condemned merely because the warrant was defective with respect to other 
  items. Though this question of law has not been directly addressed by South 
  Carolina courts in our modern jurisprudence, we believe one of our supreme courtâ€™s 
  older precedents supports the principle of â€œseverability.â€Â  Moreover, such an 
  approach is widely recognized in Fourth Amendment jurisprudence, in both federal 
  and state courts.Â  In essence, overbroad portions of a search warrant may be 
  â€œseveredâ€ from the portions for which probable cause is found to exist, thus 
  permitting the admission of evidence properly obtained.
Looking first to our stateâ€™s law, we do find support for the concept 
  of severability.Â  In Farmer v. Sellers, 89 S.C. 492, 72 S.E. 224 (1911), 
  our supreme court found a warrant, which permitted a search to be conducted 
  by day or night, was valid regardless of a statute prohibiting nighttime searches.Â  
  In that case, no search was conducted at night, and the court determined â€œthere 
  is therefore no ground to allege that the statute was violated.Â  If courts gave 
  heed to such extremely technical objections, the law would indeed be weak in 
  its struggle with crime.â€Â  Id. at 500, 72 S.E. at 227.Â  The supreme court 
  in Farmer thus implicitly recognized the propriety of admitting items 
  seized under valid provisions of a warrant supported by probable cause, despite 
  the fact that the warrant at issue was improper in other respects.
Other states have applied the concept of severability under circumstances 
  directly analogous to the present case.Â  For example, in People v. Mangliano, 
  348 N.Y.S.2d 327 (1973), a seminal state court case addressing severability, 
  a New York trial court reviewed the validity of a search warrant authorizing 
  the police to search a suspectâ€™s home for illegal narcotics and associated paraphernalia 
  as well as â€œrecords, mail, correspondence and communications used in conjunction 
  with the sale or possession of any dangerous drugs.â€Â  Id. at 330.Â  The 
  court found the affidavit submitted to obtain the warrant did not establish 
  sufficient probable cause to justify the seizure of the â€œrecords, mail, correspondence 
  and communicationsâ€ listed in the warrant.Â  Rather than suppress all of the 
  evidence obtained under the warrant, the court elected to redact the latter 
  phrase from the warrant, thereby preserving from suppression all evidence seized 
  pursuant to the valid portions of the warrant.Â  The court concluded:

[T]here is strong and persuasive authority in other 
  jurisdictions to permit a severance in order to save a warrant or a search. 
  This would seem to be supported by logic as well. If there was probable cause 
  to issue a search warrant describing particular items to be seized, and such 
  items are found and those items alone constitute the basis of the criminal charge, 
  there is no reason why some additional unsupported language in the search warrant, 
  while to be avoided, should not be severable, particularly where no items seized 
  thereunder are included as a basis for the criminal charge.

Id. at 337; see also, e.g., 
  State v. Noll, 343 N.W.2d 391, 396 (Wis. 1984) (concluding that â€œin cases 
  involving search warrants which are partially but not wholly defective, those 
  two interests are best accommodated by admitting those items seized pursuant 
  to the valid parts of the warrant and suppressing those items seized under the 
  invalid portionâ€); Butler v. State, 203 S.E.2d 558, 563 (Ga. App. 1973) 
  (holding that â€œ[w]here a search as it was actually conducted is lawful, it is 
  not rendered invalid merely because the warrant pursuant to which it was made 
  was overbroad or founded upon erroneous beliefsâ€) (internal citation omitted); 
  Aday v. Super. Ct. of Alameda County, 362 P.2d 47 (Cal. 1961) (widely 
  acknowledged as the leading state case adopting the doctrine of severability).Â 
We also note that many federal courts, including the Fourth Circuit 
  Court of Appeals, have recognized and applied the theory of severability.Â  In 
  United States v. Jacob, 657 F.2d 49 (4th Cir. 1981), the court examined 
  whether items to be seized under a search warrant met the constitutional particularity 
  requirement.Â  The court noted that the overly broad portions of the warrant 
  describing the items to be seized were severable from those portions that met 
  the particularity requirement. [2] Â  Id. at 52.Â  Other 
  federal circuits have also recognized and applied the severability concept. 
  See United States v. George, 975 F.2d 72, 79 (2d Cir. 1992) 
  (holding that evidence seized pursuant to valid portion of a search warrant 
  may be admissible, even if part of the warrant is severed or redacted for lack 
  of particularity or probable cause); LeBron v. Vitek, 751 F.2d 
  311, 312 (8th Cir. 1985) (holding that the valid portion of a warrant 
  was severable from the invalid, over broad portion); United States 
  v. Offices Known as 50 State Distrib. Co., 708 F.2d 1371, 1375-76 (9th Cir. 
  1983), cert. denied, 465 U.S. 1021 (1984) (noting that 
  â€œ[i]f probable cause was lacking as to the search of individuals, that does 
  not operate to render the warrant itself invalid in its entirety as a general 
  warrant. The remedy is not a return of all items seized but selective suppression 
  or return of the items improperly seized); United States v. Christine, 
  687 F.2d 749, 758 (3rd Cir. 1982) (holding that â€œ[r]edaction of a warrant 
  containing valid severable phrases or clauses is consistent with all five purposes 
  of the warrant requirementâ€); United States v. Cook, 657 F.2d 
  730, 735 (5th Cir. 1981) (opining that â€œ[w]e agree with the reasoning 
  of the . . . majority of state courts that have considered this question and 
  hold that in the usual case the district judge should sever the infirm portion 
  of the search warrant from so much of the warrant as passes constitutional musterâ€).
Furthermore, review of authoritative treatises addressing this subject 
  further indicates the concept of severability has gained broad acceptance:

If a search warrant is issued to search a place 
  for several items, but it is later determined that not all of those items are 
  described with sufficient particularity or that probable cause does not exist 
  as to all of the items described, it is often possible to sever the tainted 
  portion of the warrant from the valid portion so that evidence found in the 
  execution of the latter will be admissible.

2 Wayne R. LaFave et al., Criminal Procedure Â§ 3.4(f), 
  at 137 (2d ed. 1999); see also 79 C.J.S. Searches and 
  Seizures Â§ 185 (Supp. 2004) (commenting that â€œ[w]here the description 
  in a search warrant of the items to be seized is in part insufficiently particular 
  or unsupported by probable cause, the warrant may sometimes be severed so as 
  to preserve the valid portionsâ€); 68 Am. Jur. 2d Searches and 
  Seizures Â§ 168 (2000) (observing that â€œstriking from a warrant those 
  severable phrases and clauses that are invalid for lack of probable cause and 
  preserving those phrases and clauses that satisfy the Fourth Amendment, is consistent 
  with the Fourth Amendment and should be used in order to avoid unnecessary social 
  costsâ€).
In the case at bar, we find the invalid portions of the warrant relating 
  to the search of Thompsonâ€™s vehicle and luggage are severable from the authorization 
  relating to the search of Thompsonâ€™s person.Â  Because the portion of the warrant 
  allowing the search of Thompsonâ€™s person remains valid, and because none of 
  the evidence sought to be suppressed was derived from the overbroad portions 
  of the warrant, we find Thompsonâ€™s request for suppression of this evidence 
  was properly denied.Â Â 
In so holding we do not mean to suggest that invalid portions of a 
  warrant will be treated as severable under all circumstances. We are mindful 
  of the danger that warrants might be obtained which are essentially general 
  in character but arguably meet the particularity requirement in certain respects.Â  
  We in no manner sanction wholesale seizures pursuant to questionable police 
  practices.Â  Our decision today is narrowly confined to those circumstances where, 
  as here, there exists good faith [3] â€”measured objectivelyâ€”on the part of 
  law enforcement and the valid portion of the warrant is amply supported by probable 
  cause.
II.Â  Â Â Â  Staleness
We next address, and reject, Thompsonâ€™s claim that the information 
  contained in the affidavit supporting the warrant was stale, and therefore could 
  not have been the basis of a finding of probable cause.
In order for an affidavit to support probable cause, â€œit 
  must state facts so closely related to the time of the issuance of the warrant 
  as to justify a finding of probable cause at that time.â€ State v. Winborne, 
  273 S.C. 62, 64, 254 S.E.2d 297, 298 (1979) (internal quotation marks omitted). 
  â€œAn affidavit which fails altogether to state the time of the occurrence of 
  the facts alleged is insufficient.â€ Id.Â 
There is, however, no fixed standard or formula establishing a maximum 
  allowable interval between the date of events recited in an affidavit and the 
  date of a search warrant.Â  United States v. McCall, 740 F.2d 1331, 1336 
  (4th Cir. 1984).Â  This court has explained that the acceptable length of time 
  between the establishment of probable cause and the execution of the warrant 
  depends on a variety of case-specific factors:

While the lapse of time involved is an important 
  consideration and may in some cases be controlling, it is not necessarily so. 
  There are other factors to be considered, including the nature of the criminal 
  activity involved, and the kind of property for which authority to search is 
  sought.

State v. Corns, 310 S.C. 546, 550-51, 426 S.E.2d 
  324, 326 (Ct. App. 1992) (quoting United States v. Steeves, 525 F.2d 
  33 (8th Cir.1975)).
The record in this case contains ample support for the trial 
  courtâ€™s rejection of Thompsonâ€™s assertion that the circumstances providing probable 
  cause for the search had grown stale by the time the warrant was executed. The 
  affidavit provides that the informant had observed Thompson in possession of 
  crack cocaine within the past 72 hours.Â  The affidavit was sworn on 
  the same day the magistrate issued the warrant, and Officer Phillips executed 
  the warrant the day after it was issued.Â Â  Additionally, the record 
  reveals that the information received from the informant was not an isolated 
  incident. Phillips testified that he informed the magistrate that Thompson was 
  the subject of an ongoing narcotics investigation conducted during the several 
  months prior to obtaining the warrant.
Given the continuous nature of the alleged drug activity, we find the 
  record supports the trial courtâ€™s finding that it was reasonable for the magistrate 
  to conclude that Thompson would be found in possession of illegal substances.Â  
  Although isolated sales of narcotics unquestionably occur, it is generally recognized 
  that â€œnarcotics conspiracies are the very paradigm of the continuing enterprises 
  for which the courts have relaxed the temporal requirements of non-staleness.â€ 
  United States v. Rowell, 903 F.2d 899, 903 (2d Cir. 1990) (quotation 
  marks and citation omitted); see also Donaldson v. State, 
  420 A.2d 281, 286 (Md. Ct. App. 1980) (noting that the selling of drugs, by 
  its nature, is an ongoing activity).Â  Considering the informantâ€™s report of 
  Thompsonâ€™s drug possession together with Phillipsâ€™ testimony that Thompson was 
  the subject of an ongoing narcotics investigation did not suggest an isolated 
  incident, but rather described a probable continuing course of illegal drug 
  activity. We concur, therefore, with the trial court that the probable cause 
  predicate, which supported the issuance of the warrant, continued to exist at 
  the time of its execution.
III.Â  Â  Bodily Intrusion
Finally, we address Thompsonâ€™s argument that the search 
  warrant was invalid because it improperly authorized a bodily intrusion or a 
  strip search.Â  Specifically, Thompson contends the warrantâ€™s authorization to 
  search his mouth and undergarments rendered the warrant invalid because the 
  warrant did not set forth specific findings required to justify a bodily intrusion 
  as required under In re Snyder, 308 S.C. 192, 417 S.E.2d 572 (1992).Â  
  We disagree.Â  
In In re Snyder, our supreme court held that 
  South Carolina Code section 17-13-140 (search warrant statute) provides for 
  the involuntary submission of nontestimonial identification evidence, and the 
  court set forth guidelines and procedures for obtaining samples of blood and 
  saliva, along with head and pubic hair, from unarrested suspects in criminal 
  investigations.Â  In the present case, the search did not authorize the collection 
  of any bodily fluids, tissue samples, or other such physical evidence for which 
  a bodily intrusion would be required. The warrant in this case merely authorized 
  the search of Thompsonâ€™s mouth and undergarments in connection with the search 
  of his person for illegal drugs.Â  Therefore, the search of these areas did not 
  rise to the level of the type of bodily intrusion contemplated under In re 
  Snyder.Â  
Moreover, our supreme court has held that the search of a suspectâ€™s mouth is 
  appropriate in order to prevent a suspectâ€™s attempts to destroy evidence by 
  swallowing it, because â€œhe cannot consider the mouth a â€˜sacred orificeâ€™ in which 
  contraband may be irretrievably concealed from the police.â€ Â State v. Dupree, 
  319 S.C. 454, 458, 462 S.E.2d 279, 282 (1995) (quoting State v. Williams, 
  560 P.2d 1160, 1162 (Wash. App. 1977)).Â  Therefore, the magistrate could properly 
  conclude there was a reasonable probability that the crack cocaine may be found 
  in Thompsonâ€™s mouth as part of his person.Â  
We also note that when the police searched Thompsonâ€™s undergarments he had 
  already been placed under arrest and taken to the police department.Â  It is 
  well settled that, in the case of a lawful custodial arrest, the full search 
  of a person does not require a search warrant and is considered reasonable under 
  the Fourth Amendment.Â  State v. Ferrell, 274 S.C. 401, 409, 266 S.E.2d 869, 873 (1980).Â  Therefore, the validity 
  of the warrant with regard to the search of Thompsonâ€™s undergarments was of 
  no consequence because the search conducted was a valid search incident to arrest.Â Â  

CONCLUSION
We find that: (1) although portions of the search warrant issued were overbroad 
  in certain respects, this fact does not render the warrant wholly invalid; 
  (2) the search warrant was issued and executed in a timely manner; 
  and (3) the warrant did not authorize an unreasonable bodily intrusion.Â  Therefore, 
  the trial courtâ€™s denial of Thompsonâ€™s motion to suppress the drug evidence 
  is
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â 
HUFF and BEATTY, 
  JJ., concur.

 
  [1] Â Contrary to Phillipsâ€™ testimony, it is clear that Thompson 
    was under arrest when he was first detained in the convenience store parking 
    lot.Â  The determination of whether an individual is under arrest is measured 
    objectively, and the subjective view of the particular officer is not controlling. 
    See Stansbury v. California, 511 U.S. 318, 323 (1994) (opining 
    that â€œ[o]ur decisions make clear that the initial determination of custody 
    depends on the objective circumstances of the interrogation, not on the subjective 
    views harbored by either the interrogating officers or the person being questionedâ€). 
    When Thompson was detained in the parking lot, following seizure of the suspected 
    contraband, he was so substantially deprived of his freedom of movement as 
    to constitute a full custodial arrest. See Park v. Shiflett, 
    250 F.3d 843, 850 (4th Cir. 2001) (holding that â€œ[t]he test for determining 
    whether an individual is in custody or under arrest is whether, under the 
    totality of the circumstances, the suspectâ€™s freedom of action is curtailed 
    to a degree associated with formal arrestâ€ (internal quotation marks omitted)). 
  

 
  [2]  The court in that case, however, found 
    the entire warrant met the particularity requirement, defeating the need for 
    severance.Â  

 
  [3] Â See United States v. Leon, 468 U.S. 897, 922 
    (1984) (adopting the â€œgood faith exceptionâ€ to the exclusionary rule under 
    which admission of evidence will not be barred where the evidence was obtained 
    by officers who â€œmanifest[ed] objective good faithâ€ in relying on a search 
    warrant issued by a detached, neutral magistrate even though the warrant was 
    ultimately found to be invalid).Â  This good faith exception, however, may 
    not be employed to validate a warrant that is based on an affidavit that â€œdoes 
    not provide the magistrate with a substantial basis for determining the existence 
    of probable cause.â€ State v. Johnson, 302 S.C. 243, 248, 395 S.E.2d 
    167, 170 (1990) (quoting Leon, 468 U.S. at 915).

title: State v. Yarborough
description: Ernest Yarborough was convicted of obstruction of justice.  He appeals the trial court's denial of his motion for a new trial based on alleged premature jury deliberations.  We affirm.
text:
State v. Yarborough


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Ernest E. Yarborough, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chester County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3938
Heard December 13, 2004 â€“ Filed January 31, 2005 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ernest E. Yarborough, 
  of West Columbia, pro se, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Jennifer D. Evans, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Ernest 
  Yarborough was convicted of obstruction of justice in 1997.Â  He appealed, and 
  our court remanded the issue of jury misconduct to the extent that premature 
  deliberations were alleged.Â  On remand, the trial court denied Yarboroughâ€™s 
  request for a new trial, finding Yarborough had not made a prima facie 
  showing that premature deliberations had occurred.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Ernest Yarborough, an attorney, was convicted 
  of obstruction of justice for offering an alleged victim $500 to drop charges 
  against his client.Â  Before being sentenced, Yarborough requested a new trial, 
  alleging juror misconduct in two respects.Â  First, he argued the jurors improperly 
  discussed a compromise verdict, and second, he argued the jurors deliberated 
  prematurely.Â  To support these allegations, Yarborough sought to offer the testimony 
  of juror Teresa Mobley and the affidavit of juror Keisha Foster, but the trial 
  court refused to consider evidence of the allegations.Â  However, the court sealed 
  the affidavit of juror Foster for the record.Â  Fosterâ€™s affidavit suggests the 
  jurors may have compromised on the verdict, whereby a group of jurors agreed 
  to vote guilty on one charge in exchange for a not guilty verdict on another 
  charge.Â  The affidavit does not allege that any premature deliberations took 
  place.Â  
Yarborough was sentenced to ten years imprisonment, 
  suspended on the service of six months, two years probation, and payment of 
  $1,000 in costs and assessments.Â  He appealed. 
This court found the trial court committed no error 
  in refusing to hear evidence regarding the juryâ€™s alleged discussion of a compromise 
  verdict.Â  State v. Yarborough, Op. No. 2000-UP-059 (Ct. App. 2000) (hereinafter 
  â€œYarborough Iâ€). However, we found the trial court could have considered 
  evidence of premature deliberations.Â  Id. Specifically, our court stated:

Our supreme court recently held that â€œpremature deliberations may affect fundamental 
  fairness.â€Â  State v. Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 312, 509 S.E.2d 811, 813 (1999).Â  
  . . . 
The Aldret case sets forth procedures for trial courts to use in cases 
  where premature deliberations are alleged.Â  If, as here, the allegations of 
  premature deliberations are raised after the jury renders its verdict the trial 
  court may consider juror affidavits concerning the misconduct.Â  Aldret, 
  333 S.C. at 315, 509 S.E.2d at 815.Â  Furthermore:
  
If the court finds the affidavits are credible and indicate premature deliberations 
  occurred, the court should hold an evidentiary hearing to determine whether 
  such deliberations did in fact occur.Â  The court may, upon the complaining partyâ€™s 
  request, â€œreassemble the jurors and conduct voir dire to ascertain the 
  nature and extent of premature deliberations.â€Â  If the court concludes the misconduct 
  did not occur or did not prejudice the party alleging misconduct, the court 
  should make adequate findings to enable a review of the decision. If the court 
  is convinced misconduct occurred but cannot conduct an adequate inquiry because 
  of the passage of time, the court may order a new trial.
  
Id. at 315-316, 509 S.E.2d at 815.

Yarborough I.
Based on that analysis, our court remanded the issue of premature jury deliberations 
  to the trial court â€œfor consideration pursuant to Aldret.â€ [1] Â  Id.
On remand, Yarborough sought to compel the testimony 
  of two witnesses, Keisha Foster and Marcy Benson.Â  Although they had been subpoenaed, [2]  both failed to appear.Â  
  Yarborough wanted Foster, the juror who previously alleged the jury had compromised 
  on the verdict, to testify regarding the alleged premature deliberations. As 
  to Benson, Yarborough claimed that her testimony would demonstrate that she 
  told Foster not to participate in the case.Â  The trial court denied the motion 
  to compel the attendance of Foster or Benson.Â  
Because his motion to compel was denied, Yarborough 
  moved for a continuance to obtain affidavits from other jurors.Â  This motion 
  was also denied because from the time of the original motion for a new trial 
  to the remand hearing in 2003, Yarborough did nothing to obtain jurorsâ€™ affidavits.Â  
  Yarborough claimed he was prevented from obtaining additional affidavits because 
  of a letter that an Assistant Attorney General sent to the trial court judge 
  on April 2, 1997, three days before the hearing on Yarboroughâ€™s original motion 
  for a new trial.Â  The letter advised the trial court judge that Yarborough was 
  contacting jurors, and asked that the judge prohibit him from doing so until 
  the judge made a determination that that such contact was warranted.Â  However, 
  the trial court did not sympathize with Yarboroughâ€™s purported predicament, 
  finding that â€œ[n]o reasonable experienced lawyer would have ceased an investigation 
  that he believed to be appropriate based upon receipt of a copy of such a letter 
  to the court.â€ 
Finally, Yarborough moved for a new trial based on the allegations of premature jury deliberations, the passage of time (which resulted in a lack of witnessesâ€™ memory or availability), and fundamental fairness. The trial court denied the motion, finding that, pursuant to Aldret, Yarborough failed to present affidavits to establish a prima facie showing of premature deliberations. This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court reviews errors 
  of law only and is bound by factual findings of the trial court unless clearly 
  erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); 
  State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 147, 199 S.E.2d 61, 65 (1973); State 
  v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388, 577 S.E.2d 498, 500 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Yarborough 
  appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motions to compel, for a continuance, 
  and for a new trial.Â  He also asserts the trial court erred in refusing to grant 
  him an evidentiary hearing.Â  We disagree with each of his assertions.
  I.  Evidentiary Hearing and Motion to Compel 
Yarborough contends the trial court erred in refusing 
  to compel the attendance and testimony of juror Foster pursuant to the remand.Â  
  He further argues that, pursuant to Aldret, the trial court should have 
  conducted an evidentiary hearing to determine whether premature deliberations 
  occurred.
â€œA trial court . . . has inherent power to require the appearance of witnesses even as counsel for either side may require the presence and testimony of witnesses.â€ Â Greenwood Lumber Co. v. Cromer, 225 S.C. 375, 383, 82 S.E.2d 527, 530 (1954).Â  However, Aldret does not require the trial court to hear juror testimony whenever there is an allegation of premature deliberations.Â  333 S.C. at 312-16, 509 S.E.2d at 813-15.Â  According to Aldret, the trial court â€œmay consider affidavits when inquiring into allegations of premature jury deliberations.â€Â  333 S.C. at 312-313, 509 S.E.2d at 813.Â  Then, â€œ[i]f the trial court finds the affidavits credible, and indicative of premature deliberations, an evidentiary hearing should be held to assess whether such deliberations in fact occurred, and whether they affected the verdict.â€Â  Id. at 315, 509 S.E.2d at 815 (emphasis added).
In Yarborough I, we remanded the issue of premature jury deliberations and instructed the trial court to follow the procedure set forth in Aldret.Â  Based on the record, the trial court did just that.Â  It considered the affidavit of juror Foster, which makes no allegation of premature deliberations.Â Â  Because Yarborough failed to produce any other affidavit, he made no showing to the trial court that premature deliberations occurred; [3]  thus, the trial court did not err by refusing to hold an evidentiary hearing.Â  Moreover, because an evidentiary hearing was not warranted, there was no reason to compel the appearance of juror Foster; thus the trial court did not err by refusing to grant Yarboroughâ€™s motion to compel.
  II.  Motion for Continuance
Yarborough also contends the trial court erred in refusing 
  to grant his motion for a continuance â€œafter a crucial witness failed to appear.â€Â  
  The granting of a motion for a continuance is within the sound discretion of 
  the trial court and will not be disturbed absent a clear showing of an abuse 
  of discretion.Â  State v. White, 311 S.C. 289, 293, 428 S.E.2d 740, 742 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Reversals of refusals of continuances â€œare about as rare as the proverbial hensâ€™ teeth.â€Â  State v. McMilian, 349 S.C. 17, 21, 561 S.E.2d 602, 604 (2002) (citation omitted) (stating this comparison, but ultimately reversing the trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant a continuance).Â  The party asking for the continuance must show due diligence was used in trying to procure the testimony of an absent witness as well as set forth what the party believes the absent witness will testify to and the grounds for that belief.Â  See White, 311 S.C. at 293, 428 S.E.2d at 742-43; see also Rule 7(b), SCCrimP (explaining that a motion for continuance to procure the testimony of a witness will not be granted unless the party seeking the testimony made use of due diligence to procure the testimony).
Yarborough submits the trial court should have granted the continuance â€œto counter the surprise that was fostered by Juror Fosterâ€™s sudden decision not to cooperate, or, to give the court time to force Juror Foster to appear and testify.â€Â  Yarboroughâ€™s argument fails because, as explained above, no evidentiary hearing was warranted, and therefore juror Foster was not needed to testify. [4] Â  Thus, the trial court did not err in refusing to grant Yarboroughâ€™s motion for continuance.
  III.   Motion for a New Trial
Finally, Yarborough argues the trial court erred in refusing to grant his motion for a new trial based on the passage of time or based on other claims of fundamental fairness.Â  We disagree.Â  
Generally, the denial of a new trial motion will be disturbed only upon a showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Covington, 343 S.C. 157, 163, 539 S.E.2d 67, 69 (citing State v. Smith, 316 S.C. 53, 55, 447 S.E.2d 175, 176 (1993)).Â  

  a.      
  Passage of Time

Again relying on Aldret, Yarborough suggests the significant amount 
  of time that has passed since the alleged premature jury deliberations justifies 
  a new trial.Â  However, a new trial based on the passage of time is only warranted 
  if the trial court â€œis convinced premature deliberations did, in fact, occur, 
  but finds it impossible to conduct an adequate post-trial inquiry due to the 
  passage of time . . . .â€Â  Aldret, 333 S.C. at 316, 509 S.E.2d at 815.Â  
  The affidavit of Foster was insufficient even to support further inquiry into 
  the matter.Â  If the trial court did not conclude an evidentiary hearing was 
  necessary, it clearly was not convinced any premature deliberations occurred.Â  
  Therefore, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to grant 
  Yarboroughâ€™s motion for a new trial based on the passage of time. 

  b.      
  Fundamental Fairness

Yarborough also asserts he was denied fundamental fairness 
  based on discussions of his possible sentences during the deliberation.Â  Again, 
  he relies on the affidavit of Foster to support allegations of these discussions.Â  
  He argues the trial court erred in refusing to consider this claim because this 
  court â€œinferentially remandedâ€ the issue in Yarborough I.Â  We disagree.
In Yarborough I, we held that â€œ[a]lthough the 
  trial court . . . stated it could not consider the evidence concerning allegations 
  of premature deliberations presented by the defense, the Aldret case 
  finds such evidence may be admissible.Â  We remand this issue to the trial court 
  for consideration pursuant to Aldret.â€Â  In no way does our remand imply 
  that the trial court should consider any issue other than premature deliberations.Â  
  Therefore, the trial court properly denied the motion for a new trial based 
  on fundamental fairness reasons.
CONCLUSION
The trial court did not err in denying Yarboroughâ€™s 
  motion to compel, his motion for a continuance, his request for an evidentiary 
  hearing, or his motion for a new trial.Â  Thus, the trial courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED. 
GOOSLBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  

 [1]  The trial court did not have the benefit of the Aldret opinion when ruling on Yarboroughâ€™s motion for a new trial.
 [2]  From the affidavit of the process server, Foster may never have received the subpoena, which appears to have been discarded by the adult upon whom he had served it.Â  
 [3]  Yarborough suggests State v. Covington, 343 S.C. 157, 539 S.E.2d 67 (Ct. App. 2000), supports his contention that the trial court should have compelled testimony through an evidentiary hearing.Â  Yarborough misinterprets Covington, in which the trial court reassembled jurors and heard their testimony after the supreme court found the affidavits of two of the jurors were competent evidence and remanded the case for an evidentiary hearing.Â Â  343 S.C. at 159-60, 539 S.E.2d at 68.Â  Here, no affidavits indicate juror misconduct in the form of premature deliberations.
 [4]  Yarborough does not argue on appeal that he needed more time to obtain more affidavits from jurors as he claimed at trial. However, that claim would also fail based on his inability to show due diligence in obtaining more affidavits.

title: State v. Johnson
description: After a jury convicted him of murder, Rorey Jamar Johnson was granted a new trial based on an improper reference by a State's witness to a polygraph exam.  The State appeals arguing the curative instruction issued by the trial judge following the reference cured any possible prejudice.  We affirm finding the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in granting a new trial when the polygraph testimony was critical in assessing the witness's credibility, which was vital to the State's case.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Rorey Jamar Johnson, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3939
Heard December 14, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. 
  McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  After a jury convicted him of murder, Rorey 
  Jamar Johnson was granted a new trial based on an improper reference by a Stateâ€™s 
  witness to a polygraph exam.Â  The State appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Rorey Jamar Johnson was charged with the murder of Gregory Whitaker 
  who was fatally shot in the upper left shoulder while sitting in a car.Â  
  At trial, the State presented three witnesses who testified to having been 
  at the scene of the shooting.Â  The first witness to testify was Crystal Marion.Â  
  She testified she was a prostitute and friend of the victim.Â  The night of the 
  incident she got into a car with Alton â€œBlackâ€ Henderson, Johnson, and a young 
  driver she did not know. Â The three of them drove to see the victim to 
  sell him some drugs. The victim was sitting alone in a car and very intoxicated.Â  
  After they spoke to the victim, he got out of the car on the driverâ€™s side.Â  
  The victim and Johnson discussed getting some â€œweed,â€ but then the victim admitted 
  he did not have any money and got back into his car.Â Â  Marion testified she 
  saw Johnson get into a â€œbrown carâ€ before she left the area.Â  
Thereafter, when Marion returned later, she stood next to the brown 
  car talking to Henderson and Michael Jones and heard a gunshot. Johnson then 
  ran up to her from behind the victimâ€™s car with a pistol in his hand.Â  She testified 
  that she and Johnson jumped into the brown car with Henderson and Jones and 
  left. Â They subsequently let her out of the car, and she stopped two 
  police officers who took her to police headquarters to make a statement. 
Marion testified she gave a statement to the police but it was not 
  the truth.Â  She said she lied in the first statement because she was afraid 
  for her disabled parents.Â  She stated she knew the victim but not Johnson. Â She 
  testified that she later gave the police two more statements.Â  While being questioned 
  about her statements the following colloquy occurred:

The State:Â  And you, in fact, later on gave another written statement 
  to the police; is that right?
Marion:Â  Which was based on the truth. Thatâ€™s right.
The State:Â  In fact, ultimately, you gave the police three statements 
  about the incident; is that correct?
Marion:Â  Uh-huh.
The State:Â  Okay.Â  And it was during this final interview, final 
  statement when you told the complete truth on this matter; is that correct?
Marion:Â  Well, the second statement was the truth as well, but, therefore, they 
  kind of made me feel like I was lying because I didnâ€™t pass the polygraph test.Â  
  And the second one --

At this point, Johnsonâ€™s counsel objected.Â  
Counsel requested a mistrial due to Marionâ€™s statement that she did 
  not pass the polygraph.Â  He argued that the mere mention would imply to the 
  jury that her testimony was truthful because of the implication that she had 
  since passed a polygraph. Â Additionally, counsel argued that the 
  fact she had been polygraphed could lead the jury to believe not only that her 
  testimony she was truthful, but that the other witnesses may also have passed 
  a polygraph before testifying.Â  The State requested a curative charge and stated 
  that there would be no further mention or argument relating to the results of 
  the polygraph.Â Â  The trial judge denied the motion for a mistrial and gave the 
  following curative instruction:

THE COURT:Â  Ladies and Gentlemen of the jury, our United States Supreme Court 
  and State Supreme Court have both ruled that polygraph tests are not admissible 
  in court because they are not accepted scientifically as being accurate.Â  So 
  I would instruct you to disregard any â€“ they are not reliable.Â  So I would instruct 
  you to disregard any reference that anybody has made in regard to any polygraph 
  examinations or anything of that nature.Â  And completely dismiss that from your 
  mind and not let that influence you in anyway [sic].Â  Our United States Supreme 
  Court has ruled in the last year or two on a new case that they were not reliable.

There was no further mention of a polygraph test.
The State presented two additional witnesses that were present at 
  the shooting.Â  Alton â€œBlackâ€ Henderson testified he saw Johnson go up to the 
  car carrying the victim and fire a shot into the car.Â  When Henderson was brought 
  to the police station he made two statements.Â  On cross-examination, he stated 
  he told the truth in both statements but went into more detail in the second 
  statement.Â  He testified that when he first spoke to police he claimed he had 
  not seen the shooting. Â Additionally, he admitted he did not tell the 
  police he left with Johnson and Jones that night.Â  On the stand, Henderson testified 
  he saw Johnson use a large revolver to shoot the victim.Â  
Michael Jones testified he was sitting in the brown car when he heard 
  the gunshot.Â  He saw Johnson coming to the car with a brown handle that looked 
  like a gun. Â Johnson and Marion got in the car and left.Â  Jones dropped 
  Marion and Henderson off and went back to his house with Johnson.Â  Jones testified 
  he saw Johnson the next day and Johnson told him he had shot a man. Â After 
  Jones met with the police he told them to go to his house and the gun would 
  be there.Â Â  The police did not find the gun.Â  On cross-examination, Johnson 
  testified he deliberately lied to the police about having the gun because he 
  knew Johnson was coming to the house and because he wanted the police to go 
  to his house and â€œcatch [Johnson].â€Â  Marion, Henderson, and Jones were all initially 
  charged with murder in connection with the shooting.Â  At the time of the trial, 
  Henderson and Jones had pled to lesser charges.
 Detective Mark White testified about the investigation.Â  He stated 
  they never found a gun.Â  When asked what the benefit of finding the gun would 
  be, he answered, â€œ[w]e would have been able to compare the bullet to the weapon.â€ 
  Â White was asked on cross-examination whether the projectiles or bullets 
  could be sent to the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division (SLED) and examined 
  by firearms experts to determine caliber.Â  White testified the projectile found 
  in the console of the car was sent to SLED for analysis, but he did not recall 
  what the caliber was. 
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, counsel for Johnson renewed 
  the motion for a mistrial â€œbased on the testimony of Ms. Marion, specifically, 
  when she made the reference to her having failed the polygraph.â€Â  The trial 
  court denied the motion.Â  After Johnson rested, counsel again renewed his motion 
  for a mistrial â€œon the basis of Ms. Marionâ€™s comments about failing the polygraph 
  . . . . â€ Â The trial court again denied the motion.
In the course of deliberations, the jury sent out a question indicating 
  it might be considering accomplice liability.Â  In discussing the question with 
  counsel, the trial court stated, â€œThe facts of this case are he either shot 
  him or he didnâ€™t.Â  There is no accomplice liability in this case. . . . Because 
  the facts do not support accomplice liability because theyâ€™ve already charged 
  the other two with accessory.Â  So it canâ€™t be accomplice liability.â€Â  The jury 
  returned to the courtroom for an additional instruction.Â  
The jury found Johnson guilty of murder.Â  Johnsonâ€™s 
  counsel moved for a new trial on grounds of the denial of his motions for directed 
  verdict and, specifically, the denial of the motion for a mistrial following 
  Marionâ€™s reference to the polygraph test.Â  The trial court took the motion under 
  advisement overnight.Â  After listening to arguments by counsel, the trial court 
  granted the motion for a new trial.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
 The State 
  argues the trial court abused its discretion in granting a motion for a new 
  trial after a conviction for murder.Â  We disagree.
In the criminal court, the only post verdict fact-based remedy available 
  is a motion for a new trial.Â  State v. Taylor, 348 S.C. 152, 158, 558 
  S.E.2d 917, 919 (Ct. App. 2001) (citingÂ  State v. Miller, 287 S.C. 280, 
  285, 337 S.E.2d 883, 886 (1985) (Ness, J., concurring in part and dissenting 
  in part (citation omitted)).Â  The State may appeal the grant of a new trial 
  when it appears it is based â€œwholly upon an error of law.â€Â  State 
  v. Dasher, 278 S.C. 395, 400, 297 S.E.2d 414, 417 (1982) (emphasis 
  in original) (finding that â€œ[t]he trial judge did not exercise a power to grant 
  a new trial upon the facts, but rather set aside the verdict of the jury in 
  the face of conflicting facts and substituted his judgment for that of the jury. 
  In doing so, he committed an error of law, from which the State had a right 
  to appealâ€). Â â€œThe granting or refusal of a motion for a new trial is within 
  the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent a clear abuse 
  of discretion.â€Â  State v. Simmons, 279 S.C. 165, 166, 303 S.E.2d 857, 
  858 (1983) (citation omitted). 
In this case, the primary evidence of Johnsonâ€™s guilt was the testimony 
  of three witnesses to the incident, and their credibility was critical to the 
  juryâ€™s decision.Â  Moreover, each witness gave some form of inconsistent statement 
  to the police.Â  The trial judge denied Johnsonâ€™s initial motion for a mistrial 
  on grounds of polygraph testimony but issued a thorough curative instruction.Â  
  Thereafter, following testimony of the other witnesses, who also gave inconsistent 
  statements, Johnson renewed his motion for a mistrial on grounds of the polygraph 
  testimony, which was denied.Â  However, following the guilty verdict, the trial 
  judge granted Johnsonâ€™s motion for a mistrial on grounds of the polygraph testimony, 
  stating:

And it was brought up that sheâ€™d given three statements, I believe it was.Â  
  And the jury knew that she passed the polygraph test.Â  I mean they didnâ€™t know 
  whether sheâ€™d passed the test or not, but she said she didnâ€™t pass the polygraph 
  test.Â  Well, that was the first witness.Â  And I didnâ€™t know what effect that 
  was going to have on the trial anyway because I didnâ€™t know what the other witnesses 
  â€“ or what the evidence was.Â  But it appears that this whole case boils down 
  to the statements of these witnesses.
. . . .
And then as it turned out, unbeknownst to the court, the Defendant did not take 
  the witness stand.Â  And thatâ€™s his constitutional right.Â  And of course, no 
  comments can be made about him not taking the witness stand.Â  But that was the 
  problem about these polygraphs, and the inconsistent statements, and the fact 
  that the other defendants were allowed to plea in order to testify against this 
  Defendant to convict him.
. . . .
But I think the polygraph just was magnified because the jury could have inferred, 
  and I believe thereâ€™s a strong likelihood that that was the case based on the 
  intelligence and the questions of the jury, that all these witnesses had taken 
  polygraph tests, that the State had decided to let the other people plead to 
  what they did and put their testimony in as truth.Â  The solicitor argued strongly 
  that they were telling the truth.Â  And that â€“ the conclusion was after they 
  stayed out and deliberated for some time that [Johnson] was the trigger-man.Â  
  And I believe it all resulted from the polygraph tests and from all the evidence 
  as a whole. 

â€œEvidence regarding the results of a polygraph test or the defendantâ€™s 
  willingness or refusal to submit to one is inadmissible.â€Â Â  See, e.g. 
  State v. Johnson, 334 S.C. 78, 90, 512 S.E.2d 795, 801 (1999) (citations 
  omitted).Â  â€œMention of a polygraph test might arise in any one of many ways. 
  The safer course would normally be to avoid any mention of a polygraph examination.Â  
  If such is brought out in the testimony, the trial judge should be meticulous 
  to see that no improper inference is created.â€Â  State v. McGuire,  
  272 S.C. 547, 551, 253 S.E.2d 103, 105 (1979) (citation omitted).Â  However, 
  the mere mention of a polygraph test does not always automatically result in 
  error.Â  A curative instruction can cure any possible prejudice caused by the 
  polygraph testimony.Â  See Johnson, 334 S.C. at 90, 512 S.E.2d 
  at 801. 
 A curative instruction given following a witnessâ€™s reference to a 
  polygraph test is not adequate where the reference is likely to impress a jury 
  to the extent that the curative instruction does not overcome the prejudicial 
  effect.Â  See United States v. Tedder, 801 F.2d 1437, 1444 (4th 
  Cir. 1986).Â  In ruling on a motion for a new trial based on the prejudicial 
  effect of incompetent testimony, even following a curative instruction, the 
  trial judge must consider other testimony in the case.Â  See State 
  v. Singleton, 167 S.C. 543, 548, 166 S.E.2d 725, 727 (1932) (finding the 
  trial judge did not err in refusing to grant a new trial on grounds of hearsay 
  testimony, when other testimony warranted a conviction).Â  The Fourth Circuit 
  has set forth two factors to consider in reviewing whether a curative instruction 
  or a mistrial is an appropriate response to a reference to a polygraph: â€œ(1) 
  whether an inference about the result of the test may be critical in assessing 
  the witnessâ€™s credibility, and (2) whether the witnessâ€™s credibility is vital 
  to the case.â€Â  United States v. Brevard, 739 F.2d 180, 182 (4th Cir. 
  1984) (citation omitted).Â  We find these factors helpful in reviewing the trial 
  judgeâ€™s grant of a new trial in this case.Â  
In granting the new trial, the trial judge determined that the prejudicial 
  effect of the polygraph testimony was not overcome by his initial curative instruction.Â  
  He stated that because Marion was the first witness and mentioned her polygraph 
  results, the jury could infer that the other witnesses also took polygraph tests 
  and the results of those tests affected their testimony.Â Â  We agree, and pursuant 
  to the factors set forth in Brevard, we find the polygraph testimony 
  was critical in assessing Marionâ€™s credibility, which affected the credibility 
  of the other witnesses who also gave inconsistent statements.Â  Further, we find 
  Marionâ€™s credibility and the credibility of the other witnesses were vital elements 
  in the Stateâ€™s case.Â Â  
Accordingly, 
  the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in granting Johnson a new trial, 
  and the decision of the trial court is hereby
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
