title: State v. Fletcher
description: In this prosecution for homicide by child abuse, appellant presents a plethora of appellate issues:  (1) did the trial court err by admitting evidence of prior bad acts, i.e., that the victim had been handcuffed to a bedpost and left in the attic in the weeks before his death?  The admissibility of this evidence is analyzed under res gestae, Rule 404(b), SCRE, and State v. Lyle; (2) did the trial court err in admitting evidence obtained in accordance with a search warrant?  (3) did the trial court err in the redaction of a statement of appellantâ€™s co-defendant in violation of various constitutional provisions and Bruton v. United States; and (4) did the trial court err by admitting photographs of the victim?
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Henry Fletcher, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3940
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed 
  January 31, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert E. Lominack, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman 
  Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Henry Fletcher appeals his homicide by child abuse conviction.Â  
  He argues the trial court erred in refusing to (1) exclude evidence of prior 
  bad acts; (2) suppress evidence obtained through a search warrant; (3) redact 
  additional information from his co-defendantâ€™s statement; and (4) exclude photographs 
  of the victim.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Around 1:15 p.m. on September 21, 2000, nine-month-old Jaquan Perry presented 
  at the Palmetto Richland Memorial Hospital emergency room in full cardiopulmonary 
  arrest.Â  After medical personnel placed the infant on a ventilator, medicated 
  him to maintain his blood pressure, and repeatedly attempted to resuscitate 
  him, they pronounced him dead at 4:20 p.m.Â  During treatment, CT scans were 
  performed and x-rays were obtained.Â  The tests revealed injuries throughout 
  Jaquanâ€™s abdomenâ€”including internal bleeding, bruises to the liver, bowels, 
  pancreas, and little blood flow to the kidneys, spleen, and liver.
The police investigated Jaquanâ€™s death.Â  Columbia police officer Joe Smith 
  interviewed hospital personnel about Jaquanâ€™s injuries.Â  When Officer 
  Smith talked with Jaquanâ€™s mother, Ikeisha Perry, she told Smith that Jaquan 
  fell from a bed.Â  In her written statement, Perry declared she picked Jaquan 
  up, comforted him, and brought him with her while she ran errands.Â  Perry said 
  she noticed something was wrong when they left the dentistâ€™s office.Â  She could 
  not hear Jaquanâ€™s heart beating.Â  Perry then drove Jaquan to the hospital.Â  
  Her live-in friend, Henry Fletcher, attempted CPR as she drove to the hospital.
When asked by Officer Smith whether she had ever beaten or spanked Jaquan, 
  Perry claimed she had â€œpoppedâ€ Jaquan but â€œ[a]s far as beating him to bruise 
  him, no I havenâ€™t.â€Â  Perry admitted Jaquan had been handcuffed to a bedpost.
Fletcher provided statements to the police.Â  In the first of two statements, 
  Fletcher said Jaquan fell out of the bed on the morning of September 21, 2000.Â  
  He noted: Jaquan did not â€œlook rightâ€ when they left the dentistâ€™s office; they 
  did not hear Jaquanâ€™s heartbeat; and they drove to the hospital immediately, 
  with Fletcher attempting to resuscitate Jaquan on the way.Â  Fletcher maintained 
  that sometimes he would â€œplay fightâ€ with Jaquan.Â  In a later statement, Fletcher 
  denied ever hitting Jaquan, but admitted he put some of his weight on Jaquan 
  when they wrestled although he was not sure if doing so hurt Jaquan.Â  Fletcher 
  professed he hit Jaquan twice with his fists.Â  At trial, Fletcher testified 
  this statement was made in a sarcastic tone and was not meant to be taken as 
  truth.
As part of the investigation, the police executed a search warrant of the home 
  in which Perry and Fletcher lived.Â  They seized a pair of handcuffs, went into 
  the attic, and took photographs of the residence.
Fletcher and Perry were both arrested and charged with homicide by 
  child abuse.Â  They were indicted and tried. [2] Â  Before jury selection, the trial court heard several motions, 
  including motions to exclude evidence of prior bad acts and to suppress evidence 
  found in connection with an allegedly invalid search warrant.Â  The motions were 
  denied.
Jaquan suffered injuries to his internal organs, which caused an infection 
  that led to his death.Â  The testimony of two witnesses who observed Jaquan indicated 
  that Jaquanâ€™s eyes were half-closed and he was pale and non-responsive on the 
  morning of September 21.Â  One of the witnesses, Kimberly Hampton, related that 
  Jaquan was making a strange breathing sound, one she characterized as â€œa death 
  gurgle.â€Â  By noon, when Perry brought Jaquan with her and her other child to 
  the dentistâ€™s office, a witness noticed that Jaquan looked sick and pale but 
  the witness did not hear unusual breathing sounds.
The State and Fletcher disagreed as to which injuries should have been included 
  in the testimony.Â  The State introduced evidence of two instances of abuse, 
  which Fletcher describes as occurring â€œprior to that which caused Jaquanâ€™s death 
  on September 21st.â€Â  About three or four weeks prior to September 21, Carlos 
  Jenkins visited Fletcherâ€™s home and found Jaquan handcuffed to a bed.Â  Approximately 
  two weeks before September 21, Jenkins returned to Fletcherâ€™s house and discovered 
  Jaquan alone in the attic, crying and sweating profusely.Â  Jaquanâ€™s ribs had 
  been injured and were healing suggesting the injuries had been sustained about 
  two weeks before Jaquan died.Â  However, Jaquanâ€™s being handcuffed and left in 
  a hot attic did not cause his death.
The medical evidence provided more details about Jaquanâ€™s 
  injuries and offered information regarding the cause of his death.Â  Dr. Timothy 
  P. Close, a radiologist, testified the injuries revealed by the scans and x-rays 
  were inflicted at different times and Jaquanâ€™s rib fractures were â€œ[p]robably 
  notâ€ caused by Fletcherâ€™s alleged resuscitation attempts.Â  Dr. Close estimated 
  some of the rib fractures were as recent as a few hours to a few days old and 
  other, older fractures were ten days to more than two weeks old (with some of 
  the ribs having been broken twice).Â  He declared the liver injuries were likely 
  caused within forty-eight hours of Jaquanâ€™s death and the bowel injuries occurred 
  at least twelve hours or more before Jaquanâ€™s death.Â  He stated the injuries 
  were inconsistent with either a fall from a bed or with a single blow (â€œmost 
  likelyâ€ multiple blows to the front of Jaquan).Â  Rather, his injuries were caused 
  by a force equivalent to ejection from a car involved in an accident when the 
  car had been traveling sixty to seventy miles per hour or a fall from a three 
  or four story building.
Dr. Robert D. Hubbird noted when Jaquan arrived at the hospital his abdomen 
  was â€œvery, very distended and protuberant,â€ he had multiple rib fractures, a 
  ruptured bowel which caused an infection or sepsis, and such significant damage 
  to his liver that it â€œwas dying.â€Â  Dr. Hubbird explained the internal bleeding 
  had been going on for days; the injuries had been caused over a period of days; 
  and the ribs had been injured at different times.Â  He testified the abdominal 
  and back bruises occurred at different times, with some green bruises, which 
  indicated they were â€œfive to seven, [even] ten days old.â€Â  Dr. Hubbird expounded 
  that some of the bruises could have been caused by resuscitation attempts but 
  others were not.Â  He declared that the cause of the injury must have been â€œincredibly 
  concentrated striking, a very powerful blowâ€ to have caused the damageâ€”destroyed 
  bowel wall, ruptured bowel, disrupted liverâ€”and must have been more than one 
  blow.Â  He articulated blunt force might not leave a bruise each time because 
  the body sometimes absorbs the force.Â  Dr. Hubbird opined Jaquan died from â€œchild 
  abuse from massive intra-abdominal injuries; massive injuries to kill the bowel, 
  caused widespread infection, killed the liver.â€
The autopsy yielded additional information.Â  Dr. Jeffrey Allen Welsh performed 
  the autopsy.Â  The autopsy demonstrated several bruises on Jaquanâ€™s back and 
  a distended abdomen.Â  A â€œtenseâ€ abdomen is abnormal in a child.Â  Dr. Welsh confirmed 
  resuscitation attempts may have caused some of the chest bruises.Â  After reviewing 
  x-rays and CT scans and performing an external and internal examination, Dr. 
  Welsh determined the cause of death was from blunt abdominal trauma, which caused 
  infection that ultimately led to Jaquanâ€™s death.Â  He found, based on the scar 
  formation on the internal organs, the injuries occurred at least forty-eight 
  hours before death and likely earlier than that, with the injuries occurring 
  at different times.Â  Dr. Welsh opined the type of force necessary to inflict 
  the trauma evidenced on Jaquanâ€™s body â€œwould have been significant because the 
  injuries to the liver, for example, are those described mainly with motor vehicle 
  type accidents.â€Â  Dr. Welsh concluded the injuries Jaquan sustained were consistent 
  with battered child syndrome.Â  Dr. Welsh enunciated that Jaquanâ€™s injuries would 
  have caused great pain and lethargy, making it obvious Jaquan needed medical 
  attention.
Fletcher presented evidence that: (1) he was not aware Jaquan had been handcuffed 
  to the bed; (2) Perry sometimes left Jaquan in the attic while she dried her 
  laundry up there; and (3) the attic had an air conditioning vent near the door.Â  
  Fletcher professed he had never â€œbeatâ€ Jaquan.Â  Perry introduced evidence that 
  Jaquan was not injured before early September; rib fractures in children are 
  not uncommon; and Perryâ€™s mother saw Jaquan the day before he died and did not 
  notice anything wrong.
The jury found both Fletcher and Perry guilty of homicide 
  by child abuse.Â  Fletcher was sentenced to life in prison.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law 
  only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. 
  Wood, Op. No. 3900 (S.C. Ct. App. filed December 6, 2004) (Shearouse Adv. 
  Sh. No. 47 at 74).Â  This court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings 
  unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 
  527 S.E.2d 105 (2000); State v. Landis, Op. No. 3904 (S.C. Ct. App. filed 
  December 6, 2004) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 48 at 73).Â  This same standard of 
  review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility 
  of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d 
  at 829.Â  On review, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused 
  his discretion.Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); State 
  v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 391 S.E.2d 244 (1990); see also State 
  v. Corey D., 339 S.C. 107, 529 S.E.2d 20 (2000) (an abuse of discretion 
  is a conclusion with no reasonable factual support).Â  This Court does not re-evaluate 
  the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply 
  determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  Wilson, 
  345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 
  S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  PRIOR BAD ACTS
Over Fletcherâ€™s objection, the trial court allowed 
  the State to introduce evidence indicating Jaquan had been abused.Â  Carlos Jenkins, 
  who worked with Fletcher and had known him for four or five years, testified 
  about two incidents that occurred before Jaquanâ€™s death.
The first incident Jenkins recalled happened at Fletcherâ€™s 
  residence approximately two weeks before Jaquanâ€™s death.Â  When Jenkins walked 
  in the house, he heard Jaquan crying.Â  Jenkins found Jaquan in a walker in the 
  attic, which was â€œreal hot.â€Â  Jenkins took Jaquan outside to cool him off.Â  
  According to Jenkins, Jaquan was â€œpouring down sweat like he had just dipped 
  him in a bathtub.â€Â  He testified that, although the house was air-conditioned, 
  a person in the attic could not feel the air-conditioning in the house because 
  the door to the attic was closed.Â  Jenkins said Fletcher and Perry showed no 
  concern about Jaquan.Â  In fact, Fletcher told Jenkins the house was his and 
  that Jenkins should â€œmind [his own] business.â€Â  Jenkins did not see who put 
  Jaquan in the attic (which Fletcher describes as a laundry room) but Jenkins 
  stated that both Fletcher and Perry were home.
The second incident took place at Fletcherâ€™s home when 
  Jenkins went to visit Fletcher about three to four weeks prior to Jaquanâ€™s death.Â  
  When Jenkins followed Fletcher to the bedroom, he observed Jaquan lying on his 
  back, crying and screaming, handcuffed by his feet to the foot of the bed.Â  
  Jenkins unlocked the handcuffs and asked Fletcher and Perry if they were crazy.Â  
  They â€œjust giggledâ€ at him.
Jenkins did not see who handcuffed Jaquan to the bed.Â  
  He did not testify he noticed any injuries to Jaquan.
A.Â  Issue 
  Preservation
Fletcher did not object to the sufficiency of the 
  trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of Jenkinsâ€™ testimony.Â  A trial courtâ€™s 
  general ruling that evidence was admissible does not constitute reversible error.Â  
  State v. McLaughlin, 307 S.C. 19, 413 S.E.2d 819 (1992) (holding the 
  failure to request a more explicit ruling constitutes a waiver to any objection 
  to the trial courtâ€™s general ruling).Â  Although Fletcher cannot object to the 
  sufficiency of the trial courtâ€™s ruling for the first time on appeal, he contends 
  the trial court ruled on the issue during the trial and that erecting a procedural 
  barrier is unnecessary.
Fletcher did not independently object to the evidence 
  on the ground it was less than clear and convincing.Â  However, Perryâ€™s counsel 
  objected: â€œthe rib injuries should not come in because there was no clear and 
  convincing evidence as to who inflicted these rib injuries.â€Â  Fletcherâ€™s attorney 
  then joined Perryâ€™s objection: â€œFor the record, your Honor[,] . . . I would 
  join in his objection.â€
B.Â  The Continued Juridical Journey of Rule 404(b) and State v. Lyle
Fletcher argues the trial court erred in allowing evidence of the prior bad 
  acts pursuant to Rule 404(b), SCRE, and State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 
  118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  Fletcher contends the two incidents were unrelated to 
  the rib injuries and Jaquanâ€™s death and claims the incidents were not causally 
  or temporally related.Â  We disagree.
Generally, South Carolina law precludes evidence of a defendantâ€™s prior crimes 
  or other bad acts to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt for the crime charged.Â  State 
  v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Weaverling, 
  337 S.C. 460, 523 S.E.2d 787 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  It is well established that evidence 
  of other crimes or prior bad acts is inadmissible to show criminal propensity 
  or to demonstrate the accused is a bad individual. State v. Johnson, 
  293 S.C. 321, 360 S.E.2d 317 (1987); see also State v. Beck, 342 
  S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000) (finding that evidence of prior crimes or bad 
  acts is inadmissible to prove bad character of defendant or that he acted in 
  conformity therewith).
However, evidence of other crimes is generally admissible when it is necessary 
  to establish a material fact or element of the crime charged. See Johnson, 
  293 S.C. at 324, 360 S.E.2d at 319; State v. Byers, 277 S.C. 176, 284 
  S.E.2d 360 (1981); State v. Cheatham, 349 S.C. 101, 561 S.E.2d 618 (Ct. 
  App. 2002). Thus, such evidence is admissible when it tends to establish (1) 
  motive; (2) intent; (3) the absence of mistake or accident; (4) a common scheme 
  or plan embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related to each other 
  that proof of one tends to establish the proof of the other; or (5) the identity 
  of the person charged with the present crime.Â  See Rule 404(b), SCRE; 
  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923); see also Anderson 
  v. State, 354 S.C. 431, 581 S.E.2d 834 (2003) (explaining that Rule 404, 
  the modern expression of the Lyle rule, excludes evidence of other crimes, 
  wrongs, or acts offered to prove character of person in order to show action 
  in conformity therewith; the rule creates an exception when testimony is offered 
  to show motive, identity, existence of common scheme or plan, absence of mistake 
  or accident, or intent).
If not the subject of a conviction, a prior bad act must first be established 
  by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Beck, 342 S.C. at 135, 536 S.E.2d 
  at 683; State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 602 S.E.2d 62 (Ct. App. 2004); 
  see also State v. Tutton, 354 S.C. 319, 580 S.E.2d 186 (Ct. App. 
  2003) (noting when the appellate court determines whether clear and convincing 
  evidence exists of the prior bad acts, it is bound by the trial courtâ€™s findings 
  of fact unless they are clearly erroneous).Â  The bad act must logically relate 
  to the crime with which the defendant has been charged.Â  Beck, 342 S.C. 
  at 135, 536 S.E.2d at 682-83; see also State v. King, 334 S.C. 
  504, 514 S.E.2d 578 (1999) (declaring that record must support logical relevance 
  between prior bad act and crime for which defendant is accused).Â  In making 
  the determination of whether evidence of prior bad acts is admissible, the trial 
  court must gauge its logical relevancy to the particular purpose for which it 
  is sought to be introduced. See State v. Nix, 288 S.C. 492, 343 
  S.E.2d 627 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  If the prior bad act evidence is â€œlogically pertinent 
  in that it reasonably tends to prove a material fact in issue, it is not to 
  be rejected merely because it incidentally proves the defendant guilty of another 
  crime.â€Â  Id. at 497, 343 S.E.2d at 630-31 (internal quotations omitted).Â  
  If there is any evidence to support the admission of prior bad act evidence, 
  the trial judgeâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Pagan, 357 
  S.C. at 143, 591 S.E.2d at 652.
Even if evidence of other crimes is admissible under Rule 404(b), the trial 
  judge must exclude the evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed 
  by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Braxton, 
  343 S.C. 629, 541 S.E.2d 833 (2001); Beck, 342 S.C. at 135-36, 536 S.E.2d 
  at 683; see also Rule 403, SCRE (â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be

  specific as the circumstances and nature of activity under investigation permit.â€Â  
  State v. Sullivan, 281 S.C. 522, 524, 316 S.E.2d 404, 406 (1984) (internal 
  quotations omitted); see also United States v. Osborne, 630 F.2d 
  374, 377 (5th Cir. 1980) (upholding a warrant authorizing the seizure of several 
  described items and â€œany other evidence relating to the armed robberyâ€); State 
  v. Malloy, 409 N.W.2d 707, 708 (Iowa Ct. App. 1987) (approving a warrant 
  authorizing the seizure of specified items as well as â€œevidence of instrumentalities 
  which would substantiate abuse or neglectâ€).
The warrant in the instant case was limited to evidence of abusive behavior 
  toward the children.Â  The exact characteristics of the evidence were unknown 
  to investigators.Â  However, requiring a more detailed description would unreasonably 
  thwart an investigation.Â  The warrant did not authorize a search for evidence 
  of other crimes and its scope was properly limited.Â  Therefore, it was not fatally 
  general.Â  The trial court did not err in allowing evidence found pursuant to 
  the valid search.
Even if the evidence was erroneously admitted, the error is harmless beyond 
  a reasonable doubt because it could not have impacted the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  See 
  State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 576 S.E.2d 168 (2003); see also 
  State v. Tench, 353 S.C. 531, 579 S.E.2d 314 (2003) (noting the erroneous 
  admission of evidence may be harmless if it did not affect the outcome of the 
  trial); Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 420 S.E.2d 834 (1992) (stating 
  error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt where it did not contribute to the 
  verdict obtained).Â  The State established homicide by child abuse by overwhelming 
  evidence, including the medical testimony which proved the injuries could not 
  have been accidental and the childâ€™s obvious pain would have indicated he needed 
  medical attention long before Fletcher and Perry took him to the hospital.Â  
  In addition, Fletcher admitted the handcuffs belonged to him.Â  Even the erroneous 
  admission of the handcuffs could not have affected the juryâ€™s verdict.
III.Â  CONFRONTATION CLAUSE
Both Perry and Fletcher provided statements to investigators.Â  At 
  a pre-trial hearing pursuant to Bruton v. United States, 391 U.S. 123 
  (1968), Fletcher requested the trial court redact the following from Perryâ€™s 
  September 22, 2000 statement:

  
  
    
      Q.
       What was Jaquan handcuffed to?
    
    
      A.
        
       He was handcuffed to the bottom rail of the bed.
        
    
    
      Q.
       Which bed was Jaquan handcuffed to?
    
    
      A. 
       The bed in my room, the one in there now.Â  He [sic] friend 
  Carlos came in the house and took the handcuffs off and 
  told Henry he shouldnâ€™t do that.
    
  
  

The trial court redacted the reference to Carlos as â€œhe friendâ€ and the reference 
  to Fletcher in the second answer.Â  The second response then stated: â€œThe bed 
  in my room, the one in there now.Â  Carlos came in the house and took the handcuffs 
  off.â€Â  The trial court redacted references to other handcuffing incidents and 
  Perryâ€™s statement that Fletcher beat Jaquan with a belt. Â The trial judge provided 
  the jury with a limiting instruction when the statements were introduced and 
  with a similar instruction when he charged the jury on the law.
A.Â  Redacted Statement of Perry
Fletcher submits 
  the trial court erred by failing to adequately redact Perryâ€™s statement, which 
  violated the sixth and fourteenth amendments to the United States Constitution 
  and article one, section fourteen of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe constitutional right to confront and cross examine witnesses is essential 
  to a fair trial in that it promotes reliability in criminal trials and insures 
  that convictions will not result from testimony of individuals who cannot be 
  challenged at trial.â€Â  State v. Martin, 292 S.C. 437, 439, 357 S.E.2d 
  21, 22 (1987).Â  The introduction of a non-testifying co-defendantâ€™s statement 
  which implicates a defendant violates a defendantâ€™s right to confrontation because 
  no opportunity to cross-examine the co-defendant is presented.Â  Bruton, 
  391 U.S. at 137.Â  Because the right to confrontation is so fundamental, limiting 
  instructions are not an adequate substitute.Â  Id.; see also State 
  v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 523 S.E.2d 173 (1999) (recognizing that in Bruton, 
  the Supreme Court held that a defendantâ€™s rights under the Confrontation Clause 
  of the Sixth Amendment are violated by the admission of a non-testifying co-defendantâ€™s 
  confession that inculpates a defendant, even if a cautionary instruction is 
  given).
Redaction has come into play as a tool to allow admission of a co-defendantâ€™s 
  confession against the confessor in a joint trial.Â  State v. Holmes, 
  342 S.C. 113, 536 S.E.2d 671 (2000).Â  The point of redaction is to permit the 
  confession to be used against the non-testifying confessor, while avoiding implicating 
  his co-defendant.Â  Id.Â  The Confrontation Clause is not violated when 
  a defendantâ€™s name is redacted but other evidence links the statementâ€™s application 
  to the defendant, if a proper limiting instruction is given. Richardson v. 
  Marsh, 481 U.S. 200, 211 (1987) (holding â€œthe Confrontation Clause is not 
  violated by the admission of a nontestifying codefendantâ€™s confession with a 
  proper limiting instruction when, as here, the confession is redacted to eliminate 
  not only the defendantâ€™s name, but any reference to his or her existence.â€).
The redacted version of Perryâ€™s statement neither mentions nor implicates Fletcher.Â  
  Unlike the defendant in Bruton, Fletcher was not named as a participant 
  in the crime.Â  See Richardson, 481 U.S. at 208 (distinguishing 
  Bruton in a case in which the confession was not incriminating on its 
  face).
Based on Richardson, Fletcherâ€™s right to confrontation was not violated.Â  
  The statement that Jaquan was handcuffed indicates someone other than Perry 
  may have handcuffed the child but does not necessarily implicate Fletcher.Â  
  Therefore, Perry was not a witness against Fletcher and no violation of his 
  right to confront a witness against him occurred.Â  See State v. Evans, 
  316 S.C. 303, 450 S.E.2d 47 (1994) (finding a co-defendantâ€™s statement admissible 
  where, although the statementâ€™s incriminating import was inferable from other 
  evidence properly admitted against the defendant, the statement did not on its 
  face incriminate the defendant).Â  Because the trial court adequately redacted 
  Perryâ€™s statement and gave a proper limiting instruction to the jury, Fletcherâ€™s 
  right to confrontation was not violated.
B.Â  Cross-Examination by Perry
The State introduced a statement Perry gave to police officers.Â  Perry did 
  not testify, but Perryâ€™s counsel used her statement in cross-examining Fletcher.Â  
  After Fletcher said Perry was home during the alleged handcuffing incident and 
  denied Perry cussed him out or told him not to handcuff Jaquan to the bed, counsel 
  for Perry referred to Perryâ€™s statement.Â  Fletcherâ€™s attorney objected.Â  The 
  trial court overruled the objection.Â  Fletcher, as instructed by Perryâ€™s counsel, 
  read from Perryâ€™s statement:

  
  
    
       A. 
       
  â€œWhat was Jaquan doing that was so bad?â€
    
    
       Q. 
      All right.Â  Here.Â  And the answer is?
    
    
       A.
       
  I donâ€™t know what the last word is.
    
    
       Q.
       
  But what does it say?
    
    
       A.
       
  I came home; Jaquan was in theâ€”
    
    
       Q.
       
  All right.Â  And whatâ€™s the next question; the next question?
    
    
       A.
       
  â€œWhat was Jaquan handcuffed to?â€
    
    
       Q.
       
  And what does it say here?Â  What is the answer?
    
    
       A.
       
  â€œHe was handcuffed to the bottom rail of the bed.â€
    
    
       Q.
       
  So your story is that Ms. Perry was there?
    
    
       A. 
       
  Yes, sir.
    
    
       Q. 
       
  And you deny that she came home and witnessed this and cussed you out about 
  this?
    
    
      A.
       Yes, sir.
    
  
  

 Fletcher complains the use of Perryâ€™s statement in cross-examining 
  him improperly â€œpitted him against [Perryâ€™s] previous statementâ€ and the trial 
  court erred in overruling his objection.
The record shows Fletcher raised a general objection to the publication of 
  Perryâ€™s statement by Fletcher.Â  When Perryâ€™s counsel asked Fletcher to read 
  from Perryâ€™s statement, Fletcherâ€™s attorney declared: â€œIâ€™ll object to having 
  [Fletcher] publish another personâ€™s statement.â€Â  The judge overruled the objection.Â  
  It is well settled that an objection must be on a specific ground.Â  State 
  v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 543 S.E.2d 586 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  To be preserved 
  for appellate review, an objection should be sufficiently specific to bring 
  into focus the precise nature of the alleged error.Â  Id.Â  The objection 
  here lacks specificity.Â  Fletcher did not present the trial judge with the issue 
  of â€œpittingâ€ witnesses based on this colloquy.Â  This issue is not preserved 
  for our review.
IV.Â  PHOTOGRAPHS
During the trial, the State, over Fletcherâ€™s objection, was allowed to introduce 
  post-mortem photographs of Jaquan when the trial court found them â€œadmissible 
  under 403.â€Â  The photographs depicted Jaquanâ€™s external injuries.Â  The photograph 
  labeled Stateâ€™s Exhibit 1 shows Jaquan on a hospital gurney, unclothed, with 
  a tube in his mouth, as well as gauze and an unidentified incision near the 
  genital area (related to medical intervention).Â  The other photographs depict 
  bruises on Jaquanâ€™s body.
Fletcher asseverates the photographs were calculated to arouse the sympathy 
  or prejudice of the jury and were irrelevant.Â  He argues there was little probative 
  value to Stateâ€™s Exhibit 1 and several of the photographs showing bruises were 
  irrelevant, unnecessary to substantiate material facts, and inflammatory in 
  nature.
Perryâ€™s attorney noted his objection but did not state a ground.Â  He declared: 
  â€œWe would object to those.â€Â  A general objection which does not specify the 
  particular ground on which the objection is based is insufficient to preserve 
  the issue for review.Â  State v. New, 338 S.C. 313, 526 S.E.2d 237 (Ct. 
  App. 1999).Â  During the bench conference, neither Perry nor Fletcher asked to 
  place a ground for the objection on the record.Â  An objection made during an 
  off-the-record conference which is not made part of the record does not preserve 
  the question for review.Â  State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 543 S.E.2d 
  586 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In addition, an issue is not preserved for appeal merely 
  because the trial judge mentions it.Â  See, e.g., Mize v. Blue 
  Ridge Ry. Co., 219 S.C. 119, 64 S.E.2d 253 (1951).Â  Fletcher contends the 
  trial courtâ€™s ruling on the matter indicates a specific objection was made off 
  the record, and because the trial court ruled on the record, the error was preserved.Â  
  Fletcher made no independent objection on the record.Â  He concurred in the objection 
  of Perryâ€™s counsel.Â  Furthermore, the trial courtâ€™s mentioning the issue does 
  not preserve it for appeal.Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved for our review.Â  
  In addition, we disagree with Fletcherâ€™s substantive argument.
The relevance, materiality, and admissibility of photographic evidence are 
  matters within the sound discretion of the trial court and a ruling will be 
  disturbed only upon a showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Haselden, 
  353 S.C. 190, 577 S.E.2d 445 (2003); State v. Rosemond, 335 S.C. 593, 
  518 S.E.2d 588 (1999); see also State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 
  460 S.E.2d 368 (1995) (stating that trial judge has considerable latitude in 
  ruling on admissibility of evidence and his rulings will not be disturbed absent 
  showing of probable prejudice).Â  The trial judge must balance the prejudicial 
  effect of graphic photographs against their probative value.Â  State v. Vang, 
  353 S.C. 78, 577 S.E.2d 225 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding 
  the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of relevant evidence 
  should be reversed only in exceptional circumstances.Â  State v. Hamilton, 
  344 S.C. 344, 543 S.E.2d 586 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Admitting photographs which serve 
  to corroborate testimony is not an abuse of discretion.Â  See State 
  v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996); State v. Jarrell, 
  350 S.C. 90, 564 S.E.2d 362 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, photographs calculated 
  to arouse the sympathy or prejudice of the jury should be excluded if they are 
  irrelevant or not necessary to substantiate material facts or conditions.Â  State 
  v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 480 S.E.2d 64 (1997).Â  â€œTo constitute unfair prejudice, 
  the photographs must create a â€˜tendency to suggest a decision on an improper 
  basis, commonly, though not necessarily, an emotional one.â€™â€Â  Kelley, 
  319 S.C. at 178, 460 S.E.2d at 370-71 (quoting State v. Alexander, 303 
  S.C. 377, 382, 401 S.E.2d 146, 149 (1991)).
The photographs were introduced to corroborate the 
  testimony of witnesses who saw Jaquanâ€™s injuries at or near the time of his 
  death.Â  The pictures demonstrated the trauma occurred over a period of time 
  because they showed the discoloration of the bruises.Â  The photographs were 
  necessary to depict the severity of the bruises and the resultant trauma, which 
  were inconsistent with those resulting from an accident or play. Â They indicated 
  the presence of internal injuries (e.g., the distended abdomen indicated rib 
  fractures).Â  The photographs corroborated testimony that the cause of death 
  was child abuse and the abuse manifested an extreme indifference to human life.Â  
  The photographs were relevant and necessary and were not inflammatory or calculated 
  to illicit sympathy or prejudice of the jury.Â  Therefore, the trial court did 
  not abuse its discretion in admitting the photographs.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the conviction of Fletcher is
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
 [2]  Over defense counselâ€™s objection, the trials of Fletcher and Perry were not severed.

title: State v. Green
description: In this criminal appeal, appellant was convicted of criminal sexual conduct (CSC) first degree and CSC second degree.  He contends the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over both offenses.  The Court concludes that subject matter jurisdiction was lacking because of defects in the amendment procedure approved by the circuit judge.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Alvin Jermaine Green, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3941
Heard December 7, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005

VACATED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley 
  W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Cecil Kelley Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Alvin J. Green was convicted of criminal sexual conduct 
  (CSC) with a minor in the first degree and CSC with a minor in the second degree.Â  
  He contends the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over both offenses.Â  
  We vacate the convictions and sentences of Green.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Green was charged with two counts of CSC with 
  a minor, both stemming from alleged sexual assaults on the same victim.Â  The 
  allegation of CSC with a minor in the first degree concerned events before the 
  victimâ€™s eleventh birthday and the second-degree allegation related to a period 
  of time after the victimâ€™s eleventh birthday.Â  However, three of the four dates 
  listed in the two-count indictment were off by ten years.Â  At trial, the State 
  moved to amend the indictment to correct the three dates that were ten years 
  earlier than the offenses allegedly occurred.Â  Defense counsel objected to the 
  amendment, but conceded the language in the indictments followed the statute 
  creating the offenses.Â  After a discussion, the trial court allowed the amendment, 
  concluding the dates originally included were scrivenerâ€™s errors.Â  Green then 
  waived presentment to the amended indictment while purporting to preserve his 
  objection to the amendment itself.Â  After the State rested, the defense noted 
  the first count of the amended indictment (for CSC with a minor in the first 
  degree) contained a time span for the alleged offenses which included dates 
  in which Green was too young to be prosecuted in circuit court as well as dates 
  in which such prosecution was proper.Â  In response, the trial court again amended 
  the first count of the indictment to include only dates in which Green was old 
  enough to be tried as an adult.Â  The jury found Green guilty as charged and 
  the trial court sentenced him to concurrent fifteen-year prison terms.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Circuit Court does not have subject matter jurisdiction 
  to convict a defendant of an offense unless: (1) there has been an indictment 
  which sufficiently states the offense; (2) the defendant has waived presentment 
  of the indictment; or (3) the offense is a lesser included offense of the crime 
  charged in the indictment.Â  State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 564 S.E.2d 
  103 (2002); State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 572 S.E.2d 309 (Ct. App. 
  2002).Â  An indictment is sufficient to convey jurisdiction if it apprises the 
  defendant of the elements of the offense intended to be charged and informs 
  the defendant of the circumstances he must be prepared to defend.Â  Koon v. 
  State, 358 S.C. 359, 595 S.E.2d 456 (2004).Â  The acts of a court with respect 
  to a matter as to which it has no jurisdiction are void.Â  Guthrie, 352 
  S.C. at 107, 572 S.E.2d at 312.
Under section 17-19-100 of the South Carolina Code, if an indictment contains 
  any defect or, â€œon the trial of any case there shall appear to be any variance 
  between the allegations of the indictment and the evidence offered in proof 
  thereof,â€ the trial court â€œmay amend the indictment . . . if such amendment 
  does not change the nature of the offense charged.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-100 
  (2003).Â  â€œAfter such amendment the trial shall proceed in all respects and with 
  the same consequences as if the indictment had originally been returned as so 
  amended, unless such amendment shall operate as a surprise to the defendant, 
  in which case the defendant shall be entitled, upon demand, to a continuance 
  of the cause.â€Â  Id.Â  The appropriate analysis for determining whether 
  an amendment to an indictment deprives the trial court of subject matter jurisdiction 
  is whether the amendment changed the nature of the offense charged, not whether 
  the amendment in any way surprised or prejudiced the defendant.Â  State v. 
  Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 545 S.E.2d 511 (2001).
Generally, amendments are permitted for the purpose of correcting an error 
  of form, such as a scrivenerâ€™s error.Â  Cutner v. State, 354 S.C. 151, 
  580 S.E.2d 120 (2003). Otherwise, if the defendant objects to an amendment on 
  grounds that the amended indictment would change the nature of the offense, 
  the trial judge is obligated to inform the parties of the necessity of reindictment 
  or obtain a waiver of presentment from the defendant.Â  Hopkins v. State, 
  317 S.C. 7, 451 S.E.2d 389 (1994).
â€œCritical determinations to be made by a court when confronted with the issue 
  of amending the date alleged in an indictment is always whether the amendment 
  alters the nature of the offense charged and surprises the accused, preventing 
  a fair trial.â€Â  State v. Quarles, 261 S.C. 413, 417, 200 S.E.2d 384, 
  385 (1973).Â  â€œA motion to amend the date alleged in an indictment is addressed 
  to the sound discretion of the trial judge, and the burden of showing an abuse 
  of discretion and resulting prejudice is upon the party adversely affected by 
  his ruling thereon.â€Â  Id. at 417, 200 S.E.2d at 386.
The indictment as crafted by the drafter reveals a 
  date deficiency.Â  The dates contained in the indictment presented to the grand 
  jury apply to a two-year-old defendant and an unborn victim.Â  At a minimum, 
  the indictment is fatally flawed in regard to an identification and articulation 
  of criminal sexual conduct charges.
Initially, the State moved to amend the indictment to change the dates of the 
  alleged offenses to a current era.Â  After granting the amendment, the court 
  was confronted with charges against the defendant which could not be tried in 
  the circuit court because of the age of the defendant, i.e., under the age of 
  sixteen.Â  The court redacted the indictment by extirpating certain dates contained 
  in the indictment relating to the defendantâ€™s being under the age of sixteen.
We decline to place our approbation and imprimatur upon the subject matter 
  juxtaposition between the family court and the circuit court.Â  The prosecutorial 
  endeavors are not efficacious.Â  Approval of the amendment activities and rulings 
  in the case under the rubric and guise of salutary and salubrious amendments 
  flies in the face of the grand jury and indictment procedure enunciated in the 
  South Carolina Constitution and applicable statutes.
No precedent is cited in approving the amendatory 
  activities involving the indictment in this case.Â  The indictment moves through 
  a peripatetic journey from the circuit court to the family court and back to 
  the circuit court as finally amended.
The gravamen of our conclusion rests upon the efficacy of sections 20-7-400 
  and 20-7-7605 of the South Carolina Code.Â  Section 20-7-400, titled â€œExclusive 
  original jurisdiction of family court,â€ states:

(A) Except as otherwise provided herein, the court shall have exclusive 
  original jurisdiction and shall be the sole court for initiating action:

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

  
(3) Concerning any child seventeen years of age or over, living or found within 
  the geographical limits of the courtâ€™s jurisdiction, alleged to have violated 
  or attempted to violate any State or local law or municipal ordinance prior 
  to having become seventeen years of age and such person shall be dealt 
  with under the provisions of this chapter relating to children.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-400 (1985 & Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).Â  Under 
  the Childrenâ€™s Code, the general sessions court ordinarily lacks jurisdiction 
  over individuals under the age of seventeen, with certain exceptions.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-7605 (Supp. 2003).Â  Section 20-7-7605 reads in pertinent 
  part:

In accordance with the jurisdiction granted to the family 
  court pursuant to Sections 20-7-400, 20-7-410, and 20-7-420, jurisdiction over 
  a case involving a child must be transferred or retained as follows:
  
(1) If, during the pendency of a criminal or quasi-criminal charge against a 
  child in a circuit court of this State, it is ascertained that the child 
  was under the age of seventeen years at the time of committing the alleged offense, 
  it is the duty of the circuit court immediately to transfer the case, together 
  with all the papers, documents, and testimony connected with it, to the family 
  court of competent jurisdiction, except in those cases where the Constitution 
  gives to the circuit court exclusive jurisdiction or in those cases where jurisdiction 
  has properly been transferred to the circuit court by the family court under 
  the provisions of this section. The court making the transfer shall order the 
  child to be taken immediately to the place of detention designated by the court 
  or to that court itself, or shall release the child to the custody of some suitable 
  person to be brought before the court at a time designated.Â  The court then 
  shall proceed as provided in this article.Â  The provisions of this section are 
  applicable to all existing offenses and to offenses created in the future unless 
  the General Assembly specifically directs otherwise.
  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

  
(4) If a child sixteen years of age or older is charged with an offense which, 
  if committed by an adult, would be a misdemeanor, a Class E or F felony as defined 
  in Section 16-1-20, or a felony which provides for a maximum term of imprisonment 
  of ten years or less, and if the court, after full investigation, considers 
  it contrary to the best interest of the child or of the public to retain jurisdiction, 
  the court, in its discretion, acting as committing magistrate, may bind over 
  the child for proper criminal proceedings to a court which would have trial 
  jurisdiction of the offense if committed by an adult.
(5) If a child fourteen or fifteen years of age is charged with an offense which, 
  if committed by an adult, would be a Class A, B, C, or D felony as defined in 
  Section 16-1-20 or a felony which provides for a maximum term of imprisonment 
  of fifteen years or more, the court, after full investigation and hearing, may 
  determine it contrary to the best interest of the child or of the public to 
  retain jurisdiction. The court, acting as committing magistrate, may bind over 
  the child for proper criminal proceedings to a court which would have trial 
  jurisdiction of the offenses if committed by an adult.
(6) Within thirty days after the filing of a petition in the family court alleging 
  the child has committed the offense of murder or criminal sexual conduct, the 
  person executing the petition may request in writing that the case be transferred 
  to the court of general sessions with a view to proceeding against the child 
  as a criminal rather than as a child coming within the purview of this article. 
  The judge of the family court is authorized to determine this request. If the 
  request is denied, the petitioner may appeal within five days to the circuit 
  court. Upon the hearing of the appeal, the judge of the circuit court is vested 
  with the discretion of exercising and asserting the jurisdiction of the court 
  of general sessions or of relinquishing jurisdiction to the family court. If 
  the circuit judge elects to exercise the jurisdiction of the general sessions 
  court for trial of the case, he shall issue an order to that effect, and then 
  the family court has no further jurisdiction in the matter.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-7605 (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).Â  Pursuant to the 
  Childrenâ€™s Code, â€œ[c]hildâ€ is defined in section 20-7-6605(1):

â€œChildâ€ means a person less than seventeen years of age.Â  
  â€œChildâ€ does not mean a person sixteen years of age or older who is charged 
  with a Class A, B, C, or D felony as defined in Section 16-1-20 or a felony 
  which provides for a maximum term of imprisonment of fifteen years or more.Â  
  However, a person sixteen years of age who is charged with a Class A, B, C, 
  or D felony as defined in Section 16-1-20 or a felony which provides for a maximum 
  term of imprisonment of fifteen years or more may be remanded to the family 
  court for disposition of the charge at the discretion of the solicitor.Â  An 
  additional or accompanying charge associated with the charges contained in this 
  item must be heard by the court with jurisdiction over the offenses contained 
  in this item.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-6605(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  In Kent v. United States, 
  383 U.S. 541 (1966), the United States Supreme Court noted the following criteria 
  for determining whether jurisdiction should be waived under the District of 
  Columbia Juvenile Court Act:

1. The seriousness of the alleged offense to the community and whether the 
  protection of the community requires waiver.
2. Whether the alleged offense was committed in an aggressive, violent, premeditated 
  or willful manner.
3. Whether the alleged offense was against persons or against property, greater 
  weight being given to offenses against persons especially if personal injury 
  resulted.
